'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Melbourne", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4735189", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Australia (03): (SA) spike in disease", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4735189", "date": "2016-12-31 21:42:30", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA (03): (SOUTH AUSTRALIA) SPIKE IN DISEASE\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 30 Dec 2016\nSource: Adelaide Now [edited]\nhttp://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/south-australia/big-spike-in-q-fever-has-officials-urging-animal-workers-to-vaccinate/news-story/2bf49b992c9ca3a14737c68ecbcd002f\n\n\nA big rise in the potentially deadly Q fever has sparked a health alert and officials have urged people who work with animals to get vaccinated.\n\nThere have been 27 cases reported this year [2016], more than double the number last year [2015] and almost triple the number of cases 5 years ago.\n\nQ fever is caused by direct or indirect contact with the bacteria from infected animals.\n\nSA [South Australia] Health Chief Medical Officer Professor Paddy Phillips said the main carriers tend to be cattle, sheep or goats, but animals including cats, dogs, camels and kangaroos may also carry the infection.\n\n'Q fever is typically an occupational disease of meat workers, farmers and hobby farmers, kangaroo hunters, shearers and veterinarians,' he said.\n\n'Symptoms include a fever which may last up to 4 weeks, severe headache, sweats and chills, chest pains when breathing, nausea and vomiting, diarrhoea and abdominal pain.\n\n'Some people may develop pneumonia and inflammation of the liver, while in rare cases serious complications such as endocarditis -- infection of the heart valves -- can appear years after initial infection.'\n\nProf Phillips said only about half of the infected people show signs of the illness and onset of symptoms can be sudden. But with an early diagnosis and effective antibiotic therapy, a good outcome can be expected.\n\nMost people recover within several months but 1 to 2 per cent of people who develop acute Q fever die of the disease.\n\nQ fever vaccination can only be provided by trained and authorised doctors -- they are listed on the SA Health website.\n\nThese doctors will take a blood sample and skin test to see if the individual previously has been exposed to Q fever, as vaccinating those already exposed can result in a severe reaction.\n\nProf Phillips said person-to-person spread of Q fever is extremely rare and it usually occurs when people breathe in bacteria within dust, or come into contact with contaminated clothing, wool, hides or straw.\n\n'Vaccination is recommended for farmers, livestock transporters, workers in abattoirs, agricultural college staff and students, wildlife and zoo workers, shearers and wool sorters, veterinarians, professional dog and cat breeders, tanning and hide workers and laboratory personnel handling veterinary products,' he said.\n\nWhere the vaccine is not provided or funded by the employer, the individual can claim back the cost on their tax return.\n\n[Byline: Brad Crouch]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Q fever is an infection caused by _Coxiella burnetii_, a type of bacterium found worldwide except New Zealand. The infection is almost always related to direct or indirect contact with animals such as cattle, sheep or goats, although a wide range of animals including cats, dogs and kangaroos may carry the infection. Infection in animals is probably common, but animals usually do not appear to be ill.\n\nThe bacteria pass into milk, urine and faeces of infected animals and during birthing, large numbers of organisms are shed in the birth products. Q fever organisms are resistant to heat, drying, and many common disinfectants, allowing them to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of the bacteria in air carrying dust contaminated by dried placental material, birth fluids, urine or faeces of infected herd animals. Contaminated clothing, wool, hides or straw may also be a source of infection. Person-to-person spread is extremely unlikely. Usually, Q fever is an occupational disease of meat workers, farmers and veterinarians (vets). People living within 1 kilometre [about 0.6 miles] downwind of an abattoir are also at increased risk of infection.\n\nOnly about half of all people infected with _Coxiella burnetii_ show signs of clinical illness, but onset of symptoms is usually sudden, with one or more of the following:\n- fever, which may last for up to 4 weeks\n- severe headache\n- sweats and chills\n- fatigue -- and a prolonged fatigue (post Q fever fatigue syndrome) may follow infection\n- muscle aches\n- confusion\n- sore throat\n- dry cough\n- chest pain on breathing\n- nausea, vomiting\n- diarrhoea\n- abdominal pain.\n\nUp to half of symptomatic cases will develop pneumonia (lung infection or inflammation) and many people will have inflammation of the liver (hepatitis). However, most people will recover within several months without any treatment and only 1 to 2 percent of people with acute Q fever die of the disease.\n\nSome people may develop chronic Q fever after exposure. Infection persists for more than 6 months and may not be apparent until many years after the initial infection. It is rare, but can have serious complications such as endocarditis (infection of the heart valves).\n\nPeople at most risk of developing chronic Q fever include:\n- those with underlying heart abnormalities\n- transplant recipients\n- cancer patients\n- those with chronic kidney disease.\n\nIncubation time is approximately 2-3 weeks but can range from 4 days to 6 weeks.\n\nDiagnosis is made by a series of blood tests.\n\nEffective antibiotic therapy is available. With early diagnosis, treatment is simple and a good outcome can be expected.\n\nIt is extremely rare for the disease to pass between people. So keeping someone home from work/school/social events is not necessary. What is necessary to prevent the spread is to refrain from drinking unpasteurized milk.\n\nA Q fever vaccine is available in Australia and is 83 to 100 percent effective in preventing the disease. However, the vaccine can only be given to individuals 15 years of age and over.\n\nPrior to immunisation, a blood and a skin test is recommended to see if the individual has previously been exposed to Q fever -- either naturally or by previous vaccination. Vaccinating those already exposed to Q fever can result in severe reactions.\n\nVaccination will not prevent disease in someone who has already been infected but is in the incubation period of the disease.\n\nQ fever vaccination is recommended for:\n- abattoir workers and contract workers in cattle, sheep dairy and goat abattoirs (but not pig abattoirs)\n- farmers, stockyard workers and livestock transporters\n- agricultural college staff and students and wildlife and zoo workers exposed to high risk animals\n- shearers and wool sorters\n- veterinarians, veterinary nurses and students\n- professional dog and cat breeders, tanning and hide workers and laboratory personnel handling veterinary products or working with the organism\n- others exposed to cattle, camels, sheep, goats and kangaroos or their products.\n\nPeople considering immunisation against Q fever should contact their doctor or an approved Q fever vaccination provider in South Australia. The Q fever vaccination register contains the location and contact details of approved Q fever vaccination providers in South Australia.\n\nThe information provided by the SA Health website is applicable to other countries as well, albeit not all countries have kangaroos or they are only in zoos and therefore zoo workers may need to be alerted to this situation.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from: http://www.sahealth.sa.gov.au/wps/wcm/connect/Public+Content/SA+Health+Internet/Health+topics/Health+conditions+prevention+and+treatment/Infectious+diseases/Q+fever/Q+fever+-+including+symptoms+treatment+and+prevention - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/286.]", "summary": "\n\nOnly about half of all people infected with _Coxiella burnetii_ show signs of clinical illness, but onset of symptoms is usually sudden, with one or more of the following:\n- fever, which may last for up to 4 weeks\n- severe headache\n- sweats and chills\n- fatigue -- and a prolonged fatigue (post Q fever fatigue syndrome) may follow infection\n- muscle aches\n- confusion\n- sore throat\n- dry cough\n- chest pain on breathing\n- nausea, vomiting\n- diarrhoea\n- abdominal pain. \n\nQ fever vaccination is recommended for:\n- abattoir workers and contract workers in cattle, sheep dairy and goat abattoirs (but not pig abattoirs)\n- farmers, stockyard workers and livestock transporters\n- agricultural college staff and students and wildlife and zoo workers exposed to high risk animals\n- shearers and wool sorters\n- veterinarians, veterinary nurses and students\n- professional dog and cat breeders, tanning and hide workers and laboratory personnel handling veterinary products or working with the organism\n- others exposed to cattle, camels, sheep, goats and kangaroos or their products. \n\nPeople at most risk of developing chronic Q fever include:\n- those with underlying heart abnormalities\n- transplant recipients\n- cancer patients\n- those with chronic kidney disease. The situation has worsened and infections have risen to 56, according to the Assistant Sub-Secretary of Public Health, Cristian Herrera.\n\nAs a result of this scenario and according to sources of Radio Bio Bio, the Ministry of Health would decree sanitary alert in 2 regions of the country, Los Lagos and Los Rios, to face the outbreak of this disease. In fact, the Undersecretariat sent the decree to the Comptroller's Office on [Mon 6 Nov 2017] and is awaiting approval.\n\nThe disease is difficult to detect in Chile, since the transfer to humans is unusual and there is no easy way to confirm it. Because of this, international assistance is requested, which is what the Ministry of Health did a few weeks ago, by contacting the World Health Organization (WHO), Canada and the University of Queensland.\n\nThe past president of the Chilean Society of Infectology, Jeanette Dabanch, said that it is a new disease in Chile because although it is common in animals, without causing any symptoms, human infection is uncommon. Dabanch added that it is difficult to establish - for now - the true magnitude of the outbreak in humans and to quantify the proportion of cases, which could increase.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Q fever, often acquired by close exposure to animals, is infectious with a very low inoculum and may be aerosolized over a significant distance. _Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was discovered in 1937. This organism is an agent that can be resistant to heat and desiccation and is highly infectious by the aerosol route. A single inhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human] primates, the dose to kill 50 percent of primates was found to be 1.7 organisms (1).\n\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_. Infection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including other species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does not usually cause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals. Most importantly, during birthing, the organisms are shed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta. Contact with contaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common disinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is associated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are produced during standard replication along with the less resistant large cell form, metabolically dormant and spore-like (3).\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very few organisms may be required to cause infection.\n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other modes of transmission to humans, including tick bites and human-to-human transmission are rare.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. But people living on small acreages in the Townsville and Mackay regions are now the group most at risk of contracting the disease in Queensland.\n\nTownsville Hospital director of microbiology Robert Norton began investigating the issue a few years ago when he noticed most patients being treated for Q fever tended to live on lifestyle blocks. It is suspected the disease is being transmitted by native animals.\n\n'Wallabies in particular will come down to feed on the new grass. They'll leave their droppings, and when the area is mowed, these droppings are aerosolized, and the person doing the mowing breathes them in,' Professor Norton said. 'We've done some surveys of a variety of animals, and we found that between 30 and 40 per cent of the wallabies surveyed tested positive for Q fever, and this compares with about 15 to 20 per cent of cattle.' Bandicoots and possums were also found to be carriers, along with suburban dogs.\n\nThe Q fever rate among humans in Australia is between 1 and 2 people for every 100 000, and in Queensland, it affects 3 per 100 000. However, Professor Norton said statistics from hospital records showed that in the Townsville region, the Q fever rate was 6 in every 100 000 people, and in specific suburbs, it affected 30 per 100 000. In one Mackay area, the rate is 50 in 100 000 people.\n\n'These are people who have been ill enough to need hospital admission or a hospital review,' Professor Norton said. 'About 20 to 30 per cent of people who are infected will require hospital admission, and in less than 5 per cent of people, it can be quite severe and has led to death.'\n\nPregnant women, or women planning to become pregnant, are particularly in danger. 'Pregnant women are at risk of having a stillbirth or a miscarriage if they get Q fever, and this has occurred in the regions mentioned,' Professor Norton said.\n\nRural Doctors Association Queensland president Konrad Kangru, who is also a GP in Proserpine, one of the affected areas, said people living on small acreages in dry areas of north Queensland should be alert but not alarmed. 'Just like with cyclones and irukandji [a highly venomous box jellyfish - CopyEd.MSP] and everything else, living up in these areas does have its risks, and certainly, the _Coxiella burnetii_ bacteria in the soil are one that we have to watch out for,' he said.\n\nPeople who are involved in soil work are urged to talk to their GP about being vaccinated. 'What we're seeing is you've got a lot of land which has previously been grazing properties or cane farms that are now being resumed for residential development,' Dr Kangru said. 'Anybody who is involved in earthworks, anybody who's involved in setting up those new developments and construction, they need to be thinking about what sort of inhalational soil exposure they might have.'\n\nDr Kangru said patients often did not realise they had had the disease, because of its influenza-like symptoms. 'Very often, we'll actually do a blood test for Q fever, and it'll show that somebody's had a previous exposure to the illness even though they haven't been acutely unwell with it,' he said.\n\nPeople who have been exposed in the past have to be tested for any adverse reactions before having a Qvax inoculation, because it can cause extreme side effects in those who have already had the disease. For this reason, Anthony Gregory, a post-doctoral research fellow at Texas A&M University, is working on developing an alternative vaccine through funding from the US military. 'In a recent study in 2012, of 1000 US troops who were deployed to Iraq, 10 per cent of them were seropositive to Q fever,' he said. 'Because of the reactogenicity associated with Qvax in hyper-sensitised individuals, it meant that 10 per cent of this population were not eligible for the vaccine.'\n\nThe United States also wants a new vaccine to prepare for _Coxiella burnetii_ possibly being used as a bio-threat. 'It's categorized as a CDC tier 2 select agent as a bio-weapon,' Dr Gregory said. 'It has previously been developed, I believe by the Soviets during World War II.' Initial trials of the alternative vaccine on mice and guinea pigs have shown promise, but human trials are not expected for several years.\n\n[Byline: Ren\u00e9e Cluff]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Q fever, often acquired by close exposure to animals, is infectious with a very low inoculum and may be aerosolized over a significant distance. _Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was discovered in 1937. Undersecretary of Health, Jaime Burrows, explained that the 43 patients are inhabitants of the regions of Los Lagos and Los R\u00edos, in southern Chile, and 20 of them were hospitalized. It should be noted that most of the cases are workers in the dairy industry.\n\nQ fever, which is transmitted to humans through contact with animals, has symptoms such as fever, as well as gastrointestinal and respiratory complaints. Because it is the 1st time that an outbreak of this magnitude has occurred in Chile, the Ministry of Health requested assistance from Australian experts to investigate the cases.\n\nBurrows said that 'it is working to control the outbreak' and detailed that patients are receiving antimicrobial treatment. 'Unfortunately, about 10 percent of patients will develop chronic infection and we are evaluating the protocols to follow them in the long term,' he added.\n\nThe head of the Livestock Protection Division of the Agricultural and Livestock Service, Jos\u00e9 Ignacio G\u00f3mez, clarified that the bacterium causing the Q fever does not survive the milk pasteurization process. 'It is impossible for the milk that is bought and consumed by the population to cause the Q fever,' he said.\n\nQ fever, a zoonosis caused by the bacteria _Coxiella burnetii_, is an organism that does not produce symptoms in animals. The disease was initially described in 1937 in Australia as a fever of unknown etiology.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Q fever, often acquired by close exposure to animals, is infectious with a very low inoculum and may be aerosolized over a significant distance. _Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was discovered in 1937. This organism is an agent that can be resistant to heat and desiccation and is highly infectious by the aerosol route. A single inhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human] primates, the dose to kill 50 percent of primates was found to be 1.7 organisms (1).\n\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_. Infection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including other species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does not usually cause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals. Most importantly, during birthing, the organisms are shed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta. Contact with contaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common disinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is associated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are produced during standard replication along with the less resistant large cell form, metabolically dormant and spore-like (3).\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very few organisms may be required to cause infection.\n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other modes of transmission to humans, including tick bites and human-to-human transmission are rare.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. The zoonotic disease is transmitted from animals to humans and can cause fever, chills, headaches and muscle pain, and in rare cases long-term liver and heart problems.\n\nThe Australian Services Union has hit out at the council, claiming about 50 workers had tested positive to Q fever and that workers were not being vaccinated for the disease. 'We had no idea it was this bad,' Australian Services Union Victorian Branch secretary Richard Duffy said. 'Over 80 percent of people who have been tested have tested positive, and they've tested over 60 people now.\n\n'There are a variety of symptoms, some people are off work, but they're continuing to test people. The more we look into it the worse it gets.' Mr Duffy said the union was concerned by workers' claims they had not been immunised against Q fever, despite the use of vaccines being considered best practice for those working with animals. 'It turns out that nobody has been immunised against it or vaccinated against it,' he said. 'We are seeking an urgent meeting with council to find out why.'\n\nThe bacterium that causes the Q fever can remain in the environment for a long time, is airborne and can survive disinfectants and harsh conditions. Acting city services director Peter Godfrey said the council had been testing and vaccinating staff employed at the saleyards for 'a number of years', and played down the positive tests. 'It is possible for a person to test positive to Q fever antibodies without ever having shown symptoms of the infection, and many years after exposure to the bacteria,' Mr Godfrey said. 'All City employees have been informed of the risks associated with exposure to Q fever at staff meetings and through an organisation-wide safety alert.\n\n'A safety sign at the Geelong Saleyards, installed during works prior to reopening of the site in February 2017, states that Q fever vaccination is recommended for all persons attending the site.' However the Geelong Advertiser could not find the sign when it visited the saleyards yesterday [Tue 18 Jul 2017] and was later informed that the sign, which was inside the saleyards, was not 'Q fever specific'. There is no mention of Q fever or recommended vaccinations on the council's Saleyards web page, which includes advice, frequently asked questions and an Occupational Health and Safety report. A sheep and poultry sale at the Geelong Saleyards is still scheduled to go ahead on [Mon 24 Jul 2017].\n\nA report into the local livestock industry by analyst Mercado, commissioned by CoGG this year [2017], found issues raised by stakeholders including 'concern for cross-contamination of airborne diseases'. Geelong Saleyards Users Group head Ian Kelly said the results weren't surprising, and that the workers could have been exposed to the disease previously.\n\nThe bacterium that causes the Q fever can remain in the environment for a long time, is airborne and can survive disinfectants and harsh conditions.\n\nFarmers, abattoir workers and shearers are at the highest risk of developing the disease.\n\nQ fever is caused by a microorganism that is mainly carried by goats, sheep and cattle. It can also be carried by kangaroos, wallabies, camels, rodents, cats, dogs and birds. The bacteria can survive many disinfectants and harsh conditions. It can remain in the environment for long periods of time, which means dust, hay and other small particles may carry the bacteria. It is airborne so can be contracted by breathing in dust from infected premises and properties. Contact with the urine or faeces of infected animals and/or contaminated wool or hides can also transmit the disease. The highest risk of transmission is through contact with the birth products of infected animals.\n\nFlu-like symptoms including fever, headaches, chills and muscle pains. Only 50 percent of people who contract Q fever develop symptoms. In rare cases, long-term heart and liver problems can result. Acute cases usually require antibiotics. Community members concerned about Q fever can visit https://www2.health.vic.gov.au/ or https://www.qfever.org/.\n\n[Byline: Harrison Tippet]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Geelong, with a population of 191 440 residents, is a port city located on Corio Bay in the state of Victoria, Australia, 75 km (47 mi) south-west of the state capital, Melbourne (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geelong). For a map showing the location of Geelong in relation to Melbourne, see https://www.google.com/maps/place/Geelong+Saleyards,+North+Geelong+VIC+3215,+Australia.\n\nThe Geelong Saleyards, established in 1869 by the Geelong Town Corporation, is a venue for farmers from across the region to buy and sell sheep, cattle and poultry (https://www.geelongaustralia.com.au/saleyards/default.aspx). A truck wash also operates at the Saleyards, to clean out trucks between loads, reducing the possible spread of disease.\n\nThe Saleyards was subject to a study in 2016 because of location, safety and financial concerns (http://www.geelongaustralia.com.au/common/public/documents/8d3e8703357bd3e-Geelong%20Saleyards%20Feasibility%20Study%20-%20Final%20Report%20for%20Consultation%20(3).pdf). Although once located in an outlying area without neighboring urban uses, the Saleyards are now completely surrounded by urban development and is within close proximity to the Geelong city center.\n\nSerum antibodies to _Coxiella burnetii_, the cause of Q fever, remain detectable for years, or even for life. In the U.S., 3.1 percent of the general adult U.S. population has been found to have detectable antibodies to _C. burnetii_ (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr6203a1.htm) and the seroprevalence in Queensland, Australia has been found to be about 5 percent in rural, as well as metropolitan (Brisbane) settings (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21499708). Because of persistence of a positive serology, a confirmed diagnosis of acute Q fever requires a demonstration of a 4-fold rise in phase II IgG by indirect immunofluorescence assay (IFA) between serum samples from the acute and convalescent phases taken 3-6 weeks apart (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr6203a1.htm). A single positive convalescent serum sample (IgG phase II greater than or equal to 1:128) in a patient who has been ill greater than 1 week indicates a probable acute infection. Serum PCR for Q fever is positive for _C. burnetii_ in almost all patients with early acute Q fever, i.e., during the 1st 2 weeks of symptoms, before the antibody response. Chronic Q Fever (i.e., endocarditis) is diagnosed by a phase I IgG antibody titer greater than 1:800).\n\nBecause early doxycycline treatment (within the 1st 3 days of symptoms) is most effective, treatment of a symptomatic patient suspected of having Q fever should be based on clinical findings and should not be delayed while awaiting laboratory confirmation (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr6203a1.htm). Treatment is not indicated for people with only positive serologic titers (although it might be considered in persons at high risk for development of chronic Q fever - see https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr6203a1.htm).\n\nIn Australia, the organism is found in livestock, including goats, cattle, sheep, other farm and domestic animals, companion animals (dogs and cats) and in some wild animals (including kangaroos and bandicoots). People most at risk include workers from the meat and livestock industries and shearers, as well as the general population in close proximity to infected animals in stockyards, feedlots, processing plants or farms.\n\nIn Australia, immunization is recommended for high-risk occupational groups. However, there is a risk of severe local reactions to the vaccine in those people previously exposed to Q fever or Q fever vaccine. To assess prior exposure, prevaccination serologic screening is necessary. Any positive result on screening precludes Q fever vaccination (https://www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/infectious-diseases/disease-information-advice/q-fever). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/288.]", "summary": "Community members concerned about Q fever can visit https://www2.health.vic.gov.au/ or https://www.qfever.org/.\n\n[Byline: Harrison Tippet]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Geelong, with a population of 191 440 residents, is a port city located on Corio Bay in the state of Victoria, Australia, 75 km (47 mi) south-west of the state capital, Melbourne (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geelong). \n\nThe Australian Services Union has hit out at the council, claiming about 50 workers had tested positive to Q fever and that workers were not being vaccinated for the disease. Curtis Gregory said 7 cases of the potentially debilitating disease had been confirmed within the Illawarra Shoalhaven Local Health District so far this year [2016].\n\nStatewide the number of cases has doubled in 5 years, from 130 in 2012, to 260 in 2015. In the 1st 6 months of 2016, NSW [New South Wales] Health has been notified of 88 cases.\n\n'Q fever is a bacterial infection normally spread to humans by infected animals,' Mr Gregory said. 'It's mainly seen around agricultural and livestock industries and occupations but can be found in wildlife populations.' Mr Gregory said while case numbers were relatively low in the region, there had been some community concern over perceived hotspots. 'We have seen numbers group around certain areas in the Shoalhaven like Sanctuary Point, although there have been some cases in the southern Illawarra,' he said.\n\n'We have done environmental sampling at different locations -- of kangaroo and bandicoot droppings -- but no positive results have been found.' Humans usually get infected by inhaling bacteria-carrying dust contaminated by animal urine, faeces or birth products. 'Those at higher risk of infection include abattoir and meat workers; farmers and shearers; stockyard workers and animal transporters; veterinarians and agriculture college staff and students,' Mr Gregory said. 'Horticulturists or gardeners may also be concerned if there's a lot of wildlife in the area, as activities like lawn mowing may put them at risk.'\n\nSymptoms of Q fever appear 2 to 3 weeks after exposure, and include high fever, chills, sweats, headaches, muscle and joint pain, and fatigue. 'In rarer incidences the people develop more serious complications -- it can affect the heart or other organs like the liver,' Mr Gregory said.\n\nAntibiotics effectively treat the disease, however there is a vaccine available for high-risk groups. 'It's a one-off vaccine which gives life-long immunity -- however testing needs to be done first to ensure the person hasn't already been exposed,' Mr Gregory said.\n\n'I rang an ambulance because I thought I was going to die'. This patient will be giving the kangaroos at his workplace a wide berth. The 43-year-old groundskeeper from St Georges Basin contracted Q fever from infected kangaroos, after breathing in airborne particles from their droppings. After 2 misdiagnoses this year [2016], the patient's health began deteriorating. 'The local doctor originally diagnosed me with a chest infection and then it got worse so I took myself to hospital but they sent me home with crampeze [a homeopathic medication for muscle cramps],' he said. 'The doctor says it can take up to 2 years to recover and sometimes you don't properly recover at all. It got so bad after that I rang an ambulance because I thought I was going to die. I couldn't stop shivering, I had jaundice in my eyes, I was really bloated and they took me to Shoalhaven Hospital and then straight to the Wollongong Emergency Care Unit, where I stayed for 3 weeks.'\n\n[The patient's] liver had begun shutting down and he'd gone from 82 kg [about 181 lb] to 59 kg [about 130 lb]. 'My liver ate every bit of muscle off my body,' he said. 'The specialist said to me I must have some people upstairs watching over me because I shouldn't be here.' Antibiotics have cured the infection but the long-term effects are significant. 'The doctor says it can take up to 2 years to recover and sometimes you don't properly recover at all,' he said. 'I'm slowly putting weight back on but some of the side effects are I've got the same skin as a 90-year-old man, I've got no muscle tissue left on my body and I'm really weak and frail. I'm just a mere shadow of myself.'\n\n[The patient] said he wasn't aware of the dangers of Q fever or how it was contracted and urged others working near animals to get vaccinated. 'You can get vaccinated for it but I didn't know that, no-one mentioned it, and I'm sure there's a lot of other people who don't realise that too,' he said. 'If you're a groundsman or working near animals, get vaccinated. It's really important, especially if you're mowing over kangaroo droppings because that spreads the particles.'\n\n[Byline: Lisa Wachsmuth]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Q fever is caused by an obligate intracellular Gram-negative bacterium, _Coxiella burnetii_. In Australia, cattle, sheep, and goats are the main reservoir; bandicoots, kangaroos, and dogs can also be infected. Q fever is mainly usually spread from animals to humans via inhalation of aerosolized particles of dried excreta and especially birthing products (such as placental material, birth fluids) of infected animals -- because the organism is reactivated in pregnant animals. Humans are very susceptible to the disease; very few organisms are required to initiate infection. Q fever can also be transmitted by ingestion of raw milk or dairy products. Contact with contaminated hides or wool is also known to be a mode of transmission.\n\nMaps of Australia can be seen at http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5004.\nIllawarra is a coastal region in the Australian state of New South Wales, situated immediately south of Sydney and north of the Shoalhaven or South Coast region (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illawarra). The main industries in the area have traditionally been farming, coal mining, and steel making. Wollongong is a coastal city with a population of almost 300 000 residents in the Illawarra region, 82 km (51 mi) south of Sydney (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wollongong). Shoalhaven is a city of almost 100 000 residents on the south-eastern coastal region of New South Wales, approximately 200 km (120 mi) south of Sydney (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_of_Shoalhaven).\n\nFurther discussions of Q fever and its prevention by vaccination can be found in moderator comments in prior ProMED-mail posts listed below. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Q fever is mainly usually spread from animals to humans via inhalation of aerosolized particles of dried excreta and especially birthing products (such as placental material, birth fluids) of infected animals -- because the organism is reactivated in pregnant animals. \n\n'Q fever is a bacterial infection normally spread to humans by infected animals,' Mr Gregory said. ' Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Q fever is caused by an obligate intracellular Gram-negative bacterium, _Coxiella burnetii_. \n\nSymptoms of Q fever appear 2 to 3 weeks after exposure, and include high fever, chills, sweats, headaches, muscle and joint pain, and fatigue. ' \n\n[Byline: Lisa Wachsmuth]\n\n--\n [The patient] said he wasn't aware of the dangers of Q fever or how it was contracted and urged others working near animals to get vaccinated. ' \n\n'We have done environmental sampling at different locations -- of kangaroo and bandicoot droppings -- but no positive results have been found.' Those at higher risk of infection include abattoir and meat workers; farmers and shearers; stockyard workers and animal transporters; veterinarians and agriculture college staff and students,' Mr Gregory said. ' \n\nFurther discussions of Q fever and its prevention by vaccination can be found in moderator comments in prior ProMED-mail posts listed below. Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA: (NEW SOUTH WALES) VACCINATION\n**************************************************\n Curtis Gregory said 7 cases of the potentially debilitating disease had been confirmed within the Illawarra Shoalhaven Local Health District so far this year [2016]. The 43-year-old groundskeeper from St Georges Basin contracted Q fever from infected kangaroos, after breathing in airborne particles from their droppings. Shoalhaven is a city of almost 100 000 residents on the south-eastern coastal region of New South Wales, approximately 200 km (120 mi) south of Sydney (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_of_Shoalhaven). The doctor says it can take up to 2 years to recover and sometimes you don't properly recover at all,' he said. In rarer incidences the people develop more serious complications -- it can affect the heart or other organs like the liver,' Mr Gregory said. The [Illawarra] region's public health director has moved to allay community concerns after several cases of confirmed Q fever. 'I'm slowly putting weight back on but some of the side effects are I've got the same skin as a 90-year-old man, I've got no muscle tissue left on my body and I'm really weak and frail.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Illawarra", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Sydney", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4974554", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Germany: (RP) sheep cell therapy, 2014", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4974554", "date": "2017-04-16 17:50:31", "main_text": "Q FEVER - GERMANY: (RHINELAND PALATINATE) SHEEP CELL THERAPY, 2014\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 16 Apr 2017\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases (ahead of print) [edited]\nhttps://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/7/16-1693_article\n\n\nLive cell therapy as potential risk factor for Q fever\n------------------------------------------------------\nGram negative intracellular bacteria (_Coxiella burnetii_) cause Q fever, a zoonotic disease usually subclinical in livestock and humans. Typically, human patients show signs and symptoms, such as fever, severe headache, nausea, pneumonia, or hepatitis, 2-3 weeks after injection. Chronic Q fever develops in 1 per cent to 5 per cent of patients (1).\n\nOn 5 Aug 2014, a local health department in the Federal State of the Rhineland Palatinate in southern Germany alerted the Federal State Agency for Consumer and Health Protection (FSACHP) (Landau, Germany) after detecting a cluster of 8 patients with pneumonia in a rural community during a 6-week period. The local health department and FSACHP started a joint outbreak investigation to identify cases, find the source of the outbreak, and stop disease transmission. On 12 Aug 2014, 5 of 8 patients tested by ELISA and immunofluorescence test (IFT) by the local health department had results consistent with acute _C. burnetii_ infection. The local health department issued a public health warning in the local media and advised anyone in the affected community with influenza-like symptoms or pneumonia in the past 4 months to be tested for Q fever by their general practitioner. In addition, the department offered free testing to pregnant women and persons with cardiovascular risk factors (for example, heart valve defects), irrespective of symptoms (2).\n\nCase-patients were defined as persons who had phase II IgM or IgG titers for Q fever by ELISA or IFT in 2014. Data for these case-patients were entered into the German Electronic Surveillance System for Infectious Disease Outbreaks (3). 13 residential case-patients (6 men, 7 women) who lived in the affected county (Bad Duerkheim) were identified; 11 reported symptoms compatible with Q fever, of whom 6 were hospitalized (figure [for figure, see original URL. - Mod.LL]). Median age for residential case-patients was 50 (range 32-59) years for women and 44 (range 26-56) years for men.\n\nBecause all residential case-patients lived within 1.5 km of a flock of 1000 sheep, the FSACHP tested random samples from these sheep. Of 61 sheep tested, 25 were positive for _C. burnetii_ by ELISA of serum samples and 2 by PCR of vaginal swab specimens. During the investigation, the local health department discovered that young rams and pregnant ewes in the flock had been used as donor animals for live cell therapy (LCT) at 2 medical facilities in a district 10 km from the farm. LCT is injection of fetal cells or cell extracts from sheep into humans. The flock was banned for LCT production, and veterinary control measures (e.g., indoor housing and immunization of sheep) were initiated to stop transmission.\n\nStaff members of LCT facilities were offered serologic testing by ELISA or IFT. 16 persons with occupational cases (3 men, 13 women) were reported; 10 showed onset of disease, and 2 were hospitalized (figure). Median age for occupational case-patients was 48 (range 28-62) years for women and 45 (range 35-50) years for men.\n\nLCT is an alternative treatment (without medical evidence of effectiveness) that is marketed worldwide online. It consists of intramuscular injections of cell suspensions from fetal sheep to human recipients for rejuvenation (anti-aging) and other ailments. Apart from national recipients, medical tourists from North America and Asia travel to Germany to receive injections. In August, the FSACHP was notified of a patient from Canada who received LCT injections on 28 May 2014, and became ill in June 2014, before _C. burnetii_ was detected in the asymptomatic donor sheep herd (4,5).\n\nNewspaper coverage in October 2014 of the Q fever outbreak and the potential link to the LCT recipient from Canada alerted an LCT recipient in Germany who had recovered from a previously unidentified illness after receiving LCT in Rhineland Palatinate (4,6). The patient became ill (fever, severe diarrhea, and fatigue) 1 day after receiving LCT injections on 14 Jul 2014, lost 9 kg, and was hospitalized for 10 days. She was positive for Q fever by IFT in October 2014 and had a phase II IgG titer (1:65 536) that was higher than her phase I IgG titer (1:4096), which indicated a recent infection. She had no other contact with sheep or sheep products during her stay at the LCT facility or thereafter.\n\nA pharmacovigilance report by the Paul Ehrlich Institut (Langen, Germany) indicated that LCT treatment was the probable cause of the Q fever (7). The county ordered both LCT facilities to advise all 830 LCT recipients treated since January 2014 to consult their general practitioner about their possible risk for Q fever. This advice prompted 5 US citizens who received injections on 28 May 2014 in one of the clinics to be tested for Q fever. An investigation by the US CDC (Atlanta, GA, USA) identified recent Q fever in all 5 patients (phase II IgG titers <1:65 536 at 2-6 months postinjection) (5).\n\nSeveral facilities offer LCT in Germany, although the federal ministry of health recently released an assessment stating that the use of LCT is unsafe (8). Therefore, practitioners worldwide should be informed that working at an LCT clinic or receiving LCT injections should be considered potential risk factors for Q fever.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. October 8, 2014 [cited 6 Dec 205]. http://www.rheinpfalz.de/nachrichten/titelseite/artikel/q-fieber-aus-der-pfalz-nach-kanada/\n7. Cussler K, Funk MB, Schilling-Lei D. Suspected transmission of Q fever by fresh cell therapy [in German]. Bulletin zur Arzneimittelsicherheit. 2015; 5: 13-15.\n8. Federal Health Office. Consolidated summary of the opinions of the Paul Ehrlich Institute and the Federal Institute for Drugs and Medical Devices on parenteral application of fresh cells and xenogenic organ extracts in humans [in German] [cited 2017 Jan 13]. http://www.bundesgesundheitsministerium.de/service/publikationen/gesundheit/details.html?bmg%5Bpubid%5D=2972\n\n[authors: George M, Reich A, Cussler K, Jehl H, Burckhardt F]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This case report documents a parallel German case of acute _C. burnetii_ infection associated with the cases described in USA and Canadian individuals reported in 2014 and 2015.\n\nThe following is a warning regarding this non-traditional therapy from the American Cancer Society (http://www.cancer.org/treatment/treatmentsandsideeffects/complementaryandalternativemedicine/pharmacologicalandbiologicaltreatment/cell-therapy):\n\n'Cell therapy\nOther common name(s): cellular therapy, fresh cell therapy, live cell therapy, glandular therapy, xenotransplant therapy\n\n'Description: in cell therapy, processed tissue from the organs, embryos, or fetuses of animals such as sheep or cows is injected into patients. Cell therapy is promoted as an alternative form of cancer treatment.\n\n'Overview: available scientific evidence does not support claims that cell therapy is effective in treating cancer or any other disease. Serious side effects can result from cell therapy. It may in fact be lethal; several deaths have been reported. It is important to distinguish between this alternative method involving animal cells and mainstream cancer treatments that use human cells, such as bone marrow transplantation.\n\n'How is it promoted for use? In cell therapy, live or freeze-dried cells or pieces of cells from the healthy organs, fetuses, or embryos of animals such as sheep or cows are injected into patients. This is supposed to repair cellular damage and heal sick or failing organs. Cell therapy is promoted as an alternative therapy for cancer, arthritis, heart disease, Down syndrome, and Parkinson disease.\n\n'Cell therapy is also marketed to counter the effects of aging, reverse degenerative diseases, improve general health, increase vitality and stamina, and enhance sexual function. Some practitioners have proposed using cell therapy to treat AIDS patients.\n\n'The theory behind cell therapy is that the healthy animal cells injected into the body can find their way to weak or damaged organs of the same type and stimulate the body's own healing process. The choice of the type of cells to use depends on which organ is having the problem. For instance, a patient with a diseased liver may receive injections of animal liver cells. Most cell therapists today use cells taken from taken from the tissue of animal embryos.\n\n'Supporters assert that after the cells are injected into the body, they are transported directly to where they are most needed. They claim that embryonic and fetal animal tissue contains therapeutic agents that can repair damage and stimulate the immune system, thereby helping cells in the body heal.\n\n'The alternative treatment cell therapy is very different from some forms of proven therapy that use live human cells. Bone marrow transplants infuse blood stem cells -- from the patient or a carefully matched donor -- after the patient's own bone marrow cells have been destroyed. Studies have shown that bone marrow transplants are effective in helping to treat several types of cancer. In another accepted procedure, damaged knee cartilage can be repaired by taking cartilage cells from the patient's knee, carefully growing them in the laboratory, and then injecting them back into the joint. Approaches involving transplants of other types of human stem cells are being studied as a possible way to replace damaged nerve or heart muscle cells, but these approaches are still experimental.\n\n'What does it involve? 1st, healthy live cells are harvested from the organs of juvenile or adult live animals, animal embryos, or animal fetuses. These cells may be taken from the brain, pituitary gland, thyroid gland, thymus gland, liver, kidney, pancreas, spleen, heart, ovaries, testicles, or even from whole embryos. Patients might receive one or several types of animal cells. Some cell therapists inject fresh cells into their patients. Others freeze them first, which kills the cells, and they may filter out some of the cell components. Frozen cell extracts have a longer 'shelf life' and can be screened for disease. Fresh cells cannot be screened. A course of cell therapy to address a specific disease might require several injections over a short period of time, whereas cell therapy designed to treat the effects of aging and 'increase vitality' may involve injections received over many months.\n\n'Animal cell extracts are also sold in pill form as dietary supplements, usually called glandular supplements. These, too, allegedly travel to organs of the same kind in the body to promote healing.\n\n'What is the history behind it? The Swiss physician Paul Niehans, MD, invented cell therapy in 1931. During a medical emergency, Dr Niehans injected a solution containing ground-up parathyroid cells from a calf into a patient who had damaged parathyroid glands. The patient recovered, and Dr Niehans attributed the improvement to the injection. He went on to apply the idea of animal-human cellular transfer to other diseases.\n\n'Dr Niehans claimed that he treated more than 30 000 patients with cell therapy. He also claimed that the death rate from cancer among his patients who received cell therapy was 5 times less than that of the average population. He believed that injections of cells from animals resistant to cancer would increase cancer resistance in humans. A 2nd physician announced similar findings 30 years later. Neither claim has ever been supported by research studies published in medical journals.\n\n'Cell therapy may be harmful and is not legally available in the United States. Because of safety concerns and lack of proof of its effectiveness, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has banned the import of cell therapy products into the country. The treatment is provided in clinics and spas in Europe, Mexico, and the Bahamas.\n\n'What is the evidence? None of the therapeutic success claimed by cell therapists has been documented through scientific testing and published in peer-reviewed medical journals. Claims of the therapy's success take the form of individual cases, testimonials, and publicity issued by practitioners of the therapy. Even supporters of cell therapy admit they do not know how cell therapy works in the body. No reliable evidence has been published in medical journals to support the claims of cell therapy.\n\n'Are there any possible problems or complications? These substances may have not been thoroughly tested to find out how they interact with medicines, foods, or dietary supplements. Even though some reports of interactions and harmful effects may be published, full studies of interactions and effects are not often available. Because of these limitations, any information on ill effects and interactions below should be considered incomplete.\n\n'Cell therapy may be dangerous, and several patient deaths linked to the therapy have been reported in the medical literature. Patients can contract bacterial and viral infections carried by the animal cells, and some have had life-threatening and even fatal allergic reactions. Other reports list complications such as brain swelling or the immune system attacking blood vessels or nerves following cellular treatment. Serious immune system reactions resulting in death have also been reported. Women who are pregnant or breast-feeding should not use this method, as its possible effects on a fetus are unknown.'\n\nA good recent review on Q fever can be found at:\nMelgar TA, Bauler TJ, Lutwick LI. Q fever in man: a One Health paradigm disease. In: The principles and practices of Q fever: the One Health paradigm. Simeos JCC, Anastacio SF, Da Silva GJ (eds). Nova Scientific Publishers: New York, 2017; pp 1-24. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/101.]", "summary": "Other common name(s): cellular therapy, fresh cell therapy, live cell therapy, glandular therapy, xenotransplant therapy\n\n'Description: in cell therapy, processed tissue from the organs, embryos, or fetuses of animals such as sheep or cows is injected into patients. http://www.bundesgesundheitsministerium.de/service/publikationen/gesundheit/details.html?bmg%5Bpubid%5D=2972\n\n[authors: George M, Reich A, Cussler K, Jehl H, Burckhardt F]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This case report documents a parallel German case of acute _C. burnetii_ infection associated with the cases described in USA and Canadian individuals reported in 2014 and 2015. \n\nThe following is a warning regarding this non-traditional therapy from the American Cancer Society (http://www.cancer.org/treatment/treatmentsandsideeffects/complementaryandalternativemedicine/pharmacologicalandbiologicaltreatment/cell-therapy):\n\n'Cell therapy\n A course of cell therapy to address a specific disease might require several injections over a short period of time, whereas cell therapy designed to treat the effects of aging and 'increase vitality' may involve injections received over many months. \n\n'The alternative treatment cell therapy is very different from some forms of proven therapy that use live human cells. Because of safety concerns and lack of proof of its effectiveness, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has banned the import of cell therapy products into the country.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-12-25 00:00:00", "2017-01-13 00:00:00", "1931-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-24 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-01-25 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-10-08 00:00:00", "2021-08-25 00:00:00", "2050-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-05-28 00:00:00", "2014-10-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2048-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-06-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rhine", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "GA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bahamas", "country": "Bahamas"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Langen", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4256718", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands: human, 2007-2015, fatalities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4256718", "date": "2016-05-31 20:47:47", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS: HUMAN, 2007 - 2015, FATALITIES\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 31 May 2016\nSource: NLTimes [edited]\nhttp://www.nltimes.nl/2016/05/31/74-people-killed-q-fever-outbreak/\n\n\nThe official death toll of people affected by Q-Fever since the outbreak in 2007 now stands at 74, an increase of 26 since the number was last updated, NU.nl reports.\n\nThe reason for the increase in deaths can be attributed to patients still carrying the live bacteria after the 2007 outbreak. The disease has symptoms of fever, headache, muscle aches and a decreased heart rate, among other things.\n\nAccording to Annemieke de Groot, managing director of foundation Q-support, it is still important for doctors to remain alert and be able to recognize the symptoms. The foundation will explain the increased death toll at a conference at the Brabant provincial house in Den Bosch on 20 June 2016.\n\nThe Q-Fever outbreak in the Netherlands in 2007 is considered one of the largest outbreaks of this disease in the world. Thousands of people in the Netherlands fell ill. The disease is usually transmitted from animals to humans.\n\n[Byline: Janene Pieters]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Netherlands suffered a large epidemic of Q fever which started in 2007 and continued until 2010, manifested by thousands of human cases, most of them due to infection by aerosols originating in aborting dairy goats. The efforts undertaken to get the spread under control included mass tests on dairy goats and sheep farms, the slaughter of some 40 000 goats, mass vaccinations in goats and sheep and various agrotechnical measures, in particular addressing the treatment of farms' manure.\n\nWhile assessment of the above reported Q fever-related fatalities is delayed until full data are published (20 Jun 2016), the following (summarized) abstract of a 2014 paper (Ref 1) may be helpful.\n\nAbstract\n--------\n'From 2007 to 2010, the Netherlands experienced a large Q fever outbreak, which has offered a unique opportunity to analyze chronic Q fever cases. In an observational cohort study, baseline characteristics and clinical characteristics, as well as mortality, of patients with proven, probable, or possible chronic Q fever in the Netherlands, were analyzed. In total, 284 chronic Q fever patients were identified, of which 151 (53.7 percent) had proven, 64 (22.5 percent) probable, and 69 (24.3 percent) possible, chronic Q fever. Among proven and probable chronic Q fever patients, vascular infection focus (56.7 percent) was more prevalent than endocarditis (34.9 percent). An acute Q fever episode was recalled by 27 percent of the patients. The all-cause mortality rate was 19.1 percent, while the chronic Q fever-related mortality rate was 13 percent, with mortality rates of 9.3 percent among endocarditis patients and 18 percent among patients with a vascular focus of infection. Increasing age (P equal 0.004 and 0.010), proven chronic Q fever (P equal 0.020 and 0.002), vascular chronic Q fever (P equal 0.024 and 0.005), acute presentation with chronic Q fever (P equal 0.002 and P < 0.001), and surgical treatment of chronic Q fever (P = 0.025 and P less than 0.001) were significantly associated with all-cause mortality and chronic Q fever-related mortality, respectively.'\n\nOne genotype of _Coxiella burnetti_ was predominantly present in the Dutch dairy goat population; and it was suggested that this genotype probably played a key role in the epidemic. It was found that strains with the same genotype showed differences in virulence.\n\nThe draft genome sequence of the human isolate has been published in 2015 (Ref 2).\n\nOn 21 Apr 2016, the complete genome sequence of _C.burnetii_ goat outbreak strain NL3262 and that of an epidemiologically linked chronic human strain, both having the outbreak-related CbNL01 multilocus variable-number tandem-repeat analysis (MLVA) genotype, was published (Ref 3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Kampschreur LM, Delsing CE, Groenwold RH, et al. Chronic Q Fever in the Netherlands 5 Years after the Start of the Q Fever Epidemic: Results from the Dutch Chronic Q Fever Database. J Clin Microbiol. 2014; 52(5): 1637-43. Available at http://jcm.asm.org/content/52/5/1637.full.pdf+html.\n\n2. Hammerl JA, Mertens K, Sprague LD, et al. First draft genome sequence of a human _Coxiella burnetii_ isolate, originating from the largest Q fever outbreak ever reported, the Netherlands, 2007 to 2010. Genome Announc. 2015; 3(3): e00445-15. Available at http://genomea.asm.org/content/3/3/e00445-15.full.pdf+html.\n\n3. Kuley R, Smith HE, Janse I, et al. First complete genome sequence of the Dutch veterinary _Coxiella burnetii_ strain NL3262, originating from the largest global Q fever outbreak, and draft genome sequence of its epidemiologically linked chronic human isolate NLhu3345937. Genome Announc. 2016; 4(2):e00245-16. The all-cause mortality rate was 19.1 percent, while the chronic Q fever-related mortality rate was 13 percent, with mortality rates of 9.3 percent among endocarditis patients and 18 percent among patients with a vascular focus of infection. In total, 284 chronic Q fever patients were identified, of which 151 (53.7 percent) had proven, 64 (22.5 percent) probable, and 69 (24.3 percent) possible, chronic Q fever. The statistic was revealed on last week's [week of 6 Jul 2015] episode of the ABC program Landline [http://www.abc.net.au/landline/content/2015/s4271952.htm]. Federal Health Minister Sussan Ley has promised to keep a 'watching brief' on the incidence of Q fever -- an infectious disease passed from animals to humans -- as dry conditions provide an ideal environment for the airborne organism to spread.\n\nQ fever can be passed on from almost any animal, but is mostly spread by goats, sheep, and cattle. The early symptoms resemble the flu and include high temperature, sweating, and body aches and pains. If caught early, it can be treated with antibiotics. But it has become increasingly clear that 20 to 25 per cent of cases do not fully recover, with sufferers going on to develop long-term chronic fatigue.\n\nApproximately 2 per cent of people who contract the disease end up with a life-threatening failure of their heart valves, and a small percentage die from the disease.\n\nQ fever -- the Q standing for Query -- is an international disease, identified in almost every country except New Zealand, but Australia is the only place that has an effective vaccine. Classed as a notifiable disease, just under 500 Australian cases are registered each year, almost half of them in Queensland.\n\nThe Q-vax vaccine was introduced to abattoir workers in the early 1990s and resulted in a halving of the number of Q fever cases nationally. A federally funded vaccination campaign targeting sheep, cattle, and dairy farmers was rolled out from 2001-2005, again with a dramatic drop in notifications.\n\nWith case numbers edging up slightly in the past 2 years, and a lack of awareness of the disease even in rural areas where it is most prevalent, there have been calls for another subsidised vaccination campaign. But Ms Ley said she would not agree to another vaccination campaign 'at this stage'.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/47001. Guyra, a town with a population of almost 2000 people in 2011, the seat of Guyra Shire, with a population of 4397 people in 2011, is located at an elevation of 1330 m (4364 ft) above sea level on the Northern Tablelands in the New England region of New South Wales, Australia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guyra,_New_South_Wales). The New England region is about 60 km (37 mi) inland from the Pacific Coast. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people make up 10 per cent of the population of Guyra Shire.\n\n_Coxiella burnetii_, an obligate intracellular rickettsia-like bacterial pathogen causes Q fever. Q fever is primarily an occupational hazard for farmers, veterinarians, and abattoir workers in contact with infected domestic animals such as cattle, sheep, and goats, which serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. Humans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms that are shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products of infected animals; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nQ fever spreads easily in agricultural regions via airborne particles containing the _C. burnetii_ for a considerable distances to involve people living downwind from infected livestock. Widespread transmission of Q fever was recently documented in the Netherlands downwind from the index farm from a single dairy-goat farm, even beyond a 5 km (3 mi) high-risk zone (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/55/12/1591.long#T2). _C. burnetii_ is highly resistant to drying, heat, and many common disinfectants, which is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of a biphasic developmental cycle. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nGuyra was home to a large regional abattoir that employed up to 350 staff until it closed in 1995; the abattoir building now houses an angora rabbit breeding establishment (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guyra,_New_South_Wales). The principal industries include wool, lambs, and beef cattle, which may explain why Guyra is a 'hot-spot' for Q fever.\n\nIn Australia, Q fever vaccination is recommended for those working in 'at-risk' occupations such as abattoir workers, farmers, stockyard workers, shearers, animal transporters, and others exposed to cattle, camels, sheep, goats, and kangaroos or their products (including products of conception), veterinarians, veterinary nurses, veterinary students, professional dog and cat breeders, agricultural college staff and students, wildlife and zoo workers (working with high-risk animals), and laboratory personnel handling veterinary specimens or working with the organism; workers at pig abattoirs do not require Q fever vaccination (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/Handbook10-home~handbook10part4~handbook10-4-15).\n\nIf the person has a positive history of previous infection with Q fever, vaccination is contraindicated; in others, serum antibody determination and skin tests must be done before vaccination to exclude those likely to have severe local or systemic hypersensitivity reactions to the vaccine resulting from previous unrecognized exposure to the organism (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/Handbook10-home~handbook10part4~handbook10-4-15). Q fever vaccine is not routinely recommended for children aged less than 15 years of age and pregnant or breastfeeding women because safety of the vaccine in these situations has not been established. Revaccination is not indicated due to the possibility of severe hypersensitivity reactions. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "In Australia, Q fever vaccination is recommended for those working in 'at-risk' occupations such as abattoir workers, farmers, stockyard workers, shearers, animal transporters, and others exposed to cattle, camels, sheep, goats, and kangaroos or their products (including products of conception), veterinarians, veterinary nurses, veterinary students, professional dog and cat breeders, agricultural college staff and students, wildlife and zoo workers (working with high-risk animals), and laboratory personnel handling veterinary specimens or working with the organism; workers at pig abattoirs do not require Q fever vaccination (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/Handbook10-home~handbook10part4~handbook10-4-15). \n\nIf the person has a positive history of previous infection with Q fever, vaccination is contraindicated; in others, serum antibody determination and skin tests must be done before vaccination to exclude those likely to have severe local or systemic hypersensitivity reactions to the vaccine resulting from previous unrecognized exposure to the organism (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/Handbook10-home~handbook10part4~handbook10-4-15). The disease is considered rare, and these would be among the 1st cases in Brazil.\n\nThe diagnosis was reported to Municipal Health of Barbosa yesterday morning [15 Mar 2015] during a visit to the municipality of the director of the Center for Strategic Information for Health Surveillance of Sao Paulo, Gizelda Katz. She was accompanied by representatives of Cerest (The Workers' Health Reference Center), the Epidemiological Surveillance group, and defense counsels Agricultural Aracatuba.\n\nThe Health Secretary of Barbosa explained that Q fever is caused by the bacterium _Coxiella burnetii_, transmitted to humans by inhalation and contact with animals. 'In view of the facts, health professionals in the city were instructed to carry out the monitoring of these patients, since these Barbosa cases are among the 1st cases of an outbreak of this bacterium in Brazil,' he says.\n\nTests found that the staff, 16 in total, had been infected with the bacterium, however, Katz said that you cannot tell when there was transmission. 'The symptoms appeared in the acute phase, and the patients were treated with antimicrobials that fortunately kill this type of bacteria. Therefore, the disease will hardly [ever] develop [to be] chronic.'\n\nTo report on such care, employees and representatives of the refrigerator group participated in a meeting at City Hall in the early afternoon yesterday [15 Mar 2015]. 'They were told about the disease, the need for personal protective equipment, which is essential in control, and questions were answered on the subject to all present.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A previous ProMED post (Q fever - Brazil: (MG) 20130617.1777459) stated that the 1st description of Q fever in Brazilian territory was in 1953, identified by serology in Sao Paulo. Bahia, Rio de Janeiro, and Tocantins have diagnosed cases in the past.\n\nQ fever, often acquired by close exposure to animals, is infectious with a very low inoculum and may be aerosolized over a significant distance. _Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was discovered in 1937. This organism is an agent that can be resistant to heat and desiccation and is highly infectious by the aerosol route. A single inhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human] primates, the dose to kill 50 percent of primates was found to be 1.7 organisms (1).\n\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_. Infection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including other species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does not usually cause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals. Most importantly, during birthing, the organisms are shed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta. Contact with contaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common disinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is associated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are produced during standard replication along with the less resistant large cell form, metabolically dormant and spore-like (3).\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very few organisms may be required to cause infection.\n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other modes of transmission to humans, including tick bites and human-to-human transmission, are rare.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Owners of ruminants in the region described and shown on the map have to notify the authorities about numbers and movement of animals.\n2. Movements of susceptible animals are prohibited unless the authorities have issued permits.\n3. Owners have to present their animals for compulsory vaccination ('Coxevac'), schedule of vaccination as instructed by manufacturer; antibiotic treatment of clinically normal animals is strongly discouraged.\n4. Female animals have to be kept separate from males until at least 14 days after booster vaccination.\n5. No visitors unless by prior arrangement and they have to be informed about the potential risk.\n6. Protective clothing.\n7. Lambing pens can only be accessed wearing protective clothing and disinfectants have to be provided.\n8. Shoes/boots have to be cleaned and disinfected (with approved disinfectant).\n9. Lambing/calving only in dedicated pens, separated from other animals, indoors and at a minimum distance of 500 m from human dwellings.\n10. Ewes/cows with their offspring or ewes/calves after having aborted have to be kept confined and can be moved the earliest 14 days after parturition. Pens have to be disinfected immediately after removal of animals.\n11. Afterbirths or aborted lambs/calves have to be collected and should be stored in leak-proof containers until collection.\n12. Close contact between humans and ruminants should be avoided; in particular, animal caretakers should be extremely careful when attending animals during parturition and when activities are related to dust production.\n13. Treatment of dung/muck: disinfection, storage under plastic wrap for a minimum of 3 months, and then to be spread/ploughed only on wet and quiet (not windy) days.\n14. Excessive ('above normal') abortions should be immediately reported to the competent authorities.\n15. Sheep have to be treated against ticks every 6 months on veterinary advice.\n16. Shearing of sheep should be done only in closed buildings, distant from residential areas.\n17. The wool has to be packed and either treated (fumigated?) or destroyed.\n\nOwners have to comply with regulations and are required to cooperate.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview English Longhorns\nGut Laach\nD-52385 Nideggen\nGermany\nhttp://www.cvlonghorns.de\n<CVLonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[In a recent posting ( 20141006.2828583) we reported that, according to OIE data, no Q fever vaccination is applied in Germany. It appears that the information from Germany in WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database Interface) is incomplete (reports for the period January 2005-June 2013 visited; later reports, for terrestrial animals, not yet available). Is there no federal database, collecting information about the status of Q fever vaccination in animals throughout Germany?\n\nAs indicated at the official notification above, vaccination with the approved vaccine 'Coxevac' has become compulsory for all ruminants in the zone established in Bad-Duerkheim; a map is included at the source URL above.\n\nThe situation in the various 'laender' (states) of the German federation, in relation to Q fever vaccination, deserves to be clarified. Is there a uniform prevention (including vaccination) and control policy?\n\nDetails on the vaccine mentioned are available at http://www.ema.europa.eu/docs/en_GB/document_library/EPAR_-_Product_Information/veterinary/000155/WC500097773.pdf (thanks to Sabine Zentis for this source). The manufacturer provides instructions for its application in cattle and goats; the vaccine has not been licensed for sheep. To overcome this, the authorities in Bad-Duerkheim included, in their official notification, the following comment: 'for the vaccination of sheep, the manufacturer's instructions for the vaccination of goats should be followed'. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9631.]", "summary": "Castleview English Longhorns\nGut Laach\nD-52385 Nideggen\nGermany\nhttp://www.cvlonghorns.de\n<CVLonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[In a recent posting ( 20141006.2828583) we reported that, according to OIE data, no Q fever vaccination is applied in Germany.
