You might remember our investigative report back in July 2015 on the disease, which is passed from animals to humans and is under-reported. Landline can now reveal at least 24 people have contracted Q fever during an ongoing outbreak on a Victorian goat dairy farm. While the farm owners and health authorities seem to have stemmed the flow of people falling ill, they have not been able to stop the spread of the disease among the animals. Prue Adams reports.\n\nPRUE ADAMS, REPORTER: There's a picture-perfect quality to this farmland near Ballarat. Lambs at foot, bluestone buildings and at this time of year, golden canola. It's a region that also boasts one of the biggest dairy goat farms in the country. The only clue to an underlying problem here are the warnings on the front gate.\n\nSANDY CAMERON, GOAT FARM OWNER: The 1st thing is we've had to restrict access to the property, signs up saying 'Don't Enter'. Of course, being in the country, people are fairly used to ignoring signs, so then we - you've actually got to try and enforce that.\n\nPRUE ADAMS: Sandy Cameron is the 3rd generation on this land. In 1992, he and his wife Julie decided to branch out into milking sheep.\n\n(Landline, 1992): The Camerons' milking flock is the United Nations of sheep. The best milkers from a range of breeds and crosses make up the group.\n\n(Present) When Landline caught up with the Camerons in 1997, they were only producing sheep milk and cheese. Later that year, they got into goats. And now, in addition to milking thousands of sheep, they also milk 5000 goats twice daily. This is a big enterprise with 3 dairies and employing 100 staff. 4 years ago, some of those employees started getting sick.\n\nSANDY CAMERON: In 2011, we had a few people get Q fever, including our daughter, but we didn't know it was Q fever. Even though they went to doctors, we didn't know what was going on. It was late 2012 before 1 of the staff had it diagnosed as Q fever. In hindsight we realized it was during 2012 was the main incidence of staff being infected.\n\nSIMON FIRESTONE, UNIVERSITY OF MELBOURNE: It was sounding very significant from the start. So historically in Victoria, the Health Department receives notifications of about 30 cases of Q fever a year, and in 1 week, they'd 5 notified associated with the 1 farm property. So, yeah, that was an outbreak. That was clearly an outbreak smacking us in the face.\n\nPRUE ADAMS: In 2013, Dr Simon Firestone, a senior veterinary lecturer at Melbourne University, was among several authorities notified.\n\nSIMON FIRESTONE: It's the largest farm-associated outbreak in Australia's history. So we've had large abattoir-associated outbreaks and a large single outbreak where there were 25 cases previously at a saleyard in South Australia in 2004. But, yeah, at 24 cases, this is the largest by far of any of the single farm-associated outbreaks and then, as with all of these, there would be cases that have gone undiagnosed.\n\nPRUE ADAMS: Q fever is a zoonotic disease, spread from animals to humans. Shearers, people who work with beef cattle and other livestock, have traditionally been seen as at risk, although it's now believed all animals can be carriers. The _Coxiella burnetii_ bacterium that causes Q fever is held in the placenta, so the greatest risk is at birthing. But the organism can also sit in the soil for years and on dry dusty days become airborne. Some people who inhale it aren't even aware they've contracted Q fever. For others, like Mick Hudson, it's serious. The sheep meat producer came down with a crippling headache and chills after rounding up wild goats in Outback New South Wales.\n\nQ FEVER PATIENT #1: Went in to the doctor and he took 1 look at me, I told him that I was sweating and he just said, 'Mate, you've got goat fever. Straight up to the hospital with you.' I would've been happy to die when I had it and I was laying in hospital, like, I was that sick, I couldn't have cared if I'd died.\n\nPRUE ADAMS: Between 15 and 20 percent of sufferers have long-term complaints, including head and muscle aches and chronic tiredness.\n\nQ FEVER PATIENT #1: But certainly the - Q fever certainly affected me. Yeah, like - and those energy levels were pretty low for a long time after I come out of hospital, you know. I was back shearing, but I was hurting, yeah. Just driving meself to work, you know? Yeah.\n\nQ FEVER PATIENT #2: How long was I sick? Um, a very long time. Because after the initial disease process, I then developed the chronic fatigue Q fever syndrome.\n\nPRUE ADAMS: Renowned horsewoman Barbara Willoughby became critically ill after delivering a stillborn calf. She's never fully recovered and after featuring in the Landline story in July, has set up a Facebook page for other Q fever victims. Along with industry body Livestock SA, some sufferers are pushing for another federally funded vaccination campaign like that rolled out in 2002.\n\nQ FEVER PATIENT #2: It's a long time since the program has stopped and there's a whole generation of children, of young people now going out into the workforce that are exposed to the virus.\n\nPRUE ADAMS: While Q fever is found across the world, Australia has the only human vaccine. It's a 2-part process that involves taking a blood sample and doing a scratch test to make sure there are no antibodies present. If those results come back negative, a week later, the vaccine can be administered. Vaccinations were rolled out on the affected Victorian goat farm from 2013, costing the business around AUD 20 000 [USD 14 518] a year.\n\nSANDY CAMERON: Anyone who even comes for a job trial, we vaccinate. All external contractors, all staff obviously, partners of staff, we offer it to neighbours. We have an HR manager. I'd say about half her time for the last couple of years would've been dominated by enforcing that, which is not easy.\n\nPRUE ADAMS: Sandy Cameron says 1 of the issues in tackling Q fever is that it's only notifiable as a human health issue. The disease in infected animals is rarely addressed. So what were the 1st signs of Q fever in the goats?\n\nSANDY CAMERON: The main sign we see is abortion, late-term abortion in the goats and now that we know what it is and we recognise that we do have substantially more abortions in goats than what we used to, so around 5-10 per cent of 1st-lactation goats abort.\n\nPRUE ADAMS: And other than abortions, are there any other telltale signs of Q fever in stock?\n\nSANDY CAMERON: Well, we suspect that they're depressed at the time, which you would imagine they would be, but goats are pretty stoic animals. They either look healthy or they're very sick, so we don't really know.\n\nPRUE ADAMS: And do you know where the initial cases of Q fever in the animals came from?\n\nSANDY CAMERON: It's certainly endemic in the district. We actually tested staff in 2009, including myself and my father. We'd had old infections, my brother had an old infection. Lots of shearers, etc. in the district have been infected over the years. So it's obviously endemic in the district and I imagine we built up quite a large pool of goats that had never seen it. It got in there, whether from kangaroos - there's lots of kangaroos here - or from the sheep and that would have exploded, hitting a big population of susceptible animals.\n\nSIMON FIRESTONE: It's fairly endemic on that farm now. We've seen rates of infection, sort of 30, 40 per cent amongst goats within - after a couple of years of life. So it's not something you're gonna get rid of very quickly.\n\nPRUE ADAMS: While the infection among the goats is ongoing, there have been no new human cases in at least a year. That's been put down to the vaccination campaign and a range of other preventative measures. Potentially contaminated bedding and birthing straw is later dug into the ground and work clothes have to be left on site. An employee's spouse was thought to have contracted Q fever from washing her husband's infected clothing. The saving grace for this farm is its isolated location, at least 10 kilometres from the closest town and it's a small town at that. We only have to look across the globe at an eerily similar dairy goat outbreak to see what can happen in more densely populated areas. In the Netherlands from 2007 until 2010, Q fever got a foothold on a series of farms.\n\nWIM VAN DER HOEK, PUBLIC HEALTH INSTITUTE, NETHERLANDS: It took the Netherlands by surprise and it was also a shock, yeah. No doubt about it.\n\nPRUE ADAMS: With as many as 50 000 people getting sick, the Dutch Government ordered the destruction of tens of thousands of pregnant goats.\n\nWIM VAN DER HOEK: So it was definitely a very difficult period, of course, for those farmers. They were compensated for the animals that were culled, but of course that could not compensate the entire losses that they faced.\n\nPRUE ADAMS: Difficult question: in the Netherlands they culled a lot of the animals. Was it ever considered that these goats should be culled?\n\nSIMON FIRESTONE: Yeah, look, it's most definitely been considered and it's been proposed by some people that have been involved with the outbreak. But it would absolutely be the last resort in this case. Yeah, we've been trying to do everything we could to avoid that as an option.\n\nSANDY CAMERON: We're grateful to especially the Victorian Health Department that they haven't taken that easy option which is available to them to demand we slaughter all our goats.\n\nPRUE ADAMS: What would that do to the business?\n\nSANDY CAMERON: Obviously I'd be looking for a job, along with everyone else.\n\nPRUE ADAMS: Dutch farmers had a tool that Australian farmers don't: access to an animal vaccine produced by the French company Ceva. It meant goats there could be immunised, which eventually stopped the Q fever spread. Why not import the French-made animal vaccine?\n\nSIMON FIRESTONE: Yeah, we tried that. That was 1 of our 1st angles of attack. Unfortunately, that importation process was rejected by Canberra. We went through the appropriate channels, but they saw a biosecurity risk with that product. So that perplexed the Europeans a little bit because they've used it with no obvious issues throughout large parts of Europe.\n\nSANDY CAMERON: Frustrated in a sense, but Australia's got a big agricultural industry. I can understand if it's not safe, then it shouldn't come in. Ceva is a multinational company. They were frustrated. They said, 'This is nonsense.'\n\nPRUE ADAMS: When doctors take blood from patients to check for Q fever, most of those samples end up here at the Rickettsial Reference Laboratory in Geelong. This small unit tests at least 20 suspected cases a day. Headed up by Dr John Stenos, the laboratory is in the process of making a vaccine that can be used to inoculate the local infected goat herd.\n\nJOHN STENOS, AUST. RICKETTSIAL REFERENCE LAB.: The way the vaccine's produced is we've gone out onto the farm and got contaminated material which we've then been able to isolate the _Coxiella burnetii_ from. Now this is then amplified in these eggs and then returned to the same farm for the immunisation process or the vaccination process. Now, to broaden that just requires the regulator to agree to its use.\n\nPRUE ADAMS: Trials start in the Camerons' kids in the next few weeks, but there are substantial regulatory hurdles to jump before the vaccine will be available for widespread use on the farm, let alone further afield. And, amazingly, Sandy Cameron is funding, to the tune of around AUD 1 million [USD 725 900], the development and eventual production of the animal vaccine.\n\nSANDY CAMERON: We've travelled a bit with the business and I can't think of another country in the world where it would be left to an individual farm to develop a vaccine aimed at protecting a human population.\n\nPRUE ADAMS: So have you not had any help from, say, the Federal Government authorities in terms ... ?\n\nSANDY CAMERON: No.\n\nPRUE ADAMS: No, none at all ...\n\nSANDY CAMERON: None at all.\n\nPRUE ADAMS: ... in terms of getting that vaccine across the line?\n\nSANDY CAMERON: No.\n\nPRUE ADAMS: So they've basically said to you, 'No, you can't bring it in from Europe, but you're on your own'?\n\nSANDY CAMERON: That's right, yes.\n\nPRUE ADAMS: We've opted not to name the dairy in question out of concern for their business. They produce around 13 000 litres of sheep and goat milk a day and make yoghurt and cheese. Their milk is pasteurised and authorities insist you can't catch Q fever from pasteurised products. I've checked with the Dutch authorities too, and despite them enduring the world's worst outbreak of Q fever, no one contracted the disease from properly treated milk or cheese. Still, Sandy and Julie Cameron are understandably concerned about speaking out.\n\nSANDY CAMERON: I'm a big believer in openness. I'm a vet, and as I say, a bit of a scientist. I think the more people know about things, the better. But there's always that just little nagging thing that we borrowed a lot of money to get this business on the ground and I'd hate some sort of fear campaign based not on fact to damage our market. So, yes, there's always nervousness.\n\nPRUE ADAMS: Dr Simon Firestone is nervous too because he sees the Victorian outbreak as a warning sign.\n\nSIMON FIRESTONE: The farm at the centre of this outbreak really follows a European style of farming, so very intense animal densities, very high output and very high inputs, but - which is not typical of this sort of Australian pasture-based extensive farming system. But there is a very strong drive towards more farming ventures that follow that style of farming and some of that drive is coming from the international market in goat dairy products and we're seeing new ventures that are popping up. As the industry emerges, so do the risks and we need to keep up with that.\n\nSANDY CAMERON: The warning's there. If there is a big problem with Q fever, now no one can say they didn't know about it - partly from our experience, your recent reports on it, etc. The awareness is there, but there's no action.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was discovered in 1937. This organism is an agent that can be resistant to heat and desiccation and is highly infectious by the aerosol route. A single inhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human] primates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was found to be\n1.7 organisms (1).\n\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_. Infection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including other species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does not usually cause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are shed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta. Contact with contaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common disinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is associated with compact small-cell variants of the organism that are produced during standard replication along with the less resistant large-cell form, metabolically dormant, and spore-like (3).\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very few organisms may be required to cause infection.\n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other modes of transmission to humans, including tick bites and human-to-human transmission, are rare.\n\nReferences\n------\n1. China: ex Chile, alpaca, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2740390", "date": "2014-09-01 17:21:32", "main_text": "Q FEVER - CHINA: ex CHILE, ALPACA, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 28 Aug 2014\nSource: People's Daily Online [edited]\nhttp://english.peopledaily.com.cn/n/2014/0828/c98649-8775789.html\n\n\n13 alpacas were culled and destroyed by the Beijing Entry-Exit Inspection and Quarantine Bureau [CIQ] after being diagnosed with Elisa-type Q fever. This is the 1st time that China has ever identified Q fever from imported alpacas.\n\nAlpacas have become popular among people in China in recent years. These 13 alpacas from Chile were diagnosed with Q fever after taking blood in a routine examination during isolation.\n\nThere have been some reports about a booming business of alpaca purchased overseas. The CIQ has stressed that all imported alpacas should be isolated for 30 to 45 days and quarantined at the port-of-entry.\n\nAccording to medical information, Q fever is a disease caused by infection with _Coxiella burnetii_, a bacterium that infects humans and other animals. Zhang Shaoping, an official at CIQ, said humans as well as cattle, sheep, goats and other domestic mammals, including cats and dogs, are generally susceptible to Q fever. The infection results from inhalation of infectious aerosols, polluted dirt, and drinking contaminated milk or polluted water. Q fever has a high rate of infection among animals.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Query (Q) fever (or coxiellosis), one of OIE's listed diseases, is a zoonosis that occurs in most countries. Humans generally acquire infection through airborne transmission from animal reservoirs, especially from domestic ruminants, but other domestic and wildlife animals (pets, rabbits, birds, etc.) can be involved. It is included among OIE's list of 'New World camelids' diseases within 'Group II', namely 'Diseases for which camelids are potential pathogen carriers'.\n\nThe causal agent is the obligate intracellular bacterium, _Coxiella burnetii_, which displays different morphological forms in its developmental cycle. Some forms can survive extracellularly and even accumulate in the environment. Because this microorganism is classified as a Group 3 pathogen, handling viable _C. burnetii_ must be done in biosafety level 3 facilities.\n\nChina reported to the OIE in its annual reports (the last one covering 2013) that Q fever is one of the diseases 'for which no information has been provided.' The disease seems not to be notifiable in China (confirmation requested). According to a recent paper, 'serological investigations indicate that Q fever is present nationwide in China.' See at http://www.plosntds.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pntd.0002231.\n\nIn Chile, Q fever is a notifiable animal disease. According to the 2013 annual report to the OIE, the disease in Chile was last recorded in animals in 2007.\n\nIt would be interesting to note whether the veterinary certificate issued by China to permit the import of the alpacas from Chile included a requirement for Q fever testing prior to their export and to exclude the possibility of a later time of infection. Q fever in the alpacas could have had a subclinical course. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/155.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nIt would be interesting to note whether the veterinary certificate issued by China to permit the import of the alpacas from Chile included a requirement for Q fever testing prior to their export and to exclude the possibility of a later time of infection. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nChina reported to the OIE in its annual reports (the last one covering 2013) that Q fever is one of the diseases 'for which no information has been provided.' Zhang Shaoping, an official at CIQ, said humans as well as cattle, sheep, goats and other domestic mammals, including cats and dogs, are generally susceptible to Q fever. http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/n/2014/0828/c98649-8775789.html\n\n\n13 alpacas were culled and destroyed by the Beijing Entry-Exit Inspection and Quarantine Bureau [CIQ] after being diagnosed with Elisa-type Q fever.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Chile", "country": "Chile"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "CHILE", "country": "Chile"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2828583", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Canada: ex Germany, sheep cell therapy, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2828583", "date": "2014-10-06 12:43:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER - CANADA: ex GERMANY, SHEEP CELL THERAPY, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 18 Sep 2014\nSource: Epi-Info Wochenbericht Berlin Nr. 37 / 2014 [in German, transl., edited]\nhttp://kvberlin.de/20praxis/80service/87lageso_infos/ewb2014_37.pdf\n\n\nQ fever: infection possibly by fresh cell therapy/outbreak in Germany\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nIn the context of the international Health Regulations, Canadian health authorities informed the RKI in the past week about a case of Q fever in a female resident of Canada, who had probably acquired the infection in Germany. The woman had received intramuscular injections in May 2014 containing material from sheep fetuses and sheep placenta (so-called 'fresh cells'). The woman became ill nine days later with fever, buttock pain, increased liver enzyme values and pleural effusion. In Jul 2014 the diagnosis Q fever was confirmed. The treatment in the form of so-called fresh cell injections took place in a treatment facility in the Federal state of Rhineland-Palatinate (RP). More information on the case from Canada is still pending.\n\nBy investigations of responsible public health authorities in the aforementioned Federal state at the beginning of August 2014, a Q fever outbreak was discovered. 12 cases (5 male, 7 female, median age 49 years [range: 28-59]) from RP with a laboratory diagnosis were announced, with 10 of the 12 people ill, and 6 hospitalized. A further epidemiologically linked case from the Munich urban area was announced.\n\nAll laboratory-confirmed cases lived or worked in close proximity to sheep enterprises.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview English Longhorns\nGut Laach\nD-52385 Nideggen\nGermany\nhttp://www.cvlonghorns.de\n\n[It appears that the Canadian woman was infected from cells from sheep fetuses in the midst of an outbreak of German cases linked geographically to infected ovine farms, an unusual form of transmission.\n\n_Coxiella burnetii_, an obligate intracellular rickettsia-like bacterial pathogen, causes Q fever. _C. burnetii_ is highly resistant to drying and heat, which is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of a biphasic developmental cycle. Domestic ungulates such as sheep, cattle, and goats serve as the reservoir of infection for humans.\n\nHumans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms that are shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products of infected animals; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta. Acute symptoms of a flu-like illness with hepatitis or pneumonia usually develop within 2-3 weeks after exposure, although as many as half of humans infected with _C. burnetii_ do not show symptoms (http://www.cdc.gov/qfever/symptoms/index.html). Although most persons with acute Q fever recover, others may experience serious chronic illness within a few months or several years after acute infection, with complications that include endocarditis (especially in patients with previous cardiac valvulopathy), infected aneurysms or vascular prostheses, and chronic hepatitis.\n\nUsually, Q fever is primarily an occupational hazard for farmers, veterinarians, and abattoir workers in contact with infected domestic animals such as cattle, sheep, and goats and for laboratory personnel performing _C. burnetii_ cultures and working with _C. burnetii_-infected animals (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC88923/). Sporadic cases can also occur in people living in urban areas that are downstream from farms or abattoirs where the organisms have become aerosolized. Other modes of transmission to humans, including tick bites and ingestion of unpasteurized milk or dairy products (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr6203a1.htm). Q fever has rarely followed blood transfusion, bone marrow transplantation, and suspected sexual transmission via infected sperm (http://www.gezondheidsraad.nl/sites/default/files/201115EQfever.pdf).\n\nQ fever spreads easily in agricultural regions via airborne particles containing the _C. burnetii_ for a considerable distances to involve people living downwind from infected livestock. Widespread transmission of Q fever was recently documented in the Netherlands downwind from the index farm from a single dairy-goat farm, even beyond a 5 km [3 mile] high-risk zone (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/55/12/1591.long#T2).\n\nThe acute and chronic stages of infection correspond to 2 distinct antigenic phases of antibody response. During an acute infection, an antibody response to _C. burnetii_ phase II antigen is predominant and is higher than the response to the phase I antigen, whereas chronic infection is associated with a rising phase I immunoglobulin G (IgG) titer.\n\nCDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) has recently issued recommendations for the recognition, clinical and laboratory diagnosis, treatment, and management of Q fever (CDC. Diagnosis and Management of Q Fever -- United States, 2013: Recommendations from CDC and the Q Fever Working Group. Morb Mortal Wkly Rep (MMWR). Recommendations and Reports. 29 Mar 2013/62(RR03); 1-23. Available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr6203a1.htm).\n\nCell therapy (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cell_therapy), also called cellular therapy or cytotherapy, is therapy in which cellular material is injected into a patient; this generally means intact, living cells. For example, T cells capable of fighting cancer cells via cell-mediated immunity may be injected in the course of immunotherapy.\n\nCell therapy originated in the 19th century when scientists experimented by injecting animal material in an attempt to prevent and treat illness; such attempts produced no positive benefit. In some forms of alternative medicine, the practice of injecting animal materials in an attempt to cure disease is perpetuated. The practice, according to the American Cancer Society, is not backed by any medical evidence of effectiveness, and can have deadly consequences. - Mod.LL]\n\n[ProMED reported a similar case in a Canadian injected with sheep cells in Germany in 1997 -- see: Q fever, suspected - Canada ex Germany: RFI Archive No. 19971210.2462. - Mod.JW]\n\n[Q fever, a zoonotic bacterial disease, is endemic in Germany where it is included in the lists of notifiable human and animal diseases. The common transmission route is inhalation of infected aerosolized particles carried over distances of up to 2-5 km (1.2-3.1 mi) or by direct contact with birth products of infected ruminants (cattle, sheep, goats).\n\nReportedly, between 80 and 400 human cases per year are reported in Germany, with 40-80 percent of these related to outbreaks (clusters of human cases). The incidence of human disease is usually lower in winter, half the number of human cases found in summer (ref 1). However, a recent outbreak started during the winter, namely in January 2014, continuing to mid April 2014. This outbreak, in the community of Sulzfeld, Bavaria (south Germany) was reported and described in posting 20140511.2464862, citing a media report of 9 May 2014. A later report of 16 May 2014 indicated that 14 people had been infected in Sulzfeld since January 2014, 6 of which had to be hospitalised, 24 others suspected. As source of infection, the public health authorities mentioned a sheep and a goat (see, in German, at http://www.br.de/nachrichten/unterfranken/q-fieber-welle-sulzfeld-100.html).\n\nAccording to the 2013 annual report of Germany's RKI (Robert Koch Institut), the number of human cases officially reported during 2013 was 115, 58 percent lower than in 2012 and the lowest number since 2007. A graph showing weekly figures for the years 2008-2013 is available in fig 6.41.1 (page 168) of the report (ref 2). According to OIE's most recent available data from Germany (January-June 2013), during these 6 months, 106 Q-fever outbreaks were reported in animals, of which 102 in cattle, 3 in sheep, and 1 in a goat. The data for (entire) previous years are: 2009: 106, 2010: 121, 2011: 171, 2012: 246 outbreaks. This may be indicative of a continuous increased incidence. Information on the number of outbreaks in animals during the 2nd semester of 2013, and about their respective species, will be appreciated.\n\nThe animal population of Germany (2013 figures) is: cattle 12.7 million, sheep 1.57 million, goat 150 000. According to OIE data, no vaccination of animals against Q fever is applied in Germany.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Schack M, Sachse S, Roedel J, et al: _Coxiella burnetii_ (Q fever) as a cause of community-acquired pneumonia during the warm season in Germany. Epidemiol Infect. 2014; 142(9): 1905-10. doi: 10.1017/S0950268813002914; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24252152.\n2. By investigations of responsible public health authorities in the aforementioned Federal state at the beginning of August 2014, a Q fever outbreak was discovered.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-01-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "1905-10-25 00:00:00", "2014-05-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-05-09 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sulzfeld", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "GERMANY", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Munich", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Bavaria", "country": "Germany"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2863025", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Canada (02): ex Germany (RP) sheep cell therapy", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2863025", "date": "2014-10-14 18:22:12", "main_text": "Q FEVER - CANADA (02): ex GERMANY (RHINELAND-PALATINATE) SHEEP CELL THERAPY\n*************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 8 Oct 2014\nSource: Die Rheinpfalz [in German, trans. submitter SZ, edited]\nhttp://www.rheinpfalz.de/lokal/artikel/q-fieber-aus-der-pfalz-nach-kanada/\n\n\nThere is a high probability that the outbreak of ovine Q fever last August 2014 in Lachen-Speyerdorf, district of Neustadt [Rhineland-Palatinate state], has led to a case of infection in Canada. The Canadian health authorities are convinced that a woman from Canada became infected when having fresh cell therapy in the Vorderpfalz region. No similar case has ever been scientifically proven so this might well add new fuel to the long lasting, bitter discussion about fresh cell therapy.\n\nIn September 2014, Canadian health authorities notified the RKI (Robert-Koch-Institut) of a case of Q fever in Canada. They assume that the patient became infected by an injection of sheep fetal cells and sheep placenta (so called 'fresh-cells') and could not find other ways of infection. The treatment took place in May 2014 in the Suedliche Weinstrasse district [Rhineland-Palatinate]. After her return to Canada nine days later, the woman fell sick and had fever. In July 2014, after extensive laboratory tests, the Canadians confirmed Q fever infection, which must have been acquired in Germany.\n\nThe RKI confirmed the information from Canada. According to an RKI spokesperson 'the method of infection is conceivable.' The RKI is under the jurisdiction of the Federal Ministry of Health and is, among other things, responsible for handling human disease outbreaks.\n\nQ-fever is a disease of livestock which can be transmitted to humans by various routes.\n\nIn July 2014, when the diagnosis in Canada was made, no one in Germany was aware that there was an outbreak of Q fever in Lachen-Speyerdorf. During August 2014, some human cases of severe pneumonia were detected and later the competent health authorities found 3 flocks of sheep in the district infected with Q fever.\n\nAccording to the health authorities one of these sheep farms provides the animals for fresh cell therapies. Obviously, the controls which are the responsibility of the fresh cell therapist and which are in place to prevent the transmission of dangerous diseases, had failed. 'Testing of random samples from the flocks in question during April, May, and June [2014] gave no indication of Q fever infection,' the spokesperson for the district administration said.\n\nFresh cell therapy is a highly controversial treatment in alternative medicine. Patients are injected with cells, usually derived from fetal lambs or calves. The advocates of fresh cell therapy promise a cure for all kinds of chronic diseases, cancer, and conditions of old age.\n\nOrthodox medical practitioners are highly critical saying that there is no proof of their effectiveness but a high risk of allergic reactions as well as transmission of diseases. According to experts the administration of fresh cells in Germany is in decline. According to the competent authorities there are only 2 providers of fresh cell therapy in Rhineland-Palatinate -- a specialized clinic and a practitioner in the region of Suedliche Weinstrasse.\n\nIn the late 1990s the then Minister of Health Seehofer tried to implement legislation to ban the production and sale of fresh cells in Germany. His legislation fell through when put before the Federal Constitutional Court because of a technicality, as the cells are prepared by clinics and injected straight after production and are not 'put into circulation' so the Federal authorities had no responsibility.\n\nSince then the authorities seem to have a problem with fresh cells: In a statement the RKI said the controls are the responsibility of the local authorities. Dieter Starke, spokesperson for the LSjV (Rhineland-Palatinate Health authorities) and responsible for surveillance of drugs/medicines, said that a list of criteria for the safety of fresh cell products is being worked on. The common goal is to raise the safety standards to the levels of medical products.\n\nThe LSjV ordered the suspension of the production of fresh cells in Lachen-Speyerdorf. One of the therapists affected is the medical doctor Robert Janson-Mueller who has his practice in Edenkoben. He says there is the 'theoretical possibility that the patient from Canada acquired the infection in his practice but it is not proven.' Incidentally, an additional case of human Q fever infection was notified in Munich which, according to experts, is connected to the outbreak in Lachen-Speyerdorf. According to reports, a medical doctor who produces fresh cells became infected with Q fever.\n\n[Byline: Arno Becker]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview English Longhorns\nGut Laach\nD-52385 Nideggen\nGermany\nhttp://www.cvlonghorns.de\n\n[ProMED thanks Sabine Zentis for submitting and translating this report.\n\nThe Canadian case appears to be the 'bellwether' to the discovery of _Coxiella burnetii_ in a flock of sheep used for the 'therapy' and the report of Q fever in a doctor preparing the cells. The circumstantial evidence for this route of infection seems quite strong.\n\nThe following is a warning regarding this non-traditional therapy from the American Cancer Society (http://www.cancer.org/treatment/treatmentsandsideeffects/complementaryandalternativemedicine/pharmacologicalandbiologicaltreatment/cell-therapy):\n\n'Cell therapy\nOther common name(s): cellular therapy, fresh cell therapy, live cell therapy, glandular therapy, xenotransplant therapy\n\nDescription: in cell therapy, processed tissue from the organs, embryos, or fetuses of animals such as sheep or cows is injected into patients. Cell therapy is promoted as an alternative form of cancer treatment.\n\nOverview: available scientific evidence does not support claims that cell therapy is effective in treating cancer or any other disease. Serious side effects can result from cell therapy. It may in fact be lethal -- several deaths have been reported. It is important to distinguish between this alternative method involving animal cells and mainstream cancer treatments that use human cells, such as bone marrow transplantation.\n\nHow is it promoted for use? In cell therapy, live or freeze-dried cells or pieces of cells from the healthy organs, fetuses, or embryos of animals such as sheep or cows are injected into patients. This is supposed to repair cellular damage and heal sick or failing organs. Cell therapy is promoted as an alternative therapy for cancer, arthritis, heart disease, Down syndrome, and Parkinson disease.\n\nCell therapy is also marketed to counter the effects of aging, reverse degenerative diseases, improve general health, increase vitality and stamina, and enhance sexual function. Some practitioners have proposed using cell therapy to treat AIDS patients.\n\nThe theory behind cell therapy is that the healthy animal cells injected into the body can find their way to weak or damaged organs of the same type and stimulate the body's own healing process. The choice of the type of cells to use depends on which organ is having the problem. For instance, a patient with a diseased liver may receive injections of animal liver cells. Most cell therapists today use cells taken from taken from the tissue of animal embryos.\n\nSupporters assert that after the cells are injected into the body, they are transported directly to where they are most needed. They claim that embryonic and fetal animal tissue contains therapeutic agents that can repair damage and stimulate the immune system, thereby helping cells in the body heal.\n\nThe alternative treatment cell therapy is very different from some forms of proven therapy that use live human cells. Bone marrow transplants infuse blood stem cells -- from the patient or a carefully matched donor -- after the patient's own bone marrow cells have been destroyed. Studies have shown that bone marrow transplants are effective in helping to treat several types of cancer. In another accepted procedure, damaged knee cartilage can be repaired by taking cartilage cells from the patient's knee, carefully growing them in the laboratory, and then injecting them back into the joint. Approaches involving transplants of other types of human stem cells are being studied as a possible way to replace damaged nerve or heart muscle cells, but these approaches are still experimental.\n\nWhat does it involve? First, healthy live cells are harvested from the organs of juvenile or adult live animals, animal embryos, or animal fetuses. These cells may be taken from the brain, pituitary gland, thyroid gland, thymus gland, liver, kidney, pancreas, spleen, heart, ovaries, testicles, or even from whole embryos. Patients might receive one or several types of animal cells. Some cell therapists inject fresh cells into their patients. Others freeze them first, which kills the cells, and they may filter out some of the cell components. Frozen cell extracts have a longer 'shelf life' and can be screened for disease. Fresh cells cannot be screened. A course of cell therapy to address a specific disease might require several injections over a short period of time, whereas cell therapy designed to treat the effects of aging and 'increase vitality' may involve injections received over many months.\n\nAnimal cell extracts are also sold in pill form as dietary supplements, usually called glandular supplements. These, too, allegedly travel to organs of the same kind in the body to promote healing.\n\nWhat is the history behind it? The Swiss physician Paul Niehans, MD, invented cell therapy in 1931. During a medical emergency, Dr Niehans injected a solution containing ground-up parathyroid cells from a calf into a patient who had damaged parathyroid glands. The patient recovered, and Dr Niehans attributed the improvement to the injection. He went on to apply the idea of animal-human cellular transfer to other diseases.\n\nDr Niehans claimed that he treated more than 30 000 patients with cell therapy. He also claimed that the death rate from cancer among his patients who received cell therapy was 5 times less than that of the average population. He believed that injections of cells from animals resistant to cancer would increase cancer resistance in humans. A 2nd physician announced similar findings 30 years later. Neither claim has ever been supported by research studies published in medical journals.\n\nCell therapy may be harmful and is not legally available in the United States. Because of safety concerns and lack of proof of its effectiveness, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has banned the import of cell therapy products into the country. The treatment is provided in clinics and spas in Europe, Mexico, and the Bahamas.\n\nWhat is the evidence? None of the therapeutic success claimed by cell therapists has been documented through scientific testing and published in peer-reviewed medical journals. Claims of the therapy's success take the form of individual cases, testimonials, and publicity issued by practitioners of the therapy. Even supporters of cell therapy admit they do not know how cell therapy works in the body. No reliable evidence has been published in medical journals to support the claims of cell therapy.\n\nAre there any possible problems or complications? These substances may have not been thoroughly tested to find out how they interact with medicines, foods, or dietary supplements. Even though some reports of interactions and harmful effects may be published, full studies of interactions and effects are not often available. Because of these limitations, any information on ill effects and interactions below should be considered incomplete.\n\nCell therapy may be dangerous, and several patient deaths linked to the therapy have been reported in the medical literature. Patients can contract bacterial and viral infections carried by the animal cells, and some have had life-threatening and even fatal allergic reactions. Other reports list complications such as brain swelling or the immune system attacking blood vessels or nerves following cellular treatment. Serious immune system reactions resulting in death have also been reported. Women who are pregnant or breast-feeding should not use this method, as its possible effects on a fetus are unknown.' - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/41934.]", "summary": "Other common name(s): cellular therapy, fresh cell therapy, live cell therapy, glandular therapy, xenotransplant therapy\n\nDescription: in cell therapy, processed tissue from the organs, embryos, or fetuses of animals such as sheep or cows is injected into patients. \n\nThe alternative treatment cell therapy is very different from some forms of proven therapy that use live human cells. \n\nThe following is a warning regarding this non-traditional therapy from the American Cancer Society (http://www.cancer.org/treatment/treatmentsandsideeffects/complementaryandalternativemedicine/pharmacologicalandbiologicaltreatment/cell-therapy):\n\n'Cell therapy\n \n\nThe theory behind cell therapy is that the healthy animal cells injected into the body can find their way to weak or damaged organs of the same type and stimulate the body's own healing process. In Australia most vet students are vaccinated prior to commencing their studies, and abbatoir workers are strongly encouraged to become vaccinated.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs have also been unrecognised intermediate hosts, spreading Q fever to veterinary staff assisting at surgical procedures. I don't know if there is a vaccine available in the USA. If not, it would seem to me to be an opportunity missed to protect those most at risk from an infection that can cause considerable morbidity and has significant occupational health and safety implications.\n\n--\nDr Rob Boughton\nPrince Alfred Hospital\nCamperdown, New South Wales\nAustralia\n<rhboughton@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Rob Boughton for his comments.\n\nAlthough protection for at-risk workers can be provided by Q fever vaccination, no licensed vaccine is available in the United States; a vaccine for use in animals has also been developed, but is not available in the United States (http://www.cdc.gov/qfever/prevention/index.html).\n\nAn Australian company makes a Q fever vaccine (Q-VAX) composed of formalin-inactivated suspension of _Coxiella burnetii_ organisms, which had been grown in the yolk sacs of embryonated eggs (http://www.csl.com.au/docs/39/836/Q-Vax_PI_V4_TGA-Approved-17%20January%202014.pdf). In Australia, Q fever vaccination is recommended for those working in 'at-risk' occupations such as abattoir workers, farmers, stockyard workers, shearers, animal transporters, and others exposed to cattle, camels, sheep, goats and kangaroos or their products (including products of conception), veterinarians, veterinary nurses, veterinary students, professional dog and cat breeders, agricultural college staff and students, wildlife and zoo workers (working with high-risk animals) and laboratory personnel handling veterinary specimens or working with the organism; workers at pig abattoirs do not require Q fever vaccination (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/handbook10-4-15).\n\nIf the person has a positive history of previous infection with Q fever, vaccination is contraindicated; in others, serum antibody determination and skin tests must be done before vaccination to exclude those likely to have severe local or systemic hypersensitivity reactions to the vaccine resulting from previous unrecognized exposure to the organism (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/handbook10-4-15). Q fever vaccine is not routinely recommended for children aged less than 15 years of age and pregnant or breastfeeding women because safety of the vaccine in these situations has not been established. Revaccination is not indicated due to the possibility of severe hypersensitivity reactions. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "In Australia, Q fever vaccination is recommended for those working in 'at-risk' occupations such as abattoir workers, farmers, stockyard workers, shearers, animal transporters, and others exposed to cattle, camels, sheep, goats and kangaroos or their products (including products of conception), veterinarians, veterinary nurses, veterinary students, professional dog and cat breeders, agricultural college staff and students, wildlife and zoo workers (working with high-risk animals) and laboratory personnel handling veterinary specimens or working with the organism; workers at pig abattoirs do not require Q fever vaccination (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/handbook10-4-15). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nIf the person has a positive history of previous infection with Q fever, vaccination is contraindicated; in others, serum antibody determination and skin tests must be done before vaccination to exclude those likely to have severe local or systemic hypersensitivity reactions to the vaccine resulting from previous unrecognized exposure to the organism (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/handbook10-4-15). Although protection for at-risk workers can be provided by Q fever vaccination, no licensed vaccine is available in the United States; a vaccine for use in animals has also been developed, but is not available in the United States (http://www.cdc.gov/qfever/prevention/index.html). The best protection against Q fever infection is vaccination of those at risk (abbatoir workers, vets, agricultural workers). Dr Rob Boughton\nPrince Alfred Hospital\nCamperdown, New South Wales\n Q fever vaccine is not routinely recommended for children aged less than 15 years of age and pregnant or breastfeeding women because safety of the vaccine in these situations has not been established.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "vaccination", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3684869", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - USA, Canada: ex Germany (RP) sheep cell therapy, 2014", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3684869", "date": "2015-10-02 17:26:21", "main_text": "Q FEVER - USA, CANADA: ex GERMANY (RHINELAND-PALATINATE) SHEEP CELL THERAPY, 2014\n*********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 2 Oct 2015\nSource: CDC. Morb Mortal Week Rep (MMWR) 64(38);1071-1073 [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6438a3.htm?s_cid=mm6438a3_w\n\n\nQ fever outbreak among travelers to Germany who received live cell therapy -- United States and Canada, 2014\n------------------------------------------------------------------\nDuring September-November 2014, the New York State Department of Health (NYSDOH) [USA] was notified of 5 New York state residents who had tested seropositive for _Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent of Q fever. All 5 patients had symptoms compatible with Q fever (such as fever, fatigue, chills, and headache) and a history of travel to Germany to receive a medical treatment called 'live cell therapy' (sometimes called 'fresh cell therapy') in May 2014. Live cell therapy is the practice of injecting processed cells from organs or fetuses of nonhuman animals (for example, sheep) into human recipients (1). It is advertised to treat a variety of health conditions. This practice is unavailable in the USA, however, people can travel to foreign locations to receive injections.\n\nLocal health departments interviewed the patients, and NYSDOH notified the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and posted a report on CDC's Epidemic Information Exchange to solicit additional cases. Clinical and exposure information for each patient was reported to the Robert Koch Institute in Germany, which forwarded the information to local health authorities. A Canada resident who also received live cell therapy in May 2014 was diagnosed with Q fever in July 2014. Clinicians should be aware of health risks, such as Q fever and other zoonotic diseases, among patients with a history of receiving treatment with live cell therapy products.\n\nThe 5 New York patients had traveled in a group of 10-15 people to the state of Rhineland-Palatinate in Germany to receive intramuscular injections of fetal sheep cells from a German physician on 30 May 2014. A Canada resident, who received intramuscular injections of fetal sheep cells from the same German physician on 28 May 2014, sought medical care in June 2014 for fever, pain, and erythema at the site of the injection. She received a diagnosis of Q fever in July 2014, and public health authorities were notified. Under International Health Regulations, the Public Health Agency of Canada notified German authorities in September 2014. At the time of notification, the ministry of health of the federal state of Rhineland-Palatinate was investigating an outbreak of human Q fever associated with inhalation exposure to a sheep flock that was used for production of fetal sheep cell injections by the German physician.\n\nIn September 2014, the German physician notified patients treated during January-July 2014 of their potential Q fever exposure. This prompted Q fever testing of the 5 patients in New York, 3 of whom had already sought medical care for symptoms. The other 2 patients had experienced symptoms but had not sought medical care until notification of their potential Q fever exposure. The test results, with positive Q fever titers, were reported to NYSDOH and prompted investigation by local health departments. No additional USA or Canada residents with positive Q fever titers and history of intramuscular injections of fetal sheep cells in Germany have been identified. The identities and nationalities of the other people in the travel group are unknown to USA and Canadian public health authorities. It is not known whether the other people did not get tested for Q fever, tested negative, or did not report an exposure to fetal sheep cell injections.\n\nAn outbreak-associated case of Q fever was defined as an illness consisting of clinical signs and symptoms compatible with Q fever, and a single IgG titer equal to or greater than 1:128 to _C. burnetii_ phase II antigen by immunofluorescence assay in a person who received live cell therapy in Germany during May 2014 (2). Among the 6 identified cases, the median patient age was 62 years (range = 59-83 years). 4 of the 6 patients were female. None of the patients reported other potential exposures to Q fever, with the exception of 1 patient who reported contact with sheep horn or bone. 3 patients reported preexisting medical conditions: one patient with atrial fibrillation and kidney stones, one patient with Parkinson disease and osteoarthritis, and one patient with multiple sclerosis.\n\nSigns and symptoms of Q fever began within about 1 week of receipt of the intramuscular injections of fetal sheep cells. The majority of symptoms were reported as lasting 10-90 days; however, 9-10 months after exposure, 3 patients continued to report symptoms of fatigue, chills, sweats, and difficulty sleeping (Table 1 [for table, see source URL - Mod.LL]). One patient had initially reported no symptoms during an interview with the local health department after his positive titers were reported in November 2014; however, in February 2015, he informed his physician that symptoms had been occurring since the injections in May 2014.\n\nThe patients were tested for Q fever phase I and phase II antibodies at 2-6 months after exposure, using indirect immunofluorescence assay. _C. burnetii_ undergoes antigenic phase variation, between a virulent phase I form and an avirulent phase II form. During acute infection, phase II antibodies appear 1st and are higher than phase I antibodies. All patients' phase I IgG titers were elevated (1:512-1:2048), but were lower than phase II IgG titers (1:4096-1:65 536), suggesting acute disease. Phase I IgM titers were elevated in 4 patients (1:128-1:8192) and phase II IgM titers were elevated in all patients (1:64-1:32 768). All patients were treated with doxycycline after receiving a diagnosis of Q fever.\n\nAll 6 patients were initially interviewed by their local health departments; only 2 of the 5 New York patients agreed to a follow-up interview by NYSDOH. The 2 patients reported that a group had traveled to Germany for injections twice each year for the past 5 years. They chose to receive injections of fetal sheep cells to improve their general health and vitality, and had not previously experienced signs or symptoms of illness after injections. They reported that they were not informed of a risk for Q fever infection before injection.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nThe treatment known as live cell therapy was developed in Switzerland during the 1930s by Paul Niehans. Practitioners have used organs, glands, and fetuses of multiple species, including sheep, cows, and sharks (1). No published clinical evidence supporting therapeutic claims of the treatment known as live cell therapy is available. It is advertised as having anti-aging effects and as a treatment for multiple conditions and diseases (for example, erectile dysfunction, depression, and joint, neurologic, heart, kidney, lung, endocrine, and liver disease). Serious adverse events have been reported, including anaphylaxis, vasculitis, encephalitis, polyradiculitis, clostridial infections, paresis, and death (3-5).\n\nThe treatment known as live cell therapy is a type of xenotransplantation when it involves administration of live cells from a nonhuman animal source into a human recipient (6). Xenotransplantation carries a public health risk for transmission of known and unknown infectious agents from the donor organism to the human recipient and possible recombination or reassortment to form new pathogens (6). There is a theoretic potential for dissemination of disease from the original recipient to others. For this reason, discussions on safety requirements for xenotransplantation by international and domestic public health agencies continue to occur (7).\n\nRegulation of xenotransplantation varies among countries. In the USA, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) regulates xenotransplantation products as Biologic Drugs under section 351 of the Public Health Service Act and the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. FDA approval of a Biologics License Application (BLA) is required to introduce, or deliver for introduction, a biologic product into interstate commerce. FDA has not approved a BLA for a xenotransplantation product known as live cell therapy. If a xenotransplantation product is proposed for use in a clinical investigation in the USA, an Investigational New Drug Application would be required. In Canada, xenotransplantation cell therapy products are regulated as drugs under the Food and Drugs Act and the Food and Drug Regulations. Authorities in Canada have not authorized for sale any xenotransplantation products, nor have any clinical trials that involve xenotransplantation been authorized. In Germany, xenotransplantation products are regulated under the Medicinal Products Act; however, an attempt to ban fresh cell therapy in 1997 was later determined to be null and void because the federal law does not cover drugs manufactured by doctors only for use in their own patients (8). According to an assessment supported by WHO and its partners, during January 1994-September 2009, xenotransplantation procedures were identified in 12 different countries, of which 9 had no clear national regulations on xenotransplantation (9).\n\nThis outbreak highlights one of the public health issues associated with xenotourism, the travel outside a country of residence for the purpose of participating in xenotransplantation programs. FDA recommends that xenotransplantation product recipients enrolled in research studies remain under lifelong surveillance with periodic clinical and laboratory monitoring and that both they and their intimate contacts refrain from blood and tissue donation (6). However, other than self-reporting, no method to identify returned xenotourists is available. Clinicians should be aware of xenotourism and consider the potential for zoonotic disease in a patient with a history of xenotransplantation.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Transplantation 2010;90:597-603.\n\n[authors: Robyn MP, Newman AP, Arnato M, et al]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Canadian case appeared to be the 'bellwether' to the discovery of _Coxiella burnetii_ in a flock of sheep used for the 'therapy' and the report of Q fever in a doctor preparing the cells. The circumstantial evidence for this route of infection seems quite strong.\n\nThe following is a warning regarding this non-traditional therapy from the American Cancer Society (http://www.cancer.org/treatment/treatmentsandsideeffects/complementaryandalternativemedicine/pharmacologicalandbiologicaltreatment/cell-therapy):\n\n'Cell therapy\nOther common name(s): cellular therapy, fresh cell therapy, live cell therapy, glandular therapy, xenotransplant therapy\n\n'Description: in cell therapy, processed tissue from the organs, embryos, or fetuses of animals such as sheep or cows is injected into patients. Cell therapy is promoted as an alternative form of cancer treatment.\n\n'Overview: available scientific evidence does not support claims that cell therapy is effective in treating cancer or any other disease. Serious side effects can result from cell therapy. It may in fact be lethal -- several deaths have been reported. It is important to distinguish between this alternative method involving animal cells and mainstream cancer treatments that use human cells, such as bone marrow transplantation.\n\n'How is it promoted for use? In cell therapy, live or freeze-dried cells or pieces of cells from the healthy organs, fetuses, or embryos of animals such as sheep or cows are injected into patients. This is supposed to repair cellular damage and heal sick or failing organs. Cell therapy is promoted as an alternative therapy for cancer, arthritis, heart disease, Down syndrome, and Parkinson disease.\n\n'Cell therapy is also marketed to counter the effects of aging, reverse degenerative diseases, improve general health, increase vitality and stamina, and enhance sexual function. Some practitioners have proposed using cell therapy to treat AIDS patients.\n\n'The theory behind cell therapy is that the healthy animal cells injected into the body can find their way to weak or damaged organs of the same type and stimulate the body's own healing process. The choice of the type of cells to use depends on which organ is having the problem. For instance, a patient with a diseased liver may receive injections of animal liver cells. Most cell therapists today use cells taken from taken from the tissue of animal embryos.\n\n'Supporters assert that after the cells are injected into the body, they are transported directly to where they are most needed. They claim that embryonic and fetal animal tissue contains therapeutic agents that can repair damage and stimulate the immune system, thereby helping cells in the body heal.\n\n'The alternative treatment cell therapy is very different from some forms of proven therapy that use live human cells. Bone marrow transplants infuse blood stem cells -- from the patient or a carefully matched donor -- after the patient's own bone marrow cells have been destroyed. Studies have shown that bone marrow transplants are effective in helping to treat several types of cancer. In another accepted procedure, damaged knee cartilage can be repaired by taking cartilage cells from the patient's knee, carefully growing them in the laboratory, and then injecting them back into the joint. Approaches involving transplants of other types of human stem cells are being studied as a possible way to replace damaged nerve or heart muscle cells, but these approaches are still experimental.\n\n'What does it involve? First, healthy live cells are harvested from the organs of juvenile or adult live animals, animal embryos, or animal fetuses. These cells may be taken from the brain, pituitary gland, thyroid gland, thymus gland, liver, kidney, pancreas, spleen, heart, ovaries, testicles, or even from whole embryos. Patients might receive one or several types of animal cells. Some cell therapists inject fresh cells into their patients. Others freeze them first, which kills the cells, and they may filter out some of the cell components. Frozen cell extracts have a longer 'shelf life' and can be screened for disease. Fresh cells cannot be screened. A course of cell therapy to address a specific disease might require several injections over a short period of time, whereas cell therapy designed to treat the effects of aging and 'increase vitality' may involve injections received over many months.\n\n'Animal cell extracts are also sold in pill form as dietary supplements, usually called glandular supplements. These, too, allegedly travel to organs of the same kind in the body to promote healing.\n\n'What is the history behind it? The Swiss physician Paul Niehans, MD, invented cell therapy in 1931. During a medical emergency, Dr Niehans injected a solution containing ground-up parathyroid cells from a calf into a patient who had damaged parathyroid glands. The patient recovered, and Dr Niehans attributed the improvement to the injection. He went on to apply the idea of animal-human cellular transfer to other diseases.\n\n'Dr Niehans claimed that he treated more than 30 000 patients with cell therapy. He also claimed that the death rate from cancer among his patients who received cell therapy was 5 times less than that of the average population. He believed that injections of cells from animals resistant to cancer would increase cancer resistance in humans. A 2nd physician announced similar findings 30 years later. Neither claim has ever been supported by research studies published in medical journals.\n\n'Cell therapy may be harmful and is not legally available in the United States. Because of safety concerns and lack of proof of its effectiveness, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has banned the import of cell therapy products into the country. The treatment is provided in clinics and spas in Europe, Mexico, and the Bahamas.\n\n'What is the evidence? None of the therapeutic success claimed by cell therapists has been documented through scientific testing and published in peer-reviewed medical journals. Claims of the therapy's success take the form of individual cases, testimonials, and publicity issued by practitioners of the therapy. Even supporters of cell therapy admit they do not know how cell therapy works in the body. No reliable evidence has been published in medical journals to support the claims of cell therapy.\n\n'Are there any possible problems or complications? These substances may have not been thoroughly tested to find out how they interact with medicines, foods, or dietary supplements. Even though some reports of interactions and harmful effects may be published, full studies of interactions and effects are not often available. Because of these limitations, any information on ill effects and interactions below should be considered incomplete.\n\n'Cell therapy may be dangerous, and several patient deaths linked to the therapy have been reported in the medical literature. Patients can contract bacterial and viral infections carried by the animal cells, and some have had life-threatening and even fatal allergic reactions. Other reports list complications such as brain swelling or the immune system attacking blood vessels or nerves following cellular treatment. Serious immune system reactions resulting in death have also been reported. Women who are pregnant or breast-feeding should not use this method, as its possible effects on a fetus are unknown.' - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9631.]", "summary": "Other common name(s): cellular therapy, fresh cell therapy, live cell therapy, glandular therapy, xenotransplant therapy\n\n'Description: in cell therapy, processed tissue from the organs, embryos, or fetuses of animals such as sheep or cows is injected into patients. Domestic ungulates such as sheep, cattle, and goats serve as the reservoir of infection for humans.\n\nHumans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms that are shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta. Acute symptoms of a flu-like illness with hepatitis or pneumonia usually develop within 2-3 weeks after exposure, although as many as half of humans infected with _C. burnetii_ do not show symptoms (http://www.cdc.gov/qfever/symptoms/index.html). Although most persons with acute Q fever recover, others may experience serious chronic illness within a few months or several years after acute infection, with complications that include endocarditis (especially in patients with previous cardiac valvulopathy), infected aneurysms or vascular prostheses, and chronic hepatitis.\n\nQ fever is primarily an occupational hazard for farmers, veterinarians, and abattoir workers in contact with infected domestic animals such as cattle, sheep, and goats and for laboratory personnel performing _C. burnetii_ cultures and working with _C. burnetii_-infected animals (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC88923/). Sporadic cases can also occur in people living in urban areas that are downstream from farms or abattoirs where the organisms have become aerosolized.\n\nThe acute and chronic stages of infection correspond to 2 distinct antigenic phases of antibody response. During an acute infection, an antibody response to _C. burnetii_ phase II antigen is predominant and is higher than the response to the phase I antigen, whereas chronic infection is associated with a rising phase I immunoglobulin G (IgG) titer.\n\nThe CDC has recently issued recommendations for the recognition, clinical and laboratory diagnosis, treatment, and management of Q fever (Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report (MMWR). This organism is an agent that can be resistant to heat and desiccation, and is highly infectious by the aerosol route. A single inhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human] primates, the dose to kill 50 per cent of the primates was found to be 1.7 organisms (1).\n\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_. Infection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including other species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does not usually cause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are shed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta. Contact with contaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common disinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is associated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are produced during standard replication along with the less resistant large cell form, metabolically dormant, and spore-like (3).\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very few organisms may be required to cause infection.\n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other modes of transmission to humans, including tick bites and human-to-human transmission, are rare.\n\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C. An institutional outbreak of pneumonitis. III. Sabine Zentis, edited]\nhttp://www.br.de/nachrichten/unterfranken/q-fieber-welle-sulzfeld-100.html\n\n\nIn Sulzfeld (Rhoen-Grabfeld district), since January [2014], 12 people have been confirmed with Q-fever. According to the competent health authority, 25 more people are suspected to be suffering from Q-fever. Most cases are located in the centre of Sulzfeld.\n\nHorst Rusche, head of the health department of the district of Rhoen-Grabfeld, told the 'Bayerischer Rundfunk' that some of those affected are suffering from lung infections or pneumonia. Six patients had to be hospitalized. According to Rusche, the pathogen is believed to have been transmitted from sheep through dust in the air. In 5 sheep, the pathogen was confirmed. These sheep were disinfected [comment] and are now housed in a stable. The last case was registered on 28 Apr 2014. 'Additional cases can not be ruled out,' said Rusche.\n\nAccording to the health department, the incubation in humans is usually 2 to 3 weeks. Those affected mostly suffer from fever, chills, muscle pain and severe headache. Rusche warned that Q fever infection of pregnant women in the 1st 3 months of pregnancy may lead, in many cases, to loss of the child. For people with heart valve disease, or a heart valve prosthesis, there is a risk that the Q fever infection will become chronic.\n\nPeople can be infected by dust-borne Q fever pathogens from infected herds over a distance of up to 2 km. Direct transmission of Q-fever from person to person is, according to Rusche, a rare event.\n\nThe health department invites the people in Sulzfeld to an information meeting planned for 15 May 2014. The citizens will be offered a blood test.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview English Longhorns\nGut Laach\nD-52385 Nideggen\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[The report said that the 5 sheep in which the pathogen was confirmed 'were disinfected and are now housed in a stable.' However, no disinfection of live sheep is feasible.\n\nAccording to compiled data on Q fever in Germany (see 20110225.0620), numerous incidents in humans and animals have been recorded throughout the years, including 2 of significance during the previous decade:\n- 2003 - an outbreak (299 human cases) was associated with a contaminated ewe in a farmer's market in Soest (North Rhine-Westphalia).\n- 2005 - an outbreak (331 human cases, 188 laboratory-confirmed) in Jenna was related to proximity to sheep.\n\nSubscribers may be reminded of the major epidemic of Q fever in Germany's neighbour, the Netherlands, between 2007 and 2010. More than 4000 notified human cases were recorded during the event, which had a seasonal pattern synchronic with the kidding and lambing seasons of goats and sheep, respectively. From its start, experts identified dairy goat farms with Q-fever-induced abortion waves as the primary source. By the end of 2012, Dutch authorities declared the Q-fever outbreak over, after about 50 000 pregnant goats had been culled and the remaining dairy goats had been given mandatory vaccination.\n\nA useful summary and analysis of the Dutch event is available in a recent paper (Ref. below; thanks to Sabine Zentis for drawing our attention to the paper). The authors conclude:\n\n'Our findings deliver evidence that, apart from Q-fever positive farms, land-applied contaminated manure may be a significant source of human Q-fever:\n1. The temporal sequence of events, where lambing is followed by field application of manure, and manure application is followed by illness onset in human cases, is compatible with, and suggestive of, a contributing role of manure, given the average incubation period of human Q-fever;\n2. A higher percentage of human cases were temporo-spatially linked with contaminated land parcels than with Q-fever positive farms (QFPFs);\n3. Incidence of human Q-fever cases was significantly higher around contaminated land parcels than non-contaminated land parcels.\n4. Incidence of human Q-fever cases around contaminated land parcels decreased with distance, suggesting an exposure-response relationship, while incidence around non-contaminated land parcels did not;\n5. A higher percentage of human cases were temporo-spatially linked with QFPFs with land than QFPFs without land.'\n\nIt will be interesting to note whether conditions in Bavaria, including land application of manure from sheep or goat farms, are comparable to the ones observed in the Netherlands.\n\nReference:\nHermans T, Jeurissen L, Hackert V, Hoebe C (2014) Land-Applied Goat Manure as a Source of Human Q-Fever in the Netherlands, 2006-2010.
