The following\nbackground data are abstracted from the Gideon e-book series (1,2).\nPrimary references are available on request.\n\nTime and place\n--------------\n- Q fever was first characterized in Australia, in 1939.\n- Queensland and New South Wales account for over 90 percent of\ncases.\n- Over 50 percent of cases are directly, or indirectly related to\nmeat processing.\n- The male/female ratio for reported cases is approximately 5-to-1.\n\nDisease rates have gradually increased over the past 6 decades (see\ngraph at\nhttp://www.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Qfever-Australia.jpg).\n\nTravel and Q fever\n------------------\n2002 (publication year): 3 Japanese workers acquired Q fever while in\nAustralia and New Zealand.\n2005: an American tourist acquired Q fever in Australia.\n\nSeroprevalence surveys\n----------------------\n- 18.5 percent of non-vaccinated meat workers in central Queensland\n(2001 publication)\n- 6.5 percent of persons below age 25 years in South West Queensland\n(2010 publication)\n- 66 percent of persons in Kimberly have evidence for prior exposure\n(2002)\n- 7 percent of persons in the Hunter New England region of New South\nWales (2006 to 2009)\n\nThe average rate among abattoir workers in Victoria is 6600 per 100\n000 during the 1st 10 years of exposure.\n- As of 1996, vaccination programs were identified in one-third of\nabattoirs.\n- Routine immunization of abattoir workers in endemic areas was\nintroduced in 2002.\n- As of 2009, vaccine update is 100 percent among abattoir workers\nand 43 percent among farmers.\n\nThe standard vaccine is prepared from inactivated phase I whole\n_Coxiella burnetii_. A dose of 0.5 ml subcutaneous (deltoid region) is\nindicated for high-risk populations (such as, occupational exposure),\nand confers immunity for 5 years. Few side effects are reported, and\nare limited to fever and headache.\n\nA variety of local mammals serve as reservoirs, including the\nbandicoot (_Isoodon torosus_).\n_Amblyomma triguttatum_ ticks are implicated in the epidemiology of Q\nfever in Queensland.\n\nNotable outbreaks\n-----------------\n1959 (publication year): an outbreak of Q fever in Queensland was\nassociated with sheep contact.\n1962 (publication year): an outbreak was reported in a meat-works in\nSouth Australia.\n1969: an outbreak in a Brisbane meat works affected 7.9 percent of\nworkers.\n1979: an outbreak (110 cases) was reported at an abattoir in\nVictoria.\n1998: an outbreak (29 confirmed and 8 suspect cases) was reported at\nan abattoir in New South Wales.\n2004: an outbreak (9 confirmed and 6 suspect cases) was reported\namong farmers in South Australia.\n2005: an outbreak (5 cases) was reported among persons involved in\ncalving activities, in New South Wales.\n2006 (publication year): an outbreak (4 cases) was reported among\nworkers at a cosmetics factory.\n2006 (publication year): an outbreak (27 cases) was reported in rural\nSouth Australia.\n2007: an outbreak (5 cases confirmed, 1 possible fatal case) was\nassociated with an abattoir in South Australia.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Berger SA: Infectious Diseases of Australia, 2011. 503 pp., 158\ngraphs. Gideon e-book series,\nhttp://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-australia/\n2. Berger SA: Q-fever: Global Status, 2011. 73 pp, 57 graphs. Gideon\ne-book series,\nhttp://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/q-fever-global-status/\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProf Steve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\nIsrael\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Berger for continuing to share the GIDEON\ndatabase. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "----------------------\n- 18.5 percent of non-vaccinated meat workers in central Queensland\n(2001 publication)\n- 6.5 percent of persons below age 25 years in South West Queensland\n(2010 publication)\n- 66 percent of persons in Kimberly have evidence for prior exposure\n(2002)\n- 7 percent of persons in the Hunter New England region of New South\nWales (2006 to 2009) Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA (02): BACKGROUND\n************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Gideon\ne-book series,\nhttp://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/q-fever-global-status/\n\n--\n Tel Aviv Medical Center\nIsrael\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Berger for continuing to share the GIDEON\ndatabase. - Mod. -----------------\n1959 (publication year): an outbreak of Q fever in Queensland was\nassociated with sheep contact. ------------------\n2002 (publication year): 3 Japanese workers acquired Q fever while in\nAustralia and New Zealand. \n- As of 2009, vaccine update is 100 percent among abattoir workers\nand 43 percent among farmers. 60:1393 [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6040a5.htm?s_cid=mm6040a5_e&source=govdelivery\n\nOn 22 Apr 2011, the Q fever bacterium _Coxiella burnetii_ was detected\nin a goat placenta collected from a farm in Washington, where 14 of 50\n(28 percent) pregnant does had aborted since January 2011. A county\nhealth alert advised health-care providers to ask patients with\nsymptoms compatible with Q fever (e.g., fever, headache, chills, and\nmyalgia) about exposure to goats, and the owners of the farm informed\npurchasers of their goats that _C. burnetii_ had been detected in\ntheir herd. On 25 May 2011, the county health department reported a\nsymptomatic patient with antibodies to _C. burnetii_ who had purchased\ngoats from the farm in February 2011. On 27 May 2011, a report from\nMontana identified a child seropositive for _C. burnetii_ whose family\nhad purchased goats from the Washington farm in October 2010; one of\nthe goats aborted triplets 2 weeks before the child's 12 May 2011,\nillness onset. On 31 May 2011, 5 more persons reported onset of\nsymptoms compatible with Q fever from late March to mid-May 2011,\nfollowing exposure at a Montana farm to goats purchased from the\nWashington farm at various times during October 2010-January 2011. On\n10 June 2011, the Washington State Department of Health and Montana\nDepartment of Public Health and Human Services requested CDC\nassistance to characterize the extent of the outbreak, distribute Q\nfever information, and identify others at risk for infection.\n\nGoats sold after June 2010 by the Washington farm where _C. burnetii_\ninitially was detected were traced to 21 farms in Washington (10\ncounties), Montana (3 counties), and Oregon (1 county). 17 farms\nparticipated in the outbreak investigation. _C. burneti_i infection\nwas detected in 16 of 17 goat herds, including polymerase chain\nreaction confirmation of bacterial shedding in feces, vaginal mucous,\nor milk in 161 of 667 (24 percent) goats tested and an overall\nseroprevalence of 21 percent (131 of 615) by enzyme-linked\nimmunosorbent assay. To date, 19 percent (20 of 108; 11 in Washington\nand 9 in Montana) of serologically tested persons met the outbreak\ncase definition of a person epidemiologically linked to at least 1\nfarm of interest (i.e., as a goat owner, farm visitor, or neighbor)\nsince January 2011 with a _C. burnetii_ phase II immunoglobulin G\ntiter =1:128 by immunofluorescence assay (1). No deaths were reported;\n4 of the 20 persons were hospitalized, and 5 were asymptomatic.\n\nBoth states implemented a herd management plan to promote continued\ncommunication between public health and agricultural authorities and\nto advise goat owners to disinfect birthing areas, avoid contact with\nbirth products, limit visitor access to animal holding areas, maintain\nan animal registry, and report animal abortions and positive Q fever\ntest results to state authorities. All homes within a 1-mile radius of\nthe Washington farm where _C. burnetii_ was initially detected and a\nMontana farm that also had high goat seroprevalence linked to human\nillness were visited once by CDC or by county public health officials\nand CDC in July or August 2011 to provide Q fever health education and\noffer human serologic testing. The states have received no additional\nreports of Q fever since July 2011.\n\nQ fever (a category B bioterrorism agent) is a nationally notifiable\ndisease in humans and is endemic throughout the USA with a national\nseroprevalence of 3 percent (2). Washington and Montana typically\nreport about 3 cases of Q fever annually. Acute Q fever is\ncharacterized by a self-limited febrile illness or, less often, by\npneumonia or hepatitis. Less common still is chronic Q fever, which\naffects less than 5 percent of infected persons and presents as\nendocarditis in patients with preexisting valvular disease. Pregnant\nwomen, immunosuppressed persons, and patients with a preexisting\nheart-valve defect are at greatest risk for chronic Q fever.\nDoxycycline is recommended for treatment of acute Q fever. _C.\nburnetii_ is highly infectious, persists in the environment, and can\ntravel for miles once windborne (3). Transmission can occur via\ninhalation of contaminated aerosols or dust; human-to-human\ntransmission is rare. Cattle, sheep, and goats are the primary Q fever\nreservoirs. Continued community awareness is essential for disease\nprevention and control. Additional information is available at\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/qfever.\n\nReferences\n--------\n1. Bamberg WM, Pape WJ, Beebe JL, et al: Outbreak of Q fever\nassociated with a horse-boarding ranch, Colorado, 2005. Vector Borne\nZoonotic Dis 2007;7: 394-402.\n2. Anderson AD, Kruszon-Moran D, Loftis AD, et al: Seroprevalence of Q\nfever in the United States, 2003-2004. Am J Trop Med Hyg 2009;81:\n691-694.\n3. Hawker JI, Ayres JG, Blair I, et al: A large outbreak of Q fever in\nthe West Midlands: windborne spread into a metropolitan area? Commun\nDis Public Health 1998;1: 180-187.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak was 1st reported in ProMED in June 2011. (Q fever -\nUSA: raw cow's milk, ex goat 20110624.1938). The clinical\nmanifesttions of the infection in man in these cases is not stated.\nIn humans, the acute symptoms caused by infection with _Coxiella\nburnetii_ http://www.cdc.gov/qfever/symptoms/index.html usually\ndevelop within 2-3 weeks of exposure, although as many as half of\nhumans infected with _C. burnetii_ do not show symptoms.\n\nThe following is a list of symptoms commonly seen with acute Q fever.\nHowever, it is important to note that the combination of symptoms\nvaries greatly from person to person:\n-high fevers (up to 104-105 degrees F)\n-severe headache\n-general malaise\n-myalgia\n-chills and/or sweats\n-non-productive cough\n-nausea\n-vomiting\n-diarrhea\n-abdominal pain\n-chest pain\n\nAlthough most persons with acute Q fever infection recover, others may\nexperience serious illness with complications that may include\npneumonia, granulomatous hepatitis (inflammation of the liver),\nmyocarditis (inflammation of the heart tissue) and central nervous\nsystem complications. Pregnant women who are infected may be at risk\nfor pre-term delivery or miscarriage. The estimated case fatality rate\n(i.e. the proportion of persons who die as a result of their\ninfection) is low, at less than 2 percent of hospitalized patients.\nTreatment with the correct antibiotic may shorten the course of\nillness for acute Q fever. - Mod. LL]\n\n[The causative bacterium is fairly ubiquitous. Most animals, including\nhumans are susceptible to the effects of the bacterium. Cattle, sheep\nand goats can harbor the bacterium. Caretakers of the animals are most\noften exposed during the birthing process. People are exposed to the\nbacterium via dust particles.\n\n_Coxiella burnetii_ is increasingly recognized as an important cause\nof caprine abortion, especially in the western USA. Occasional\noutbreaks also occur in sheep. Late-term abortions, stillbirths, and\nweak lambs are the common presentations. Up to 50 percent of the flock\nmay be involved. The placenta is covered by gray-brown exudate and the\nintercotyledonary areas are thickened. Microscopically, there is a\nnecrotizing vasculitis in the placenta, and many chorionic epithelial\ncells are distended by small, coccobacillary organisms less than 1 mm\nin diameter. Infection involves only the placenta; without it, the\ndiagnosis usually cannot be made. Diagnosis is by identification of\n_C.burnetii_ by immunologic staining methods or by isolation. Coxiella\nis zoonotic, causing Q fever in humans.\n\nPeople most at risk may be veterinarians, producers, milkers and those\nin the slaughter facilities as the bacteria may be aerosolized at\nvarious times in the course of each individual's work. Animals may be\ninfected, but with mild signs that may be missed by the caretakers --\nor there may not be any clinical signs.\n\nRespiratory protection for these individuals as well as strict code of\nhygiene is important in preventing the disease.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from:\nhttp://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110306.htm&word=q%2cfever\n- Mod.TG]\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for the state of Washington is\navailable at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1kJo. The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map\nfor the state of Montana is available at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1kJm - CopyEd.EJP]", "summary": "All homes within a 1-mile radius of\nthe Washington farm where _C. burnetii_ was initially detected and a\nMontana farm that also had high goat seroprevalence linked to human\nillness were visited once by CDC or by county public health officials\nand CDC in July or August 2011 to provide Q fever health education and\noffer human serologic testing. A county\nhealth alert advised health-care providers to ask patients with\nsymptoms compatible with Q fever (e.g., fever, headache, chills, and\nmyalgia) about exposure to goats, and the owners of the farm informed\npurchasers of their goats that _C. burnetii_ had been detected in\ntheir herd. \n\nBoth states implemented a herd management plan to promote continued\ncommunication between public health and agricultural authorities and\nto advise goat owners to disinfect birthing areas, avoid contact with\nbirth products, limit visitor access to animal holding areas, maintain\nan animal registry, and report animal abortions and positive Q fever\ntest results to state authorities. Less common still is chronic Q fever, which\naffects less than 5 percent of infected persons and presents as\nendocarditis in patients with preexisting valvular disease. Pregnant\nwomen, immunosuppressed persons, and patients with a preexisting\nheart-valve defect are at greatest risk for chronic Q fever. Acute Q fever is\ncharacterized by a self-limited febrile illness or, less often, by\npneumonia or hepatitis. \n\nPeople most at risk may be veterinarians, producers, milkers and those\nin the slaughter facilities as the bacteria may be aerosolized at\nvarious times in the course of each individual's work. goats tested and an overall\nseroprevalence of 21 percent (131 of 615) by enzyme-linked\nimmunosorbent assay. TG]\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for the state of Washington is\navailable at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1kJo. _C.\nburnetii_ is highly infectious, persists in the environment, and can\ntravel for miles once windborne (3). \n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from:\nhttp://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110306.htm&word=q%2cfever\n- Mod.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-07-25 00:00:00", "2011-06-25 00:00:00", "2011-08-25 00:00:00", "2011-06-10 00:00:00", "2021-07-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-05-12 00:00:00", "2010-06-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2011-05-31 00:00:00", "2011-05-25 00:00:00", "2011-01-25 00:00:00", "2010-10-25 00:00:00", "2011-05-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WASHINGTON", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Kruszon", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "866442", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - USA (02): (AK) seals", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=866442", "date": "2011-09-11 22:41:58", "main_text": "Q FEVER - USA (02): (ALASKA) SEALS\n***********************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 9 Sep 2011\nSource: Alaska Dispatch [edited]\nhttp://www.alaskadispatch.com/article/q-fever-source-detected-alaskas-fur-seals\n\n\nA discovery last year [2010] that northern fur seals on St. Paul\nIsland were carrying _Coxiella burnetti_, a bacteria that can cause\nillness, has motivated scientists to do more sleuthing. Can the\nbacteria cause seals and other marine mammals to get sick? Were\nvillagers ever exposed to it, and if so, did they become ill?\n\nThe infection, known as Q Fever, can cause a varying mix of flu-like\nsymptoms, including a high fever, according to the Centers for Disease\nControl.\n\nAlaska has documented only one case of the bacteria making an Alaskan\nsick, and that person picked it up overseas, according a bulletin\nissued 7 Sep [2011] by the Alaska Department of Epidemiology in\nresponse to findings by Colorado State University researchers. But\nthat doesn't mean there haven't been other cases, since Alaska didn't\nbegin to collect data on human _Coxiella_ infections until 2007.\n\n_Coxiella burnetti_ is more generally known to occur in land animals\nand birds. In Alaska, caribou, muskoxen, mountain goats, Dall sheep,\nwolves, and grizzly bears have been tested for the bacteria, with\ncaribou discovered as the largest carrier. Although the bacteria are\npresent among this wildlife, there is no evidence the bacteria has\nmade any of the wildlife sick, according to the bulletin. The CSU\nstudy, combined with recent occurrences of human illness in places\nlike the state of Washington, Greenland and the Netherlands, has the\nscience community taking a new look at the disease.\n\nThere is a long list of known facts about Q Fever. It's been around a\nlong time. It's found just about everywhere, including places you\nmight expect, like near animals, and those that might surprise you,\nlike schools, retail stores and banks. It's hard to kill. It travels\neasily on dust particles and is found in animal placentas, milk and\nfeces, and because it could feasibly be used in an aerosol to spray\nover a wide area, it's considered a potential bioterrorism agent, one\nthat won't kill people but which could debilitate large numbers of\nthem by making them sick.\n\nLouis Castrodale, an epidemiologist with the state of Alaska who\nhelped author the Q Fever bulletin, describes the bacteria as a\n'ubiquitous organism' that's found not just in animals but also in\noceans, sediments, and other places in the environment. Of interest is\nthat while it is present in a wide variety of places, the numbers of\npeople who get sick from it aren't huge, she said.\n\nData from the CDC illustrates how unusual the illness is in people in\nthe United States. The CDC has never received more than 200 reports of\nit in a given year. Yet common flu can strike between 5 to 20 percent\nof the U.S. population each year, anywhere from 15 to 62 million\npeople.\n\nHistorically, people have not routinely looked for _Coxiella burnetti_\nin marine mammals, which makes the current findings difficult to place\ninto context. Has the bacteria always been around in marine mammal\npopulations but just hasn't been noticed? Or, is it just starting to\naffect species that had previously been unexposed or unaffected? And,\ndoes it have the potential to make sea life or the humans that come\ninto contact with it sick? The answers aren't known.\n\nTo learn more, CSU has returned to the Pribilof Islands to study the\nbacteria's effect on fur seals in more depth. Scientists also want to\nfind out whether _Coxiella_ is present in Stellar sea lions, ice\nseals, walrus and other animals and birds from the area.\n\nPrevious blood samples collected from villagers of St. Paul and St.\nGeorge Islands in the 1980s and 1990s will also be tested for\n_Coxiella burnetti_ antibodies.\n\nUltimately, scientists want to know how widespread _Coxiella_ is among\nAlaska's marine life, how long it's been around, whether it's made\npeople sick in the past, and how to prevent it in the future.\n\n[Byline: Jill Burke <jill@alaskadispatch.com>]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a fascinating observation. The article does not raise the\nquestion of how important is it in the seal population or what it\nmeans for human health. There\nare unconfirmed reports of up to 6 cases presenting at the Coffs\nHarbour Health Campus during the past 6 weeks.\n\nQ Fever is a disease contracted by infection from bacteria found\ntypically in the urine, feces, or milk from cattle and sheep. The\ndirector of public health for the North Coast, Paul Corben, said there\nwas a vaccine available for those working with animals, like vets and\nabattoir workers, but it was a 2-step process which involved a skin\ntest and blood sample before the doctor made a decision, because if\nthe person showed evidence of prior immunity, the vaccine caused 'a\nnasty local reaction.'\n\nMr Corbin said while they had seen a couple of probable or confirmed\ncases of Q fever from south of Coffs Harbour to as far north as\nWoolgoolga, there was nothing that warranted extra follow-up or\nindicated a higher risk than normal. He said the North Coast averaged\nabout 40 confirmed cases of Q fever annually.\n\nA reader who contacted The Advocate said one man from Emerald Beach\nhad died and she had almost lost a friend this week [week of 28 Mar\n2011], who was now in the intensive care unit. She believed the cases\nwere focused on the northern beaches. 'It is not where you would\nnormally find Q fever,' Mr Corben said. 'But it is a hardy bacterium\nand very persistent in the environment. We have done normal follow-up\nand there is nothing that links those people together. We are still\nwaiting for some lab reports. You traditionally think of Q fever as\nassociated with farm areas but there have been recent outbreaks in\nother areas.\n\nMr Corben said Q fever was particularly likely to be associated with\nanimal birthing times.\n\n[Byline: Belinda Scott]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Coffs Coast area of New South Wales can be seen on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0DPp. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[Q fever was first described in Australia where this posting\noriginates. It was called 'Query fever' because the causative agent\nwas initially unknown. _Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was\ndiscovered in 1937. This organism is an agent that can be resistant to\nheat and desiccation and highly infectious by the aerosol route. A\nsingle inhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in\n[non-human] primates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was\nfound to be 1.7 organisms (1).\n\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including\nother species of livestock and domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does\nnot usually cause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion\nin goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection.\nOrganisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals.\nMost importantly, during birthing the organisms are shed in high\nnumbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta. Contact with\ncontaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small-cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication (along with the less resistant\nlarge-cell form) and are metabolically dormant and spore-like (3).\n\nThe Q fever organism is a category B bioterrorism agent and, in fact,\nalthough not thought to be related to bioterrorism, was spread by mail\nin a post office in the UK in 1987 (4).\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. Instances of other modes of transmission to humans,\nincluding tick bites and human to human transmission, are rare.\n\nAn earlier outbreak of infection in 51 persons in Scotland, UK, was\ntied to a meat processing plant and appeared to spread via aerosol for\nat least 0.5 mi (0.8 km).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C: An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of 'Q fever.' Pub Hlth Rep 1041; 56:\n1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D: Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12: 518-53.\n(available at http://cmr.asm.org/cgi/content/full/12/4/518).\n3. Norlander L: Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes\nInfect 2000; 2:417-24 (abstract available at\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10817644).\n4. Winner SJ, Eglin RP, Moore VI, Mayon-White RT: An outbreak of Q\nfever affecting postal workers in Oxfordshire. J Infect 1987; 14(3):\n255-61 (abstract available at\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3585037). - Mod.LL]", "summary": "The\ndirector of public health for the North Coast, Paul Corben, said there\nwas a vaccine available for those working with animals, like vets and\nabattoir workers, but it was a 2-step process which involved a skin\ntest and blood sample before the doctor made a decision, because if\nthe person showed evidence of prior immunity, the vaccine caused 'a\nnasty local reaction.' Because the disease was concentrated in the\nNoord-Brabant area, it was regarded as a regional problem. And at\nregional level there were deficiencies in duty assignments for\nthorough measures to be undertaken.\n\nThese are some of the conclusions of the investigation ordered by the\nProvincial Council for Public Health in Noord-Brabant. The report was\npresented today [29 Sep 2010].\n\nThe outbreak, which started in 2006 in the village of Herpen, turned\ninto an epidemic of more than 2000 human cases in 2009, regarded the\nlargest ever anywhere in the world. At least 12 people died. In 2009,\npanic and social anxiety eventually got to levels causing a clear need\nfor measures to be taken. However, says the researcher Mirte Post, at\nthis stage the Mexican flu [H1N1] scare drew all the government's\nattention and Q-fever remained in the background.\n\nAlso, the collaboration between the 2 ministries (Agriculture and\nPublic Health) could have been better. Killing the goats would\nprobably not have been necessary if the measures had been applied more\nadequately. The advice about animal vaccination and the purchase of\nvaccine were delayed too long, according to Post.\n\nThe provincial Council for Public Health emphasises that Brabant\n[Province] was not prepared for a Q-fever outbreak and supports the\nrecommendation for special care for patients with long-term fatigue\ncomplaints. Post recommends province and government to make a decision\nregarding compensation to the patients.\n\nThe evaluation report on lessons to be learnt, ordered by the 2\nministries (agriculture and public-health) from the investigation\ncommittee headed by the agroeconomist Prof Van Dijk (Commission van\nDijk), is due to be presented on 22 Nov 2010.\n\n[Byline: Mariska Vermaas]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nChristine Bijl\nSecretary, European Livestock Association (ELA)\n<christinebijl@gmail.com>\n\n[The conclusions and recommendations of the Dutch Q fever Evaluation\nCommittee, nominated by the 2 ministers and chaired by Prof. van Dijk,\nwere initially expected earlier this year (2010), final date extended\ntwice. To date, a total of around 40 people have been\ninfected, of which about half live in Arnsberg (HSK) and in the\ndistrict Waldeck-Frankenberg.\n\nThe results of previous studies indicate that the infection\noriginates from sheep flocks, where the causative agent of Q fever was\nconfirmed. The pathogen has been confirmed in several flocks of sheep\nfrom both 'Lander' (Hesse and North Rhine-Westphalia) and is\ntransmitted to humans via direct contact or contaminated dust.\n\nImmediately after the Arnsberg and the Waldeck-Frankenberg\nauthorities detected an increase of Q-fever infection in humans, the\ncompetent national authorities became involved. The municipalities and\nthe districts of North Rhine-Westphalia and Hesse, Hochsauerland and\nWaldeck-Frankenberg are working closely together. The veterinary\nauthorities have put restrictions upon the flocks of sheep shown to be\ninfected, have notified the owners and have imposed further protective\nmeasures. The sheep will be vaccinated to reduce the shedding of the\npathogen. This requires that the vaccine, which is not currently\nlicensed in Germany, is temporarily approved by the competent local\nauthorities.\n\nQ fever occurs worldwide and is a common bacterial infection mainly\ntransmitted by sheep, goats and cattle. Transmission takes place by\ninfectious dust or direct contact with the animals. Human-to-human\ntransmission is very unlikely.\n\nThe disease results in flu-like symptoms. An acute infection usually\nbegins with high fever, chills, muscle pain and severe frontal\nheadache. High risks have been established for pregnant women. Acute Q\nfever can be treated with a specified antibiotic. Suspicion of a\npossibility of Q fever infection should be notified to the family\ndoctor.\n\nA health hazard outside Hallenberg and the other affected areas in\nHesse, where the disease was detected in sheep, is not to be\nexpected.\n\nFurther information can be accessed from\n<http://www.hochsauerlandkreis.de>, and, in addition, the\nHochsauerlandkreis has activated a telephone hotline (0291/94-2200).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nGut Laach\n52385 Nideggen, Germany\n<CVLonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[An administrative map of Germany is available at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germany#Administrative_divisions>.\n\nAccording to OIE's WAHID data, Germany reported 121 outbreaks of Q\nfever in animals during 2010, all in cattle. Information from Germany\non human cases is available in the said source up to 2007; in 2006,\n204 human cases were reported. A report form for this purpose can\nbe downloaded at the RIVM web-site.\n\n2. In the 2 farms which\nhave been found positive during the current (July 2010) month, no\nanimals have been killed because none of the animals were pregnant\n[due to the breeding ban applied since Dec 2009]. Since the application of bulk milk testing is\ncontinuing , contaminated farms are expected to be found but they are\nnot to be culled. Since all farms have been vaccinated, the discovery\nof a positive farm will not be followed by warning letters being sent\nto neighbouring households. As of 2 Feb 2011, there were 8 more confirmed cases so\nfar in 2011.\n\nSince 2007, there have been more than 4000 cases and several deaths,\nincluding 11 deaths in 2010.\n\nThough the cases have been seen throughout the country, the US\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) notes that most of\nthese cases have been in Noord (North) Brabant, Gelderland, Limburg,\nand Utrecht Provinces in the southern part of the country. The CDC\noffers the following prevention recommendations for US travelers to\nthe Netherlands:\n- Avoid farms in the affected areas.\n- If you cannot avoid visiting farms, avoid going near areas where\nanimals are kept, such as barns and pens, and avoid direct contact\nwith animals.\n- Breathing in soil and dust contaminated by animals can make you\nsick.\n- Eat only milk and dairy products that have been pasteurized. Do not\ndrink raw milk or eat raw milk products.\n- Wash your hands often with soap and water, especially if you have\nbeen near animals. If soap and water are not available, use an\nalcohol-based hand gel with at least 60 percent alcohol.\n- Pay attention to your health after your trip. People can become\nsick with Q fever 2-5 weeks after being exposed to the disease. If you\nfeel sick, go to the doctor and tell him or her that you have traveled\nto The Netherlands.\n\nQ fever is caused by the obligate intracellular pathogen, _Coxiella\nburnetii_. The disease is usually transmitted to people through either\ninfected milk or through aerosols. This disease is found on most\ncontinents with the reported incidence probably much lower than the\nactual because so many cases are so mild. Animal reservoirs of _C.\nburnetii_ include sheep, cattle, goats, dogs and cats. In areas where\nthese animals are present, Q fever affects veterinarians, meatpacking\nworkers and farmers. Q fever is also considered a potential agent of\nbioterrorism.\n\nThe symptoms of Q fever according to the CDC are an unexplained\nfebrile illness, sometimes accompanied by pneumonia and/or hepatitis,\nthe most common clinical presentation. Illness onset typically occurs\nwithin 2-5 weeks after exposure. The mortality rate for acute Q fever\nis low (1-2 percent), and the majority of persons with mild illness\nrecover spontaneously within a few weeks, although antibiotic\ntreatment will shorten the duration of illness and lessen the risk of\ncomplications. Chronic Q fever is uncommon (less than one percent of\nacutely infected patients) but may cause life-threatening heart valve\ndisease (endocarditis).\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 6 Feb 2011\nSource: IMED 2011, Vienna, Austria, 4-7 Feb 2011. Session 17 'Q Fever\nin the Netherlands,' abstract 17.001 [edited]\n\n\nQ fever in the Netherlands: The animal health aspects. By Christianne\nBruschke, CVO, Ministry of Economic Affairs, Agriculture and\nInnovation, The Hague, Netherlands\n\nUp to 2007, some 20 people became infected yearly with Q fever, a\nzoonotic disease. Suddenly in 2007, 170 people fell ill, and in 2008\nthere were 1000 cases. In 2009, there were more than 2300 known cases\nof people becoming infected. Experts believed that there was a\nrelationship between Q fever abortions on milking goat and milking\nsheep farms and the sharp increase in the numbers of human\ninfections.\n\nIn the Netherlands, several measures were taken between June 2008 and\nDecember 2009 to control Q-fever in animals. Measures were directed in\nparticular at the dairy goat and sheep sector, but measures were also\ntaken for small ruminants that come into close contact with the\ngeneral public. Q fever in sheep and goats was made notifiable in June\n2008. Hygiene measures, transport restrictions and restrictions for\nvisitors were implemented. Vaccination with a non-licensed vaccine was\nperformed in a restricted area in 2008 (voluntary) and 2009\n(compulsory).\n\nIn October 2009, monitoring based on bulk milk PCR was started to\ndetect infected farms. Knowing that the vaccine was not fully\nefficacious in infected or pregnant animals, and having the\npossibility to detect infected farms at the end of 2009, the\nresponsible ministers took the following decisions:\n1. cull all pregnant animals on infected farms\n2. a nationwide breeding ban for dairy sheep and goats\n3. a compulsory vaccination program for the whole country in 2010.\n\nWith these very drastic measures, further contamination of the\nenvironment during the lambing season would be prevented. Breeding\nwould be only allowed thereafter with animals coming from non-infected\nvaccinated farms.\n\nIn 2010, the number of human patients with Q-fever was 382. As of\nnow, the focus of the measures is to prevent another outbreak, with\nyearly vaccination of the dairy goat and sheep population.\n\n[Byline: C. Bruschke]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Sun 6 Feb 2011\nSource: IMED 2011, Vienna, Austria, 4-7 Feb 2011. Session 17 'Q Fever\nin the Netherlands,' abstract 17.002 [edited]\n\n\nQ fever in the Netherlands: The public health aspects. By J. Van\nSteenbergen, W. V. D. Hoek, D. Notermans, C. Wijkmans & T. Oomen.\n\nBackground: From 2007 through 2009, The Netherlands faced a series of\nmultiple Q fever outbreaks in the southern part of the country. Q\nfever was specifically seen in the vicinity of dairy goat farms where\nabortion waves due to _Coxiella burnetii_ occurred.\n\nMethods and Materials: Seroprevalence of antibodies against _Coxiella\nburnetii_ was tested in 2006 in a random sample of the population\n(ELISA phase I and II). Hospital discharge data were used in\nretrospect to find previously undetected clusters in time and space.\nIncidence of acute Q fever was calculated using notification data.\nSmoothing incidence lines were calculated using 6 digit area codes. A\ncase control study was performed in 2007. A sample of blood donors\noriginating from the areas with highest incidence was tested twice in\n2009 with IFA. A sample of sera from the pregnancy screening (e.g.\nHBsAg, lues) was tested for antibodies against _Coxiella burnetii_.\n\nResults: In 2006, the seroprevalence of antibodies against _Coxiella\nburnetii_ in The Netherlands was low (less than 2.7 percent). Before\n2007, small clusters of lower respiratory tract infections went\nundetected. Incidence of Q fever increased from 192 in 2007, to 1000\nin 2008 and over 2300 in 2009. Risk for acute Q fever was increased\nfor males in age group 45-55 yrs and living in proximity of infected\ngoat farms, not living near infected sheep farms. In areas where blood\ndonor infection rate could be ascertained, only an estimated 12\npercent of infections are leading to microbiologically confirmed\ndisease. Preliminary data show no serious adverse events of infection\nduring pregnancy on pregnancy outcome.\n\nConclusion: The total number of reported acute Q fever cases\napproaches 4000. Living near infected dairy goat farms was the major\nrisk factor. The number of chronic infections with serious\ncomplications remains unknown.\n\n[Byline: J. Van Steenbergen, W. V. D. Hoek, D. Notermans, C. Wijkmans\n& T. Oomen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4]\nDate: Sun 6 Feb 2011\nSource: IMED 2011, Vienna, Austria, 4 - 7 Feb 2011. Session 17 'Q\nFever in the Netherlands,' abstract 17.003 [edited]\n\n\nQ fever in the Netherlands: _Coxiella burnetii_, laboratory aspects.\nBy: H.-J. Roest, Central Veterinary Institute of Wageningen, Lelystad,\nNetherlands\n\nBackground: _Coxiella burnetii_ is a Gram-negative intracellular\nbacterium, which belongs to the family of the Coxiellaceae and the\norder of the Legionellales. Two phases of the bacterium can be\ndistinguished: phase I, associated with full length lipopolysaccharide\n(LPS) and phase II, associated with truncated LPS. In the life cycle\nof _C. burnetii_, 2 stages can be distinguished. The Large Cell\nVariant (LCV), which is able to multiply, and the Small Cell Variant\n(SCV), the spore-like form in which _C. burnetii_ is resistant to\noutside influences.\n\nMethods and Materials: Genotyping was performed by MLVA [Multiple\nLoci Variable Number of Tandem Repeats Analysis].\n\nResults: The link between dairy goats as the source of human Q fever\ncases in the Netherlands has been made on the basis of epidemiological\nevidence. Genotyping of _C. burnetii_ is a tool to further investigate\nthe connection between source and host. Using MLVA, the connection\nbetween sheep and humans in a small Q fever outbreak in the\nNetherlands could be made. MLVA was also used to type a considerable\nnumber of goat samples from goats that were considered to be the\nsource of the Q fever outbreak in the Netherlands. Results show that\none MLVA type is predominantly present on all dairy goat farms in the\nepidemic area in the south of the Netherlands.\n\n_C. burnetii_ contaminated goat manure is considered to be a major\nfactor in the transmission to humans. Little is known about the\ntemperature build-up in goat manure piles and the influence of the\ncomposting process on _C. burnetii_. In a joint effort of national\nresearch institutes, temperatures and numbers of _C. burnetii_ in goat\nmanure and the decimal reduction time of _C. burnetii_ under these\nconditions were assessed. Results of this study [have been\npresented].\n\nConclusion: Results on genotyping show that one MLVA type is\npredominantly present on all dairy goat farms in the epidemic area in\nthe south of the Netherlands. This MLVA type should also be found in\ninfected humans. Research on this in ongoing. Conclusions on the\nresults of the survival of _C. burnetii_ [have been] given during the\npresentation.\n\n[Byline: H.J. Roest]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The IMED 2011 International Meeting on Emerging Diseases and\nSurveillance, held in Vienna, Austria, 4-7 Feb 2011, was organized by\nthe International Society for Infectious Diseases. It was co-sponsored\nby ProMED-mail, EcoHealth Alliance, European Centre for Disease\nPrevention and Control (ECDC), European Commission (EC), European\nSociety of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious Diseases (ESCMID),\nHealthMap, Wildlife Conservation Society (WCS) and the World\nOrganisation for Animal Health (OIE).\n\nThough the exceptionally high number of human infections in the\naffected Dutch districts during 2008-2009, was mainly attributed to\nthe development of dairy-goat mega-farms during recent years, the\npossibility that this epizootic was caused by a strain of the\nbacterium with particular characteristics deserves attention. Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (28): UPDATE\n**********************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-09-25 00:00:00"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "766961", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - USA: raw cow's milk, ex goat", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=766961", "date": "2011-06-24 13:20:03", "main_text": "Q FEVER - USA: RAW COW'S MILK, ex GOAT\n***************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n\n[1] Michigan: unpasteurized milk\n[2] Washington, Montana: caprine exposure\n\n******\n[1] Michigan: unpasteurized milk\nDate: Fri 24 Jun 2011\nSource: Detroit (MI) Free Press [edited]\nhttp://www.freep.com/article/20110624/NEWS06/110624008/3-Michigan-women-ill-after-consuming-raw-milk\n\n\nHealth officials say 3 Michigan women who reported consuming raw milk\nhave been diagnosed with a rare bacterial infection called Q fever.\n\nThe Michigan Department of Community Health says that the raw milk\nwas from a Livingston County farm, where people own shares of cows in\nexchange for unpasteurized milk products. The department says 2 Q\nfever cases were in Washtenaw County and one was in Monroe County.\n\nPeople can become ill with the bacteria if they inhale barnyard dust\nparticles contaminated by infected animals or consume raw milk. They\nsuffer flu like symptoms, including high fever, headaches, malaise,\nabdominal pain, chills, vomiting, and diarrhea. Left untreated,\nserious cases of Q fever can lead to chronic illness that may affect a\nperson's heart, liver, brain, and lungs and may be fatal.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A detailed discussion on the transmission of _Coxiella burnetii_ is\nposted below.\n\nAfter an incubation period of several weeks, the infection (which can\nbe asymptomatic) generally presented with fever, a dry cough, and\njoint pains. Not uncommonly, the patient, diagnosed as having\npneumonia, is also found to have notable abnormalities in liver\nfunction. It is that combination that should make the astute clinician\nconcerned about the diagnosis especially in the setting of exposure to\nlivestock or living near farms where the livestock are raised. It is\nnot stated what symptoms were manifest in these cases or if the\nexposure to raw milk was ascertained before or after the diagnosis of\nQ fever was made.\n\nClassical zoonotic organisms such as _Brucella abortus_, _Brucella\nmelitensis_, _Mycobacterium bovis_, _Salmonella_ species, _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_, _Campylobacter_ species, _Yersinia_ species, _Coxiella\nburnetii_, and _E. coli_ O157:H7 are associated with raw milk\ningestion.\n\nNon-zoonotic organisms such as _Streptococcus pyogenes_, _Salmonella_\nTyphi, _Corynebacterium diphtheriae_, _Shigella_ species, _Salmonella_\nParatyphi A, _Salmonella_ Paratyphi B, enterotoxins from\n_Staphylococcus aureus_, and hepatitis A virus have also been\nassociated with raw milk ingestion.\n\nOther diseases that can be related to unpasteurized milk are\nhighlighted in these paragraphs extracted from Leedom JM: Milk and\ninfectious diseases in humans. Clin Infect Dis 2006; 43(5): 610-5\n(http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/full/10.1086/507035) with the\ncitations renumbered to be consecutive starting from 1:\n\nIn 1996 and 1998, there were 2 episodes involving rabid cows that\noccurred in Massachusetts (1). Milk from rabid cows can contain rabies\nvirus, and transmission via unpasteurized milk is theoretically\npossible. Temperatures reached during pasteurization kill the virus.\n80 persons consumed unpasteurized milk that was collected from the 2\ncows, and 9 more had contact with saliva from the cows. All 89 persons\nreceived postexposure rabies prophylaxis, and no human cases of rabies\neventuated. A similar report in Oklahoma of possible rabies exposure\nassociated with the consumption of raw milk or cream from a rabid cow\nwas circulated in 2006 (2).\n\nTickborne encephalitis, a zoonotic arbovirus infection usually\ntransmitted to humans by the bite of an _Ixodes persulcatus_ or\n_Ixodes ricinus_ tick, is endemic to Central Europe, Eastern Europe,\nand Russia (3). However, the virus can be found in the milk of cows\nand goats with tickborne encephalitis and was reported to be\ntransmissible to humans by the consumption of unpasteurized milk (4).\nA case-control study failed to confirm oral transmission (5).\n\nA diarrhea syndrome (later named Brainerd diarrhea) occurred among\n122 residents of Brainerd, Minnesota, during the period December\n1983-July 1984 (6). It was characterized by acute onset, marked\nurgency, lack of systemic symptoms, failure to respond to conventional\nantimicrobial agents, and a long median duration of illness (median\nduration, 16.5 months). The syndrome was linked to consumption of raw\nmilk from a single dairy (6). No etiologic agent was ever isolated.\nThe outbreak of Brainerd diarrhea stopped when all of the dairy's\noutput was diverted and pasteurized (6, MT Osterholm, personal\ncommunication).\n\nSubsequent outbreaks in Illinois and Texas were not directly\nassociated with milk, although cattle had been in the vicinity of an\nIllinois well that had its water implicated as a vehicle of\ntransmission (7). Another outbreak of Brainerd-like diarrhea, although\nnot associated with raw milk, affected 58 (15 per cent) of 394\npassengers aboard a cruise ship visiting the Galapagos Islands in\nEcuador (8).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. CDC. Mass treatment of humans who drank unpasteurized milk from\nrabid cows -- Massachusetts, 1996-1998. Accessed 26 Jul 2006].\n3. Dumpis U, Crook D, Oksi J. Tick-borne encephalitis. Clin Infect\nDis 1999; 28(4): 882-90 [available at\nhttp://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/28/4/882.full.pdf+html].\n4. Matuszczyk I, Tarnowska H, Zabica J, Gut W. The outbreak of an\nepidemic of tick-borne encephalitis in Kielec province induced by milk\ningestion [in Polish]. Przegl Epidemiol 1997; 51(4): 381-8 [abstract\navailable at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9562785].\n5. Rieger MA, Nubling M, Kaiser R, et al. Tick-borne encephalitis\ntransmitted by raw milk -- what is the significance of this route of\ninfection? Studies in the epidemic region of Southwest Germany.\nGesundheitswesen 1998; 60(6): 348-56 [abstract available at\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9697358].\n6. J Infect Dis 1998; 177: 1041-5 [available at\nhttp://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/177/4/1041.full.pdf+html]. -\nMod.LL\n\nMichigan can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map\nat http://healthmap.org/r/0-6l. Livingston, Washtenaw, and Monroe\ncounties in southern Michigan can be seen on the map at\nhttp://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/michigan.shtml. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Washington, Montana: caprine exposure\nDate: Thu 23 Jun 2011\nSource: United Press International (UPI) [edited]\nhttp://www.upi.com/Health_News/2011/06/23/Livestock-infection-hits-victims-in-Wash/UPI-86551308858911/.\n\n\nHealth officials in Washington say 5 people have been diagnosed with\nwhat doctors suspect is a rare livestock-related bacterial infection\ncalled Q fever.\n\nFederal, state, and local health and agricultural officials say they\nhave traced the infection to goats purchased from or bred at farms in\nWashington state's Grant County, The Spokesman Review of Spokane\nreported.\n\nGoats from the farms have been traced to 9 other Washington counties\nand to Cascade and Teton counties in Montana, where 6 more people have\nbeen stricken with suspected Q fever, the newspaper said.\n\nSuch bacterial infections are common among goat, sheep, and cattle\nherds, Jason Kelly, a spokesman for the Washington state Department of\nAgriculture, said, citing a national study that found that at times 90\npercent of dairy herds can carry the organism.\n\nHuman cases of Q fever are rare, however, with only between 0-3 cases\nof Q fever normally confirmed in Washington each year, Donn Moyer, a\nspokesman for the state Department of Health, said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The states of Washington and Montana can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0-6q. County maps can be seen at\nhttp://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/washington.shtml\n(Washington) and\nhttp://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/montana.shtml (Montana).\n- Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[Q fever was first described in Australia. It was called 'Query\nfever' because the causative agent was initially unknown. _Coxiella\nburnetii_, the causative agent, was discovered in 1937. This organism\nis an agent that can be resistant to heat and desiccation and highly\ninfectious by the aerosol route. A single inhaled organism may produce\nclinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human] primates, the dose to kill 50\nper cent of the primates was found to be 1.7 organisms (1).\n\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including\nother species of livestock and domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does\nnot usually cause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion\nin goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection.\nOrganisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals.\nMost importantly, during birthing the organisms are shed in high\nnumbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta. Contact with\ncontaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small-cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication (along with the less resistant\nlarge-cell form) and are metabolically dormant and spore-like (3).\n\nThe Q fever organism is a category B bioterrorism agent and, in fact,\nalthough not thought to be related to bioterrorism, was spread by mail\nin a post office in the UK in 1987 (4).\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. Instances of other modes of transmission to humans,\nincluding tick bites and human to human transmission, are rare.\n\nAn earlier outbreak of infection in 51 people in Scotland, UK, was\ntied to a meat processing plant and appeared to spread via aerosol for\nat least 0.5 mi (0.8 km).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C. An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of 'Q fever.' Pub Hlth Rep 1041; 56:\n1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D. Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12: 518-53.\n(available at http://cmr.asm.org/cgi/content/full/12/4/518).\n3. Norlander L. Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes\nInfect 2000; 2: 417-24 (abstract available at\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10817644).\n4. Winner SJ, Eglin RP, Moore VI, Mayon-White RT. An outbreak of Q\nfever affecting postal workers in Oxfordshire. J Infect 1987; 14(3):\n255-61 (abstract available at\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3585037). - Mod.LL]", "summary": "Q FEVER - USA: RAW COW'S MILK, ex GOAT\n***************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n _Brucella\nmelitensis_, _Mycobacterium bovis_, _Salmonella_ species, _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_, _Campylobacter_ species, _Yersinia_ species, _Coxiella\nburnetii_, and _E. coli_ O157:H7 are associated with raw milk\ningestion. Germany: (NW, HE) human, animal\n20110223.0604]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAn ongoing outbreak in Hesse and North Rhine-Westphalia reminds us\nthat Q-fever is no stranger to Germany.\n\nThe following review is abstracted from the Gideon e-book series.\n[1,2] The primary references are available on request.\n\nTime and place\n--------------\nQ-fever was first recognized in Germany in 1947.\n- Reporting was instituted in West Germany in 1962, and in East\nGermany in 1979. The 2 systems were combined in 1991.\n- Most cases are reported in Bavaria, Baden-Wurttemberg,\nRhineland-Palatinate, Hesse, North Rhine-Westphalia, and Thuringia.\n- Hesse has experienced the greatest increase in incidence since\n1990.\n\nOutbreaks peak during spring to summer, and may be related to\nurbanization.\n- 40 outbreaks were reported during 1947 to 1999. Sheep were\nimplicated in 24 of the outbreaks, and cattle in 6.\n- 2 laboratory outbreaks (in 1947 and 1948) were reported during 1947\nto 1999.\n\nReported rates of Q-fever in Germany are summarized in the graph at\n<http://www.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Qfever-Germany.jpg>.\n\nAdditional notes\n----------------\n1. The mean rate was 0.08 per 100 000 during 1979 to 1989; 0.14 per\n100 000 during 1990 to 1999 (0.31 in Baden Wurttemberg).\n2. 3 cases of travel-associated Q-fever were reported in Germany --\nacquired in Sri Lanka, Sudan, and the Sahara desert (2007\npublication).\n\nPrevalence surveys\n------------------\n- 0 percent of rodents and _Ixodes ricinus_ ticks in Stuttgart (2008\npublication).\n- 1.9 percent of _Ixodes ricinus_ in central Germany, often in\nassociation with _Borrelia_, _Babesia_, or spotted fever-group\nrickettsiae (2006 to 2007).\n\nSeroprevalence surveys\n----------------------\n- 22 percent of blood donors are seropositive (nationwide, 1983 to\n1986).\n- 22 percent of military personnel (1985 to 1987).\n- 0 percent of Vietnamese refugees in Germany (1980 publication).\n- 12 percent of cattle in the southern Bavarian foothills.\n- 0.9 percent of 10.2 percent of sheep in Baden-Wurttemberg (2004\npublication).\n\nThe average number of cattle reported herds infected with Q-fever was\n71 per year during 1971 to 1979; 328 during 1980 to 1989; 303 during\n1990 to 1998.\n\nNotable outbreaks\n-----------------\n1947 (publication year) - an outbreak of presumed Q-fever was\nreported in Munich.\n1947 to 1948 - an outbreak (326 cases, 7 fatal) was reported among\nmembers of a farming community in Remmingsheim.\n1948 - outbreaks (1500 cases, estimated) were reported in villages\nnear Tubingen.\n1949 to 1950 - an outbreak (100 cases) was reported in Stuttgart.\n1951 (publication year) - an outbreak was reported in Zuzenhausen.\n1951 - an outbreak (6 cases) was reported among members of a single\nhousehold in Munich.\n1966 - an outbreak was associated with a slaughterhouse in Hamburg.\n1973 - an outbreak was reported in Simmerath/Eifel.\n1982 (publication year) - an outbreak (12 cases) was reported at a\nPathology Institute in Tubingen.\n1989 - an outbreak (16 cases) in Vorderpfalz was associated with\nsheep contact.\n1992 - an outbreak (80 cases) was reported among staff from a\nveterinary institute in Berlin.\n1993 - an outbreak (121 cases) was reported in Hessen.\n1994 - an outbreak was reported in Dusseldorf.\n1996 - an outbreak (60 cases) in the Rollshausen area (Lohra, Hessen)\nwas associated with infected sheep.\n1997 - an outbreak (105 confirmed cases) at a university was\nassociated with proximity to sheep.\n1999 - an outbreak (81 cases) in Dortmund was associated with\nproximity to sheep.\n2000 to 2001 - an outbreak (68 clinical cases) was reported in\nHochsauerland and Nordhessen.\n2002 - an outbreak (72 cases, 1 fatal) was reported in Hesse.\n2003 - an outbreak (299 cases) was associated with a contaminated ewe\nin farmer's market in Soest (North Rhine-Westphalia).\n2005 - an outbreak (331 cases, 188 laboratory-confirmed) in Jenna was\nrelated to proximity to sheep.\n2009 (publication year) - an outbreak (5 cases) was reported among\nresearchers working with sheep.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Berger SA. Infectious Diseases of Germany, 2011. 488 pp. Gideon\nE-books\n<http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-germany>\n2. Berger SA. Q-fever: Global Status, 2011. 73 pp. Gideon E-books\n<http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/q-fever-global-status/>\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProf Steve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\nIsrael\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Professor Berger for providing these useful data.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 24 Feb 2011\n \n- 1.9 percent of _Ixodes ricinus_ in central Germany, often in\nassociation with _Borrelia_, _Babesia_, or spotted fever-group\nrickettsiae (2006 to 2007). NETHERLANDS (29): UPDATE\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 15 Jul 2010\nSource: RNW (Radio Netherlands Worldwide) via Expatica.com [edited]\n<http://www.expatica.com/nl/news/local_news/q-fever-restrictions-in-the-netherlands-lifted_83636.html#>\n\n\nQ fever restrictions in the Netherlands lifted\n----------------------------------------------\nThe Dutch Agriculture Ministry has lifted restrictions on breeding\nand transporting milk goats and milk sheep, which had been in force\nsince the outbreak of Q fever earlier this year [2010].\n\nThe disease is spread by bacteria that use pregnant goats and sheep\nas hosts; it affects humans and can be lethal for weakened patients.\nSince Jan 2010, 420 people have been infected with Q fever, and 5\npeople who were already suffering from other afflictions died.\n\nThe lifting of restrictions enables goat farmers to repopulate their\nstables. In an attempt to minimise the spread of Q fever, 89 goat and\nsheep farms were cleared of all livestock. This has led to a shortage\nof some 35 000 goats, according to farmers' umbrella organisation\nLTO. Many farmers have been financially crippled by the loss of\nincome, and LTO warns that many of them may not be able to restart\ntheir businesses.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 91st farm to be found Q-fever infected in the Netherlands is a\ndairy goat farm in Oirschot, North Brabant, about 12 km (7.5 miles)\nnorth-west of Eindhoven (map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01Ju>). Infection, detected by the PCR\ntesting of milk, has occurred in spite of vaccination, which had been\nduly and timely carried on. Vaccination does not rule out infection\naltogether, but is expected to significantly reduce bacteria\nproliferation and spread by infected animals, and will prevent abortions.\n\nThe case was announced by the Ministry of Agriculture on 13 Jul 2010.\nThe vaccinated flock will not be culled nor will a breeding ban\nimplemented. To be on the safe side, prescribed biosecurity measures\nhave been applied.\n\nThe new infected location has been added to the Dutch Q-fever map,\navailable at\n<http://www.vwa.nl/onderwerpen/dierziekten/dossier/q-koorts/kaart-met-overzicht-van-besmette-bedrijven>\n(go to 'Kaart overzicht').\n\nAccording to the data of the public health authorities, out of the\n420 human Q-fever cases notified during 2010, 310 patients have\nundergone their infection during 2010. It is known that 95 patients\ngot infected during 2009, 6 earlier, while the infection year of the\nremaining 9 patients is still to be determined. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 15 Jul 2010\n \n\nThe new infected location has been added to the Dutch Q-fever map,\navailable at\n<http://www.vwa.nl/onderwerpen/dierziekten/dossier/q-koorts/kaart-met-overzicht-van-besmette-bedrijven>\n(go to 'Kaart overzicht'). Source: RNW (Radio Netherlands Worldwide) via Expatica.com [edited]\n<http://www.expatica.com/nl/news/local_news/q-fever-restrictions-in-the-netherlands-lifted_83636.html#>\n\n\nQ fever restrictions in the Netherlands lifted\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-01-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LTO", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Oirschot", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "434061", "headline": "PRO/AH> Q fever - Netherlands (27): risk assessment, Europe", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=434061", "date": "2010-05-25 18:00:04", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLNDS (27): RISK ASSESSMENT, EUROPE\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 24 May 2010\nSource: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC)\npress release [edited]\n<http://ecdc.europa.eu/en/press/news/Documents/100524_Press_release_RiskAssessment_Qfever.pdf>\n\n\nThe European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) today\n[24 May 2010] releases a risk assessment providing a summary of the\nbest available scientific evidence for Q fever in Europe. ECDC\ndeveloped this risk assessment at the request of the European\nCommission, which was initiated due to the high number of Q fever\ncases observed in the Netherlands over the last couple of years. The\naim of the risk assessment is to clarify the implications for public\nhealth.\n\nQ fever, caused by the bacterium _Coxiella burnetii_, often develops\nas outbreaks, mainly in the vicinity of sheep or goat farming\nactivities. The bacteria is transmitted from animals to humans by\nairborne transmission and can cause an acute form of flu-like\ndisease, which is usually self-limited.\n\nIf the acute disease is not treated, Q fever occasionally evolves\ninto a more serious chronic disease, especially among people with\nunderlying health conditions, such as heart valve disease, vessel\ngrafts, cancer, or compromised immune system, and it can be fatal\nwithout treatment.\n\nJohan Giesecke, Chief Scientist at ECDC says; 'The main conclusion of\nthe report is that chronic Q fever can be a serious disease. Since\nthe acute infection can be mild and unspecific, it is easily\noverlooked, both by the patient and by the physician, and the\nevidence suggests that chronic Q fever is often under diagnosed and\nunderreported.'\n\nThe management of Q-fever is the responsibility of national\nauthorities, and the report aims to provide an additional assessment\nof the best available evidence and suggests possible interventions to\nprevent and control Q fever. ECDC Chief Scientist, Johan Giesecke\nadds: 'Early detection and correct treatment for both acute and\nchronic infection is essential, and health authorities must work\ntogether with veterinary authorities at a national and a local level\nto be able to take necessary actions to stop an outbreak.'\n\nThe report states that preventing and controlling the acute form of Q\nfever can be addressed by various strategies such as public awareness\ncampaigns to make patients and doctors more observant of mild or\nunspecific symptoms, measures to limit Q fever bacteria in the\nenvironment and to limit contact with possibly infected animals.\n\nThe present outbreak seems largely limited to the southern parts of\nthe Netherlands, but since the bacteria can spread over considerable\ndistances, the risk in neighbouring countries cannot be neglected.\n\nThe ECDC risk assessment has been developed in close collaboration\nwith the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) to provide\ndecision-makers with integrated European-level advice on Q fever\ncovering both human and animal health, as well as the transmission of\nthe disease from animals to humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nGut Laach\n52385 Nideggen, Germany\n<CVLonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[The full report (46 pages) is available at\n<http://ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications/Publications/1005_TER_Risk_Assessment_Qfever.pdf>.\nThe following is a segment from the Executive summary:\n\n'Chronic Q fever is a serious complication of an acute Q fever\ninfection that develops in some 2 percent of acute symptomatic cases,\nand the fatality rate may vary from 5 percent to 50 percent. Chronic\nQ fever causes endocarditis in risk groups like people with previous\nheart valve disease, a prosthetic valve or vascular graft. Patients\nwith cancer or those who are immunosuppressed are also at a higher\nrisk. Chronic Q fever must be treated for at least one year, in some\ncases for the lifetime with more than one antibiotic. Surgical\nreplacement of damaged heart valves might be needed.\n\nEffective detection of, and treatment for, acute Q fever is the best\nstrategy for avoiding chronic cases. Three possible strategies are\ndescribed: (1) awareness raising among healthcare staff and the\npublic to address the risk groups; (2) active follow-up with serology\nfor known risk groups to detect and treat an acute Q fever infection\nearly; or (3) refer all known acute Q fever patients to\nechocardiography for active case finding and follow-up.\n\nThere is a need to initiate good prospective cohort studies and\ncontrolled trials (when ethically feasible) to obtain more robust\nevidence on how to prevent and inhibit outbreaks of Q fever in the\npublic health field, and on how to diagnose and treat acute and\nchronic disease at the clinical level.\n\nEvidence on Q fever in pregnancy is very limited and comes mainly\nfrom observations and research in domestic and experimental animals,\nseroprevalence studies, case reports, and one case series including\n53 pregnant women over a 15-year period. The risk for pregnant women\nof severe Q fever outcomes compared with the risk for the general\n(female) population cannot be quantified based on currently available\nevidence. Several cases of _Coxiella burnetii_ infection during\npregnancy resulting in adverse pregnancy outcomes have been reported.\nIn some of the cases _C. burnetii_ was found in the placenta and in\nfetal tissue. _Coxiella_ has also been identified in human breast\nmilk, but no case of transmission to the breastfed child has been\nvalidated.\n\nThere is some indication that long-term antibiotic therapy with\ncotrimoxazole has the potential to prevent severe pregnancy outcomes,\nbut the evidence is based on a case series without randomisation and\nwithout controlling for potential biases. As long as no further\nevidence from high quality treatment studies is available, pregnant\nwomen with diagnosed Q fever infection should be treated with\nantibiotics throughout the remaining pregnancy. However, the\nscientific basis for this recommendation is weak, and ECDC would\nstrongly recommend that randomised controlled trials are performed to\nobtain more reliable evidence.\n\nPregnant women should be advised not to visit farms in affected\nareas. ECDC does not recommend against breastfeeding except in cases\nof chronic disease that need long-term treatment of the mother.\n\nA formaline-inactivated whole-cell Q fever vaccine is produced and\nlicensed in Australia. The vaccine is effective, but pre-vaccination\ntesting is necessary due to high reactogenicity in persons who have\nearlier been infected with _C. burnetii_, making the vaccine more\nsuitable for defined risk groups than for general vaccination.\nAvailable evidence suggests an effective range of airborne spread of\n_C. burnetii_ of less than 5 km. The risk of airborne spread from the\nNetherlands is therefore limited to neighbouring countries (i.e.\nGermany, Belgium), and to areas close to outbreak sources. Active\nsurveillance or case finding for acute Q fever in possible risk\ngroups (i.e. pregnant women, patients with heart valve or vascular\ndiseases) on a local level and for a defined period of time is\nreported feasible and an efficient method for detecting acute\ninfections. In areas adjacent to epidemic settings (0.5 km from the\nsource), awareness campaigns among healthcare providers should be\ninitiated. If the area also affects other Member States, the\nresponsible public health authorities need to inform their\ncross-border counterparts. Sharing of information between public\nhealth and veterinary authorities would facilitate an early\nrecognition of an outbreak. Further, the health and veterinary\nauthorities at national and local levels should take the necessary\naction to stop an outbreak.' - Mod.AS]", "summary": "Three possible strategies are\ndescribed: (1) awareness raising among healthcare staff and the\npublic to address the risk groups; (2) active follow-up with serology\nfor known risk groups to detect and treat an acute Q fever infection\nearly; or (3) refer all known acute Q fever patients to\nechocardiography for active case finding and follow-up. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 24 May 2010\n \n\nThe report states that preventing and controlling the acute form of Q\nfever can be addressed by various strategies such as public awareness\ncampaigns to make patients and doctors more observant of mild or\nunspecific symptoms, measures to limit Q fever bacteria in the\nenvironment and to limit contact with possibly infected animals. \n\nThere is a need to initiate good prospective cohort studies and\ncontrolled trials (when ethically feasible) to obtain more robust\nevidence on how to prevent and inhibit outbreaks of Q fever in the\npublic health field, and on how to diagnose and treat acute and\nchronic disease at the clinical level. \n\nIf the acute disease is not treated, Q fever occasionally evolves\ninto a more serious chronic disease, especially among people with\nunderlying health conditions, such as heart valve disease, vessel\ngrafts, cancer, or compromised immune system, and it can be fatal\nwithout treatment. The ECDC risk assessment has been developed in close collaboration\nwith the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) to provide\ndecision-makers with integrated European-level advice on Q fever\ncovering both human and animal health, as well as the transmission of\nthe disease from animals to humans. ECDC Chief Scientist, Johan Giesecke\nadds: 'Early detection and correct treatment for both acute and\nchronic infection is essential, and health authorities must work\ntogether with veterinary authorities at a national and a local level\nto be able to take necessary actions to stop an outbreak.' \n\nThe management of Q-fever is the responsibility of national\nauthorities, and the report aims to provide an additional assessment\nof the best available evidence and suggests possible interventions to\nprevent and control Q fever. \n\nEvidence on Q fever in pregnancy is very limited and comes mainly\nfrom observations and research in domestic and experimental animals,\nseroprevalence studies, case reports, and one case series including\n53 pregnant women over a 15-year period. The risk for pregnant women\nof severe Q fever outcomes compared with the risk for the general\n(female) population cannot be quantified based on currently available\nevidence. As long as no further\nevidence from high quality treatment studies is available, pregnant\nwomen with diagnosed Q fever infection should be treated with\nantibiotics throughout the remaining pregnancy. the acute infection can be mild and unspecific, it is easily\noverlooked, both by the patient and by the physician, and the\nevidence suggests that chronic Q fever is often under diagnosed and\nunderreported.' \n\nThere is some indication that long-term antibiotic therapy with\ncotrimoxazole has the potential to prevent severe pregnancy outcomes,\nbut the evidence is based on a case series without randomisation and\nwithout controlling for potential biases. ECDC\ndeveloped this risk assessment at the request of the European\nCommission, which was initiated due to the high number of Q fever\ncases observed in the Netherlands over the last couple of years. The vaccine is effective, but pre-vaccination\ntesting is necessary due to high reactogenicity in persons who have\nearlier been infected with _C. burnetii_, making the vaccine more\nsuitable for defined risk groups than for general vaccination. heart valve or vascular\ndiseases) on a local level and for a defined period of time is\nreported feasible and an efficient method for detecting acute\ninfections. The list includes now a total of\n88 commercial dairy farms, identified as 'positive' or 'infected'. 86 of\nthem are dairy goat farms (out of the country's total of 360, namely 24 per\ncent) and 2 are dairy sheep farms (out of 40, namely 5 per cent}. More than\na million people are known to live within the 5 km radius areas around\nthose farms.
