Only when vaccination is\ncompleted in a timely fashion on all farms, would the breeding ban and\nthe supply ban be lifted [a complete vaccination means 2 primary\nvaccinations or revaccination following a primary vaccination round].\nLifting the ban will also depend upon the continued support for this\nstep by the expert advisory panel led by Mr Coutinho (director of the\nNational Centre for the control of infectious diseases, CIB), without\nreconsideration.\n\nVaccination\n-----------\nDairy goat and sheep farmers are obliged to vaccinate their animals\nbefore 1 Jun [2010]. Up to now, only 383 out of the 426 dairy goat and\nsheep farms have been registered for vaccination at the AH [animal\nhealth] Service (GD). Based on the numbers given, the vaccine doses\nare distributed to the veterinary practitioners. 455 000 vaccine doses\nhave so far been delivered. A sufficient quantity of vaccine is kept\navailable for the remaining, not-yet-registered farms.\n\n_Coxiella burnetii_ in secreted milk\n------------------------------------\nA possible reason for farmers to postpone vaccination, has been the\nrecent publication of a study, carried out by the Jeroen Bosch\nHospital, suspecting that _C. burnetii_ DNA could be demonstrated in\nthe milk of post-vaccinated animals. The status of such farms being 'Q\nfever free' had to be discussed, including the judgment of the results\nof their bulk milk tests.\n\nSubsequently, ministers Verburg (LNV) and Klink (VWS/Ministry of\nHealth, Welfare and Sport) asked the Central Veterinary Institute\n(CVI) and the AH Service (GD) to perform some additional research.\nPreliminary results demonstrate that the tests up to 8 days after\nvaccination show no increase of excretion of the _C. burnetii_ DNA in\nthe milk. This information might be an important incentive for the\nfarmers to push on with vaccination after all (The final research\nresults will be known at the beginning of June [2010]).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nChristine Bijl\nEuropean Livestock Association (ELA) Secretary\n<Christinebijl@gmail.com>\n\n[We are indebted also to Mary Marshall for drawing attention to the\npress release above. - Mod.AS]\n\n******\n[2] EFSA scientific advice\nDate: Wed 12 May 2010\nSource: European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) [edited]\n<http://www.efsa.europa.eu/en/press/news/ahaw100511.htm?WT.mc_id=EFSAHL01&emt=1>\n\n\nEFSA issues scientific advice on Q fever\n----------------------------------------\nFollowing a significant increase of human cases of Q fever in the\nNetherlands, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) has provided\nscientific advice on this animal disease which can also be transmitted\nto humans. The opinion addresses the significance of Q fever in\nanimals and humans, different risk factors involved in the occurrence\nand spread of the disease, and the effectiveness of possible control\nmeasures at the EU level.\n\nEFSA's advice states that infection with _Coxiella burnetii_, the\nbacterium which causes Q fever, is widespread in cattle, sheep, and\ngoats in the EU. Several factors can affect the spread of the\ninfection between these animals, but the overall impact on their\nhealth is limited as they rarely develop the disease itself. When it\noccurs, notably in sheep and goats, it may cause reproductive\ndisorders, including abortion. The opinion suggests that a combination\nof measures could be used to control Q fever in the long-term and\nshort-term, with preventive vaccination of animals considered to be\nthe most effective long-term option.\n\nThe available information indicates that Q fever also has a limited\nimpact on public health, although it can be significant for some risk\ngroups. Humans generally become infected through air-borne\ntransmission of the bacterium. There is no evidence that people can\nbecome ill by consuming contaminated milk or meat.\n\nThe Chair of EFSA's expert Panel on Animal Health and Welfare,\nPhilippe Vannier, said: 'Cooperation across animal and public health\ndisciplines is key in addressing the risks and challenges posed by a\ndisease such as Q fever. EFSA has therefore worked in close\ncollaboration with the European Centre for Disease Prevention and\nControl to provide decision-makers with integrated European-level\nadvice on Q fever covering both human and animal health, as well as\nthe transmission of the disease from animals to humans.\n\n'We need early exchange of information between veterinarians and human\nhealth practitioners to better identify the origin of outbreaks in\nhumans and to implement preventive measures when possible.\nImportantly, we need to all speak the same language and record data in\nthe same way. Harmonisation of data collection is critical in order to\ndefine a more accurate picture of the situation in Europe and how it\nis evolving over time.'\n\nInfection with _C. burnetii_ can be present in a wide range of\ndifferent farming systems. A number of factors -- including proximity\nto sheep and goats (especially when giving birth) and dry, windy\nweather -- can affect the risk of human infection. However, there is\nconsiderable uncertainty about the relative importance of these risk\nfactors, and it is likely that there is often more than one factor\ninvolved. No clear link was demonstrated between the spillover of\ninfection from farms to humans and either the size of the farms\ninvolved or the virulence of different strains of infection.\n\nThe opinion identified a number of measures which could be used to\ncontrol _C. burnetii_ infection in sheep and goats, but stressed that\na combination of measures may be needed to deal with both farm-based\nand environmental routes of infection. Some options, including the\nculling of pregnant animals, were not considered suitable for\nlong-term control but may have a role in the face of an outbreak.\nAntibiotic treatment of infected animals was not recommended.\n\nThe EFSA opinion included a number of recommendations, including the\nharmonisation of data collection on Q fever in animals so as to enable\ncomparisons over time and between countries. It also stressed the\nimportance of the rapid identification and reporting of Q fever cases\nin animals, as well as the early exchange of information between\nveterinarians and public health practitioners.\n\nEFSA has also published today [12 May 2010] a separate report which\nincludes proposals for the development of a harmonised monitoring and\nreporting scheme for Q fever in animals in the EU Member States and\nwhich was referred to extensively in the EFSA opinion. The report was\nfunded by EFSA, in line with Article 36 of its founding regulation,\nand was prepared by a consortium of scientific institutions from\ndifferent Member States, led by the French Agence Francaise de\nSecurite Sanitaire des Aliments (AFSSA).\n\n[The full scientific opinion (114 pages), is available at\n<http://www.efsa.europa.eu/en/scdocs/doc/1595.pdf>.\nA summary (4 pages) is available at\n<http://www.efsa.europa.eu/en/scdocs/doc/s1595.pdf>. - Mod.AS]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to a letter to the Dutch Parliament from the Minister of\nAgriculture, dated 11 May 2010, the number of pregnant goats and\nsheep, culled on the 88 infected commercial farms (of which 2 were\ndairy sheep, the others dairy goat farms), is about 62 500. One\nadditional goat farm is currently regarded suspected; future addition\nof others cannot yet be excluded.\n\nWe are unofficially told that the goat sector in the Netherlands is,\nnot surprisingly, seriously concerned about the situation,\nparticularly after experiencing the negative impact of the media\npublications, 2 months ago, of the preliminary results of the Jeroen\nBosch Hospital milk study. There are doubts about the odds to timely\nalleviate/mitigate, as planned, the current measures of breeding and\ntransportation bans. Final decision will become feasible when the\ncomplementary study in Lelystad is completed and summarised, namely\nearly June 2010. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n EFSA has therefore worked in close\ncollaboration with the European Centre for Disease Prevention and\nControl to provide decision-makers with integrated European-level\nadvice on Q fever covering both human and animal health, as well as\nthe transmission of the disease from animals to humans. \n\nWe are unofficially told that the goat sector in the Netherlands is,\nnot surprisingly, seriously concerned about the situation,\nparticularly after experiencing the negative impact of the media\npublications, 2 months ago, of the preliminary results of the Jeroen\n The report was\nfunded by EFSA, in line with Article 36 of its founding regulation,\nand was prepared by a consortium of scientific institutions from\ndifferent Member States, led by the French Agence Francaise de\nSecurite Sanitaire des Aliments (AFSSA). promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to a letter to the Dutch Parliament from the Minister of\nAgriculture, dated 11 May 2010, the number of pregnant goats and\nsheep, culled on the 88 infected commercial farms (of which 2 were\ndairy sheep, the others dairy goat farms), is about 62 500. Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (26): UPDATE, EUROPEAN FOOD SAFETY AUTHORITY\nSCIENTIFIC ADVICE\n***************************************************************************\n AS]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Lifting the ban will also depend upon the continued support for this\nstep by the expert advisory panel led by Mr Coutinho (director of the\nNational Centre for the control of infectious diseases, CIB), without\nreconsideration. Communicated by:\nChristine Bijl\nEuropean Livestock Association (ELA) Secretary\n<Christinebijl@gmail.com>\n\n However, there is\nconsiderable uncertainty about the relative importance of these risk\nfactors, and it is likely that there is often more than one factor\ninvolved. \n\nThe available information indicates that Q fever also has a limited\nimpact on public health, although it can be significant for some risk\ngroups. A number of factors -- including proximity\nto sheep and goats (especially when giving birth) and dry, windy\nweather -- can affect the risk of human infection. The EFSA opinion included a number of recommendations, including the\nharmonisation of data collection on Q fever in animals so as to enable\ncomparisons over time and between countries.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-05-11 00:00:00", "2010-05-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "the \n Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Verburg", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "411770", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands (24): update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=411770", "date": "2010-04-18 21:00:04", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (24): UPDATE\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: Sun 18 Apr 2010 (accessed)\nSource: Eurosurveillance, Volume 15, Issue 12, Rapid communications\n[abridged and edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/images/dynamic/EE/V15N12/art19520.pdf>\n\n\nQ fever in the Netherlands: an update on the epidemiology and control measures\n------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n1. Extent of the problem\n------------------------\nThe Netherlands is facing a Q fever problem that is still increasing\nin size since the last report in this journal [Eurosurveillance,\nVolume 14, Issue 19, 14 May 2009\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19210>].\n\nIn 2009, a total of 2357 new Q fever patients were registered in the\nnational infectious disease notification database. These patients\nfulfilled the case notification criteria of fever, pneumonia, or\nhepatitis, combined with a positive laboratory result. Q fever\ninfection is asymptomatic in 60 percent of cases and if symptomatic\noften presents as influenza-like illness. Increasing awareness among\npatients and doctors will likely result in detection of more\nrelatively mild cases.\n\nHowever, the proportion of notified patients that had to be admitted\nto a hospital seems to have stabilised around 20 percent, after a\ndecline from 2007 to 2008 (For the table, go to the full text at the\nabove URL). The high percentage of 50 percent in 2007 was largely\ninfluenced by active case finding in a retrospective survey among\nhospitalised cases. The 19.7 percent of 2009 are still much higher\nthan the 2-5 percent hospitalisation that are reported in the\nliterature.\n\nIn the 1st 10 weeks of 2010 a considerable number of cases has\nalready been notified, which, based on experiences of preceding years\nand taking into account the drastic measures taken, was not expected\nat this time of year (figure 1 at the above URL). The intensified\nmedia attention in late 2009 and early 2010 might have caused an\nincrease in the number of consultations. Improved laboratory capacity\nwill also have influenced the number of notified cases and quality of\nthe notified data. As can be seen in the epidemiological curve of\n2007 there is a more or less scattered pattern due to delayed\nnotifications. From 2009 onwards, routine PCR is included in the\ndiagnostic workup of acute Q fever, which can accelerate diagnosis.\nHowever, PCR is only positive in early Q fever.\n\nThe high background of notified cases in the winter of 2009-10 may be\na reflection of high seroprevalence among the affected population,\ndue to persisting antibodies, both IgG and IgM phase II, used to\ndiagnose acute Q-fever. This, combined with non-specific clinical\nsymptoms of Q fever, makes it difficult to differentiate between\nacute and past Q fever infections, and thus makes notifications less\naccurate.\n\nIn 2009, 6 deaths were reported, all in patients with other\nunderlying medical conditions. The median age of the patients was 49\n(interquartile range (IQR):38-59), and 61 percent were male. In 2008,\nthe median age was 50 years (IQR: 41-59), with 64 percent male cases.\n\nGeographically, the epidemic affected an area that was larger than in\nthe preceding years. A large new cluster was observed in Limburg, the\nsouthernmost province of the Netherlands, near a Q fever-affected\ndairy goat farm. There is consensus among public health and\nveterinary professionals that most of the human Q fever cases are\nlinked to abortion waves on large dairy goat farms, and to a much\nlesser extent on dairy sheep farms. Consequently, interventions have\nfocused on these types of farms. However, there are indications that\ndirect contact with non-dairy sheep has also caused a limited number\nof human cases: at least 28 among patients and staff of a mental\nhealth institution and possibly up to 46 among 12 000 people who\nvisited a sheep farm during the lambing season in February and March\n2009.\n\n2. Control measures\n-------------------\nIn February 2009, a nationwide hygiene protocol became mandatory for\nprofessional dairy goat and dairy sheep farms. Between April and\nNovember 2009, approximately 250 000 small ruminants were mandatorily\nvaccinated, including those on farms in the high incidence area in\nthe south of the country (Figure 2 at the above URL), farms with a\nrecent history of Q fever, and farms offering recreational\nactivities. Veterinarians, physicians and the public were informed\nthrough targeted mailings, publications and the media. On 1 Oct 2009,\nbulk milk monitoring became mandatory on farms with more than 50\ndairy goats or dairy sheep, and PCR positive bulk milk has since been\nused as an additional criterion for veterinary notification of Q\nfever.\n\nThe initial frequency of testing each farm every other month has been\nincreased to once every 2 weeks as of 14 Dec 2009. By 18 Feb 2010, 74\ndairy goat farms and 2 dairy sheep farms, out of the total of 360\ndairy goat farms and 40 dairy sheep farms with more than 50 animals\nin the Netherlands, had been declared Q fever-infected based on\nPCR-positive bulk milk testing. The number of positive farms is\nexpected to increase further towards the peak of the lambing season\n(March-April). [As of 18 Apr 2010, the total number of positive farms\nhas increased by 7, becoming 83, of which 81 dairy goats (22.5\npercent of 360) and 2 dairy sheep (5 percent). - Mod.AS]\n\nIn retrospect, a large human cluster in an urban area in 2008 could\nclearly be linked to a dairy goat farm (with over 400 animals) with a\nQ fever related abortion wave a few weeks before the first human\ncases presented. People living within 2 km of the farm had a much\nhigher risk for Q fever than those living more than 5 km away\n(relative risk 31.1; 95 percent confidence interval (CI): 16.4-59.1).\nBased on this study, a public information campaign has been targeted\nto zones of increased risk around affected farms. When a dairy goat\nor dairy sheep farm tests positive for _Coxiella burnetii_ in a bulk\nmilk sample for the 1st time, all inhabitants living within a radius\nof 5 km of the farm receive a letter informing them on the presence\nof a Q fever-positive farm in their proximity.\n\nThe letter gives no specific advice, but allows people with known\nrisk factors to avoid the farm. [See commentary below]. The list of\npositive farms is updated daily and is available to the public on the\nwebsite of the Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority [Go to the\nweb-site\n<http://www.vwa.nl/onderwerpen/dierziekten/dossier/4833780/q-koorts_kaart-met-overzicht-van-besmette-bedrijven>;\nfor the map, click on 'Kaart overzicht besmettingen Q-koorts'; for\nthe listed positive farms, on 'Adres locaties besmette bedrijven\nQ-koorts'].\n\nIn 2009, 59 percent of the notified human Q fever cases lived within\na radius of 5 km of an infected dairy goat or dairy sheep farm, while\nonly 12 percent of the Dutch population live within these zones. The\nincidence of Q fever in 2009 was 69 per 100 000 population within,\nand 6 per 100 000 outside the 5 km-areas.\n\nScreening of pregnant women\n---------------------------\nInternational literature suggests that a Q fever infection during\npregnancy may lead to adverse pregnancy outcome in a large percentage\nof cases. However, in a recently completed retrospective study in the\nhigh incidence area in the Netherlands, the presence of antibodies\nagainst _C. burnetii_ in early pregnancy was not significantly\nassociated with preterm delivery, low birth weight, or perinatal\nmortality (van der Hoek et al., unpublished data). A large-scale\nprospective screening and treatment study coordinated by the\nUniversity Medical Centre Groningen, was started in March 2010, aimed\nat providing more conclusive data on the need to screen pregnant\nwomen in high incidence areas.\n\nScreening of blood donors\n-------------------------\nThere is a theoretical risk for transmission of _C. burnetii_ through\nblood transfusion. Preliminary results indicate that in 2009, _C.\nburnetii_ DNA was detected in a small minority of blood donations in\nthe affected area. The risk of infection is probably negligible, but\nas a precautionary measure, Sanquin Blood Supply Foundation, the\norganisation responsible for all blood products in the Netherlands,\nstarted screening donated blood for _C. burnetii_ in the\nhigh-incidence area of the country on 15 March 2010.\n\nExpectations for 2010\n---------------------\nThe veterinary interventions, especially vaccination, animal movement\nrestrictions, culling and hygiene measures, are expected to have an\nimpact in 2010 and 2011. However, the resilience of _C. burnetii_ in\nthe environment and the possible role of animal species other than\nsmall ruminants make a prediction difficult but could potentially\nlead to incidence levels not much lower or even higher than those\nobserved in 2009. If spores persist in stables even after removing\nall animals or if environmental contamination and different animal\nreservoirs turn out to become relatively more important for\ntransmission to humans, the striking seasonal pattern of the years\n2007-2009 may be altered, possibly resulting in a more erratic\ntransmission pattern over time. So far, there are no signs that the Q\nfever problem is spreading to neighbouring countries. It could be\nthat factors such as lower population density, lower animal density,\nand different animal production methods in Belgium and G!\nermany, compared to the Netherlands, play a role.\n\nResearch agenda\n---------------\nTo fill the many knowledge gaps regarding Q fever, there is a large\ninterdisciplinary research agenda in the Netherlands focusing on\nhuman and veterinary public health and individual patient care.\nFurther elucidating the source and transmission routes will to a\nlarge extent depend on advances in molecular biology.\n\nConclusive matching of the bacteria that are found in animals with\nhuman and environmental samples has not yet been successful.\nObtaining _C. burnetii_ DNA is difficult, except from placenta\nmaterial of infected goats and sheep. Typing by multiple-locus\nvariable number tandem repeat analysis (MLVA) has been used on a\nlimited scale in human and veterinary samples and indicated\nsimilarity in strains isolated from a small sheep herd with strains\nfrom the human cluster in the mental health institution in May 2008.\n\nHowever, while various different MLVA types were identified, research\nby the Central Veterinary Institute in Lelystad shows that one MLVA\ntype prevails on many dairy goat farms in the high risk area in the\nsouthern part of the Netherlands, possibly indicating clonal spread\nin this area. This hampers tracing the source of human Q fever in the\nhigh-risk area to a specific farm. In a newly started project, whole\ngenome sequencing will be used to be able to distinguish between\nCoxiella bacteria from different sources.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nQ fever is now considered a major public health problem in the\nNetherlands and has recently led to drastic measures, including the\nlarge-scale culling of pregnant goats and sheep. Despite the\nstrictest veterinary measures possible, Q fever is expected to remain\na significant problem over the coming years. The control measures are\naimed at stabilising the number of human cases in 2010, while the\nsustained compulsory vaccination campaign in small ruminants which is\nimplemented in 2010 nationwide for target farms, is expected to\neventually cause a drop in human cases in 2011 and subsequent years.\n\n[Byline: W van der Hoek , F Dijkstra, B Schimmer, P M Schneeberger, P\nVellema, C Wijkmans4, R ter Schegget, V Hackert, Y van Duynhoven]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 18 Apr 2010\nSource: Web-site of Dutch Ministry of Agriculture (trans. by sender,\nabridged and edited]\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/portal/page?_pageid=116,1640336&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_subject=&p_month=0&p_year=0&p_submit=&p_page=3>\n\nOn Wed, 7 Apr 2010, the Minister of Agriculture answered a list of\nquestions from Members of Parliament (MPs). Selected items and\nadditional information, derived from the web-site of the Ministry of\nAgriculture, are included in the following report.\n\n1. The 'van Dijk Q fever Evaluation Commission' report, addressing\nthe Dutch Q-fever epidemic and its handling, will be presented in\nSeptember 2010. Initially, the report was due before summer 2010; see\n20100112.0144.\n\n2. Female goats/sheep, not culled in positive holdings since they\nwere not pregnant, are liable to life-long breeding ban. The minister\nhas appealed to non-contaminated farms to increase their available\ncrop of female animals for breeding, needed for the re-population of\naffected farms.\n\n3. There are indications that vegetation, moist soil conditions and\nfarm management contribute to increased infection rate of humans and\nanimals. Research is still ongoing.\n\n4. There is no clarity as yet if specific _C. burnetii_ strains are\nresponsible for the Dutch Q fever epidemic. So far, 14 different\nbacterium types have been identified.\n\n5. Farms that have been negative for a year are no direct risk to\npublic health. However, the risk for public health around a farm that\nwas contaminated and then (after a year) declared disease-free, is\nnot totally absent since the bacterium may still persist in the\nenvironment. There is not yet a risk profile for the environment\naround a previously contaminated farm.\n\n6. About 80 percent of the goat-holders and their family members have\nbeen found infected. The infection rate with the general Dutch\npopulation is 2.4 percent. These are the preliminary results of 2\nstudies. These data are not surprising; the disease is known to be\npresent in the Netherlands since the late 1950's, though on a\nlow-endemic level in the general public.\n\n7. There are no data of how many animals that were vaccinated in 2008\nand 2009 are still on the farms; therefore, it is not known yet how\nmany animals will need the booster vaccination this year.\n\n8. As of now [7 Apr 2010], 225 000 vaccine doses have been delivered\nto veterinary practices for application this year.\n\n9. The expert advisory group will reconvene end May to decide upon\npossible mitigation of the breeding ban and the introduction of\nbreeding animals to flocks.\n\n10. Advice on the possible use of a human Q fever vaccine, for groups\nat risk, is expected before summer 2010 from the Public Health\nCouncil. The Australian vaccine is the only existing vaccine and used\nonly for workers in the industry. Therefore there is no experience\nwith vaccinating people with specific health risks.\n\n11. The veterinary vaccine is being tested for efficiency at the EMA\n[the European Medicines Agency, formerly known as EMEA]. Furthermore,\nthe GD [Animal Health Service] has tested the vaccine and concluded\nthat the chance of infection has been reduced in view of most animals\nbeen vaccinated, abortions almost completely eliminated and excretion\nof the bacterium considerably reduced. More information will be\navailable in due course.\n\n12. Based on these data, the experts believe that in the absence of\nresearch findings indicative of possible new deleterious\ndevelopments, there are sufficient indications to stop the breeding\nand supplying ban, to stop culling and to reduce the frequency of\nbulk milk testing.\n\n13. There is a difference in Q-fever control measures required for\ndairy farms in comparison to mutton farms. The reason is that there\nare no indications that non-dairy farms have caused human infections.\nThe physiological reasons have not been sufficiently investigated but\ncould be related to differences in hormone and energy factors.\n\n14. With 3 studies into the effect of antibiotics on Q-fever, there\nare no indications that their application will reduce abortion or\nagent's excretion. There is however the risk of developed resistance\nagainst the antibiotic, as studies have shown.\n\n15. There has been some commotion around vaccination these past days.\nFarmers have become reluctant to vaccinate, related to rumors that\nthe vaccine could cause positive bulk milk tests with subsequent\ncullings. Based on a limited test (by the Jeroen Bosch Hospital on 6\nanimals) it appears that after vaccination some DNA from _C.\nburnetii_ shows in milk samples during the first 9 post-vaccination\ndays. There was no indication that farms have been erroneously\nculled. However, this was a limited test and therefore the CVI and\nRIVM have been asked by the ministers to further investigate this\nissue on a larger scale. We hope that this research by the CVI and\nRIVM will either give more clarity.\n\nIn addition: before a farm is declared positive, 3 samples must all\nhave a positive result:\n1- testing by the GD (Animal Health service)\n2- confirmation of the same sample by the CVI (Central Veterinarian Institute)\n3- the sampling by the VWA (Food Safety Authority)\n\nThe time lapse between the 3 tests (in particular Nos 1 and 3) has\nalways been more than 9 days (excluding tests of animals vaccinated 2\nmonths before sampling).\n\n16. A study on cows in France showed that they became Q-fever free\nafter 4 years of vaccinations. It is too early to state the same\neffectivity for the Netherlands, because the different circumstances.\nThe minister expects a much sooner (than 4 years) effect of\nvaccination in Dutch small ruminants, because of the strict measures\ntaken in the Netherlands.\n\n17. The regulations for storing and dispersing manure from Q-fever\ncontaminated farms have been adjusted. Contaminated farms are obliged\nto keep the manure, covered, at the farm and until at least 1 Jun\n2010. The regulations for not-contaminated farms have not been\nchanged: they may disperse the manure, when stored under coverage for\n90 days on the farm.\n\n18. Ministers Verburg (LNV/Agriculture) en Klink (VWS/Public health)\nhave decided to adjust the manure regulations for contaminated farms\nin order to limit the risk of spreading the Q-fever bacterium,\npotentially affecting public health.\n\n19. To eliminate the Q-fever bacterium in manure, dairy goat and\nsheep farmers with more than 50 animals must store and cover the\nmanure, facilitating the composting process. Due to this process the\ntemperature inside the covered heap rises, and the bacterium\neliminated. In contaminated premises, the period of manure storage\nhas been prolonged to 150 days.\n\n20. Other regulations have changed as well. One of them addressed the\ndiscontinued obligation to isolate parturient sheep or goats in dairy\ngoat and sheep farms, with more than 50 animals and with a public\nfunction. This is decided because these farms have to participate in\nthe fortnightly bulk milk testing procedure. However, these farms may\nallow visitors only after timely and full vaccination.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nChristine Bijl\nEuropean Livestock Association (ELA) Secretary\n<Christinebijl@gmail.com>\n<christinebijl@planet.nl>\n\n[The number of Dutch citizens, living within a radius of 5 km of\npositive farms, to whom a letter informing on the presence of a Q\nfever-positive farm in their proximity has been sent, as updated by\nthe Ministers on 7 Apr 2010, is one million (the total population of\nthe Netherlands is 16.5 million).\n\nThe ministers have provided also some financial data related to the Q\nfever event. So far, 45 000 animals have been culled, for which\ncompensations to the owners were 23 million Euros. The costs of the\ncontrol measures application, including culling, disinfection,\nevaluation, transportation etc have been 11 million Euros. The costs\nfor vaccination, bulk tank tests and research for 2010 will,\nreportedly, be 8 million Euros (this sum seems somewhat\nunderestimated; does it indeed cover all the relevant 2010\nactivities?!). Costs related to human health and economy at large\n(e.g., hospitalisation, sick days, job loss, etc.) have not been\ncalculated yet.\n\nSubscribers are encouraged to visit the 15 presentations of the\nInternational Q fever Conference, Breda, the Netherlands, 25-26 Feb\n2010. Netherlands (23): scientific advice, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=400882", "date": "2010-03-24 22:00:03", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (23): SCIENTIFIC ADVICE, UPDATE\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 22 Mar 2010\nSource: Dutch Ministry of Agriculture -- Advice to Ministries of\nAgriculture and Health [trans. and abridged by communicator, edited]\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/portal/page?_pageid=116,1640330&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_file_id=2000340>\n\n\nAdvice on Q fever, 9 Mar 2010, Doc 168/210 RC/TO/evtb\n-----------------------------------------------------\nAn additional expert consultation has been carried out on 5 Mar 2010.\nDuring this consultation both the CVI (Central Veterinary Institute)\nand the GD (Gezondheidsdienst voor Dieren/Animal Health Service) have\npresented the currently available data from international scientific\nliterature and the effects of vaccination in small ruminants, as\nrecorded up till now. Also, the 1st results have been presented of\nthe research into the temperature course of [collected] manure.\n\nFrom the scientific literature we know that during abortion of an\ninfected small ruminant billions of bacteria are shed in the\nenvironment; during normal partus of an infected small ruminant the\nshedding is considerably less, in the range of millions of bacteria.\nFrom the limited data of the field study done by GD and CVI and from\nthe literature study done by the CVI the preliminary conclusion is\nthat vaccination reduces the chance of an abortion considerably, and\nwill probably prevent it almost all together. At the same time there\nare indications that a considerable reduction in shedding of _C.\nburnetii_ is achieved by fully and timely vaccination of the animals.\nThe vaccine used in the Netherlands is not (yet) registered in the\nEU, but has meanwhile temporary admittance in France.\n\nI would like to stress again that much is still unclear as to how the\ngradation in quantitative shedding of _C. burnetii_ bacteria by farms\nwith small ruminants is related to the gradation of the number of\nhuman cases. The experts expect that vaccination (as a means to\nreduce the shedding of _C. burnetii_) will significantly reduce the\nrisk of airborne spread of the bacteria from positive farms, thus\ndecreasing the risk for human cases. It is, however, difficult to\ntell if and how many people will get sick in 2010 and later due to\nthe presence of viable bacteria in the environment, shed during\nprevious years.\n\nYour questions (letter of 3 Mar 2010) have been discussed with the\nexperts, and here are the responses:\n\n1. How effective is the vaccine in preventing infection of animals?\n\nThere are indications that the vaccine reduces the infection rate by\n_C. burnetii_ in the majority of the vaccinated animals. An exact\nestimation of the efficacy is not possible yet.\n\n2. How effective is the vaccine in preventing abortions in animals?\n\nThe experts believe that there are sufficient indications that the\nvaccine will prevent abortions considerably, or almost entirely, in\ntimely and fully vaccinated small ruminants.\n\n3. How effective is the vaccine in preventing the shedding of _C.\nburnetii_ during abortion/partus?\n\nThere is some possibility that, despite timely and full vaccination,\nabortions may yet occur in small ruminants as a result of other\ncauses. There are sufficient indications that in such situations a\nconsiderable reduction in the shedding of _C. burnetii_ is seen,\ncompared to its shedding by aborting, Q-fever infected, unvaccinated\nanimals. An exact estimate of the reduction is at this moment not yet\navailable.\n\n4. Will substantial risks for public health remain after vaccination?\nIf affirmative, which will they be?\n\nAs already indicated in the introduction, vaccination will reduce the\nshedding of _C.burnetii_ and subsequently reduce also the risk of\nairborne bacteria spread from positive farms. It is also expected\nthat as outcome of the said reduction, risk of human cases related to\nthis shedding will decrease.\n\nThe experts have established that the presence of infectious Q-fever\nbacteria in the environment has increased due to their large-scale\nspread from positive farms during the recent years. The effect of\nthis upon the human epidemic in 2010 and years to follow is\nunpredictable. Thus, the experts cannot eliminate the possibility\nthat in 2010 and coming years new human cases will occur as a result\nof the already contaminated environment, as well as of other\n(smaller) sources and via other (as yet unknown) transmission routes.\nAt the same time, direct contact of humans with infected animals on\nthe farms will remain a potential source of infection for employees\nand visitors. Employees could be at extra risk of infection if they\nwork in the contaminated environment without proper protection.\n\nThe experts therefore agree that substantial risks for public health\ncould be maintained after vaccination. Their exact estimation is not\nyet possible.\n\n5. What would be the weight of the above risks for a possible\nphasing-out of the measures contained in the 'Continuation Strategy\nfor Q-fever control'? Could you indicate this for each measure?\n\nIn the measures overview you attached, the measures have been\nclassified into 3 groups. I will use the same classification for my\nreplies.\n\nNot all experts [in the team] have the knowledge to be able to\naddress the detailed, elaborate veterinary measures as described by\nyou. Therefore, the assessment of these measures has been formulated\nprimarily by the veterinary experts.\n\nI. Source control and preventing the expansion of the [infection] source:\n\n-For the measures that you mention in group I, the advice is to\nmaintain the fortnightly bulk milk testing of dairy goat and sheep\nfarms with more than 50 animals, until 1 Jun 2010. After 1 Jun 2010,\nthe testing could return to the original bimonthly frequency,\nproviding that the animals have been fully vaccinated before that\ndate.\n\n-All experts advise you to grant the 'negative' [non-infected] status\nonly one year has elapsed with negative periodic milk test results.\nThis, since at least one lambing season [without positive result] is\nrequired to justify this status, in view of the known increase [in\nC._burnetii_] shedding during the lambing season and its known\ngradual decrease in the months afterwards.\n\n-Both the prescribed obligatory notification of Q fever suspicion,\nand the compulsory vaccination, must be maintained.\n\n-According to the veterinary experts, the breeding ban should be\nmaintained, until 1 Jun 2010, only for the female non-pregnant\nanimals that were now spared on the farms [where culling has been\napplied].\n\n-The ban upon introduction of animals from other farms can be lifted\nas from 1 Jun 2010, provided they have been fully and timely\nvaccinated and derived from negative farms.\n\n-Vaccinating animals is supposed to reduce the shedding of _C.\nburnetii_ from positive farms. This, provided no changes have taken\nplace regarding the management and size of the farms in question.\n\n-In view of the many uncertainties, the experts advise to maintain,\nfor the time being, the bans upon the expansion of farms and upon\nadded buildings; this ban to be anew reconsidered over one year.\n\n-As to additional measures on the premises declared infected, the\nculling of pregnant animals can be nullified provided the intended\nvaccination strategy has been implemented before 1 Jun 2010.\n\n-We regard the culling steps as a one-time emergency measure applied\nfor the lambing season of 2009 - 2010.\n\n-The he-goats and rams are no source for human cases related to\nairborne spread, and therefore are not regarded a considerable public\nhealth risk. The experts believe therefore that it can be left to the\nfarming sector to decide about the conditions under which these\nanimals can be involved in the breeding process.\n\n-The animal transport ban and the rodents and birds control measures\nmust remain in force.\n\n-The measures for other goat and sheep farms, among which farms with\na public function [e.g., children's petting farms, educational\ninstitutions, nursing homes] must remain in force. The only measure\nwhich may be lifted is the breeding ban, after 1 Jun 2010 and\nprovided the animals are vaccinated. Obviously, the 1 Jun 2010\n[vaccination deadline] does not apply to recently born offspring.\n\nII. Transmission from animal to human:\n\nThe experts see no reason to revise the present general\nguidelines/information to the public.\n\nFrom preliminary results of research into the manure issue, and based\nupon studies in dairy [farms], there are indications that three\nquarters of the covered manure heaps contain no infectious _C.\nburnetii_ within a month [since collection]. Remarkably, the outer\nlayer probably contains no live _C.burnetii_ within several days, due\nto the high composting temperatures in the outer layer of the manure\nheap. In waiting for the final test results, the veterinary experts\nadvise to maintain the currently prevailing manure measures and the\nhygiene directives for dairy goat and sheep farms. They also advise\nto maintain the measures required from farms declared infected,\nsimilarly to all other measures, described in your review, in\nrelation to other goat and sheep farms.\n\nIII. In the human sector, to limit the effects of infection:\n\nThe measures for the human sector remain unchanged, with areas where\nno positive bulk milk tests have been detected deserving special\nattention.\n\nEmployers are obliged to comply to the health and safety legislation\nto prevent the risk of employees' exposure as well as possible\ndeleterious effect upon their health. It is important that permanent\nemployees and temporary workers are informed in advance about the\npossibly contaminated environment in which they will be working and\nwill know how to work safely and soundly.\n\nFormulating national Q-fever guidelines by health and safety experts\nfor secure working in a contaminated environment is essential.\n\n6. Can the dot and/or the 5-km zone be removed from the VWA Q fever\nmap for farms where the contamination status has been lifted? [For\nthe map, updated 23 Mar 2010, currently including all 78 'dots and\nstains' which stand for farms declared infected since the beginning\nof the surveillance, click on 'Kaart overzicht besmettingen Q-koorts'\nin the VWA web-site, available at\n<http://www.vwa.nl/portal/page?_pageid=119,2025799&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_document_id=932575&p_node_id=2198882&p_mode=BROWSE>.\n-Mod.AS]\n\nOn the so-called 'stains map' there are dots to indicate the\ncontaminated farms; around these dots there are 5-km zones ['stains']\nwithin which there is a higher risk of human cases and in which\ninhabitants are informed about the possible effects of a Q-fever\ncontaminated farm in their region. The experts believe that the\npublic health risk around such a farm has not disappeared when such a\nfarm has been declared Q-fever free (repeated negative bulk milk\ntests, or culled and disinfected). The farm can however be removed\nfrom the list and the dot from the geographical map; however, for the\ntime being the 5-km zones ['stains'] shall be maintained on the map\nafter lifting the contamination status. [The reason for maintaining\nthe 5-km areas on the map] is the need for incidental employees,\ntemporary workers and other services providers in and around farms\nwhich had undergone a recent Q-fever history, to be informed in\nadvance about this and be able to work safely and soundly, even!\nif the farm has become free in the meantime.\n\nDepending on the further course of the human epidemic and on better\nknowledge of transmission, we hope to provide further advice on this\nissue at a later stage.\n\nFinally I would like to emphasise that in order to phase out the\nmeasures, as clarified above, it will be essential to carry out the\nvaccination campaign for all groups of relevant animals, timely\n(namely before pregnancy) and fully (namely 2 primary vaccinations,\nor a revaccination after a primary series), before 1 Jun 2010. New\ndata from research or from epidemiology could require reconsideration\nof the phasing-out of the measures. Involved parties will closely\nfollow the course of the epidemic in humans and in animals and the\nobtained results of research activities.\n\nDepending on new findings, I intend to reconvene with the experts at\nthe end of May [2010], at the latest.\n\n[Byline: Prof.dr. R.A. Coutinho,\nDirector, Infectious Disease Control, RIVM]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nChristine Bijl\nEuropean Livestock Association (ELA) Secretary\n<Christinebijl@gmail.com>\n\n[The above advisory document includes interim follow-up and\nconclusions of the (unique) prevention and control policy undertaken\nin the Netherlands in relation to this (unique) Q-fever epidemic. The\nmajor veterinary effort included, inter alia, fortnightly milk bulk\ntesting of about 400 dairy farms of goats and sheep since\nNovember-December 2009, throughout the country and the culling,\nagainst compensation, of more than 45 000 pregnant animals (mainly\ngoats) in 77 farms found positive (the culling of about 1500 goats on\nthe 78th farm, in Wanroij, provincie Noord-Brabant, found positive on\n23 Mar 2010, is currently underway). From the scientific literature we know that during abortion of an\ninfected small ruminant billions of bacteria are shed in the\nenvironment; during normal partus of an infected small ruminant the\nshedding is considerably less, in the range of millions of bacteria. Dr Menzies is gratefully\nacknowledged. - Mod.AS]\n\nPaula Menzies (Canada): Q fever and coxiellosis in Canada\n---------------------------------------------------------\nAlthough small ruminant numbers are lower in Canada than in other\ncountries, in Ontario sheep and goats are often raised in confinement\nsituations with high stocking densities.\n\nReported human Q fever (notifiable) cases are low in Ontario.\nCoxiellosis (Q fever) is not reportable in animals, but annually\nnotifiable. No action is taken by the federal or provincial\ngovernments after diagnosis. No routine surveillance in animals is\ncurrently performed.\n\nOutbreaks of human Q fever are usually related to visiting farms and\nfairs and outbreaks of abortion in sheep and goats due to _Coxiella_\n-- but human disease has been associated with parturient cats with no\ncontact with livestock. No human cases have been linked to infection\nin cattle; but there are links with wildlife, such as, snaring hares.\nAfter the cod fishery collapsed, Newfoundland imported goats to start\na dairy goat industry. The outbreak of coxiellosis associated with\nmixing of these introduced animals resulted in 80 cases of human Q\nfever in the surrounding community.\n\nCoxiellosis -- the disease in animals -- is unlikely to become\nreportable in Canada. Q fever in humans is likely under-diagnosed in\ngeneral. Better communication of the risks of this infection to\nmedical health professionals and the public in general, is needed. A\nsero-prevalence study in sheep and goat flocks and their caregivers\nis commencing in May [2010] in Ontario. This will help to clarify the\nimportance of the infection in this province.\n\n--\nDr Paula I Menzies\nAssoc Professor Dip.ECSRHM\nSmall Ruminant Research Coordinator\nRuminant Health Management Group\nDepartment of Population Medicine\nOntario Veterinary College, University of Guelph\nGuelph, Ontario Canada N1G 2W1\n<pmenzies@uoguelph.ca>\n\n[The CFIA (Canadian Food Inspection Agency) website\n(<http://www.inspection.gc.ca/english/anima/disemala/guidee.shtml>)\nincludes 3 lists of animal diseases:\n\n1. A list of the (32) reportable animal diseases (as mentioned by Dr\nMenzies, Q fever not included).\nAnimal owners, veterinarians and laboratories are required to\nimmediately report the presence of an animal that is contaminated or\nsuspected of being contaminated with one of these diseases to a CFIA\ndistrict veterinarian. Control or eradication measures will be\napplied immediately.\n\n2. Immediately notifiable diseases (for laboratories only).\nIn general, immediately notifiable diseases are diseases exotic to\nCanada for which there are no control or eradication programs.\nThe CFIA can undertake control measures for such diseases when\nnotified of their presence in Canada. This category also includes\nsome rare indigenous diseases. A herd or flock of origin must be\ncertified as being free from these diseases in order to meet import\nrequirements of trading partners.\n\n3. Annually notifiable diseases (for laboratories only; Q fever included).\nAnnually notifiable diseases are diseases for which Canada must\nsubmit an annual report to the World Organisation for Animal Health\n(OIE) indicating their presence within Canada. In general, they are\ndiseases that are present in Canada, but are not classified as\nreportable or immediately notifiable.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 8 Mar 2010\n ECSRHM\nSmall Ruminant Research Coordinator\nRuminant Health Management Group\nDepartment of Population Medicine\nOntario Veterinary College, University of Guelph\n \n\nOutbreaks of human Q fever are usually related to visiting farms and\nfairs and outbreaks of abortion in sheep and goats due to _Coxiella_\n-- but human disease has been associated with parturient cats with no\ncontact with livestock. However, Q fever is\nreportable in humans in Ontario under the Health Protection and Promotion Act.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nCsaba Varga, DVM, MSc\nVeterinary Consultant\nEnteric, Zoonotic & Vector-Borne Diseases Unit\nOntario Ministry of Health and Long Term Care\nPublic Health Protection & Prevention Branch\nToronto, Ontario, M2M 4K5\n<Csaba.Varga@ontario.ca>\n\n[Following the above information, we requested\nand kindly obtained from Dr Varga the following additional clarifications:\n\nQ1. Is every case (or suspected case) of Q fever\nin a human, officially notifiable in Ontario? In\ncase the answer is yes -- to whom is it reported?\n\nA1. My answer is yes. Every suspected human case\nis tested for Q fever. In Ontario a legislated\nhealth care professional (LHCP) if suspecting a Q\nfever case could submit a sample to the Public\nHealth Laboratory for testing. In case of\npositive sample, a report would be sent to the\nLHCP and an immediate treatment will follow.\nBecause the Q fever is reportable in Ontario,\nevery Q fever case will be reported to the\nOntario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care.\nTherefore the remark of 'No actions are taken after diagnosis' is not accurate.\n\nQ2. Is every case (or suspected case) of Q fever\nin a human officially notifiable in Canada (thus\na national requirement)? In case the answer is yes -- to whom is it reported?\n\nA2. Nationally Q fever is not reportable in Canada.\n\nQ3. Is there in Canada a provision requiring\nannual (accumulated?) but not immediate\nnotification of Q fever, as apparent from Bijl's recordings?\n\nA3. There is no national requirement of reporting\nQ fever in humans (no accumulated annual\nreporting requirement and no immediate\nnotification requirement). Q fever is not\nincluded among diseases under national surveillance.\n\nClearly, Ontario -- the Canadian province most\nseriously affected by Q fever -- applies\nspecific, and more intensive, policy and measures.\n\nWe are grateful to Dr Varga for the initial\nresponse and for the additional information on\nthe Canadian Q fever policy. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 4 Feb 2010\n [Paragraph 9 of the above posting , titled 'Paula\nMenzies (Canada) \u00ad Q-fever & Coxiellosis in\nCanada', included the following text:\n'Coxiellosis is not reportable for humans, but\nannually notifiable. Weekly Report 2010; 4(8), 26 Feb\n[edited]\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpr/archives/2010/news0810.htm#qfnl>\n\n\nOngoing outbreak of Q fever in the Netherlands: HAIRS group considers risk\nfor UK\n---------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nNotifications of Q fever in the Netherlands \u00ad- that in earlier years\naveraged 17 human cases annually [1] \u00ad- increased to 168 cases in 2007,\n1000 in 2008, and over 2000 in 2009. The most affected area is the highly\nagricultural southern province of Noord Brabant, but cases have also been\nreported from neighbouring provinces. The disease has now been confirmed on\na total of 73 dairy goat farms [now 74; see commentary] and 2 sheep farms.\nThe specific epidemiology of Q fever in the Netherlands is most likely\nrelated to intensive goat farming in the proximity of densely populated areas.\n\nControl measures in the Netherlands\n-----------------------------------\nDutch authorities have introduced a number of measures to try to control\nthe spread of the outbreak. These include mandatory vaccination of small\nruminants (initially in the affected regions but extended throughout the\ncountry in 2010 to include holdings of more than 50 sheep or dairy goats,\nand premises such as petting farms and zoos), a general ban on breeding,\nand fortnightly Q fever bulk milk testing on all farms with 50 or more\ndairy goats or dairy sheep. In December 2009 a cull commenced of all\npregnant dairy goats, whether vaccinated or unvaccinated, on infected\nfarms. Non-pregnant females were spared but are banned from use for\nbreeding purposes during their lifetime.\n\nECDC threat assessment\n----------------------\nIn December 2009 the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control\n(ECDC) undertook a threat assessment concluding that 'to date, there is no\nevidence for a significant increase in the number of human cases of Q-fever\nsince 2007 in other European countries. In Belgium and Germany, goat\npopulation density is much less than in the Netherlands and 'intensive'\nfarming is not practised in the same way. Therefore, sporadic occupational\ncases and localised outbreaks could be expected in other countries,\nincluding neighbouring Germany and Belgium, if infected animals reach the\nfarms. However, the spread to the general population is unlikely to reach\nthe extent it has in the Netherlands, as farms are not so often in the\nproximity of densely populated areas and goats are not kept in the same way.'\n\nImplications for the UK\n-----------------------\nThe Human Animal Infections Risk Surveillance (HAIRS) group is a\nmulti-agency and cross-disciplinary horizon scanning group with members\nfrom the HPA, DEFRA, Veterinary Laboratories Agency, Department of Health,\nFood Standards Agency, Animal Health, and the Devolved Administrations. The\nHAIRS group met in January 2010 to discuss the implications of the Dutch\nsituation for the UK, considering evidence from the Dutch outbreak and the\nECDC threat assessment, together with UK Q fever surveillance data and\ninformation on UK farming practices.\n\nCurrent surveillance of Q fever in humans and animals does not indicate any\nrecent increase in numbers of cases in the UK. There are between 50-100\ncases per year in humans in the UK, with no apparent increase seen in 2009.\nFewer than 10 cases in animals were identified in Great Britain annually\nbetween 2006 and 2008, and none were diagnosed in 2009 to the end of\nSeptember. Further information on the background level of Q fever infection\nin sheep and goats will be available from a Q fever seroprevalence study,\ncommissioned by DEFRA, that involves screening blood samples (from about\n6000 sheep and 500 goats) collected during the 2008 routine Brucella\nscreening programme. Preliminary results are expected in early 2010.\n\nThere are significant differences in the pattern of husbandry and density\nof stocking of goats between the UK and the Netherlands. The goat industry\nin the UK is not intensive and there are very few large dairy goat farms,\nmost goat farming being small-scale and not concentrated in any one area.\n\nThe HAIRS group concluded that, due to these differences, it is highly\nunlikely that the events in the Netherlands could be repeated in the UK. In\naddition, current scientific evidence does not support the suggestion that\na hypervirulent strain may be contributing to the extent of the outbreak in\nthe Netherlands. HAIRS will continue to monitor the situation closely.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 22 Feb 2010\nSource: Agrarisch Dagblad [trans. Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.agd.nl/1095664/Nieuws/Veehouderij/Tankmelkonderzoek-bij-Duitse-melkveebedrijven.htm>\n\n\nBulk tank milk testing in German dairy plants\n---------------------------------------------\nThe veterinary services of the German county Cleves [Kleve, northwest of\nDusseldorf, less than 8 km (5 miles) south of the Dutch border] have\nannounced measures to prevent Q fever. Plants applying direct milk\nmarketing are obliged to introduce bulk tank milk Q sampling for Q fever\ntesting. The direct marketing will be resumed once it is demonstrated that\nthe plant is not infected.\n\nThough there is, so far, no evidence of Q fever in Cleves, the German\nauthorities are worried about the risk that the bacterium will cross the\nborder from the nneighboring Dutch teritory, where the disease is raging.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nGut Laach 52385 Nideggen, Germany\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Sat 27 Feb 2010 [accessed]\nSource: Letter to the Editor, Vaccine 2009; 27: 3801 [edited]\n\n\nQ fever vaccination \u0097 unfinished business in Australia\n------------------------------------------------------\nWe celebrate with Gidding et al [1] the achievements of the short-lived\nnational Q fever vaccination program in Australia. The data presented\nsuggest a significant impact on Q fever in certain at-risk populations at\nthe time of the program, particularly abattoir workers. Similar benefits\nmay accrue in other countries with a Q fever burden, if a national program\nwas conducted.\n\nHowever, Australia's Q fever immunisation challenge is not yet completed.\nMore than 400 cases of Q fever were reported in Australia for 2006 and in\nNew South Wales, Australia's most populous state, during 2007 the crude\nrate of notification was 3.15 per 100 000 population (n=215). These cases\noccurred despite an effective vaccine being available. The national Q fever\nvaccination program in Australia was a short-term intervention and public\nhealth history clearly demonstrates that intensive time-limited\ninterventions that are not accompanied by system change are unlikely to be\nsustainable.\n\nThere has been a shift in the epidemiology of Q fever notifications in NSW.\nRecent data suggest that the ongoing burden is being borne by rural people\nwho live and work in close contact with farm animals. Human infection\ncommonly occurs through inhaling contaminated aerosols or dust, such as\nwhen people work and live around livestock.\n\nIt is clear that while advocating international application of Q fever\nvaccination in at-risk populations, there is a need for a sustainable\nsystematic program in Australia that ensures that non-abattoir workers who\nremain at risk from this serious disease can access the protection offered\nby the available vaccine.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Gidding HF, Wallace C, Lawrence G, McIntyre PB. (). Australia's national\nQ fever vaccination program. Vaccine 2009; 27: 2037\u00ad41.\n\n[byline: Peter D Massey, David N Durrheim, Andrew Way. Hunter New England\nHealth, Population Health]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 76th infected goat farm was declared as 'Q fever infected' on 26 Feb\n2010 in Zegveld, Utrecht province. Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.agriholland.nl/nieuws/artikel.html?id=112292>\n\n\nUntil now, 8 human deaths of Q fever\n------------------------------------\nSince the beginning of January 2010, 2 people have died of Q fever. This\nwas announced by the National Institute for Public Health and the\nEnvironment (RIVM). The 2 victims suffered of chronic Q fever which they\nacquired a long time back; they had also additional illnesses.\n\nThe total number of officially reported human fatalities, due to Q fever,\nis 8. According to experts, the actual number of victims is rather higher.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 26 Feb 2010\nSource: Agrarisch Dagblad via AgriHolland [trans. Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.agriholland.nl/nieuws/artikel.html?id=112380>\n\n\nMost Dutch goat breeders are infected by Q fever\n------------------------------------------------\nThe majority of the Dutch goat holders and their family members are\ninfected by Q fever. This information emerged during the international\ncongress on Q fever in Breda. Tests, carried out by RIVM, involving 120\ngoat holders and their family members, showed that 83 per cent of them were\ninfected by the _Coxiella burnetii_ bacterium. Veterinarians were found to\nbe infected as well: 80.5 per cent of the 133 tested vets were found to\nhave had contact with _Coxiella burnetii_.\n\nAn investigation covering 5600 blood samples showed that some 2.4 per cent\nof the Dutch population has already been infected. For people in close\ncontact with animals, the percentage is 6.9 per cent [this relates, most\nprobably, mainly to contact with pets; details would help. - Mod.AS]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Fri 26 Feb 2010\nSource: Agrarisch Dagblad via AgriHolland [trans. Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.agriholland.nl/nieuws/artikel.html?id=112379>\n\n\nInternational specialists question the Dutch handling of Q fever\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nForeign specialists, mainly from France and Australia, have their doubts\nabout the Dutch policy regarding Q fever. This has become apparent during\nan international congress in Breda concerning the disease.\n\nThe Australian Q fever specialist Stephen Graves said: 'Killing of goats\ndoes not safeguard the killing of the bacterium, but will destroy an\nimportant economic sector.' Graves recommends replacing culling by\nvaccination of young animals, combined with vaccination of humans. In\nAustralia, human vaccination has been used for the last 20 years.\n\nAlso in France and Belgium, culling is not applied since the eradication of\nthe bacterium from the environment is impossible.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above data from the Breda conference are partial and should be\nreferred to with caution; 1st-hand proceedings are expected with great\ninterest. For example, what population sector is liable to be vaccinated in\nAustralia?\n\nThe RIVM data (item 1) may be a cause for concern; if the survey covered\ngoat owners in the entire country, the results may mean that most, if not\nall, goat farms are already infected. Full data are anticipated. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n******\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< AS]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Veterinarians were found to\nbe infected as well: 80.5 per cent of the 133 tested vets were found to\nhave had contact with _Coxiella burnetii_.\n\n Tests, carried out by RIVM, involving 120\ngoat holders and their family members, showed that 83 per cent of them were\ninfected by the _Coxiella burnetii_ bacterium. The RIVM data (item 1) may be a cause for concern; if the survey covered\ngoat owners in the entire country, the results may mean that most, if not\nall, goat farms are already infected. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above data from the Breda conference are partial and should be\nreferred to with caution; 1st-hand proceedings are expected with great\ninterest. For people in close\ncontact with animals, the percentage is 6.9 per cent [this relates, most\nprobably, mainly to contact with pets; details would help.
