Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (16): HUMAN, ANIMAL\n*****************************************\n This\nwas announced by the National Institute for Public Health and the\nEnvironment (RIVM). \n\nThe total number of officially reported human fatalities, due to Q fever,\nis 8. The majority of the Dutch goat holders and their family members are\ninfected by Q fever. Most Dutch goat breeders are infected by Q fever\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2010-02-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Breda", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "390753", "headline": "PRO/AH> Q fever - Netherlands (18): update & review", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=390753", "date": "2010-03-03 23:50:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (18): UPDATE AND REVIEW\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed, 3 Feb 2010\nFrom: Christine Bijl <Christinebijl@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\n[We are most grateful to Christine Bijl for the submission of her\nfollowing recorded minutes; an official report (proceedings) is not\n(yet?) available. These recordings have been abridged and edited;\ndiscussions omitted. - Mod. AS]\n\nThe conference was attended and the report made by Christine Bijl, as\nELA representative.\n\nThe conference, organised by the Ministry of Agriculture in\ncollaboration with Wageningen UR and the Animal Health Service,\nstarted early on Thu 25 Feb 2010.\n\n1st day: 25 Feb 2010\n\nThe 1st day was chaired by Jaap Wagenaar (Veterinary Faculty Utrecht)\nwith the opening words of welcome by Elske Smith (Ministry\nLNV/Agriculture). Wagenaar emphasised that the conference had an\ninformative character.\n\n1. Christianne Bruschke (Ministry-CVO) - Actual veterinary situation\nand developments in the Netherlands Christianne sketched the\ndevelopment of the Dutch situation from the veterinary point of view.\nThe human side of the problems would be outlined in the next\npresentation by Yvonne. No one in the Netherlands had ever expected\nthat after the 1st human cases (2007) this epidemic would grow to\nsuch proportions. Nowhere in the world has such a development been\ndocumented before. At this moment, 70 percent of all dairy goat farms\nare still Q-fever free. Some contaminations were caused by\ntransporting animals from one farm to the other. Investigations into\nan industrial way of killing the bacterium in manure are in process.\nMuch is still to be learned about the Dutch problem.\n\n2. Yvonne van Duynhoven (RIVM) - The story of human Q-fever in the Netherlands\n\nThere have been retrospective investigations into previous clusters\nof Q-fever patients in hospitals: 2 in 2005, 1 in 2006 and 4 in 2007.\nIn Herpen (1st village in Brabant reporting human Q-fever), 24\npercent of the people became infected. In Helmond, 30 percent of\nabortions in a goat farm resulted in the 1st human cases 3 weeks\nlater, most of them in the 2-km-zone and decreasingly in the\n5-km-zone. Research into the risks of an infection for pregnant women\nshowed no complications for partus or neonatals. The Public Health\nCouncil has been requested to advise on the possible use of a human\nvaccine, answer expected in June 2010. Diagnostic delay has\ndecreased: more awareness made patients visit the doctors sooner, and\nthe doctors did not wait long before checking for Q-fever. Why is it\nthat in all Q-fever literature, just 5 percent serious illness is\nmentioned, when in the Netherlands 20 percent have been hospitalised?\nAn artefact? The hospitalisation rate has gone down from 20 to 16.8\npercent. Occurring complications: hepatitis 3.5, and endocarditis 0.3 percent.\n\n3. Francisco Reviriego Gordejo (DGSANCO) - Q-fever: the EU public and\nanimal health legislative context\n\nRiviriego sketched Q-fever as an apparently underestimated and\nunder-listed disease not included in EU legislation for animal\ndiseases, in contrast to brucellosis and RVF, and as a zoonosis not\nexplicitly listed in zoonoses- monitoring, in contrast to brucellosis\nand salmonella. Q-fever is progressively covered by EU surveillance\nfor public health monitoring. In the basic OIE standards, Q-fever is\nlisted but not for international trade. Apparently, the EU wheels are\nturning slowly; however, moves are being made now to include Q-fever\nin future as a notifiable disease.\n\n3. Pia Makela (EFSA) - Current reporting and monitoring of Q-fever in\nanimals in EU\n\nEFSA collects yearly data on monitoring of zoonoses. MSs have to\nsubmit these data on 8 zoonoses, among which Q-fever is not listed.\nHowever, based on the epidemiological situation of the MSs, other\nzoonoses may be included. Currently, data of 7 other zoonoses,\nincluding Q-fever, are reported. EFSA collaborates closely with ECDC\n(European Centre for Disease prevention and Control) to analyse and\npublish the yearly reports. Reporting list B diseases (like Q-fever)\nor not is an MS decision.\n\nEncouraged by EFSA, Q-fever reporting started in 2005. Since then,\nmore and more MSs are sending in their data. The reported data are\nnot harmonised: most reports are from clinical investigations\n(abortions), some from monitoring, some from surveillance and some\nfrom surveys. Data do not show whether they are herd based or from\nindividual sampling, nor what diagnostic methods were used. So data\nbetween MSs are not comparable. EFSA has given a grant to a\nconsortium of MSs institutes (AFSSA/France, CVI/Netherlands,\nFLI/Germany and NVRI/Poland) led by AFSSA to produce a harmonised\nmonitoring and reporting scheme for Q-fever in animals. (See Richard\nThiery's presentation on 26 Feb 2010). Up till today, Q-fever was\npresent in all 18 reporting MSs. Without harmonisation, it is\nimpossible to interpret the data.\n\n4. Denis Coulombier (ECDC) - Implications for public health in the EU\n\nECDC is involved in an advisory role re Q-fever since 2007/08. With\nthe rise of cases in the Netherlands, there seems to be a new\ndimension in the Q-fever situation. The EU Commission has requested\nECDC to assess the risks. The Bavarian problems in Germany appear not\nto be related to the Dutch situation. His conclusion: Confirmed\ncirculation of _C. burnetii_ should start early warning for public health.\n\n5. Jeannette van de Ven (ZLTO) - The meaning and consequences of\nQ-fever for farmers in general and especially the situation of goat farming\n\nJeanette and her husband started the family farm in 1995 with 200\nkids and have expanded that number to 2000 goats today. In 2008,\ntheir farm is situated in the compulsory vaccination zone, and\ntherefore all animals were vaccinated twice (boost after 6 weeks); in\n2009, the old animals were vaccinated once and the kids twice. Then\nin December 2009, the farm was declared contaminated based on bulk\nmilk monitoring. Out of 2000 animals, 524 pregnant animals were\nkilled in the 1st round and 101 in the 2nd. Not only did she tell her\nown sad story, she also told us about a farm outside the compulsory\nvaccination zone where all animals had been vaccinated voluntarily\nand yet this farm too was declared contaminated. Again the pregnant\nanimals were culled based on bulk milk testing results. Bulk milk\ntests give no information about the number of infected animals at a\ncontaminated farm. It could be that the majority of culled animals\nwere healthy. At the moment, there is continuing uncertainty for the\nfarmers: the breeding ban is set till July 2010, but what is going to\nhappen afterwards? The culling policy undermined the vaccination\npolicy. The vaccination policy should have avoided unnecessary\nkilling as control policy. Farmers are eager to do everything to\nprevent people from getting sick (therefore, they did agree to the\ndrastic measures this time), but eradication of the bacterium is\nimpossible. There must be a risk-based balance in future and not a\npolicy based on sentiment and media impact.\n\n6. Annie Rodolakis (France) - Q-fever in France - An elaborate\ndescription of the Q-fever situation in France where most human cases\nwere due to infection in sheep herds.\n\nTo compare virulence of strains, a mouse model was developed. Sheep\nstrains appeared to be less virulent for mice than the ones from\nbovines and goats. So possibly other factors could be responsible for\nthe route to humans. Sheep mostly shed in faeces and vaginal mucus.\nBovines hardly do. Studies into the efficacy of the available\nvaccines showed that the CEVA vaccine Coxevac is very efficient, not\nonly reduces the number of abortions in a herd, but also the amount\nof shedding. Whereas the Merial vaccine Chlamyvax (combination\nvaccination against Chlamydophila and Q-fever) did neither. The\nFrench have developed a skin test for infected herds to determine\nwhich ones are to be vaccinated. Then, one can suffice with\nvaccinating the non-reacting animals. Hygienic measures are in place\nas well, like carefully destroying afterbirth material (so it will\nnot be taken-up by domestic or wild animals), birthing in confined\nlocations, disinfection of these locations afterwards and treating\nthe manure with lime or calcium cyanamide and refraining from its\nspreading/dissemination in windy conditions. Still more research is\ndone regarding the best way to handle manure and the other hygienic measures.\n\n7. Stephen Graves (Australia) - Epidemiology and the role of human vaccination\n\nAfter giving us the history of _C. burnetii_, Graves told us that\nQ-fever is widely spread in Australia, with concentrations in\nQueensland and anywhere around localities with livestock and\nabattoirs etc. Australia is a scarcely-populated country with widely\nscattered farms (lots of space for all the Dutch goats). The Coxiella\nbacterium is found in all ruminants, kangaroos and the kangaroo tick,\nnot so much in domestic animals. Most human cases are due to aerosol\nspread from dried animal waste. The Australians developed a vaccine\nfor humans, licensed in 1989. It is still the only approved human\nvaccine in the world. However, before vaccinating a person, one MUST\n(obligatory) perform a skin test to prevent post-vaccination\nreactions. Anyone with previous Q-fever history will test positive\nand therefore be excluded from vaccination, unless the risk of\ninfection is higher than a possibly harmful reaction to the vaccine.\nImmunity is supposed to last 10 years. Q-fever (for humans) is a\nnotifiable disease. It is often not diagnosed, therefore\nunder-diagnosed. The incidence is higher in dry years. Vaccination is\nnot government funded; however, meat-industry companies take\nresponsibility by offering their workers vaccination. The use of\nvaccination in rural communities is common. His suggestions for the\nNetherlands: 'Buy our vaccine, try its efficacy for your local\nstrains and then develop your own vaccine. Good luck!'\n\n8. Martin Ganter (Germany) - Q-fever in Germany\n\nIn Germany, there have been over the years (notifiable since 1947)\nsome outbreaks of human Q-fever, mainly in the south (Bavaria). But\nthere have been 2 outbreaks in Jena/Thuringia (2005) and in North\nRhine-Westphalia where in 2003 some 300 people became ill with\nQ-fever after they had visited a country fair, where a single\naborting sheep had shed _C. burnetii_. In the Jena valley, the source\nof infection was found to be a small flock of lambing sheep. There\nare no specific regulations for Q-fever; it is handled when necessary\nusually by the veterinary officer, who can instate a transport ban,\nhygienic measures regarding birthing and disposal of material, and\nantibiotic treatments (tetracyclines) and vaccination. But all this\ndepends on the available knowledge of Q-fever of the involved\npersons. Due to some large outbreaks, a research network of\npublic-health and veterinary groups is working on diagnostics and\nepidemiology of Q-fever. Ganter has performed his own trial (ongoing)\nto investigate and evaluate the vaccination of a pregnant flock of\nsheep. It looks like there is a decrease (in 2009) of _C. burnetii_\nin the flock, but too soon for conclusions.\n\n9. Paula Menzies (Canada) - Q-fever & Coxiellosis in Canada\n\nCanada is a scarcely-populated country. However, in Ontario there are\nhigh animal concentrations (sheep and goats). Reported human Q-fever\ncases are low. Coxiellosis is not reportable for humans, but annually\nnotifiable. No actions are taken after diagnosis, no routine\nsurveillance. Outbreaks are always related to visiting barn shows and\nfairs. No human cases have been reported as due to cattle source;\nthere are links with cats and trapped hares (wildlife). After the cod\nfishery collapsed, Newfoundland imported goats to start dairy goat\nfarming. In the virgin area, Coxiella found a receptive, susceptible\nhost. There have been several outbreaks on 6 of the 8 farms, a\nsituation of concern [Will this turn out to be the Dutch scenario?].\nHowever, Coxiellosis is unlikely to become reportable in Canada and\nis under-diagnosed in general. Better communication to the public is\nneeded. More awareness with the authorities is needed. And Menzies is\nlooking for evidence in the Netherlands to support her efforts\ntowards the Canadian government. In May this year [2010], a study\nstarts on prevalence in Ontario.\n\n2nd day: 26 Feb 2010\n\nChairman: Frits Pluimers (former Ministry CVO)\n\n10. Benaouda Kadra (CEVA) - Q-fever: Vaccine production and control\n\nAs producer of the vaccine Coxevac, Kadra gave an overview of its\nbenefits and of the production process (purification of the bacterium\nis a difficult technique). Coxevac is registered in France since 2004\nand is used on a voluntary basis. The Netherlands have a temporary\nregistration since 2008. The Dutch have bought every possible\navailable dose for 2010. Because of the difficult production process,\nnot a single extra dose will be available this year [2010].\n\n11. Hendrik-Jan Roest (CVI) - Diagnosis, genotyping, virulence and\nculture of _C. burnetii_ in the Netherlands\n\nIn the Netherlands, bulk milk testing is used since October 2009;\nbeforehand, the abortion rate of more than 5 percent was the\nindicator for notification. A lot of discussion has been going on\nabout the efficiency and credibility of bulk milk testing as a\ncriterion for culling. However, according to Roest, the detection of\n_C. burnetii_ in a milk sample provides an absolute positive result,\neven if another test should be negative. And the fact that at culled\nfarms the last test results were negative after positive initial\nresults does not mean there is no infection on the farm, just that\nthe shedding went below the detection threshold. 30 percent of the\nanimals will not be detected. In genotying, 13 types were found in\nthe Netherlands using Multi Locus variable number tandem repeat\nAnalysis (MLVA). MLVA-type 11 is predominant on all Brabant farms and\non all dairy goat farms. Harmonising of the typing methods is\nessential for interpretation (see EFSA-grant). Whether the\npredominant type 11 is more virulent than the others is still a\nquestion not answered. However in cooperation with France, several\nDutch and French strains will be compared to find the answer,\nexpectedly this year [2010]. It may be assumed that the Dutch goats\nand people are relatively more susceptible ('virgin') regarding\nQ-fever, this possibly leading to more severe effect.\n\n12. Richard Thiery (AFSSA) - Results of EFSA's grant on improving\nharmonised Q-fever monitoring in the EU\n\nAs we heard from Pia Makela (EFSA), the reports from MSs are not\nharmonised and therefore cannot be properly interpreted or compared.\nThe EFSA-grant to AFSSA (in collaboration with CVI, FLI and NVRI)\naims to create a harmonising-system. So harmonisation is the key\nword. In 14 of 18 reporting MSs, the disease is notifiable for\nanimals. Some MSs are reporting at level of animals (individual)\nothers at herd level. There are no definitions or specificity of\nclinical signs. Harmonisation will start with central reporting of\nclinically affected herds (of domestic ruminants only) after serial\nabortions and presence of the bacterium is confirmed by PCR, and\npositive serology by ELISA. RT-PCR is most effective when performed\nwithin 8 days after abortion, and ELISA is very effective in\nvaccinated herds. For active surveillance, bulk milk testing is very\neffective. The final report is expected this spring [2010].\n\n13. Dimitrios Frangoulidis (Germany) - _Coxiella burnetii_ -\nstability in the environment and molecular typing\n\nThere are 55 strains and 17 genotypes. Despite the fact that _C.\nburnetii_ is spread all over the world and is found in many species,\nit is rarely reported. _C. burnetii_ is known as large cell variants\n(LCV) and small cell variants (SCV). The small variant is more stable\nand can survive in soil or dust for many years, in various\ncircumstances like in acid environments and high temperatures\n(resistance up to 70 C for 15 minutes). Diagnostic capabilities have\nimproved over the years, but there is still a lot to be learned about\nthe epidemiology of the disease.\n\n14. Piet Vellema (Animal Health Service Deventer) - Research in\nrelation to the approach of Q-fever\n\nBulk milk testing was initially (October 2009) aiming at accrediting\nrepeatedly test negative dairy farms. However in December 2009, this\ntesting was used to identify positive farms and consequently kill all\npregnant animals at such farms. Efficacy of vaccination was tested on\n15 dairy farms. There was some elevation of temperature, some skin\neffects, and a few cases of a drop in milk production. However, the\nshedding of bacteria was considerable after some time. At the request\nof the audience, Vellema elaborated on research into the relation\nbetween temperature in the manure heap and survival of the bacterium.\nIt became apparent that the temperature in manure rose to over 70 C\nwithin 2 days, but only in the upper layer. The core never rose above\n40 C. The more oxygen could be induced (like in the top layer), the\nhigher the temperature rose. As up-turning a contaminated heap\nproduces the risk of freeing bacteria, one believes that airing the\nheap with pipes would be the best way to raise the temperature in the core.\n\nIt was a very interesting and well organised conference with a wide\nrange of speakers and enough time for questions and discussion. In\nthe afternoon, the speakers and invited experts and stakeholders\nremained to discuss several angles in smaller groups. This session\nwas open only to selected people.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nChristine Bijl\nEuropean Livestock Association (ELA) Secretary\nKootwijkerbroek, The Netherlands\n<http://www.ela-europe.org/>\n<Christinebijl@gmail.com>\n\n[Should the presentations or official abstracts become available, we\nshall be happy to include them in future posting(s). - Mod.AS]", "summary": "Francisco Reviriego Gordejo (DGSANCO) - Q-fever: the EU public and\nanimal health legislative context\n\nRiviriego sketched Q-fever as an apparently underestimated and\nunder-listed disease not included in EU legislation for animal\ndiseases, in contrast to brucellosis and RVF, and as a zoonosis not\nexplicitly listed in zoonoses- monitoring, in contrast to brucellosis\nand salmonella. Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (18): UPDATE AND REVIEW\n*********************************************\n However, according to Roest, the detection of\n_C. burnetii_ in a milk sample provides an absolute positive result,\neven if another test should be negative. The Coxiella\nbacterium is found in all ruminants, kangaroos and the kangaroo tick,\nnot so much in domestic animals. The conference, organised by the Ministry of Agriculture in\ncollaboration with Wageningen UR and the Animal Health Service,\nstarted early on Thu 25 Feb 2010. As up-turning a contaminated heap\nproduces the risk of freeing bacteria, one believes that airing the\nheap with pipes would be the best way to raise the temperature in the core. No one in the Netherlands had ever expected\nthat after the 1st human cases (2007) this epidemic would grow to\nsuch proportions. Vaccination is\nnot government funded; however, meat-industry companies take\nresponsibility by offering their workers vaccination. However, before vaccinating a person, one MUST\n(obligatory) perform a skin test to prevent post-vaccination\nreactions. Ganter has performed his own trial (ongoing)\nto investigate and evaluate the vaccination of a pregnant flock of\nsheep. There have been several outbreaks on 6 of the 8 farms, a\nsituation of concern [Will this turn out to be the Dutch scenario?].\n A lot of discussion has been going on\nabout the efficiency and credibility of bulk milk testing as a\ncriterion for culling. Christianne Bruschke (Ministry-CVO) - Actual veterinary situation\nand developments in the Netherlands Christianne sketched the\ndevelopment of the Dutch situation from the veterinary point of view. His suggestions for the\nNetherlands: 'Buy our vaccine, try its efficacy for your local\nstrains and then develop your own vaccine. Despite the fact that _C.\nburnetii_ is spread all over the world and is found in many species,\nit is rarely reported. At the request\nof the audience, Vellema elaborated on research into the relation\nbetween temperature in the manure heap and survival of the bacterium. The\nFrench have developed a skin test for infected herds to determine\nwhich ones are to be vaccinated. However in cooperation with France, several\nDutch and French strains will be compared to find the answer,\nexpectedly this year [2010]. At the moment, there is continuing uncertainty for the\nfarmers: the breeding ban is set till July 2010, but what is going to\nhappen afterwards? After the cod\nfishery collapsed, Newfoundland imported goats to start dairy goat\nfarming. RT-PCR is most effective when performed\nwithin 8 days after abortion, and ELISA is very effective in\nvaccinated herds. Sheep\nstrains appeared to be less virulent for mice than the ones from\nbovines and goats. Diagnostic capabilities have\nimproved over the years, but there is still a lot to be learned about\nthe epidemiology of the disease. [We are most grateful to Christine Bijl for the submission of her\nfollowing recorded minutes; an official report (proceedings) is not\n(yet?) available. The 1st day was chaired by Jaap Wagenaar (Veterinary Faculty Utrecht)\nwith the opening words of welcome by Elske Smith (Ministry\nLNV/Agriculture). In genotying, 13 types were found in\nthe Netherlands using Multi Locus variable number tandem repeat\nAnalysis (MLVA). Netherlands (14): PCR test reliability", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=383840", "date": "2010-02-17 22:00:03", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (14): PCR TEST RELIABILITY\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 17 Feb 2010\nSource: Annex to an update letter from the Ministers of Agriculture\nand of Health to the Dutch Parliament on the Q-fever situation, dated\n16 Feb 2010 [trans. by communicator, edited]\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/pls/portal/url/page/minlnv/actueel/voorlooppagina?p_file_id=51083>\n\n\n[The above Ministers' letter included, as an annex, the following\nreport, sent on 7 Feb 2010 from the Central Veterinary Institute,\nUniversity of Wageningen, to the Dutch CVO Dr Christianne Bruschke,\naddressing the PCR test in use for the detection of infected dairy\ngoat and sheep farms in the Netherlands. - Mod.AS]\n\nDoubts about the validity of the PCR tests for Q-fever have been\nexpressed in the media and by various persons acting as experts.\n\nAs mentioned earlier in several notices both by the broad experts'\ngroup as well as by the CVI, a negative PCR result does not guarantee\nthat the animal in question or, in case of bulk milk testing, the farm\nin question are not infected/contaminated. This aspect has been\nelaborately described: there could be times when the animals shed\nmore, less or no bacteria. Repeatedly testing samples from farms with\ncontinuously negative results will increase the reliability of the\ndecision to define the status of a farm as not contaminated. For this\nreason, bulk milk testing is now performed with an interval of 2 weeks.\n\nRecently, there have also been doubts about the reliability of\npositive test results, also because of the different outcome of the\nresults from the 'same' sample tested at various laboratories.\nDoubting a positive result, however, is not justified. I will try to\nclarify the apparent discrepancies of the results at the various\nlaboratories or within one and the same laboratory.\n\nThere are various PCR tests available to demonstrate the DNA of the\nbacterium _Coxiella burnettii_ in a sample. The sensitivity of such a\ntest depends, among other things, upon the chosen 'target DNA.' For\n_C. burnettii_, some unique DNA particles are described. Some of these\nparticles occur only once in a bacterium. Others occur more than once\nin one bacterium. The number of times that such a DNA particle shows\nin _C. burnettii_ can vary per strain. Our CVI test used to detect\npositive farms aims to detect the so called IS1111 gene, several\ncopies of which are known to be present in _C. burnettii_; their\nnumber varies in different strains.\n\nAs described in the validation report, this PCR test is 100-fold more\nsensitive than a PCR test based on a DNA particle that appears only\nonce in one bacterium. This means that differences between results\nfrom various laboratories could occur: One laboratory can test more\nsensitively than the other depending on the choice of the target DNA\nparticle.\n\nEven if the various laboratories use the same target DNA sample,\ndifferent results can be generated by small differences of test\nprocedures. Even within the same laboratory, various random tests from\none sample could give different results. This can happen when the\namount of bacteria in the sample is close to the detection level of\nthe test. A positive result incontrovertibly demonstrates the presence\nof _C. burnettii_ DNA and, therefore, the presence of the bacterium. A\npositive result is, therefore, absolutely reliable.\n\nA negative result gives 2 possibilities: either there is no DNA in the\nsample and, therefore, _C. burnettii_ is absent; or, there is a chance\nthat the DNA is insufficient in the sample and, therefore, does not\nshow.\n\nTo illustrate the above: suppose I have received a sample of one liter\nof milk. As you know, but this might not be clear to laymen, only part\nof the submitted sample is used for the final test (in other words, a\nsingle test of a sample is only a single random test from the sample).\nSuppose I use one ml in my test with a detection limit of one\nbacterium per ml. If, for instance, there were one million bacteria in\nthat one liter of milk, thus 1000 bacteria per ml, any laboratory will\ntest this sample to be positive, and various random tests within the\nsame laboratory will all give a positive test result. On the other\nhand, if the amount of bacteria in that liter of milk is lower, e.g.\n1000, meaning one bacterium per ml, this will be on the detection\nlimit of my test, and it could, therefore, lead to a one-time negative\nrandom test. That applies even more in case of an even lower amount of\nbacteria (e.g. with 10 random tests from one sample: 7 random tests\nwith negative results and 3 with a positive result). Despite the 7\nnegative scores, the final outcome of the said test is a positive milk\nsample.\n\nApparently, there is some confusion as well about the specificity of\nthe test using the data from the CVI-validity report.\n\nTo clarify this: the test has an analytical specificity of 100\npercent: if the test is positive, DNA of the _Coxiella burnettii_\nbacterium will show in all cases. There are no false-positive results.\n\nApparently, some expert has indicated that based on data from our\nreport, the predictive value of a positive test is 84 percent; on\naccount of a comparison of our results in the validation report made\nbetween the PCR-test and an ELISA for detection of antibodies. We are\nasked for such data to accredit the tests. In technical terms, it has\nto do with a comparison of 2 different tests when no 'golden standard'\nis available and relative diagnostic sensitivities are bilaterally\ncalculated. Such data, however, are irrelevant for the predictive\nvalue of the PCR test in order to show bacterial DNA and, therefore,\ncannot be used to estimate the reliability of a positive PCR result,\nas apparently has been done.\n\nF.G. van Zijderveld\nHead of Bacteriology and TSEs Division\nActing Director CVI of Wageningen UR\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nChristine Bijl\nKootwijkerbroek, Netherlands\nSecretary European Livestock association (ELA)\n\n[The above explanatory note is timely and rather convincing. One point\ndeserves to be stressed and is valid for PCR tests in general: in view\nof the high sensitivity of PCR tests, with the potential to detect the\ntarget DNA and thus produce a positive result even when the number of\nbacteria is indeed minimal, the samples should be collected,\ntransported and handled throughout with maximal biosecurity and\ncaution, avoiding any chance of their incidental cross-contamination.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "One point\ndeserves to be stressed and is valid for PCR tests in general: in view\nof the high sensitivity of PCR tests, with the potential to detect the\ntarget DNA and thus produce a positive result even when the number of\nbacteria is indeed minimal, the samples should be collected,\ntransported and handled throughout with maximal biosecurity and\ncaution, avoiding any chance of their incidental cross-contamination. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 17 Feb 2010\n On the other\nhand, if the amount of bacteria in that liter of milk is lower, e.g.\n1000, meaning one bacterium per ml, this will be on the detection\nlimit of my test, and it could, therefore, lead to a one-time negative\nrandom test. Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.agriholland.nl/nieuws/artikel.html?id=112165>\n\n\nQ-fever infections in Lunteren and Zuidermeer\n---------------------------------------------\nA total of 2 new farms have been declared to be infected with Q-fever.\nThis relates to a dairy goat farm in Lunteren (Gelderland province)\nwith approximately 1160 animals and a dairy goat farm in Zuidermeer,\nin the North-Holland municipality of Koggenland with 850 animals. The\npregnant animals on the infected farms are to be culled.\n\nThere are currently 75 officially declared Q-fever infected dairy\nfarms in the Netherlands, 73 of goats and 2 of sheep. The Food and\nConsumer Product Safety Authority (VWA) of the Ministry of Agriculture\nput warning signs on the 2 new farms.\n\nThe Ministers of Health and Agriculture have sent letters with\ninformation to all those living in the area of 5-km [3 mile] radius\naround the 2 farms. For the Lunteren farm this relates to the\nresidents of the municipalities Barneveld, Ede, Renswoude,\nScherpenzeel and Veenendaal. For the farm in Zuidermeer, it concerns\nthe residents of the municipalities Koggenland, Beemster, Hoorn,\nMedemblik and Opmeer.\n\nA list of all Q-fever infected farms in the Netherlands, and a map,\nare available on the web-site of the VWA.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The farm in Koggenland is the 1st to be infected in the province of\nNorth Holland; only 2 Dutch provinces, Friesland and Zeeland, now\nremain free of Q fever in dairy goat or dairy sheep farms. The\nauthority's forecast was that up to a third of all such commercial\nfarms in the Netherlands may eventually be found infected, namely up\nto 130 farms.\n\nSince end December 2009, about 41 000 goats and sheep have been\nculled. According to a recently cited statement by a researcher in the\nCentral Veterinary Institute, no culling will be necessary in 2011. -\nMod.AS]\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 20 Feb 2010 (accessed)\nSource: A letter from the Ministers of Agriculture and of Health to\nthe Dutch Parliament on the Q-fever situation, dated 16 Feb 2010.\n[Trans. Mod.AS, summarised and edited].\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/pls/portal/url/page/minlnv/actueel/voorlooppagina?p_file_id=51083>\n\n\n[The letter included, inter alia, replies to queries from MP's\n(members of Parliament). The following 6 replies have been selected\ndue to their significant additions to available information. - Mod.AS]\n\n1. Information requested on the possible relationship between clusters\nof sick people and non-dairy farms (including mutton-type sheep).\n\nThe information on possible role of mutton-sheep in human infection\nwill be forwarded to the House as soon as scientific advice is obtained.\n\n2. Requested information concerning the updated policy of animal vaccination.\n\nAccording to the published regulations, all goats and sheep present on\nfarms which are to be vaccinated compulsorily, should be vaccinated\nbefore 1 Jan 2011. To make sure that such vaccination is performed\nprior to gestation in milk-producing and breeding farms, the final\ndate in this category of farms has been modified, becoming 1 Jun 2010.\n\n3. What is the Q fever situation in other [EU] Member States?\n\nWe refer you to the recent publication of the European Food Safety\nAuthority (EFSA), named 'THE COMMUNITY SUMMARY REPORT ON TRENDS AND\nSOURCES OF ZOONOSES AND ZOONOTIC AGENTS AND FOOD-BORNE OUTBREAKS IN\nTHE EUROPEAN UNION IN 2008', which was published on 28 Jan 2010. The\nreport paid specific attention to Q fever and to the occurrence of the\nbacterium in various member states\n(<http://www.efsa.europa.eu/en/scdocs/scdoc/1496.htm>). In addition,\nthe European Commission (EC) has requested EFSA to provide, in the\nnear future, scientific advice concerning Q fever. This advice will\ncover the incidence of the disease in man and animal in Europe, a well\nas the risk factors and the potential ways to control the disease.\n\n4. In reply to a query on research and investigation during the\nculling procedures:\n\nStudies concerning the vaccine have shown that it reduces the\ninfection rate, abortion incidence and dissemination of the pathogen\nby infected animals. At present, information is gathered by sampling\nvarious tissues and organs, such as amniotic fluids and placentas from\nthe culled animals, which may come from vaccinated as well as from\nunvaccinated farms. These samples will be tested for the presence of\nthe Q fever bacterium. This may provide knowledge concerning the\nefficiency of the vaccine within the Dutch circumstances.\n\n5. Regarding notified human cases of Q fever during 2010:\n\nRIVM-Clb (The National Institute for Public Health and the Environment\n-- Centre for Infectious Disease Control) has received since 1 Jan\n2010, from 17 Municipal Health Services (GGD's), reports on 136 cases\nof which the disease onset was between 2007 and early 2010. Doctors\nand laboratories are officially obliged to notify each Q fever case.\nIn each case the GGD performs an investigation which includes contact\nwith the doctor or the patient, to clarify where and when the\ninfection had taken place. Of the 136 mentioned cases, it is known\nthat 11 became initially sick in 2010; 48 are known to have fallen ill\nwith the disease during 2009, 3 had their onset during 2008 and one\npatient in 2007. No information on the date of onset is known\nconcerning the remaining 73 notifications.\n\nIn 2009, 6 patients were notified during the 1st 5 weeks, one of which\nwith onset in 2007, one in May 2008, 2 in November 2008, one in\nDecember 2008 and one in January 2009. Since both physicians and\npatients are currently more aware of the disease, RIVM-Clb expects an\nincrease in the number of notifications. If observed, it will be\ninvestigated if such an increase reflects a higher disease incidence\nor rather an enhanced notification rate. It is too early to make such\na judgement at the present point in time.\n\n6. Concerning research on public health aspects of Q fever:\n\nCurrent research is directed at risk factors for humans (in the\ngeneral population as well as in specific risk groups), at the impact\nof infection upon pregnancy, at the development of better diagnostic\nmethods, at the identification of the most effective medical treatment\nand at the impact of the disease on patients and upon society at large.\n\nA case is notified by the GGD only if the diagnosis was confirmed by\nlaboratory test. Positive serological tests of persons who have not\n(or had no) complaints, are not included in the notifications.\n\nMost notified cases reside near infected dairy goat or dairy sheep\nfarms (less than 5 km). Other possible factors, such as profession or\nrecreation -- outdoor activities -- are under ongoing investigation.\nBased upon currently available information fom the international\nscientific literature, there is no evidence for a man-to-man infection\nof significance. This aspect is not being investigated.\n\nVarious therapeutic treatments are being investigated by the medical\ninstitutions and a hospital. A research project into the comparative\nefficiency of the 2 main antibiotics currently in use, proposed by 2\nhospitals, is under consideration.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n******\n Concerning research on public health aspects of Q fever:\n\nCurrent research is directed at risk factors for humans (in the\ngeneral population as well as in specific risk groups), at the impact\nof infection upon pregnancy, at the development of better diagnostic\nmethods, at the identification of the most effective medical treatment\nand at the impact of the disease on patients and upon society at large. In Hilvarenbeek, this refers to a\nfarm including 1050 dairy goats, in Esch 3000 and in Liessel 1030\ndairy goats. The declaration followed the identification of the Q\nfever bacterium in each of the 3 farms in 2 separate tests, performed\nin both the Animal Health Service (GD) laboratory as well as in the\nCentral Veterinary Institute (CVI), in 2 different milk samples.\n\nThe Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority (VWA) of the Ministry\nof Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality (LNV) has placed warning\nsigns on the farms. The full addresses and the locations of the\ninfected farms will be made public on the web-site of the VWA.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In total, 71 dairy farms have been found infected with _Coxiella\nburnetii_ in the Netherlands since October 2009, of which there are\n70 goat farms and one sheep farm. The total number of commercial\ndairy goat and sheep farms in the Netherlands is approximately 450.\n\nAll pregnant animals on the 1st 68 infected farms have been culled,\nto be followed by the pregnant goats in the 3 newly-added farms.\nThese 3 farms are located in the province North Brabant, the Dutch\nprovince with the highest density of dairy goats. The total number of\nculled animals will have exceeded, by now, 40 000.\n\nThe detailed list and map of 68 Q-fever infected farms, as of 8 Feb\n2010, are available at:\n<http://www.vwa.nl/portal/page?_pageid=119,2025799&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_document_id=932575&p_node_id=2167182&p_mode=BROWSE>.\nBulk milk tests (PCR) of dairy goat and sheep farms with more than 50\nmilking animals have become compulsory in the Netherlands as of 1 Oct\n2009. On 14 Dec 2009 it became a requirement to perform the sampling\nand test every 2 weeks instead of the previously requirement of every\n2 months. The change was explained by the possibility that the\nexcretion of the bacterium may be intermittent.\n\nAccording to the official policy, initial testing is carried out by\nthe regional animal-health service (GD) laboratory; if found\npositive, a visit is paid to the farm, the issue explained to the\nowners, guidelines provided and a 2nd sample taken, sent for\nconfirmation to the Central Veterinary Institute in Lelystad. If\nconfirmed, the farm is declared officially infected.\n\nThe Netherlands notified the OIE of 63 Q fever outbreaks in dairy\ngoats on 13 Jan 2010; the reason for notification was 'unexpected\nincrease in incidence of a listed disease.' The immediate\nnotification is available at:\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=8842>.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 12 Feb 2010\n According to the official policy, initial testing is carried out by\nthe regional animal-health service (GD) laboratory; if found\npositive, a visit is paid to the farm, the issue explained to the\nowners, guidelines provided and a 2nd sample taken, sent for\nconfirmation to the Central Veterinary Institute in Lelystad. It is the 1st time\na court has stopped the cull procedure, which covers all pregnant\ngoats on farms where Q fever has been found.\n\nThe farm owner applied for an injunction to head off the cull after\ntests for the disease came up with conflicting results. He wants vets\nto take new samples and have them tested in different laboratories to\nfind out if his herd really is carrying Q fever.\n\nThe judge will explain his ruling on Monday, news agency ANP reported.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 5 Feb 2010\nSource: Agrarisch Dagblad [trans. Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.agd.nl/1094606/Nieuws/Artikel/LTO-Onderzoek-melktank-anders-beoordelen.htm>\n\n\nLTO: Different view on the value of bulk milk testing results\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nLTO Netherlands [the Dutch Federation of Agriculture and Horticulture,\nan entrepreneurial and employers' organisation] wishes the declaration\nof a farm as Q fever infected, based upon a single positive test, to\nbe cancelled.\n\nThe milk tanks of goat and sheep dairy farms are sampled and tested\nevery 2 weeks. It occurs that plants are found repeatedly negative,\nbut following a single positive test they are culled. According LTO\nNetherlands, there have been more cases similar to the one in Belfeld.\nIn those cases, a single positive test led to culling. In the current\ncase, the court denied the killing of the animals.\n\nAccording to the spokesman of Minister Gerda Verburg [Agriculture],\nLTO is also aware that 2 milk samplings undergo 3 tests. In the\nBelfeld case, the owner requested an additional test of the goats'\nmilk; according to the Ministry, this complementary test did not\nproduce unequivocal results. This was the background to Friday's court\ndecision to suspend the culling, requesting additional investigation.\nThe plant is still officially declared infected.\n\nToon van Hoof, the holder of the animal health portfolio in LTO,\nbelieves that experts should come forward with a proposal addressing\nthe variation in the results of the so-called bulk milk tests.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The application of PCR for the identification of _Coxiella burnetii_\ninfection in milk from dairy animals was initially published in the\nearly 90's, addressing cow's milk. Later, it was applied in testing of\nbulk milk samples and in other species.\n\nAccording to a 2005 paper (Ref 1), 316 bulk tank milk samples from\ndairy herds in the United States were PCR-tested during a 3-year\nperiod (from January 2001 to December 2003) by using trans-PCR.\nPositive results were confirmed by nested PCR and DNA sequencing. The\noverall prevalence of _C. burnetii_ in the tested samples was 94.3\npercent with little variation (93.2 to 94.7 percent) from year to\nyear. Samples from New York State did not show significant variation\nfrom other states, which indicated, according to the authors, that _C.\nburnetii_ infection in the dairy herds was persistent or steady, with\nlittle temporal or regional variations, suggesting that _C. burnetii_\ninfections in dairy herds 'are common throughout the United States.'\n\nThroughout the recent decade, PCR was applied in the detection of _C.\nburnetii_ in milk of small ruminants (sheep and goats) in several\ncountries, including bulk milk samples (see Ref 2). Its application in\nthe Netherlands, within a 'test and slaughter' policy, is -- to the\nbest knowledge of this moderator -- unique.\n\nAccording to the Dutch daily De Telegraaf, the dairy goat operation in\nBelfeld includes 2700 animals; the newspaper does not disclose how\nmany of them are pregnant, to be culled in line with the current policy.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Kim SG, Kim EH, Lafferty CJ, Dubovi E. (2005). _Coxiella burnetii_\nin bulk tank milk samples, United States. Emerg Infect Dis. ;11: Vol.\n11, No. 4, April 2005 619 - 621.\n<http://www.cdc.gov/NCIDOD/eid/vol11no04/pdfs/04-1036.pdf>\n\n2. A. Rodolakis, M. Berri, C. He'chard, C. Caudron, A. Souriau, C. C.\nBodier, B. Blanchard, P. Camuset, P. Devillechaise, J. C. Natorp, J.\nP. Vadet, and N. Arricau-Bouvery (2007). Comparison of _Coxiella\nburnetii_ Shedding in Milk of Dairy Bovine, Caprine, and Ovine Herds.\nJ. Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.agd.nl/1095261/Nieuws/Artikel/Tweede-melkschapenbedrijf-besmet-met-Q-koorts.htm>\n\n\n2nd dairy sheep plant with Q fever\n----------------------------------\nThe Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority (VWA) announced that a\ndairy sheep farm in Stolwijk, South Holland, has been declared Q-fever\ninfected. It is the 2nd dairy sheep plant declared infected in the\nNetherlands [since 1 Oct 2009]. In January [2010], a dairy sheep farm\nin Kraggenburg was found infected.\n\nIn addition, another dairy goat farm in Haren, North Brabant, has now\nbeen declared infected. The current total number of Q-fever infected\nfarms found in the Netherlands [since 1 Oct 2009], is 73 [of which 71\nare dairy goat farms].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview Pedigree English Longhorns\nGut Laach\n52385 Nideggen\nGermany\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n******\n[2] Human\nDate: Thu 11 Feb 2010\nSource: AgriHolland [in Dutch, trans. & summ. Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.agriholland.nl/nieuws/artikel.html?id=111875>\n\n\n11 new Q fever patients so far in 2010\n--------------------------------------\nAccording to the Dutch National Institute for Public Health and the\nEnvironment (RIVM), 136 new human cases of Q fever have been reported\nin the country during the current year [2010]. In 11 of the patients,\nthe onset of disease took place during 2010 and it is assumed that\nthey had been infected within the previous weeks. The dates of onset\nof disease in the other patients are not known, but are considered to\nhave taken place during 2009 or even earlier. Many people report their\nhealth complaints to their family doctors only now, following the\ndisease becoming a news item [eventually leading to serological\nconfirmation. The incubation period for acute Q fever in humans varies\nfrom 2 to 48 days; the typical incubation period is approximately 2 to\n3 weeks. Chronic Q fever can occur from months to years after\ninfection. - Mod.AS]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An epidemic curve graph, showing the number of reported Dutch Q fever\npatients by week of onset for the period 1 Jan 2007-10 Feb 2010, is\navailable at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/Epicurve%20Q-koorts_tcm92-59728.pdf>.\nThe cases are presented according to the relevant Community Health\nServices (GGD): dark green - 'Hart voor Brabant' (NE Brabant); medium\ngreen - SE Brabant; light green - South Limburg; gray - others. The\nannual total numbers - 2007: N=194, 2008: N=980, 2009: N=2267, 2010:\nN=11.\n\nAccording to a recent literature search, 53 lab-confirmed outbreaks of\nQ fever in humans have been published during the years 1981-2007. The\nfollowing 6 countries experienced the largest number of confirmed\noutbreaks: Germany (9), France (6), Australia (5), Canada (5), UK (5),\nUSA (5). The remaining 18 outbreaks were reported from various parts\nof the globe. In 26 of the 53 outbreaks, sheep were regarded as source\nof infection; goats in 6. Among the other animal sources, cats were\nsuspected in 3 smaller outbreaks. Larger outbreaks were reported from\nEast European countries, but lab confirmation was not available.\n\n_C. burnetii_ can infect many species of domestic animals and\nwildlife; in many species, the infection appears to be asymptomatic.\nIts reservoirs may be only partially known. Sheep, goats, and cattle\nseem to be the most common domesticat animal reservoirs. Wild rodents\nmay be important reservoirs in some areas, and cats -- particularly\nfollowing parturition -- are suspected in urban outbreaks. _C.\nburnetii_ has also been isolated from dogs, rabbits, horses, pigs,\ncamels, buffalo, deer, pigeons, swallows, parrots, crows, geese, and\nother mammals and birds. Antibodies have been found in coyotes,\nraccoons, opossums, badgers, jackrabbits, black bears, musk oxen and\nother species. There are also reports of _C. burnetii_ in fish and\nsnakes. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Maps of the Netherlands are available at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/netherlands_pol87.jpg> and\n<http://healthmap.org/r/017x>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] Ovine, caprine\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An epidemic curve graph, showing the number of reported Dutch Q fever\npatients by week of onset for the period 1 Jan 2007-10 Feb 2010, is\navailable at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/Epicurve%20Q-koorts_tcm92-59728.pdf>. Netherlands (10): international response", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=376585", "date": "2010-02-04 22:00:03", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (10): INTERNATIONAL RESPONSE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 4 Feb 2010 [accessed]\nSource: EFSA Animal Health topics - Q fever [abridged, edited]\n<http://www.efsa.europa.eu/en/ahawtopics/topic/qfever.htm?WT.mc_id=EFSAHL01&emt=1>\n\n\nFollowing the increase of Q fever cases in humans reported in 2008 and\nin particular in the last months of 2009 in some EU Member States, the\nEuropean Commission asked EFSA to provide urgent scientific advice to\ninform possible EU risk management measures in this area.\n\nEFSA's Panel on Animal Health and Welfare (AHAW) will lead the work\nwith the support of the Biological Hazard Panel (BIOHAZ) and in close\ncollaboration with the European Centre for Disease Prevention and\nControl (ECDC).\n\nA scientific opinion is expected by the end of April 2010. The Panel\nwill look at the occurrence and spread of Q-fever in farm animals and\nhumans across the EU, assess the risk factors related to the disease,\nas well as evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of disease\ncontrol options. These may include vaccination, animal movement and\nbiosecurity restrictions and pharmaceutical treatments.\n\nIn the context of their work on gathering and sharing information on\nzoonoses in different EU Member States, EFSA and ECDC collected data\non occurrence of Q fever in animals and humans. The information is\npublished in the Annual Community Summary Report on Zoonoses and\nFood-borne outbreaks for 2008.\n\nThe report gives an overview of zoonotic infections shared by humans\nand animals and disease outbreaks caused by consuming contaminated\nfood, based on data provided by Member States.\n\nThe report also identifies Q fever cases in humans and animals\n(cattle, sheep and goats) notified in the EU. It highlights that the\nnumber of reported cases in humans has increased in 2008, with 1594\ncases compared to 585 in 2007. In animals, the highest infection rates\nwere reported in goats, increasing from 9.7 percent in 2007 to 15.7\npercent in 2008.\n\n[The Community Summary Report on trends and sources of zoonoses,\nzoonotic agents and food-borne outbreaks in the European Union in\n2008: <http://www.efsa.europa.eu/en/scdocs/scdoc/1496.htm>]\n\nEFSA is inviting Member States to provide the latest information on\nthe occurrence of Q fever in animals in their respective countries.\n\nEFSA will also issue in spring 2010 guidance for Member States on\nmonitoring and reporting of Q fever in animals.\n\nDirective 2009/99/EC on the monitoring of zoonotic agents requires EU\nMember States to monitor and report on cases of Q fever in animals\nwarranted by the epidemiological situation. Furthermore, Commission\nDecision 2000/96/EC, as amended by Decision 2003/534/EC, lists Q fever\nin humans as a communicable disease to be monitored and controlled in\nthe EU.\n\n[Legislation on Communicable diseases - European Commission:\n<http://ec.europa.eu/health/ph_threats/com/comm_legislation_en.htm>]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 4 Feb 2010 [accessed]\nSource: The Community Summary Report on trends and sources of\nzoonoses, zoonotic agents and food-borne outbreaks in the European\nUnion in 2008. Published: 28 Jan 2010. Adopted: 23 Dec 2009 [abridged\nchapter on Q fever, pp 223-227, edited]\n<http://www.efsa.europa.eu/en/scdocs/doc/1496.pdf>\n\n\nIn 2007, 18 Member States [MSs] and in 2008, 17 MSs and 2 non-MSs\nprovided information about _C. burnetii_ in animals [See Table QF1 at\nthe above source URL.]. The majority of samples were [collected] due\nto clinical suspicion or after abortion and were examined using\nserological tests; most of the samples originated from cattle (Table\nQF3).\n\nThe proportion of positive cattle samples was 7.4 percent in 2007 and\n10.0 percent in 2008. Poland reported the highest increase in positive\ncases from 2.2 percent in 2007 to 40.1 percent in 2008, whereas\nBelgium reported a large decrease from 33.2 percent to 8.0 percent in\n2008. However, the results do not necessarily reflect the situation in\nMSs, since most data originate from sampling based on suspicion. In\ngoats, the proportion of positive samples increased from 9.7 percent\nin 2007 to 15.7 percent in 2008. All MSs providing data from both\nyears reported more positive samples in 2008 compared to 2007 in\ngoats; and the Netherlands reported a 3-fold increase in 2008.\nFurthermore, the Netherlands also reported an increase of positive\nsamples from 0 to 10.1 percent in sheep. Denmark was the only MS to\nprovide information at herd level for both years, with prevalence\naround 50 percent, which is by far the highest level in the EU. During\nthe last couple of years, Denmark has focu!\nsed especially on the sampling of animals suspected of being infected\nwith _C. burnetii_. This fact may, in part, explain the high number of\npositive findings.\n\nAdditionally, in 2008, Germany, Italy, Slovakia and Switzerland\nanalysed samples from buffalo, dogs, solipeds [equine animals], and\nwater buffalo; one German sample from a soliped was positive. For\nadditional information on data, please refer to Level 3 tables.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Mon 18 Jan 2010\nSource: AGD daily [trans. Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.agd.nl/1093752/Nieuws/Veehouderij/Q-koorts/IFAP-vraagt-hulp-OIE-bij-Q-koorts.htm>\n\n\nThe international farmers organisation IFAP [International Federation\nof Agricultural Producers] has requested the World Animal Health\nOrganisation's (OIE) support in relation to the Q fever issue.\n\nDavid King, General Secretary of IFAP sent a letter requesting OIE's\nhelp in obtaining replies to the many questions concerning Q fever.\nIFAP acted upon a request from LTO Netherlands (the Dutch Organisation\nfor Agriculture and Horticulture).\n\nIFAP stated that there is no international protocol for the control of\nQ fever. The majority of samples were [collected] due\nto clinical suspicion or after abortion and were examined using\nserological tests; most of the samples originated from cattle (Table\nQF3). In animals, the highest infection rates\nwere reported in goats, increasing from 9.7 percent in 2007 to 15.7\npercent in 2008. Netherlands (09): zoo-sanitary measures", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=372698", "date": "2010-01-28 20:00:03", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (09): ZOO-SANITARY MEASURES\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 28 Jan 2010\nSource: Radio Netherlands worldwide [edited]\n<http://www.rnw.nl/english/article/mps-stop-q-fever-cull-male-goats-and-sheep>\n\n\nA motion has been put forward in the Dutch Lower House to reverse a\ndecision by Health Minister Ab Klink and Agriculture Minister Gerda\nVerburg to have all rams and billy goats on dairy farms infected with\nQ-fever destroyed.\n\nSince male sheep and goats can also carry the bacteria, they may\ninfect females during mating. As it is difficult to distinguish\nbetween sick and healthy animals, the health and agriculture\nministers had opted to cull the males rather than take the risk.\n\nBut MPs said the measure was too drastic and have proposed that the\nanimals be 1st tested individually. Minister Verburg is against the\nmotion but has said she will await the outcome of next week's\nparliamentary vote on the issue.\n\nThere are 64 sheep and goat dairy farms in the Netherlands infected\nwith Q-fever, but most of the farmers keep only a few males.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 28 Jan 2010\nSource: Volkskrant via Agriholland [trans. Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.agriholland.com/nieuws/artikel.html?id=111394>\n\n\nSubsequent to the parliamentary debate, the Minister of Agriculture\nhas delayed the planned culling of rams and he-goats present in the\nQ-fever infected holdings. The final decision on their fate will be\ntaken after the final vote, planned to take place on 2 Feb 2010.\nMinister Verburg said that she regards the male animals as potential\nrisk since they can infect covered females with their semen. She\nsupposed that repeated testing cannot guarantee the males' freedom of\nQ fever, precluding their use for breeding. Farms which plan a new\nstart must guarantee the absence of infected animals.\n\nVerburg promised to make an effort to safeguard the supply, in 2010,\nof larger quantities of vaccines against Q fever than the already\nordered 1.5 million doses. The parliament wished that all sheep and\ngoats in the Netherlands will be vaccinated; this falls in line with\nVerburg's aim. She considers the possible adoption of the combined\nChlamydophila/Q fever vaccine, currently used in France.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On top of animal welfare aspects of the issue, there are significant\nzootechnical/economical ones. Male breeding animals are selected\naccording to their genetic potential, their monetary value usually\nmuch higher than that of the females and may go into 4-digit figures\nor even more, in Euros. They may represent many years of breeding\nefforts and investments. - Mod.AS]\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Thu 28 Jan 2010\nSource: Press release, Dutch Ministry of Agriculture [trans. Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/portal/page?_pageid=116,1640333&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_news_item_id=25032>\n\n\nThe decision of Tue 26 Jan 2010 on measures concerning the seclusion\nof birthing sheep and goats on holdings with public function is to go\ninto force today [28 Jan 2010] 11.00 am.\n\nChildren's petting farms and all other holdings with a public\nfunction [e.g. nursing homes etc.] will be obliged to secure that\nbirthings of pregnant goats and sheep will take place in enclosed\nspaces fully separated from the public. The separation will have to\nbe implemented from the end of the 4th gestation month until 2 weeks\npost-parturition. The offspring are to stay by their mothers within\nthe separated pace during those 2 weeks [The gestation period of\nsheep and goats is about 5 months. - Mod.AS].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4]\nDate: Tue 26 Jan 2010\nSource: NRC Handelsblad [edited]\n<http://www.nrc.nl/international/article2468402.ece/Veterinary_diseases%2C_new_trend_or_old_foe?service=Print>\n\n\nThe culling of thousands of goats after an outbreak of Q-fever in the\nNetherlands has shocked many and reinforced calls for early\nvaccination of animals.\n\nIt seems like an unmistakable new trend: every 2 to 3 years a major\noutbreak of a veterinary disease takes thousands of animals' lives.\nThey are either killed by the disease itself or are culled to avoid\nthe plague from spreading further. Today, the Netherlands suffers\nfrom an outbreak of Q-fever among goats; 3 years ago it was hit by an\noutbreak of bluetongue (catarrhal fever); in 2003 bird flu (avian\ninfluenza) was an issue; foot-and-mouth struck in 2001, and classical\nswine fever ruled in 1997. In the meantime, mad cow disease lingered\nfor years. Last year [2009] was the 1st since 1997 that no new cases\nof the illness were reported.\n\nThe assumption is that industrialisation of agriculture goes hand in\nhand with larger, more frequent, and deadlier veterinary diseases.\nBut does it really?\n\nFred van Zijderveld, the deputy director of the Central Veterinary\nInstitute, thinks not. 'What has changed is our perception of events\nbecause of the large scale media attention. At the same time, people\naccept less when it comes to the suffering of animals. There was an\noutbreak of classical swine fever in 1952 in which 3000 farms were\ncontaminated, and the same happened to 1700 businesses in 1962.'\n\nThe shift in perception and tolerance manifested itself during the\n1997 epidemic of classical swine fever. Throughout the 1990s, a\nstrong non-vaccination policy was implemented in the Netherlands\nbecause some countries importing pigs did not want them vaccinated.\nThe vaccine leaves traces in the animal that resembled those of the\nactual disease, making it impossible to tell if an animal was ill or\nhad been vaccinated. That is why animals were not protected through\nvaccination after an epidemic was discovered in 1997. When it spun\nout of control, as many as 9.6 million pigs had to be culled.\n\n'Non-vaccination is very risky with all the long distance transport\nwe have today,' according to Van Zijderveld. 'Exporting countries\nmust guarantee their animals are healthy, but an infected animal will\noccasionally slip through, and viruses can spread rapidly. I think\nthe Netherlands today would choose to immediately vaccinate healthy\nanimals in the vicinity of an outbreak,' he said. 'Definitely in the\ncase of classical swine fever, because we now have a so-called marker\nvaccine that helps distinguish between vaccinated and contaminated animals.'\n\nOver the last few years, farmers have argued in favour of\ninoculating. 'Both society at large and the farmers involved want to\nstop the killing of healthy animals,' a farmers' lobby organisation\nwrote in a press release 4 years ago. In spite of this plea, the\ngovernment failed to vaccinate goats en masse even after bacteria\nthey carried had infected 2300 and killed at least 6 people. In the\npast weeks, 38 000 goats and sheep were culled to prevent more humans\nbeing infected.\n\nProfessor Roel Coutinho, the director of the Centre for Infectious\nDisease Control, believes the size of the goat industry and their\nproximity to humans caused the unprecedented outbreak. 'We used to\nsay: things like this happen in China, where many people and animals\nlive very close to each other. But the Netherlands is the China of\nEurope.' With a livestock population of 119 million animals and over\n16 million people, the country is prone to quick transmission of\ndiseases. Yet Coutinho was astonished by the impact of Q-fever. 'I\nwas surprised by the sudden appearance of intensive goat farming,' he\nsaid. Goats had become a very popular type of cattle, largely because\nother animals had proven so prone to infectious disease.\n\nIt is difficult to pass a black-and-white judgment on the relation\nbetween modern, large scale farming and animal diseases, Van\nZijderveld said. 'The scale has led to improved hygiene and the\ndisappearance of worm infections that originate in livestock. If\norganic farming grows, tapeworm infections in humans may reappear.'\n\nPartly due to specialisation of businesses, said Van Zijderveld, a\nnumber of diseases, like tuberculosis and brucellosis, have\ndisappeared completely. 'In the fifties, many people got TB from\ninfected cattle. That was the main reason for pasteurising milk,\nregular animal testing and the removal of infected animals from the\npopulation. Since 1990, we are officially a tuberculosis-free\ncountry,' Van Zijderveld said.\n\nProfessor Coutinho was involved in round table discussions at the\nministry of agriculture in 2007. 'I am amazed that people believe\nrisks can be eradicated,' he said at the time. 'I believe there is a\nlot we can't predict. All it takes is one incident, and the\nconsequences are huge. The image of the industry in society can turn\ncompletely.' One of the other speakers replied: 'That is what we do\nin agriculture, we only change after incidents and the reactions they evoke.'\n\n[Byline: Hans van der Lugt]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n Today, the Netherlands suffers\nfrom an outbreak of Q-fever among goats; 3 years ago it was hit by an\noutbreak of bluetongue (catarrhal fever); in 2003 bird flu (avian\ninfluenza) was an issue; foot-and-mouth struck in 2001, and classical\nswine fever ruled in 1997. \n\nChildren's petting farms and all other holdings with a public\nfunction [e.g. nursing homes etc.] will be obliged to secure that\nbirthings of pregnant goats and sheep will take place in enclosed\nspaces fully separated from the public. 23(2) [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=8842>\n\n\nQ fever, Netherlands\n--------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 13 Jan 2010 from Mr Peter W de\nLeeuw, Chief Veterinary Officer, Food Quality and Animal Health,\nMinistry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, La Haye, Netherlands\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nStart date: 1 Oct 2009\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event: 12 Nov 2009\nReport date: 13 Jan 2010\nDate submitted to OIE: 13 Jan 2010\nReason for notification: unexpected increase in morbidity or mortality\nof a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Coxiella burnetii_\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: There are 63 outbreaks of Q fever at this\nmoment in the Netherlands.\n\nNote by the OIE's Animal Health Information Department: after\ninvestigation, the reason for notification has been changed from 'new\nstrain of a listed disease' to 'unexpected increase in incidence of a\nlisted disease'. This report replaces the immediate notification\nreport published on 29 Dec 2009 and having for reason 'new strain of a\nlisted disease'.\n\nIncreased distribution\nDisease impact\n[The incidence of the disease in animals has been recorded in the\nfollowing provinces]:\n\nProvince /species / Incidence change\n\nNoord-Brabant / goats / from 1 to 4\nDrenthe / goats / from 0 to 2\nGroningen / goats / from 0 to 2\nLimburg / goats / from 0 to 2\nOverijssel / goats / from 0 to 2\nUtrecht / goats / from 0 to 2\nZuid-Holland / goats / from 0 to 2\nGelderland / goats / from 0 to 2\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; The situation on\nsheep farms (both dairy and mutton flocks) is to be discussed on\nWednesday [27 Jan 2010] in an emergency debate in the House with\nMinisters Verburg (Agriculture) and Klink (Public Health).\n\nEarlier this week, it was suggested by MD Ronald Schegget of the\nPublic Health Service in Southeast Brabant that there is a linkage\nbetween 46 human cases of Q fever in Nuenen and the 12 000 visitors\nto the lamb-viewing days at a (mutton-type) sheep farm in Nuenen.\n\nAhead of the parliamentary debate, the ministers will clarify their\npolicy concerning measures against Q fever on sheep farms in a letter\naddressed to the House. So far, bulk-milk tests were the mode upon\nwhich actions on [dairy] sheep farms were determined. Mutton-sheep\nhave not been addressed so far [in relation to the current Q fever epidemic].\n\nIn the due emergency debate, the VVD party (Dutch liberal party) will\nargue for a parliamentary investigation into the control of Q-fever.\nAccording to the VVD, the inquiry set up [see 20100112.0144] has no\naccess to the cabinet's files. Various research reports and other\ndocuments have shown that the Q fever bacteria were found already in\n2005 on goat farms in the south of the country, but their locations\nhave remained secret.\n\nIn 2007, the disease was found for the 1st time in humans. Only at\nthe end of 2009, the government decided to adopt drastic control\nmeasures. According to the Ministry of Public Health and The National\nInstitute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM), 6 out of the\nalmost 3600 Q fever patients have died.\n\nThe physician-microbiologist Peter Wever (Jeroen Bosch Hospital) has,\nfollowing his survey covering 12 hospitals, counted at least 11\nfatalities. 'Our reported 6 fatalities might be an underestimate. We\ndepend upon notifications from the Public Health Service, which\nreport all disease cases but not all fatalities,' acknowledges the\nspokesperson of RIVM.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The nomination of the investigation committee of the Q fever (Qf)\nepidemic by ministers Verborg (Agriculture) and Klink (Public health)\nwas completed on 20 Jan 2010.
