Netherlands (03): update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=361661", "date": "2010-01-07 20:00:03", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (03): UPDATE\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 6 Jan 2010\nSource: Dutch Ministry of Agriculture press release [trans. by\ncommunicator, abridged, edited]\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/portal/page?_pageid=116,1640333&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_news_item_id=24977>\n\n\n6 Jan 2010 Ministries update\n-----------------------------\nMinisters Verburg (LNV/Agriculture) and Klink (VWS/Public Health)\nhave sent a letter to Parliament today [6 Jan 2010] about the\nactivities regarding Q-fever control. This press release covers the\nmain points included in that letter, as well as information on\nmodifications for bulk milk monitoring and other current issues\npresented hereunder.\n\n1. Update on the cullings\n-------------------------\nAt the moment, 61 farms have been declared contaminated, based on\nbulk milk testing results. We expect to have the results of the\ncurrent [biweekly] bulk milk tests next week. At 24 contaminated\nfarms, animals have been examined for pregnancy to distinguish the\npregnant and not-pregnant. Subsequently, all pregnant animals on\nthese farms have been valued. So far, a total of 8724 animals on 21\nfarms have been culled.\n\n2. Small-scale farms and children's/petting farms\n-----------------------------------------\nMinister Klink has asked the experts' group [see comment] to advise\nhim about the health risks of Q-fever at children's farms, farms with\nless than 50 animals and farms with a public function [e.g. nursing\nhomes etc.]. According to the experts, no extra measures need to be\ntaken regarding this cluster of farms.\n\nThe experts believe that direct contact with sheep and goats is not a\nrisk factor. Recent research data also show that Q-fever bacteria are\nhardly ever found at children's farms. There are no indications that\nchildren's farms and other small-scale farms have a higher health\nrisk to the public.\n\nThe experts advised, however, to pay special attention to hygiene\nmeasures. Therefore, a hygiene protocol will be made for the\nsmall-scale sheep and goat farms. As soon as this protocol is\navailable, it will be published on the website page 'Hobbydierhouders\nen dierhouders met een publieke functie' (Hobby animal holders and\nanimal keepers with a public function).\n\nNotification to the VWA (Food Safety Authority) in case of an\nabnormal number of abortions, has long been obligatory for hobby\nanimal holders and animal keepers with a public function (like\nchildren's farms). After notification, the VWA used to investigate\nthe farm as a standard procedure; until recently, such holdings were\ntested for _Brucella melitensis_ bacteria (causing Brucellosis).\nCurrently, such notifications will be followed also by testing for\nthe Q-fever bacteria (_Coxiella burnetii_).\n\n3. Mutton sheep farms\n---------------------\nThe experts' group led by the RIVM (National Institute for Public\nHealth and Environment) has already advised on 24 Jul 2009 that\nmutton-type sheep farms pose no risk within the Q-fever epidemic.\nHowever, large numbers of ewes are soon to start lambing in the huge\nstraw-bedding stables at the large-scale mutton-type sheep farms.\nTherefore, it has been decided that for these large-scale farms, the\nsame precautionary policy will be applied as for small-scale farms\nwith less than 50 ruminants. Hence, the advice addressing the hygiene\nprotocol for small-scale farms and children's farms will be also\napplied in the mutton producing farms.\n\n4. Judicial verdict\n-------------------\nOn 4 Jan 2010, the judge of the Board of Appeal for Commerce and\nIndustry has issued a sentence on account of the request from a goat\nkeeper to spare from culling the animals which were kept in a\ndifferent location than the holding found infected, although both\ngroups of animals were registered under the same company number as\nthe infected farm. The request from this goat keeper has been denied.\nAccording to the judge, both locations are connected units of one\ncompany, as goats have been taken from one location to the other. At\nthe location which, according to the goat keeper, was Q-fever free,\noffspring of goats from the infected holding are kept. The latter was\nfound infected by means of the bulk milk tests. Besides, the goats on\nthe Q-fever 'free' location have not all been vaccinated on time. The\nfull text of the judge's sentence (verdict No BK8183 is available at\n<http://www.rechtspraak.nl/Gerechten/CBb/Actualiteiten/Doden+van+drachtige+en+mannelijke+geiten+op+beide+locat!\n\nies+toegestaan.htm>.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nChristine Bijl\nEuropean Livestock Association (ELA) Secretary\n<Christinebijl@gmail.com>\n\n[Thanks to Christine Bijl, as well as to Mary Marshall and Sabine\nZentis for their share in obtaining the above information.\n\nThe letter VDC 09.2949/CPM of the Agriculture Minister to the Dutch\nParliament, dated 6 Jan 2010, is accompanied by 2 letters (23 Dec\n2009, 5 Jan 2010), addressed to both ministries by Prof Roel\nCoutinho, Director of the Centre for Infectious Disease Control of\nthe RIVM [National Dutch Institute for Public Health and the\nEnvironment]. The 2 letters include the detailed replies to new\nqueries from the 2 Ministries requesting scientific advice concerning\nissues raised during the epidemic. The RIVM response is based upon\nconsultations of experts, principally veterinarians, physicians and\nmicrobiologists. The consultations are chaired by Prof Coutinho, and\nthe secretary of the body is Dr Jim van Steenbergen, RIVM. The lists\nof the experts involved are attached to each advisory response.\nEarlier meetings of the experts group were conducted on 11 and 30 Nov\n2009, similarly chaired by Prof Coutinho. Several written advices,\nagreed to by the experts, have already been attached to Ministers'\nletters to the Parliament (e.g. 16 Dec 2009). All interested in the\nvarious aspects (e.g. scientific-professional, political, social,\neconomic etc.) of coordinated control of emerging or re-emerging\nzoonotic diseases are certainly following with great interest the\nevolvement and management of the Dutch Q fever epidemic. - Mod.AS]\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 7 Jan 2010 (accessed)\nSource: Applied & Environmental Microbiology Vol. 75, No. 2, 2009, pp\n428-433 [edited]\n<http://aem.asm.org/cgi/reprint/75/2/428.pdf>\n\n\n_Coxiella burnetii_ Shedding Routes and Antibody Response after\nOutbreaks of Q Fever-Induced Abortion in Dairy Goat Herds\n---------------------------------\nAbstract\nQ fever is a zoonosis caused by _Coxiella burnetii_, a bacterium\nlargely carried by ruminants and shed into milk, vaginal mucus, and\nfeces. The main potential hazard to humans and animals is due to\nshedding of bacteria that can then persist in the environment and be\naerosolized. The purpose of this study was to evaluate shedding after\nan outbreak of Q fever abortion in goat herds and to assess the\nrelationship with the occurrence of abortions and antibody responses.\nAborting and nonaborting goats were monitored by PCR for _C.\nburnetii_ shedding 15 and 30 days after the abortion episodes. PCR\nanalysis of all samples showed that 70 percent (n 50) of the aborting\nand 53 percent (n 70) of the non-aborting goats were positive. _C.\nburnetii_ was shed into vaginal mucus, feces, and milk of 44, 21, and\n38 percent, respectively, of goats that aborted and 27, 20, and 31\npercent, respectively, of goats that delivered normally. Statistical\ncomparison of these shedding results did not reveal any difference\nbetween these 2 groups. PCR results obtained for the vaginal and\nfecal routes were concordant in 81 percent of cases, whereas those\nfor milk correlated with only 49 percent of cases with either vaginal\nor fecal shedding status. Serological analysis, using enzyme-linked\nimmunosorbent assay (ELISA), indirect immunofluorescence assay (IFA),\nand complement fixation tests showed that at least 24 percent of the\nseronegative goats shed bacteria. Positive vaginal and fecal\nshedding, unlike positive milk shedding, was observed more often in\nanimals that were weakly positive or negative by ELISA or IFA. Two\nopposite shedding trends were thus apparent for the milk and\nvaginal-fecal routes. Moreover, this study showed that a\nnon-negligible proportion of seronegative animals that delivered\nnormally could excrete _C. burnetii_.\n\n[Byline: Elodie Rousset, Mustapha Berri, Benoit Durand, Philippe\nDufour, Myriam Prigent, Thibault Delcroix, Anne Touratier, and Annie Rodolakis]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "On 4 Jan 2010, the judge of the Board of Appeal for Commerce and\nIndustry has issued a sentence on account of the request from a goat\nkeeper to spare from culling the animals which were kept in a\ndifferent location than the holding found infected, although both\ngroups of animals were registered under the same company number as\nthe infected farm. The experts' group led by the RIVM (National Institute for Public\nHealth and Environment) has already advised on 24 Jul 2009 that\nmutton-type sheep farms pose no risk within the Q-fever epidemic.\n _C.\nburnetii_ was shed into vaginal mucus, feces, and milk of 44, 21, and\n38 percent, respectively, of goats that aborted and 27, 20, and 31\npercent, respectively, of goats that delivered normally. \n\nNotification to the VWA (Food Safety Authority) in case of an\nabnormal number of abortions, has long been obligatory for hobby\nanimal holders and animal keepers with a public function (like\nchildren's farms). PCR results obtained for the vaginal and\nfecal routes were concordant in 81 percent of cases, whereas those\nfor milk correlated with only 49 percent of cases with either vaginal\nor fecal shedding status. Serological analysis, using enzyme-linked\nimmunosorbent assay (ELISA), indirect immunofluorescence assay (IFA),\nand complement fixation tests showed that at least 24 percent of the\nseronegative goats shed bacteria. As soon as this protocol is\navailable, it will be published on the website page 'Hobbydierhouders\nen dierhouders met een publieke functie' (Hobby animal holders and\nanimal keepers with a public function). This press release covers the\nmain points included in that letter, as well as information on\nmodifications for bulk milk monitoring and other current issues\npresented hereunder. Source: Dutch Ministry of Agriculture press release [trans. by\ncommunicator, abridged, edited]\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/portal/page?_pageid=116,1640333&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_news_item_id=24977>\n\n\n6 Jan 2010 Ministries update\n----------------------------- Hence, the advice addressing the hygiene\nprotocol for small-scale farms and children's farms will be also\napplied in the mutton producing farms. Therefore, it has been decided that for these large-scale farms, the\nsame precautionary policy will be applied as for small-scale farms\nwith less than 50 ruminants. There are no indications that\nchildren's farms and other small-scale farms have a higher health\nrisk to the public. Positive vaginal and fecal\nshedding, unlike positive milk shedding, was observed more often in\nanimals that were weakly positive or negative by ELISA or IFA. However, large numbers of ewes are soon to start lambing in the huge\nstraw-bedding stables at the large-scale mutton-type sheep farms.\n PCR\nanalysis of all samples showed that 70 percent (n 50) of the aborting\nand 53 percent (n 70) of the non-aborting goats were positive. At 24 contaminated\nfarms, animals have been examined for pregnancy to distinguish the\npregnant and not-pregnant. At\nthe location which, according to the goat keeper, was Q-fever free,\noffspring of goats from the infected holding are kept. The purpose of this study was to evaluate shedding after\nan outbreak of Q fever abortion in goat herds and to assess the\nrelationship with the occurrence of abortions and antibody responses. The Animal Health Service (GD) examines bulk tank milk samples\nfor the presence of _Coxiella burnetii_ (Q fever). In most sheep and\ngoat farms, these samples are collected by the GD. Some farmers,\nhowever, send their samples to the GD independently. Following the\nmodification in the regulations, the DG will collect samples from\nthese farms directly, similarly to all other farms. By this\narrangement, the quality of the samples and the reliability of the\nresearch results will improve. This regulation addresses about 50 out\nof the 411 sheep and goat farms. The changes take effect on 30 Dec\n2009, at 4.00 pm.\n\nCompulsory periodic bulk tank milk monitoring has been introduced in\nthe Netherlands as of 1 Oct 2009. Its purpose is to detect, by\nfrequent testing, newly infected farms. The monitoring frequency is,\nas of 14 Dec 2009, increased to once every 2 weeks. [The initial\nrequired sampling frequency was once in 2 months; the revision is\nexplained by the fact that excretion of the bacterium may be\nintermittent. - Mod.AS]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The given number of monitored farms, 411, most probably does not\ninclude the 61 farms already declared infected, in which all pregnant\nanimals are to be culled (a measure already under application). The\nmonitoring system addresses farms with more than 50 lactating\nanimals. These make only part of the Dutch goat and sheep industries,\nwith a total of 350 000 goats and at least 1.2 million sheep (2008\nfigures; reportedly, there are also several hundred-thousand sheep\nkept in non-commercial holdings as 'hobby animals'). While most goats\nare milk producers, most sheep are kept for mutton production. The\ncurrent monitoring addresses only dairy sheep, the number of which\nbeing rather low (how many farms?). However, sheep are regarded, in\nmany countries, as the major Q fever reservoir, excreting the\npathogen mainly during the lambing season. Data on serosurveillance\nin Dutch sheep, and the number of dairy goat farms with less than 50\nanimals, will be of epidemiological interest.\n\nMore than 75 years following its initial discovery (in Hamilton,\nMontana, USA and in Melbourne, Queensland, Australia) there are still\nmany 'queries' regarding Q or query fever. These relate, mainly, to\nthe epidemiology of the disease in animals and man and to the\ncharacteristics of the microorganism. Investigations by the Dutch\nresearchers have already provided some interesting results, such as\nthe initial findings that the bacterium can be detected in air\nsamples, shortly after the outbreak, at distances of 500 and 1000 m\n(0.3-0.6 mi] around the infected dairy goat farm. However, the\nduration of detectability of the bacteria in the air is not yet known.\n\nThe current outbreak of unprecedented magnitude in a highly\nindustrialised, densely populated country with a (still) strong\nagrarian sector may provide a unique opportunity for research in\norder to obtain answers to some of the pending queries. The effort,\nwhich seems to be invested by the researchers, eventually backed by\nthe government, is promising. - Mod.AS]\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of The Netherlands is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00S1>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 30 Dec 2009\n Investigations by the Dutch\nresearchers have already provided some interesting results, such as\nthe initial findings that the bacterium can be detected in air\nsamples, shortly after the outbreak, at distances of 500 and 1000 m\n(0.3-0.6 mi] around the infected dairy goat farm. Why are all pregnant animals on infected large dairy\nfarms culled, while those in small holdings and children's farms are\nnot? Is this not a double standard? The answer is: It seems so, but\nthere are good reasons for the distinction.\n\nAll control measures are considered from a public health point of\nview. During 2009, 2300 people became ill in the Netherlands from the\nQ fever bacterium. Therefore, everything is now focused on the aim to\nreduce this number as far as possible over the coming years.\n\nCulling in infected, large-scale holdings\n-----------------------------------\nThe greatest risk to public health is posed by large groups of\npregnant dairy goats and sheep, which excrete very large quantities of\nthe Q fever bacteria during normal birthing or abortions. This was\nindicated in the advice received from the expert group led by Roel\nCoutinho of RIVM (the Dutch National Institute for Public Health and\nEnvironment). If an infected goat gives birth to a live lamb, millions\nof Q-fever bacteria are released; in case of an abortion, their\nnumbers go into the billions.\n\nIn large farms, most matings are managed to take place within a short\nperiod, or mating is synchronised, leading to the birth of many\nanimals taking place during comparatively short periods, many on the\nsame days. Similarly, abortions, if occurring, may involve many\nanimals, sometimes taking the form of abortion 'storms.' In case those\nanimals are infected by Q fever, this means the excretion of very\nlarge quantities of bacteria by many animals simultaneously: This is\nthe greatest threat to public health. Consequently, the presence of\ninfected pregnant animals on the farm should be prevented ahead of the\nlambing season (which usually starts in January). Since individual\ntesting of animals in the short term is not possible, all pregnant\nanimals on infected farms should be culled. [Subscribers are also\nreferred to the research paper cited in the commentary to posting\n20100107.0079. The authors indicated, among other things, that 'the\nstudy showed that a non-negligible [i.e. epidemiologically significant\n- Mod.JW] proportion of seronegative animals that delivered normally\ncould excrete _C. burnetii_.' - Mod.AS]\n\nSaving animals on children's farms\n---------------------------------\nQ fever may infect sheep and goats also on petting farms, small\nholders' yards or occupational therapeutic farms ('businesses with a\npublic function'.) The difference between these farms and large\nmilk-producing goat or sheep farms is the number of animals crowded\ntogether and birthing (or aborting) simultaneously. In small-scale\nfarms, there are fewer animals in a state of Q fever bacteria\nsecretion. Therefore, these holdings pose a lower risk to human\nhealth, and the pregnant animals on these farms are not culled.\n\nResearch shows that, so far, the Q fever bacterium has hardly ever\nbeen found in children's farms. Yet, visitors to petting farms where Q\nfever-infected sheep or goats are kept may always be exposed to some\nrisk of getting infected.\n\nThe RIVM-led expert group was asked to provide advice pertaining to\nthe said risk on petting farms or other small-scale holdings with less\nthan 50 animals. According to experts, it is generally not necessary\nto take additional measures concerning such holdings.\n\nHowever, it was recommended to pay special attention to hygiene on\nchildren's farms. In addition, children's ('petting') farms and\noccupational therapeutic farms are advised to let the birthing take\nplace in separate pens without pubic access. This will prevent contact\nbetween infected birthing or aborting animals and visitors, and the\nexcretion of bacteria close to visitors, and further diminish the risk\nof infection.\n\nFurthermore, it has been decided that petting and therapeutic farms\nwill be vaccinated with priority. Fortunately, there is vaccine enough\navailable for all such establishments.\n\nAdults and children visiting petting farms are advised to pay\nattention to hygiene. Appropriate advisory information is available on\nthe website of the VWA (Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Additional explanation on the significant weight of the large dairy\ngoat farms in the large-scale dissemination of _C. burnetii_ can be\nfound in the advisory letter to Ministers sent by Prof Coutinho on 17\nJul 2009. It provided several examples demonstrating the temporal and\nspatial association between large, infected dairy goat farms and human\ninfection. The 1st example (2007) came from Herpen village, where many\nhuman infections were recorded around a goat farm with an abortion\nstorm. A significant case was that of Helmond town in 2008: the\npercentage of infected humans increased in proportion to the proximity\nof their dwellings to a large dairy goat establishment. Similar\nfindings of measurable connections were recorded in South Limburg.\n\nA map showing all commercial dairy goat/sheep flocks regarded infected\nas of 8 Jan 2010, indicating the 5-km zone around each, is available\nat\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/gebiedskaart_100108_tcm92-65083.pdf>.\n\nA map showing municipalities with notified Q fever patients (per 100\n000), 1 Jan-22 Dec 2009, as well as the locations of infected\ncommercial dairy goat farms, is available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/Q-koorts%20incidentie_tcm92-60500.pdf>.\n\nA 62nd infected farm has been officially added to the list on 9 Jan\n2010, located in Een West in Drente province. The holding includes 450\ngoats, 249 of them pregnant; those are to be culled on 11 Jan 2010\n(today).\n\nThe Dutch delegation is expected to present an updating report on the\nQ fever situation during the next meeting of the EU's Standing\nCommittee on the Food Chain and Animal Health (SCFCAH), due in\nBrussels on Tue 12 Jan 2010. The last report on the issue (dated 6 Oct\n2009) was presented during the 3 Nov 2009 meeting (available at\n<http://ec.europa.eu/food/committees/regulatory/scfcah/animal_health/presentations/0304112009_q_fever_nl.pdf>).\n\nThose interested in additional information may refer to the paper 'Q\nfever outbreaks in small ruminants and people in the Netherlands' by\nR. Van den Brom & P. Vellema in Small Ruminant Research 86 (2009)\n74-79. Journal homepage: <http://www.elsevier.com/locate/smallrumres>.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 8 Jan 2010\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Additional explanation on the significant weight of the large dairy\ngoat farms in the large-scale dissemination of _C. burnetii_ can be\nfound in the advisory letter to Ministers sent by Prof Coutinho on 17\n \n\nA map showing municipalities with notified Q fever patients (per 100\n000), 1 Jan-22 Dec 2009, as well as the locations of infected\ncommercial dairy goat farms, is available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/Q-koorts%20incidentie_tcm92-60500.pdf>. ---------------------------------\nQ fever may infect sheep and goats also on petting farms, small\nholders' yards or occupational therapeutic farms ('businesses with a\npublic function'.) Vellema in Small Ruminant Research 86 (2009)\n The message that ministers Verburg (LNV) and Klink (VWS) had decided\nto refrain from culling goats in children's petting farms and\neducational institutions [see posting 20100107.0079 ] has prompted\nmany questions. \n\nThe Dutch delegation is expected to present an updating report on the\nQ fever situation during the next meeting of the EU's Standing\nCommittee on the Food Chain and Animal Health (SCFCAH), due in\nBrussels on Tue 12 Jan 2010. The difference between these farms and large\nmilk-producing goat or sheep farms is the number of animals crowded\ntogether and birthing (or aborting) simultaneously. Yet, visitors to petting farms where Q\nfever-infected sheep or goats are kept may always be exposed to some\nrisk of getting infected. In addition, children's ('petting') farms and\noccupational therapeutic farms are advised to let the birthing take\nplace in separate pens without pubic access. The RIVM-led expert group was asked to provide advice pertaining to\nthe said risk on petting farms or other small-scale holdings with less\nthan 50 animals. It provided several examples demonstrating the temporal and\nspatial association between large, infected dairy goat farms and human\ninfection.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-01-09 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-01-12 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-25 00:00:00", "2010-01-11 00:00:00", "2010-01-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "South Limburg", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Drente province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Een West", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Verburg", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "366325", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands (07): update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=366325", "date": "2010-01-15 23:00:11", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (07): UPDATE\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri 15 Jan 2010\nSource: Science Magazine [abridged, edited]\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/summary/327/5963/266-a>\n(abstract; the full article requires a subscription)\n\n\n[Ref: Enserink M: Questions abound in Q-fever explosion in the\nNetherlands. Science 2010 Jan; 327(5963): 266-7]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nIn the United States, Q fever is classified as a 'Category B'\nbioterrorism agent because it would be relatively easy to use and\nbecause, although not as deadly as anthrax or plague, attacks could\nstill create widespread disease and panic. The US Army exposed human\nvolunteers to it as part of its biowarfare program in the 1950s; the\nSoviet Union experimented with it as well, as did the Japanese cult\nAum Shinrikyo, known for its 1995 sarin attack. Bioterror worries\nbrought more attention to it in the 1990s and prompted the United\nStates to make it reportable in 1999. This increased awareness --\nalong with better diagnostic tests -- may explain the rising number of\nreported outbreaks of Q fever over the past 10 years worldwide, says\nepidemiologist Didier Raoult of the Universite de la Mediterranee in\nMarseille, France, the foremost expert in human Q fever. 'Once you\nstart looking for Q fever, you'll find more and more of it,' he says.\n\nBut what is going on in the Netherlands now is not just better\ndetection but something new and different, says epidemiologist Roel\nCoutinho, head of the Centre for Infectious Disease Control in\nBilthoven. When 182 human cases were detected in and around a town\ncalled Herpen in the summer of 2007, it seemed like a one-off\noutbreak. But in 2008, a new wave erupted, quickly filling up\nintensive-care units in the province of Noord-Brabant. A thousand\ncases were reported that year. In 2009, the number of new cases jumped\nto almost 2200, and the disease was found across the country. It is\nstill unclear what is behind the massive spread. Part of the reason\nhas to be the recent expansion of high-intensity goat farming in the\ndensely populated country, says Coutinho. The number of goats has\nquadrupled in Holland to more then 350 000 since 1995, and the number\nof them per farm has tripled; the country is now home to some of the\nbiggest goat farms in the world. (In a sad twist of fate, some farmers\nswitched to goats after a devastating swine flu outbreak ruined the\nDutch pig industry in the 1990s.) Farms are often close together, and\nanimals are frequently transported between them, presumably\nfacilitating spread, says Coutinho. Bacteria released during abortions\nend up in manure, which is often spread onto farm fields; the wind may\nhave carried them to the many surrounding towns and cities.\n\nBut Hendrik-Jan Roest, a scientist at the Central Veterinary Institute\nof Wageningen UR in Lelystad, says the sudden increase could be linked\nto a more virulent subtype of the microbe that started spreading in\nabout 2005. Genetic typing by Corne Klaassen at Canisius Wilhelmina\nHospital in Nijmegen has shown that all Dutch farms and patients are\ninfected by a single subtype of _C. burnetii_. That suggests that the\nstrain is somehow better at propagating itself than others, Roest\nsays. He plans to compare strains in a collaborative study with Annie\nRodolakis of the French National Institute for Agricultural Research\nin Tours, who has developed a mouse model of Q fever.\n\nA more urgent question is how to bring the outbreak under control. In\n2008, veterinary and public health authorities hoped that hygienic\nmeasures, such as a ban on distributing manure on farm fields, would\nhelp reduce human exposure. Now, the hope is that an animal vaccine\nproduced by CEVA, a French company, can help bring the microbe under\ncontrol. In short supply in 2008 and 2009, the vaccine will be\nplentiful this year [2010], says Christianne Bruschke, chief\nveterinary officer at the agriculture ministry. The vaccine does not\nprevent all infections, but it does prevent most abortions, which\nshould help curtail the spread of the disease. The vaccine does not\nwork in infected animals, however, which is why an expert panel\nrecommended in early December [2009] the emergency slaughter of all\npregnant goats at affected farms. (There is no reliable way to quickly\ndistinguish infected goats from healthy goats.) Bruschke says the cull\nis a one-time measure to prevent another massive release of microbes\nin the spring of 2010, when the goats would normally give birth. Then\nfrom 2011 on, the effects of the vaccine should start kicking in.\n\nThe impact on some farmers could be devastating, says Van Lokven. The\nDutch government reimburses farmers for the current value of the goats\nbut doesn't do so for the loss of income while they rebuild their\nflocks. How well the measure will work is unclear as well. The huge\nnumbers of _C. burnetii_ already in the environment may persist for\nmonths or years; there is no good way to measure their numbers or to\nassess the threat they pose, says Roest. And there are many other\nquestions. Although there is little doubt that goat farms are key\namplifiers in the current outbreak, the role of cattle farms is unclear.\n\nFor now, most experts say another surge of human cases this spring\n[2010] is inevitable -- they just hope it will be smaller than that of\n2009.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 15 Jan 2010\nSource: Science Magazine [edited]\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/summary/327/5963/266-b>\n(abstract; the full article requires a subscription)\n\n\n[Ref: Enserink M: Humans, animals -- It's One Health. Or is it?\nScience 2010 Jan; 327(5963): 266-7]\n---------------------------------------------\nA 'holistic approach' and 'synergism' working for the health of all\nspecies. Those are the buzzwords of the One Health movement, which\naims to bring veterinary and human health closer together. Because\npeople and animals form such a close-knit ecosystem -- and most new or\nre-emerging diseases come from animals -- the classic divide between\nveterinarians and doctors is hampering disease control, 3 scientists\nargued when they began promoting the concept 3 years ago (Science, 15\nJun 2007, p. 1553).\n\nBut the Dutch Q-fever outbreak provides a vivid example of how those 2\nworlds often don't get along, especially when the stakes are different\nfor each. Public health officials have complained that the veterinary\ncommunity didn't properly inform them and that the outbreak spiraled\nout of control in part because economic interests trumped human\nhealth. 'Sure, One Health, it's a nice concept, but we clearly have a\nlong way to go,' says Roel Coutinho, head of the Centre for Infectious\nDisease Control.\n\nWhat makes Q fever tricky is that the vast majority of animals are\nhealthy and asymptomatic, says French epidemiologist Didier Raoult of\nthe Universite de la Mediterranee in Marseille, France. The disease\ndoes trigger some abortion and premature birth, but the economic\ndamage is limited, so there's little incentive to do anything about an\noutbreak. 'The vets don't care about it,' says Raoult -- and human\nhealth suffers as a result.\n\nAnimal health authorities were slow to investigate suspected farms\neven as human cases started pouring into hospitals in 2008, says Jos\nvan de Sande, a doctor at a regional health service in Noord-Brabant,\nthe hardest-hit province. To protect farmers from stigmatization, van\nde Sande and his colleagues weren't told the exact location of\ncontaminated holdings, only the general area. 'You can't fight an\nepidemic like that,' he says. Coutinho adds: 'We just weren't able to\nget across how serious the human problem was getting.'\n\nChristianne Bruschke, the country's chief veterinary officer,\ndismisses those claims. From the onset, policy was set by a working\ngroup with members from both the agriculture and the health ministries\n-- and it included Coutinho and other scientists. 'They should have\nspoken up before if they disagreed,' says Bruschke. She says the\ngovernment had to strike a balance between farmers\u0092 interests and\npublic health in the face of insufficient data about how Q fever\nspread: 'You can't impose draconian measures on farmers if you have no\nidea whether they will have an effect.'\n\nThe Dutch government plans to investigate how the epidemic was\nhandled. The article was included in ProMED-mail's posting\n20090814.2889.\n\n'Veterinary situation\n---------------------\nThe total number of registered small ruminant farms in the Netherlands\nis 52 000, of which 350 are professional dairy goat farms with more\nthan 200 adult goats, and 40 are professional dairy sheep farms. In\n2005, Q fever was diagnosed for the 1st time as a cause of abortion at\na dairy goat farm, using immunohistochemistry on sections of placenta.\nA 2nd case was diagnosed later in 2005. In 2006, 2007 and 2008, 6, 7,\nand 7 new cases at dairy goat farms were confirmed, respectively,\nmainly in the same area where human cases occurred. In the same\nperiod, 2 cases of abortion caused by _C. burnetii_ were confirmed at\ndairy sheep farms, one in the southern and one in the northern part of\nthe country, but these 2 cases do not seem to be related to human\ncases. Analyses of abortion outbreaks showed that the average number\nof goats per farm was 900, of which 20 percent aborted, ranging from\n10-60 per cent. The average number of sheep on both infected sheep\nfarms was 400, and the abortion rate was 5 per cent.\n\nAbortion outbreaks before June 2008 were reported on a voluntary basis\nto the Animal Health Service and also confirmed by\nimmunohistochemistry. Since June 2008, notification of Q fever in\ngoats and sheep is mandatory in the Netherlands. There is a legal\nrequirement for farmers and their private veterinary surgeons to\nnotify the occurrence of abortion in small ruminants held in deep\nlitter houses. For large farms (greater than 100 animals), the\nnotification criterion is an abortion wave defined as an abortion\npercentage higher than 5 per cent among pregnant animals. For smaller\nholdings, a criterion of 3 or more abortions in a 30 day period is\nused. From January to April 2009, this new regulation has led to\nnotification of 3 dairy goat farms with clinical cases of Q fever. One\nfarm is located in the province of Overijssel (notified in February\n2009), one in the south of the province of Limburg (notified in March\n2009), and one in the province of Noord-Brabant (notified in April\n2009). This veterinary notification can potentially facilitate the\ndetection of related human cases or clusters. Veterinarians,\nphysicians, and the public are informed through targeted mailings,\npublications, and the media. The exact location of animal farms with\nclinical Q fever is now reported to the municipal health service. In\nFebruary 2009, a nationwide stringent hygiene protocol became\nmandatory for all professional dairy goat and sheep farms, independent\nof Q fever status.'\n\nThe evolution of the Q fever situation in the Netherlands since 2005\nis unprecedented in its public health implications. _C. burnetii_ has\nreportedly been spreading by air, affecting thousands of humans,\nincluding city dwellers who had not got closer than 1000 meters (0.6\nmi) or even more to the animals which are suspected to be the\nreservoir and amplifiers of the agent. In hindsight, investigators may\nnow suppose that active surveillance covering all goats, sheep (why\nexclude cattle?!) farms in North Brabant and Gelderland should have\nstarted in 2007, when the 1st human cases were reported. To the best\nof this moderator's knowledge, no such measure has been undertaken\nglobally elsewhere, in situations such as the one seen in 2007 in the\nsouth of the Netherlands; there are several descriptions of such\nscenarios. Q fever is known to cause abortions in small and large\nruminants globally (New Zealand is the known exception); human\ninfections with _C. Burnetii_ , allegedly of animal origin, have been\nrecorded in the past in various countries, but did not lead to\nwide-scale, compulsory, meticulous, active surveillance encompassing\nwhole regions or countries. In the unfortunate absence of\nclairvoyance, no such surveillance was undertaken before the epidemic\ntook its eventual dimensions. This, in difference with another,\n'classical' zoonosis, namely brucellosis, where 'test and slaughter'\npolicy, or 'modified stamping out', sometimes combined with or\nreplaced by vaccination, were the prescribed modus operandi. The\nbackground to this difference, and lessons to be learned, may be\nincluded in the shortly expected investigation of this exceptional\nevent.\n\nShould active surveillance be contemplated (selectively?) whenever\nanimals are suspected to harbour or spread a disease agent with\nzoonotic potential? An interesting question, with a broad spectrum of\ntheoretical and practical ramifications and far-reaching economical\nimplications. A 33-year-old man was\ndiagnosed with the illness on Monday [14 Dec 2009], and has since\nrecovered fully with treatment. A 31 [year-old] woman was diagnosed\non Thursday [17 Dec 2009] and is in a satisfactory condition.\n\nSA Health's Chief Medical Officer, Professor Paddy Phillips, said Q\nfever is caught from infected animals, person-to-person spread was\nextremely unlikely, and the risk to the public is low.\n\n'Approximately half of all people infected do not develop symptoms\nand, in the majority of others, illness is mild. Hospitalization and\nserious complications are rare,' Professor Phillips said.\n\n'Infection usually occurs through inhalation of bacteria from animals\nand animal secretions or products, and the incubation period is\nusually between 2 and 4 weeks. The breach of laboratory protocols\noccurred 5 weeks ago and has been thoroughly investigated. The breach\ninvolved a live specimen being transported incorrectly in SA\nPathology's laboratory on Frome Road [in Adelaide].'\n\n'At this stage, SA Pathology cannot confirm a definitive link between\nthe breach in protocol and the positive test results recorded by our\nemployees this week. SA Pathology is also offering screening to any\nemployee who may require it.'\n\nQ Fever is an infection caused by _Coxiella burnetii_, which is\nalmost always related to direct or indirect contact with infected\nanimals. Most people who contract Q fever recover fully with or\nwithout treatment. However some people may develop a chronic illness\nlasting months. Acute and chronic Q fever can be treated with\nantimicrobial agents.\n\nSA Health has consulted with the Public Services Association, who\nwill provide additional advice and support to SA Pathology employees.\n\n[Posted by Hal Newman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The circumstances of the breach in laboratory protocol are not\nspelled out. Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.agriholland.nl/dossiers/qkoorts/#hoeveel>\n\n\nHow many dairy sheep and dairy goats are there in the Netherlands?\n-----------------------------------------------------------------\nAccording to the 2009 data of the Dutch agricultural census, there\nare 230 000 dairy goats in the Netherlands, distributed among 600\nfarms. About half of them keep more than 100 goats. Most of the goat\nholdings are situated in the provinces Gelderland and Noord Brabant.\nThe number of dairy sheep is estimated to be about 10 000. There are\nabout 40 commercially operational, milk producing sheep farms.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nA Dutch subscriber, in response to ProMED-mail's queries in posting\n20100103.0028.\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 4 Jan 2010\nSource: NRC Daily [Trans. and abridged Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.nrc.nl/binnenland/article2448124.ece/Coutinho_alarmsysteem_voor_dierinfectieziekten>\n\n\nCoutinho: alarm system for animal diseases\n------------------------------------------\nAn alert system should be established, to detect dangerous infectious\ndiseases in cattle and other animals. This was said by infectious\ndisease fighter Roel Coutinho in an interview in this newspaper.\n\nDue to the absence of such an alarm system, said Coutinho, new\ninfectious diseases remain invisible. Such diseases occur on farms\nand threaten man as well. One example is the Q-fever, of which 6\npeople died this year.\n\nCoutinho, Director of the Centre for Infectious Disease Control of\nthe RIVM [National Dutch Institute for Public Health and the\nEnvironment], says this situation drives him to feel 'powerless.' 'I\nthink there should be much more openness about what exactly happens\nin the livestock industry.' Due to the belated intervention in the Q\nfever outbreak, 40 000 pregnant, including healthy, goats are\ncurrently to be killed.\n\nIn the Netherlands, the risk that an animal disease will jump to\nhumans is considerable. There are many animals (119 million), the\ncontact between animals and humans is intense and the population\ndensity is high.\n\nThe Ministry of Agriculture responded, saying that they have all\nanimal diseases 'good in sight.' A spokesman wonders 'whether\nCoutinho is indeed aware of the current state of affairs.' The\nministry does not envisage a need for a change or improvement of the\nexisting systems.\n\n[Byline: Hans van der Lugt and Hester van Santen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Roel Coutinho is also Professor of Epidemiology and Infectious\nDisease Control at the Academic Medical Centre in Amsterdam. For\nadditional background, go to\n<http://www.rivm.nl/en/aboutrivm/organization/cib/cv_contact.jsp>. - Mod.AS]\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Tue 5 Jan 2010\nSource: Agri Holland [Trans. Mod.AS, abridged and edited]\n<http://www.agriholland.nl/nieuws/artikel.html?id=110571>\n\n\nCommission Vaarkamp-Ohl: Combination of anesthesia - euthanasia\nrecommended from animal welfare perspective\n-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe combination: 1st anesthesia, then euthanasia by an experienced\nteam of workers of the Food and Goods Authority in collaboration with\nthe private farm's veterinarian, seems the preferable mode for\nculling of goats from a welfare perspective. This was proposed by the\nVaarkamp-Ohl committee, the welfare committee which has been\nappointed to watch over the measures against Q fever and their\nanimal-welfare-wise responsible application. Their report on the 2nd\nweek of the culling has now been released.\n\nDuring the 2nd week of the operation, the committee paid 2\nunannounced inspections at culling locations in different regions. It\nwas found again that the workers treat the animals with respect and\ncaution. There is virtually no bleat to hear; escape nor anxiety\nbehavior of the animals were not observed. High sedative doses were\nfound to be most effective.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4]\nDate: Sun 3 Jan 2010\nFrom: Miles H Beaman\n<miles.beaman@symbionhealth.com>\n\n\nRe: Commentary in 'Q fever - Netherlands: monitoring - 20100103.0028'\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe human disease was recognised and 1st isolates were achieved in\nguinea pigs, rats, and mice by Derrick in Brisbane, Queensland, in\n1933-5 (reported in The Medical Journal of Australia in 1937). Burnet\nwas able to passage Derrick's isolates in mice in 1935 in Melbourne,\nVictoria, and demonstrated rickettsial-like inclusions in spleens and\nfound it to be a filter-passing 'virus' (also reported in MJA 1937).\nDavis isolated the organism from ticks at Nine Mile Creek in Montana\nin 1935 (reported in 1938). Cox passaged Davis' strain in yolk sacs\nin 1938 at the Rocky Mountain Laboratory in Montana (reported in\n1939). Dyer accidentaly infected himself with one of Cox' isolates in\n1939 at the RML and later demonstrated cross-immunity between this\nisolate and one of Burnet's strains.\n\nHence, Derrick isolated the 1st human strain 6 years before the next\nhuman strain was isolated and 2 years before the 1st arthropod strain.\n\nIt is surprising, therefore, that the organism was not called\n_Derrickia burnetii_.\n\n--\nMiles H Beaman FRACP FRCPA FACTM\nDirector of Pathology, Infectious Diseases Physician\nWestern Diagnostic Pathology\nMyaree\nWA 6154\nAdjunct Professor of Medicine, University of Notre Dame\ne-mail: <miles.beaman@symbionhealth.com>\n\n[Subscribers interested in the deliberations leading to the decision\nto name the Q fever pathogen _Coxiella burnetii_ are referred to the\narticle by Joseph e McDade (1990), 'Naming of an organism', included\nin chapter 1 'Historical aspects of Q fever' of the book 'Q fever.\nVol 1: the disease'. Ed Thomas Marrie. CRC Press. p 17.\n\nFor the convenience of those interested in the early history of the\ndisease and its pathogen, we copy herewith one of the several\navailable manuscripts: Byrne WR. Q fever. (1997). Chapter 26 In:\nMedical Aspects of Chemical and Biological Warfare (Sidell FR,\nTakafugi ET, Franz DR, eds). Washington, DC:TMM Publications,\n1997;523-537. This is a concise history; a comprehensive one is to be\nfound in the 1990 CRC book mentioned above.\n\nHistory\n-------\nQ fever was 1st described in 1937 by Edward Derrick,(17) while he was\nthe Director of Microbiology and Pathology for the Queensland\n(Australia) Health Department at Brisbane. In 1935, he was contacted\nabout a febrile illness that had been occurring among abattoir\nworkers in Brisbane. When routine blood cultures and serologic\ntesting did not reveal a diagnosis, Derrick suspected that he was\ndealing with a new illness. He thoroughly described the clinical\ncharacteristics and designated the disease Q (for query) fever.\nDerricks laboratory investigation demonstrated that it was possible\nto transmit the disease to animals by inoculating guinea pigs and\nmice with the blood of humans suffering from acute Q fever. Although\nDerrick had initially concluded that the infectious agent was a\nvirus, studies of a guinea pig liver emulsion sent to MacFarlane\nBurnet in Melbourne subsequently indicated that the causative\norganism was a rickettsia,(18) according to the terminology used at that time.\n\nInterestingly, Derrick may not have been the 1st to transfer the\ndisease to laboratory animals. Hideyo Noguchi, working at the\nRockefeller Institute in New York City in 1925, may have passed _C\nburnetii_ to guinea pigs from ticks that had been collected at Saw\nTooth Canyon by Ralph Parker at the Rocky Mountain Laboratory in\nHamilton, Montana.(19) This agent, however, was ultimately lost in\nanimal passage.\n\nAbout the same time that the investigations were being done in\nAustralia, Gordon Davis was studying Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever at\nthe Rocky Mountain Laboratory. He observed that a febrile illness\nresulted when ticks collected from the area around the nearby Nine\nMile Creek were allowed to feed on guinea pigs.(20) The disease\nproduced in guinea pigs did not, however, resemble Rocky Mountain\nSpotted Fever. Herald Cox was subsequently able to characterize the\norganism (then called the Nine Mile Agent) as similar to rickettsia\nand to cultivate this organism in the yolk sac membrane of\nembryonated hen eggs. (21) The relation of Q fever to the Nine Mile\nAgent was established by Rolla Dyer, director of the National\nInstitutes of Health at the time, after the spleens of infected mice\nwere sent to him by Burnet. In an event that presaged the problems of\ntransmission of Q fever in laboratory workers, Dyer himself acquired\nacute Q fever during a visit to Hamilton in 1938.(22)\n\nThe work of Ralph Parker, also at the Rocky Mountain Laboratory,\nindicated that ticks are the reservoir of the Nine Mile Agent.\nDerrick had also suspected tick transmission from a primary\nreservoir, and from a secondary reservoir of domestic animals. The\nsignificance of exposure to parturient animals was not, however,\nrecognized until 1950.\n\nThe causative agent of Q fever was ultimately designated _Coxiella\nburnetii_ to recognize the outstanding contributions of both Cox and\nBurnet to the isolation and characterization of this new pathogen.(23)\n\nReferences\n----------\n17. Derrick EH. Q fever, a new fever entity: Clinical features,\ndiagnosis and laboratory investigation. Med J Aust. 1937;2:281299.\n18. Burnet FM, Freeman M. Experimental studies on the virus of Q\nfever. Med J Aust. 1937;2:299305.\n19. Noguchi H. A filter-passing infectious agent obtained from\n_Dermacentor andersoni_. J Exp Med. 1926;44:110.\n20. Davis GE, Cox HR. A filter-passing infectious agent isolated from\nticks, I: Isolation from _Dermacentor andersoni_, reactions in\nanimals, and filtration experiments. Public Health Rep. 1938; 53:22592267.\n21. Cox HR. Studies of a filter-passing infectious agent isolated\nfrom ticks, V: Further attempts to cultivate in cellfree media.\nSuggested classification. Public Health Rep. 1939;54:21712178.\n22. Dyer RE. A filter-passing infectious agent isolated from ticks,\nIV: Human infection. Public Health Rep. 1938;53:22772283.\n23. Philip CB. Comments on the name of the Q fever organism. Netherlands (16): pathogenicity, RFI 20091222.4304\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nWith respect to the request for information about the strain(s) of\n_Coxiella burnetii_ causing the Dutch Q Fever outbreak, the US\nCenters for Disease Control Emerging Infectious Diseases journal\npublished a letter from Dutch researchers working in Nijmegen and\nEindhoven in April 2009, reporting some preliminary results from\nmultiple-locus variable-number tandem repeat analysis (MLVA) typing\nof _C. burnetii_ from a variety of human and animal clinical samples\nlinked to the outbreak obtained from different locations in the Netherlands.\n\nThe article (Multigenotype Q Fever Outbreak, the Netherlands by CHW\nKlaassen, MH Nabuurs-Franssen, JJHC Tilburg, et al, Emerg Infect Dis.\n2009 April; 15(4): 613-4. doi: 10.3201/eid1504.081612) is available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/eid/content/15/4/613.htm>.\n\nThe authors reported results showing 'that the unprecedented, ongoing\nQ fever outbreak in the Netherlands involves multiple genotypes of\n_C. burnetii_. Because most of the genotypes differ only by a single\nrepeat difference, they might represent microvariants of a\nhypervirulent strain that has been introduced in the Dutch animal population.'\n\n--\nDr Catherine Filejski, DVM, MA, MEPA, PhD[ABD]\nVeterinary Consultant\nEnteric, Zoonotic and Vector-Borne Disease Unit\nPrevention and Control Section\nPublic Health Protection and Prevention Branch\nOntario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care\nToronto, ON M2M 4K5\nCanada\n<Catherine.Filejski@ontario.ca>\n\n[The authors of the letter to the editor of 'Emerging Infectious\nDiseases' above hypothesize that the Dutch strain of _C. burnetii_ is\n'hypervirulent'. Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.nrc.nl/binnenland/article2445456.ece/Ruim_2500_geiten_gedood>\n\n\n2548 goats have been destroyed so far in the combat against Q fever;\nthis was reported by the spokesperson of the Ministry of Agriculture.\nDuring each of the last 3 days, 3 holdings were emptied, totaling 9\nfarms, mainly in the south and southeast of the country. Today [Thu\n24 Dec 2009], the work was discontinued, to be restarted Monday [28\nDec 2009], again handling 3 farms per day, pausing during the New Year's days.\n\nAccording to the spokesman, there are no details to report. 'It went\nwell, but it was sad.'\n\nIt is not so that fewer animals need to be killed in the infected\npremises. Minister Gerda Verburg (Agriculture) received a negative\nopinion of the Central Veterinary Institute (CVI) upon her query of\nwhether repeated testing of individual animals on infected farms\ncould enable a distinction between infected and non-infected animals\nin order to spare the latter. The CVI said that such testing will not\nprovide a complete assurance of the animals' freedom of infection; on\ntop of that, such testing is not performable, since the lambing is\nsoon to start. Consequently, the announced measures remain in force,\nas Verburg informed the House.\n\nOn the Ministry's website, Verburg reported how depressing it was\nthat healthy, pregnant animals should be killed. 'It cuts deep into\nmy soul.' According to her, such an event had never happened in Dutch\nhistory. However, according to the Minister, the culling of all\npregnant animals on infected farms is currently the only way to\ndrastically decrease the spread of the Q fever bacteria in 2010.\n\nThe culling of the 61 infected farms began Monday [21 Dec 2009] in\nVinkel, Tilburg and Horssen, because the animals there were soon to\nstart lambing. 'I hope very much that not many more new infected\nfarms are to be found and that the number of Q-fever patients in 2010\nwill be limited. We need to see the light at the end of the tunnel,\nand the industry needs a sustainable and healthy future prospect,'\nsaid Verburg.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above report includes a useful map, demonstrating the locations\nof human cases and infected animal farms in the Netherlands.\n\nIt will be interesting to obtain information on the role of\nvaccination in suppressing Q fever dissemination, as viewed by CDI.\n\nOn 24 Dec 2009, Minister Verburg sent the Dutch Parliament a detailed\nreply, addressing several questions regarding the press coverage of\nthe culling operation. AS, edited]\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/portal/page?_pageid=116,3169811&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_news_item_id=24967>\n\n\nQueen and Minister Verburg visiting goat farmer\n-----------------------------------------------\nHer Majesty the Queen has visited this morning a goat farm in Bakel,\nNoord-Brabant. This holding has been hit by Q-fever. Later during the\nmorning the Queen spoke, in the town of Gemert-Bakel, with Q-fever\npatients, a physician and a representative of the Regional Public\nHealth Service. Minister Verburg of the Ministry of Agriculture,\nNature and Food Quality accompanied the Queen.\n\nThe visit started at the town hall, where Jeroen Gosse (Director of\nthe Regional Affairs Directorate) briefly described the organization\nand implementation of the culls. Subsequently, the Queen and Minister\nVerburg paid a visit to the goat farm. They had a round tour of the\npremises and spoke with the family members. The company included,\nbefore the cull, about 700 goats. Following the discovery of the Q\nfever bacterium, all 366 pregnant goats were killed a week ago.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 28 Dec 2009\nSource: Meat Trade News Daily [Edited]\n<http://www.meattradenewsdaily.co.uk/news/281209/qatar___rumours_abot_q_fever_denied_.aspx>\n\n\nQatar - Rumors about Q-Fever denied\n-----------------------------------\nThe Supreme Council of Health (SCH) has scotched rumors about the\nspread of a new pandemic known as Q-Fever. Q-Fever is a known\ninfectious disease but it currently does not cause any concern\nworldwide, the SCH said in a statement issued yesterday [Sun, 27 Dec\n2009].\n\n'Recently some news has been circulating about the spread of a new\npandemic known as Q-Fever. The SCH would like to inform the public\nthat the disease is currently restricted to the Netherlands.\nTherefore it is not a disease that causes any concern right now,'\nsaid the statement.\n\nQ-Fever is not a new disease and it was reported before in all\ncontinents. In 2009 around 2300 people around the world were infected\nwith Q-Fever with 6 fatalities, added the statement.\n\nThe disease usually infects veterinarians, meat workers, dairy\nworkers and farmers. The disease is caused by a species of bacteria\nknown as _Coxiella burnetii_ which comes out of cattle, sheep, goats\ncats, dogs and some wild animals.\n\nDirect transfer of the disease from a human being to another is rare;\nhowever clothes of an infected person may transmit the disease.\nSymptoms are shown in high fever, severe headache, malaise, myalgia,\nconfusion, sore throat, chills, sweat, non-productive cough, nausea,\nvomiting and stomach and chest pain.\n\nAntibiotic treatment is quite effective, namely doxycyclin. This\ntreatment is most effective during the 1st 3 days of the illness.\nAfter full recovery the person may gain permanent immunity against\nthe disease in the future.\n\nQ-Fever outbreaks occur mainly due to occupational exposure involving\nveterinarians, meat processing plant workers, sheep and dairy\nworkers, livestock farmers and researchers at facilities housing\nsheep.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The culling of pregnant goats in the infected goat holdings in the\nNetherlands is continuing in a pace of 3 holdings per day; as of Mon\n28 Dec 2009 the operation was completed in 12 of the 61 infected\nholdings.\n\nAuthorities in neighbouring Belgium, where, so far, 7 goat or sheep\nholdings have been found Q-fever infected, have intensified their\npreparedness, and are keeping an open eye for developments. However,\nreportedly they are not overly concerned since the structure of the\ndairy goat and sheep farming industry there is not similar to the one\nprevailing in south Netherlands.\n\n\nThe Belgian Food Safety agency also took measures to safeguard the\nadequate pasteurisation of sheep and goat milk before entering the\ndairy plants. The newswire from Qatar is posted to demonstrate the\npotential impact of a Q fever epizootic (of unusual dimensions and\nprobably enhanced, or unknown, pathogenicity) upon international\ntrade in animals and their products. This, in spite of the fact that\nQ fever is generally not regarded as a trade-limiting factor, being\nendemic in most countries and avoided by standard food-processing\ntechniques. Similar media reports appeared, several weeks ago, in\nRussia.\n\nOn Tue 29 Dec 2009 the Dutch Veterinary Services submitted to the OIE\ntheir 1st ('initial' and 'immediate') notification on the Q fever\noutbreak. The rest of the outbreaks will be\nprovided in the next weekly follow-up report.'\n\nHopefully, the due weekly report will include further details,\nexplaining the decision of the Dutch Veterinary Services to define\nthe _Coxiella burnetii_ strain which is circulating in the\nNetherlands as 'new.' As reported in posting 20091222.4312, a letter\nfrom Dutch researchers, published in the US Centers for Disease\nControl 'Emerging Infectious Diseases' journal of April 2009,\nreported results showing 'that the unprecedented, ongoing Q fever\noutbreak in the Netherlands involves multiple genotypes of _C.\nburnetii_. Because most of the genotypes differ only by a single\nrepeat difference, they might represent microvariants of a\nhypervirulent strain that has been introduced in the Dutch animal\npopulation.' Netherlands (14): update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=352850", "date": "2009-12-17 20:00:03", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (14): UPDATE\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: Thu 17 Dec 2009\nSource: Reuters via Forexyard [edited]\n<http://www.forexyard.com/en/reuters_inner.tpl?action=2009-12-17T171325Z_01_LDE5BG1VS_RTRIDST_0_DUTCH-LIVESTOCK-DISEASE>\n\n\nMore Dutch farms hit by infectious goat fever\n---------------------------------------------\nDutch authorities, already battling an outbreak of the highly infectious\ndisease, Q fever, have discovered contamination at 5 more farms and expect\nfurther outbreaks, the Agriculture Ministry said on Thursday [17 Dec 2009].\n\nQ fever is caused by a bacterium that is mostly transmitted to humans from\ngoats and sheep, especially during delivery of young, and the number of\nhuman cases of the disease has risen to about 2200 currently from about 170\nin 2007.\n\nA total of 60 farms in the country are now known to be affected and\nauthorities plan to cull an extra 5000 goats on top of the 35 000 announced\non Wednesday [16 Dec 2009], a spokesman for the agriculture ministry said.\nThe culling of goats is set to begin on 21 Dec 2009, and will be done by\nlethal injection.\n\nFor humans, Q fever causes flu-like symptoms treatable with antibiotics,\nbut in rare cases it can be fatal. Six people who had other diseases or\nwere weakened have died this year while having Q fever.\n\nDutch authorities have toughened up measures to stop the disease spreading\nto humans following health advice, but Dutch farmers organisation LTO has\nopposed the plans, particularly the decision to kill healthy animals on\ncontaminated farms.\n\n[byline: Catherine Hornby]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 17 Dec 2009\nSource: Radio Netherlands Worldwide [edited]\n<http://www.rnw.nl/english/article/dutch-farmers-resist-culling-healthy-goats>\n\n\nDutch farmers resist culling of healthy goats\n---------------------------------------------\nThe Dutch Farmers Association LTO has said it rejects the killing of\nhealthy goats to fight the spread of Q fever, following a cabinet proposal\nto eradicate the disease by a mass slaughter of goats.\n\nAgriculture minister Gerda Verburg and health minister Ab Klink on Thursday\n[17 Dec 2009] announced an extension of the extermination scheme. Initially\njust pregnant goats carrying the Q fever bacteria would be culled, because\nthe bacteria is mainly spread through miscarriages. Minister Verburg\nchanged her mind after the methods used to determine whether animals are\ninfected proved to be unreliable.\n\nIt is not clear whether LTO will take action against the government decision.\n\nMass cull starts on Monday\n--------------------------\nThe disease has been confirmed at 55 farms, mainly in the densely populated\nsouthern province of Noord-Brabant. An estimated 35 000 goats will be\nculled, starting on Monday [21 Dec 2009].\n\nClear warning signs will be placed near infected farms, and maps detailing\ninfection locations have been published.\n\nLTO chairman Albert Jan Maat acknowledged that Minister Verburg had wanted\nto spare the lives of healthy animals, but he questions the validity and\ntiming of the arguments she gave to now include all goats.\n\nHorrible\n--------\nLTO also says it is callous to let the goat farmers foot the bill. MPs in\nThe Hague support the ministers' decision, but emphasise they find it\nhorrible. The matter will be debated on Thursday.\n\nGoat farming spread in the Netherlands when other cattle, such as pigs,\ncows, as well as chickens, were widely affected by diseases. Goats appeared\na safer option, and the number of animals rose to 374 000. The average goat\nfarm has about a thousand animals. They are kept for their milk and meat,\nmost of which is exported.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Wed 16 Dec 2009\nSource: AFP via IOL [edited]\n<http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=31&art_id=nw20091216181330919C221815>\n\n\nNetherlands to slaughter more animals\n-------------------------------------\nThe Netherlands stepped up measures on Wednesday [16 Dec 2009] against the\nworld's biggest Q fever epidemic that has killed 10 humans, by ordering the\nslaughter of over 30 000 animals, a press release said. The ministry of\nagriculture announced the 'preventative slaughter' of 34 000 expectant\ngoats and ewes, and 1200 billy goats 'will be killed too as they can\ntransmit the infection through their sperm.'\n\nQ fever, found in 55 Dutch farms so far, has killed 6 people in 2009 and\nDutch authorities say 10 farm workers have died in total since the fever\nappeared in 2007 in the south of the country.\n\nThe slaughter had involved 15 000 - 20 000 non-vaccinated expectant goats,\nbut this has now been extended to vaccinated animals in an attempt to limit\nthe spread of bacteria when animals give birth or during forced abortions.\n[Updated figures available in items 1,2].\n\nThe slaughter accounts for more than half the livestock from the 55\ninfected farms, mostly situated in the southern Brabant province. The\nauthorities warn that the slaughter will now be carried out in all farms\nwhere the infection is found.\n\nAll reproductive activity in ovine and caprine farms is forbidden until\nJuly 2010 and reproduction between animals in the infected farms has been\nbanned for life.\n\nAn obligatory animal vaccination campaign was launched at the start of 2009\nin the Netherlands, but due to a lack of vaccinations, it was not able to\ncover the whole country.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4]\nDate: Thu 17 Dec 2009\nSource: Dutch Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality website -\nAnimal diseases - Q fever [Dutch, trans. Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/portal/page?_pageid=116,3169799&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_document_id=2124959&p_node_id=2127404&p_mode=BROWSE>\n\n\nQuestions and answers regarding Q fever\n---------------------------------------\n1. How many goats are there in the Netherlands?\nDuring 2008, there were about 350 000 goats [on commercial farms. -\nMod.AS]. These animals are not kept exclusively on goat farms; many cattle\nfarms keep goats as well, as a side-line business. In addition, several\nhundred thousand goats are kept as 'hobby animals'.\n2. How many dairy goats are there in the Netherlands?\nAbout 250 000\n3. How many sheep are there in the Netherlands?\nDuring 2008 there were about 1 200 000 sheep in the Netherlands. These\nanimals are not kept exclusively on sheep farms; many cattle farms keep\nsheep as well, as a side-line business. In addition, several hundred\nthousand sheep are kept as 'hobby animals.'\n4. How many dairy sheep are there in the Netherlands?\nThere are few dairy sheep farms in the Netherlands, including a total of\nseveral thousand animals. Besides, no dairy sheep farms are infected by Q\nfever [it would help if this last statement were officially confirmed. -\nMod.AS].\n5. How many farms are infected?\nBased upon the results of the bulk milk tests, it has been established that\nthe Q fever bacterium is present on 55 dairy goat farms. 43 of them\nvaccinated during 2009 against Q fever; 1 farm is situated outside the\nvaccination area. [for updated data, see item 1 above. - Mod.AS].\n6. When is a farm declared as infected?\nA farm is declared infected when repeated bulk milk tests, performed by\nboth the VWA (Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority) and CVI (Central\nVeterinary Institute), are found positive.\n7. How can I, as a citizen, know if a farm is infected?\nInfected farms are banned for visitors. The farms themselves must make this\nknown. Only persons who are required to visit the farms due to their\nprofessional obligations, are allowed to enter infected premises. The state\nauthorities publish the areas within which infected farms are present. Once\nin 2 months, geographic maps are published on the websites of the VWA and\nRIVM (Institute for Public Health and the Environment).\n8. Is Q fever an occupational disease?\nQ fever is a disease which appears more often in animal holders,\nveterinarians and slaughterhouse personnel. But Q fever appears also in\npeople who have no connection to animals. Anyone can get infected by\ninhaling air which includes the bacterium.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to a press release of the Dutch Ministry of Agriculture, dated\n16 Dec 2009, the total number of animals in the 55 infected farms is around\n64 000 dairy goats, of which over 34 000 are pregnant animals and over 1200\nare bucks. The 5 farms found now infected and added to the 55 list, are\npart of 16 hitherto 'suspected' farms with 17 500 animals (including 10 000\npregnant animals and 350 bucks), of which results were expected this week.\nIt would be interesting to know if the remaining 11 'suspected' farms have\nbeen found to be uninfected or otherwise. According to the press release,\nthe expectation is that during the coming few months, bulk-milk testing\nwill discover new infected farms.\n\nIt would be helpful to know the total number of dairy goat and dairy sheep\nfarms which have been already tested, at least once, by the bulk milk (PCR)\ntests. In the\nNetherlands, 6 people have died from the disease. The authorities in\nBelgium say Q fever does not pose a major threat in Belgium, which\nhas a much smaller goat population. The Federal Food Safety Agency\nsays 2 Belgian farms have been infected.\n\nAccording to the FASFC, the Federal Agency for the Safety of the Food\nChain, 2 farms have goats that are infected with Q fever: one in\nFlanders and one in Wallonia. Federal Health Minister Laurette\nOnkelinckx does not think the situation warrants extra measures here.\nThis year [2009], there have been 36 cases of people contracting Q\nfever in Belgium (mostly in Flanders).\n\nQ fever is a rare bacterial disease that can't be spread between\npeople and usually causes only flu-like symptoms. Many animals can\ncarry the bacteria, but contact with infected goats is believed to be\nthe main source of human infections. Most humans are infected between\nFebruary and May, when goats and sheep give birth.\n\nFlanders is planning to take some general measures. Following a\nmeeting on Thursday [10 Dec 2009] between the government, farm\norganisations and the union of goat farmers, Flemish Prime Minister\nKris Peeters stressed that the situation in Belgium is under control.\nHowever, it was decided that the situation would be monitored more\nclosely. It was also decided to speed up work on the new vaccination\nnow in the making.\n\n'It was agreed that the vaccination will be prepared as soon as\npossible and in sufficient quantities,' said PM Peeters. The\nvaccination must be prepared before the next birthing period.\n\nIt was also decided to keep in close contact with the Dutch\nauthorities regarding the evolution of Q fever. Transport of goats or\nequipment used for goats and goats' milk between the Netherlands and\nFlanders will also be monitored very closely.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Belgium's swift reaction to the recent detection of Q fever\ninfection in local goat farms is plausible, in view of the alarming\nnews from neighbouring Netherlands. However, it remains to be seen if\nthe Belgian findings indicate a new development or that they just\nreflect enhanced alertness with subsequent intensified testing. _C.\nburnetti_ is regarded to be present in most if not all countries\naround the globe. According to Belgium's reports to the OIE, no Q\nfever outbreaks have been recorded there during the years 2005-2008.\nHowever, Belgium does not claim that the disease has never occurred;\nthe last year of Q fever occurrence in Belgium is claimed to be\n'unknown'. It will be interesting to note whether Q fever was\nincluded in serological surveillance in Belgium in the past,\ninvolving cattle, sheep and goats.\n\nAre the new findings to be regarded as an 'emerging disease?' Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.agd.nl/1090668/Nieuws/Varkenshouderij/Advies-drachtige-geiten-op-besmette-bedrijven-ruimen.htm>\n\n\nThe RIVM [Dutch National Institute for Public Health and the\nEnvironment] expert consultation on Q-fever advises the Ministry of\nAgriculture to remove [in fact, kill] all pregnant goats from farms\ninfected with Q fever.\n\nThis advice is included in the opinion paper, submitted by RIVM to\nthe Ministry. The measure is meant to be applied on holdings where\nbulk milk tests have repeatedly been found positive for Q fever.\n\nThe expert consultation related to this as a one-off measure to\nprevent infection spread during the due kidding season, when\napparently normal or aborted offspring may spread the pathogen. 'It\nis possible that uninfected pregnant goats will be removed as well,'\nwrites the RIVM. The organization indicates that there may be a\ndistinction made between vaccinated and unvaccinated holdings. 'In\nunvaccinated holdings, this strategy is the only way to eliminate or\nsubstantially reduce the secretion of the pathogen in 2010,' said the\nRIVM. 'On vaccinated holdings, this strategy can be used as an\nadditional reducing measure, because these holdings have already\nreduced the secretion by the vaccination.'\n\nIt has also been recommended to continue the vaccination strategy as\nwell as to temporarily ban increase in the size of goat holdings or\nadding new ones.\n\nThe expert consultation involved both veterinary as well as public\nhealth experts. The ministries of agriculture and health are expected\nto decide during this week about the approach towards Q fever\ncontrol. The experts' advice addresses 8 possible strategies.\n\n[Byline: Mariska Vermaas]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview Pedigree English Longhorns\nGut Laach 52385 Nideggen, Germany\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[According to data from RIVM, as of 25 Nov 2009, 2293 clinical cases\nof Q fever and 6 fatalities have been recorded during 2009 (as of 25\nNov 2009). The disease is\nprevalent in areas in the southern Netherlands with large-scale goat\nfarms and a relatively dense population. Following a recommendation by the National\nInstitute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM), they decided\nto order all pregnant goats slaughtered on contaminated farms.\n\nQ-fever first appeared in the Netherlands in 2007. It is caused by\ninfection with the _Coxiella burnetti_ bacterium, which can be found\nin cattle, sheep, goats or domestic animals. It is easily released\nwhen a pregnant infected animal miscarries because of the disease.\n\nIn humans, Q-fever can cause permanent heart problems. Close to 2330\npeople in the Netherlands have been infected so far. Six patients\nwith an underlying illness died as a result.\n\nLast week, the RIVM advised the government to slaughter all pregnant\ngoats on contaminated farms, regardless of whether the animals are\ninfected. Even if this would result in the slaughter of 'tens of\nthousands' of animals, it would be 'the most effective measure,' the RIVM said.\n\nThere has been increasing criticism of the government's handling of\nQ-fever lately. Doctors from North Brabant, the area where the\ndisease is the most widespread, have accused the government of giving\nin to the farming industry.\n\nOn Tuesday [8 Dec 2009], the association of Dutch municipalities\nasked the government to 'let the public health interest be the\nguiding principle' in setting policy on Q-fever.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[While small ruminants, namely goats and sheep are traditionally\nregarded as the main potential source of human infection, other\nanimals, such as cattle, dogs and cats, are not to be disregarded. In\nurban areas, littering cats have been seriously suspected as a\nsignificant source of human infection. In the Dutch context, the\nearlier (1997) review 'Q fever in Europe' is of interest. It included\nthe following text: 'In some human cases, no relation with\n'classical' sources can be found, and possible new sources must be\nsought. In a serological study of dogs and cats [in central\nNetherlands, 1992], 13.2 percent (91/688) of dogs and 10.4 percent\n(46/441) of cats were found to be positive for specific antibodies\nagainst _C. burnetii_. This implies that cats and dogs may be a\nsource of infection. Special attention to hygiene during parturition\nmay be needed.' The disease has spread across a third of the\nNetherlands. Q fever in humans causes flu-like symptoms and can lead\nto pneumonia. In some cases it leads to death. This year [2009] alone\n2200 people have contracted it, most of them in the southern rural\nprovince of Brabant, and at least 6 people have died.\n\nTo prevent further spread of the disease, goats are to be vaccinated.\nAgriculture minister Gerda Verburg says, 'This is not a voluntary\nmeasure. All measures are geared towards human health. An aborted goat\nis a pity for a farmer, but it is starting to affect humans.' The\nresults of this measure will not be visible until next year [2010].\nThe cabinet also wants to prevent farms where animals have Q fever\nfrom expanding. And in areas with high numbers of human Q fever cases,\nministers even want farms to be closed for a year.\n\nIn a debate in the Lower House on Wednesday [11 Nov 2009], the\nminister said it is not likely that people will be vaccinated against\nthe disease on a large scale. He has agreed to put the vaccine forward\nfor registration, although he pointed out that there are unpleasant\nside effects in people who have already had the disease. Christian\nDemocrat MP Henk Jan Ormel pointed out that in Australia 55 000 people\nhad been vaccinated. There, he said, the worst side effect had been\nitchiness.\n\nA publication of the University of New South Wales reported that\nvaccination of high risk groups (abattoir staff, farmers) with Q-vax\nresulted in a 50 percent decrease of Q fever infections in Australia\nfrom 2002 to 2006. Precautionary, only people who did not have\nantibodies against Q fever were vaccinated. The vaccination program is\nfunded by the Australian government.\n\nA total of 31 Q fever studies are underway. In 2008 and 2009, 3\nmillion euros [approx USD 4.5 million] was spent on research, the same\namount is available for more international studies in the future.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 13 Nov 2009\n \n\nA publication of the University of New South Wales reported that\nvaccination of high risk groups (abattoir staff, farmers) with Q-vax\nresulted in a 50 percent decrease of Q fever infections in Australia\nfrom 2002 to 2006.
