This was reported by the Animal Health Service in Deventer.\nConfirmation of tests will take another 2 weeks. Measures will not be\napplied until 4 weeks from now.\n\nSo far this year 4 goat farms in the Netherlands were officially declared\ncontaminated, based on a former detection method. A farm was considered\ninfected only if the percentage of abortions was larger than 5 per cent.\nHowever, it appears that the agriculture ministry knew that another 41\nfarms had infected goats, based on milk sample tests. No measures were\napplied to these farms. In sheep farms Q fever is rare. From 40 farms, only\none proved infected.\n\nQ fever is a serious zoonosis, that causes not that severe problems in\ngoats, but has high morbidity in people with serious symptoms: fatigue,\nhigh fever, serious headaches, severe pneumonia, sometimes resulting in\nhospitalization and even death. The causal agent is _Coxiella burnetii_,\nwhich spreads through air. The bacteria is particularly dangerous in case\nof pregnancy or heart valve abnormalities.\n\nIn the Netherlands, the outbreak started in 2007 in Herpen, a village in\nthe south of the country, and since then the disease has spread every year.\n6 people died. This year 2100 people were infected. It is the largest\noutbreak of Q fever ever reported in the world.\n\nControlling the disease is difficult, because the bacteria does not\ndisappear from the soil. Until now, measures consisted of prohibition of\nspreading out manure and moving animals from infected farms.\n\nResults of vaccination are still being investigated by the Animal Health\nService. The vaccine seems to prevent abortion and animals produce\nsufficient antibodies, but it is not clear yet whether excretion of\nbacteria is prevented. Milk production may decrease by 8 to 10 percent in\nthe 1st weeks following vaccination.\n\nThe Dutch authorities commissioned the National Institute for Public Health\nand the Environment (RIVM) to develop scenarios to fight Q fever,\nconsidering also moving or closing down farms.\n\nSource: NOVA/Animal Health Service/Agrarisch dagblad\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to data from RIVM (the National Dutch Institute for Public\nHealth and the Environment), as of 29 Oct 2009, 2236 cases of Q fever have\nbeen suspected since 1 Jan 2009, 2126 of which have been\nlaboratory-confirmed and 110 regarded as 'probable'. 6 Q fever patients\ndied. The numbers for previous years were: 2007 -- 168, 2008 -- 1000. A\nhistogram presenting weekly figures for the period 1 Jan 2007 - 28 Oct 2009\nis available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/epicurve%20Q-koorts_tcm92-59728.pdf#%20class=>.\nA map, showing the distribution of the disease throughout the Netherlands\nduring 2009 (incidence per 100 000 inhabitants), is available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/Qkoorts_per_gemeente_tcm92-60500.pdf#%20class=>.\n\nThe EU's Standing Committee on the Food Chain and Animal Health (SCFCAH),\nSection : Animal Health & Animal Welfare, included the subject 'Information\nfrom the Netherlands on the Q fever situation' on its agenda for the\nmeeting of 3-4 Nov 2009. We would\nnot be surprised if the numbers exceed those of 2009.\n\na) in the vaccinated area:\nThe environment was heavily contaminated during the years 2007, 2008, and\n2009. _Coxiella_ is environment-resistant. In warm dry months, we will see\nmany new human cases in 2010 (even if the vaccine is 100 per cent effective\nin preventing abortions in goats in that area).\nb) other areas:\nIn 2009, we have seen spread of human and goat Q fever *outside* the\ndesignated vaccination area. The vaccination of sheep and goats in those\n['other'] areas will start *after* the 2010 lambing season. We expect in\n2010 several newly infected goat farms experiencing high abortion\npercentages. This will inevitably lead to spread of _Coxiella_ in the\nenvironment in the immediate surroundings, leading to many new human cases\nin 2010 (assuming favourable weather conditions).\n\n--\nJim van Steenbergen\nLCI/Unit Preparedness and Response\nCentre for Infectious Disease Control/RIVM\nNL-3720 BA Bilthoven, Netherlands\n<lci@rivm.nl>\n<http://www.rivm.nl/infectieziekten>\n\n[The concerns expressed by Dr Steenbergen, who views the issue from the\nstandpoint of a physician and public health epidemiologist, are underlined\nby the fact that human Q fever cases are now not restricted to the south.\nDr Steenbergen was one of the first to indicate the possible origin of the\noutbreak in humans, as early as 2007, as related to goat holdings. Cases,\nthough not numerous, are now being recorded also from other parts of the\nNetherlands, including northern provinces. This can be seen in the map\nshowing the spread of the 2193 human Q fever cases recorded this year (1\nJan-30 Sep 2009) available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/Qkoorts_per_gemeente_tcm92-60500.pdf#%20class=>.\nThe total number of human patients since the start of the outbreak in\nsummer 2007, as of 30 Sep 2009, exceeds 3350. This has become the largest Q\nfever epidemic ever reported globally.\n\nBrowsing through recent Dutch animal and public health publications\nunravels some expressions of discontent, in particular related to the steps\nundertaken to contain infection in animals. The situation has been\naddressed, among others, in several recent publications of the Royal Dutch\nVeterinary Society (KNMvD).\n\nA main obstacle in the handling of the disease in animals is the fact that,\nwhile exposing humans, the disease has -- so far -- not caused serious\ndirect losses to the farming industry. Animal vaccination has, therefore,\nbeen more a matter of public health than animal health concern. A KNMvD\nnewsletter, dedicated to the recently published new measures (as detailed\nin posting 20090927.3380) includes the following statement: 'Ministers\nKlink [public health] and Verburg [agriculture] intend to reduce the number\nof human cases by these measures, but they warn against excessive optimism\nin the short term: a reduction in the number of Q-fever patients is not\nexpected in 2010, at most, stabilization is expected. This is related to\nthe fact that the animal vaccine, while in state to prevent mass abortions\non the animal holdings, thus eliminating a significant source of infection,\nis not capable of suppressing the disease altogether. Another point of\nsignificance is the fact that the Q fever bacterium will survive in the\nenvironment among dust particles.' The Society encouraged practitioners to\nstimulate their client-farmers to report even sporadic abortions in sheep\nand goats. Obviously, such stimulation is not sufficient if farmers fear\nresulting repercussions.\n\nSubscribers may consider viewing the presentation 'Q-fever in the\nNetherlands - Vaccination strategy, 2009' of the Dutch Veterinary Services,\npresented by Christianne Bruschke during the 5-6 May 2009 monthly meeting\nof EU's Standing Committee on the Food Chain and Animal Health (SCFCAH),\n(ANIMAL HEALTH & ANIMAL WELFARE). The presentation is available at\n<http://ec.europa.eu/food/committees/regulatory/scfcah/animal_health/presentations/q_fever0506052009.pdf>.\nAmong other things, it shows that, during 2007, Q-fever outbreaks were\ndiagnosed on 7 dairy-goat farms, and during 2008 on 7 dairy-goat farms and\none dairy-sheep farm. This looks like a strikingly low number of outbreaks,\nin the context of the alarmingly extensive spread in humans.\n\nVarious aspects of this outbreak remain enigmatic, in particular its\nepidemiology within the animal population, the interface with humans, its\ndimensions and the role of climate/weather conditions (such as wind,\ntemperature, humidity, precipitation). Dr Steenbergen referred to these as\n'favorable weather conditions'; specification could help.\n\nFurther reading: Delsing CE, Kullberg BJ. Q fever in the Netherlands: a\nconcise overview and implications of the largest ongoing outbreak. Neth J\nMed 2008; 66(9): 365-7.\n<http://www.zuidencomm.nl/njm/getpdf.php?id=10000365>. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A KNMvD\nnewsletter, dedicated to the recently published new measures (as detailed\nin posting 20090927.3380) includes the following statement: 'Ministers\nKlink [public health] and Verburg [agriculture] intend to reduce the number\nof human cases by these measures, but they warn against excessive optimism\nin the short term: a reduction in the number of Q-fever patients is not\nexpected in 2010, at most, stabilization is expected. Browsing through recent Dutch animal and public health publications\nunravels some expressions of discontent, in particular related to the steps\nundertaken to contain infection in animals.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-09-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-05-06 00:00:00", "2009-05-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-04-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-09-30 00:00:00", "2193-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-04-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "CE", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Verburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the \n Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "300311", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands (08): update, monitoring & animal vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=300311", "date": "2009-09-27 19:00:03", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (08): UPDATE, MONITORING AND ANIMAL VACCINATION\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: Sat 26 Sep 2009\nSource: Reuters via OttawaCitizen [edited]\n<http://www2.canada.com/ottawacitizen/health/men/story.html?id=b8dc47a2-0b01-4539-b96e-c1cc51f52773>\n\nDutch to extend animal vaccination to fight Q fever\n---------------------------------------------------\nDutch farms, children's farms and zoos holding more than 50 goats or\nsheep will have to vaccinate the animals against a highly infectious\ndisease known as Q fever, the Dutch Agriculture Ministry said on\nSaturday [26 Sep 2009].\n\nQ fever is caused by a bacterium that is transmitted by goats and\nsheep to humans. Since 2007 human cases of the disease have risen\nsharply in the Netherlands to more than 2000 in 2009, according to\nthe National Institute for Public Health on its website. The illness\ncauses flu-like symptoms treatable with antibiotics, but can in rare\ncases be fatal. 5 people have so far died from Q-fever.\n\nThis year only farmers in parts of the southern provinces of\nNoord-Brabant, Limburg and Gelderland had to vaccinate their animals.\n\n'The ultimate goal is to force back the amount of human cases of\nQ-fever,' Agricultural Minister Gerda Verburg wrote in a letter to\nparliament [see item 2, below].\n\nThe Ministry will make 1.5 million vaccinations available.\n\n[Byline: Charles Dick]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview Pedigree English Longhorns\nGut Laach\n52385 Nideggen, Germany\n<CVLonghorns@aol.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 26 Sep 2009\nSource: Minister of Agriculture\nNature and Food Quality letter to Parliament, ref VDC 09.1803/CPM\n[trans. Mod.AS, abridged & edited]\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/portal/page?_pageid=116,1640321&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_file_id=43042>\n\nQ fever\n-------\nIn addition to the letter of 28 Aug 2009 (2008-2009 Parliamentary\npaper: 28 286), I provide you, also on behalf of Minister [of Health]\nKlink, the following information on the state of matters relating to\nthe new approach addressing Q fever. The new approach is aimed at\nmaintaining the freedom from Q fever of those dairy goats and sheep\nfarms throughout the Netherlands not yet infected, and the\nrehabilitation of the Q fever-infected farms.\n\nWe assume that by addressing the main sources of infection in sheep\nand goats, the Q-fever epidemic in humans is to be controlled.\n\nBulk tank milk monitoring\n------------------------\nStarting 1 Oct 2009, holders of more than 50 dairy goats or sheep\nwill be obliged to participate in the Q-fever monitoring. For this\npurpose, each farm will be sampled once in 2 months for Q-fever\ntesting. Suspected/positive samples will be forwarded for\nconfirmatory testing to the Central Veterinary Institute (CVI). If\nconfirmed, those farms will be declared infected.\n\nMeasures applied in infected farms\n----------------------------------\nHygienic measures:\n\nPending the outcome of the ongoing investigation into improved manure\nhandling procedures, the current, published measures are to be\nmaintained. This means that throughout the lambing season and up to\n30 days after its termination, no manure is permitted to be mucked\nout. The spread of manure in the fields will be allowed only after\nadditional 90 days of storage under cover.\n\n- Exit of animals:\nAnimals are not allowed exit to other farms for milk production or breeding.\nThe transportation of animals to slaughterhouses is permitted.\nAnimals under the age of 4 weeks are allowed transportation to fattening units.\n\n- Introduction of animals:\nInfected farms are allowed to introduce only vaccinated animals from\nQ fever-free farms.\n\n- Visits ban:\nNo visitors are allowed on infected premises.\n\n- Vaccination:\nInfected farms must vaccinate all their animals.\n\nMeasures applied in free holdings:\n------------------------------------\n- There are no restrictions upon the handling/use of manure, or upon\nexit of animals from free holdings.\n\n- Introduction of animals is allowed only from Q fever-free holdings.\n\n- Vaccination: Free holdings should be vaccinated.\n\nPolicy regarding the fate of infected farms:\n-------------------------------------------\nInfected Dairy goats and sheep farms may regain their free status\nafter a year of negative bi-monthly bulk tank milk test results. This\nperiod is relatively long due to uncertainties concerning the pattern\nof excretion of the Q-fever pathogen and the role thereupon of the\nlambing season.\n\nPilot studies, aiming at the identification of additional measures to\nobtain early eradication of the disease on infected farms, have been\nundertaken by the CVI and the Animal Health Service (GD).\n\nManure treatment:\n----------------\nAs stated in the letter of 28 Aug 2009, industrial composting of\nmanure was to be experimentally investigated as an alternative to its\nincineration. Meanwhile, a request to carry out such investigation\nhas been received from the province Zuid-Holland. This research is\nbeing addressed by the CVI and the Animal Science Group. The results\nof this investigation is expected before the next lambing season.\n\nVaccination Campaign 2010:\n-------------------------\nDuring 2010, vaccination will be compulsory throughout the\nNetherlands, including all holdings of more than 50 sheep or dairy\ngoats, all animals on children's farms, care farms and zoos.\nVaccination will be also compulsory in wandering sheep flocks, in\nnature reserves and on farms holding lamb petting days. In other\nsheep and goat holdings, vaccination will be voluntary.\n\nThe number of available vaccine doses is sufficient for the\nvaccination of all the above described holdings. For the vaccination\ncampaign of 2010, 1.5 million doses of vaccine are available, of\nwhich 100 000 doses are to be delivered in November 2009. The rest of\nthe vaccine doses will become available during 2010. The precise\ndelivery schedule is still being negotiated with the vaccine\nmanufacturer. We strive, of course, for the earliest possible\ndelivery.\n\n[signed]\nGerda Verburg\nMinister of Agriculture, Nature and Food Safety\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the figures of the Dutch National Institute for Public\nHealth and the Environment (RIVM), the number of human infections\nwith Q fever, since the start of this epidemic in mid 2007, is 3313\n(2007: N=168, 2008: N=1000, 2009: N=2145). Out of the 2145 cases\nreported so far during 2009, 2047 have been laboratory confirmed, 98\nsuspected; 5 died. An epicurve can be seen at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/epicurve%20Q-koorts_tcm92-59728.pdf#%20class=>.\n\nFurther data, including an outbreak map, graphics, 'Information for\nprofessionals' and several presentations on the disease in man and\nanimal (in Dutch), are available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/themas/Q-koorts/>).\n\nThe Dutch Q fever outbreak is the largest of its kind on record. - Mod.AS].\n\n[The Netherlands can be located using the HealthMap/ProMEDmail\ninteractive map at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00S1>.\n- CopyEd.EJP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n******\n ---------------------------------------------------\nDutch farms, children's farms and zoos holding more than 50 goats or\nsheep will have to vaccinate the animals against a highly infectious\ndisease known as Q fever, the Dutch Agriculture Ministry said on\nSaturday The new approach is aimed at\nmaintaining the freedom from Q fever of those dairy goats and sheep\nfarms throughout the Netherlands not yet infected, and the\nrehabilitation of the Q fever-infected farms. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the figures of the Dutch National Institute for Public\nHealth and the Environment (RIVM), the number of human infections\nwith Q fever, since the start of this epidemic in mid 2007, is 3313\n(2007: N=168, 2008: N=1000, 2009: N=2145). \n\n[signed]\nGerda Verburg\nMinister of Agriculture, Nature and Food Safety\n\n--\n In addition to the letter of 28 Aug 2009 (2008-2009 Parliamentary\npaper: 28 286), I provide you, also on behalf of Minister [of Health]\nKlink, the following information on the state of matters relating to\nthe new approach addressing Q fever. \n\nFurther data, including an outbreak map, graphics, 'Information for\nprofessionals' and several presentations on the disease in man and\nanimal (in Dutch), are available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/themas/Q-koorts/>). 'It is almost as if it is\nbeing hushed up to protect the agricultural and tourism industries,'\nsaid retired professor of medicine Ton Maassen. 'There should be\ntransparent communication about this, especially for people who have\na low resistance because they are HIV-positive or have recently\nundergone chemotherapy.'\n\nMaassen himself has given up on bicycle trips in the countryside of\nNorth Brabant, a province in the south of the Netherlands. North\nBrabant has a high concentration of sheep and goat farms, which the\nauthorities say are the source of Q fever. The disease first surfaced\nin 2007, but the agriculture ministry said it won't know exactly\nwhich farms are infected before the end of 2009.\n\nThere are no plans to exterminate entire farms as was done for\ndiseases like classical swine fever or foot-and-mouth disease.\nNeither will the ministry name the infected farms, said Peter de\nLeeuw, the chief veterinary officer at the ministry. Instead the\nfarmers themselves will be asked to present a plan for making their\nfarms disease-free.\n\nSpores of the bacteria can survive for a long time and can be carried\nby the wind. Because of its persistency, the US Center for Disease\nControl and Prevention has called it a possible means of biological\nwarfare or terror.\n\nUntil now the only indication of the presence of Q fever at a farm\nhas been an unusually high number of spontaneous miscarriages among\ngoat or sheep. This would prompt an inspection of the farm in\nquestion. 'But we know there must be many infected farms out there\nthat we don't know about,' said Van Steenbergen.\n\nIt is hoped that a new test, in which the milk coming from farms is\ntested for traces of the bacteria, will lead to the discovery of as\nmany as a 100 more farms. The ministry hopes to counter the disease\nthrough compulsory vaccination, the controlled processing of manure\nand checks on animal transports.\n\n[Byline: Hans van der Lugt]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[One major point missed in this posting is that influenza can spread\nrapidly from person-to-person and therefore can cause major pandemics\nwhereas Q fever is not spread from person-to-person. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 2 Sep 2009\n There should be\ntransparent communication about this, especially for people who have\na low resistance because they are HIV-positive or have recently\nundergone chemotherapy.' promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[One major point missed in this posting is that influenza can spread\nrapidly from person-to-person and therefore can cause major pandemics\nwhereas Q fever is not spread from person-to-person. \n\nIt is hoped that a new test, in which the milk coming from farms is\ntested for traces of the bacteria, will lead to the discovery of as\nmany as a 100 more farms. The difference\nis the way we keep our goats with herds of 5000 in open stables, concrete\nfloor, where the farmer adds a little straw every day and removes\neverything (including previously deposited placentas) 2 or 3 times a year.\nThe open stables assist the wind in blowing _Coxiella_ into the outside\nenvironment. In a herd of 5000 you can easily miss a few abortions. The\ntypical abortion storm is regularly seen (10-20 per cent of pregnancies\nending in abortion), and reported. But we miss hundreds of abortions that\noccur in less than 5 per cent of pregnancies (reportable if abortion rate\nis over 5 per cent). In a herd of 5000 no obligation to report 1 to 259\nabortions.\n\nThe vaccination started in 2008 with, at that time, all available vaccine\n(40 000 doses). In 2009, there is still a shortage but now over 190 000\ndoses have been bought and are being administered now by the public health\nvets. This is still not enough for the 350 000 goats in the country.\nAmazingly enough, the 1.1 million sheep are not (as yet) suffering any\nabortions (and no problems at all are seen in cattle).\n\nThe area is covered by a thin layer of _Coxiella_ built up in 3 years,\nwhich will undoubtedly infect humans again next year [2009] under certain\nweather conditions. We'll see large numbers of human cases next year, even\nif the abortion rate were lowered substantially.\n\n--\nJim van Steenbergen\nCoordinator, Communicable Disease Control\nNetherlands National Institute for Public Health and the Environment\nDutch: Rijksinstituut voor Volksgezondheid en Milieu (RIVM)\nBilthoven, Netherlands\n<Jim.van.Steenbergen@rivm.nl>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 27 Jun 2009\n Jim van Steenbergen\nCoordinator, Communicable Disease Control\nNetherlands National Institute for Public Health and the Environment\nDutch: Rijksinstituut voor Volksgezondheid en Milieu (RIVM)\n The difference\nis the way we keep our goats with herds of 5000 in open stables, concrete\nfloor, where the farmer adds a little straw every day and removes\neverything (including previously deposited placentas) 2 or 3 times a year. Given that between 1 and 2\npercent of people admitted to hospital with the disease die, more\ndeaths should be expected, he said. Some 600 people have been\nhospitalized with Q fever, ANP said, without giving a time frame.\n\nQ fever was rarely known among humans in the Netherlands until 2007,\nwhen 168 cases were reported. In 2008, there were more than 1000\ncases. The disease is spread by livestock, which shed the bacteria in\nurine, feces, birth products, and milk. Q fever, which leads to\nspontaneous abortion in sheep and goats, causes flu-like symptoms in\nhumans but can lead to lung infections.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 26 Jun 2009\nSource: Expatica [edited]\n<http://www.expatica.com/nl/news/dutch-news/Goat_borne-fever-kills-three_53971.html>\n\n\nSo far in 2009, 3 people in the Netherlands have died after\ncontracting so-called Q fever, according to the national institute for\npublic health and the environment.\n\nRoel Coutinho, director of the institute, said one patient died in\n2008 and then 3 in 2009. All of the patients were suffering from\nadditional serious medical conditions.\n\nSome 1429 infected patients have been reported by general\npractitioners since the beginning of 2009. To limit the spread of the\ndisease, 130 000 goats in the provinces of [North]-Brabant, Limburg,\nand Gelderland will be vaccinated.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The pathogenic organism of Q fever, often acquired by close exposure\nto animals, is infectious with a very low inoculum and may be\naerosolized over a distance. It is not clear what contact the infected\npeople had with animals or how close they were to farms.\n\n_Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was discovered in 1937. This\norganism is an agent that can be resistant to heat and desiccation,\nand is highly infectious by the aerosol route. A single inhaled\norganism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human]\nprimates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was found to be\n1.7 organisms (1).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication along with the less resistant\nlarge cell form, metabolically dormant, and spore-like (2).\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. Other modes of transmission to humans, including tick\nbites and human-to-human transmission, are rare.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C: An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of 'Q fever.' Pub Hlth Rep 1941; 56:\n1419-25.\n2. Norlander L: Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (04): FATALITIES\n**************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "1937-03-25 00:00:00", "1941-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Wever", "country": "Antarctica"}, {"location": "Limburg", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "192729", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q Fever - Netherlands (02): (NB)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=192729", "date": "2009-05-08 15:00:05", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (02): (NORTH BRABANT)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 6 May 2009\nSource: Dutch News [edited]\n<http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2009/05/q_fever_cases_surge.php>\n\n\nThe number of cases of Q fever reported among humans in the\nNetherlands has risen 'explosively' over the past few weeks, the\nVolkskrant reports on Wednesday [6 May 2009]. The paper says over 200\ncases have been reported in recent days, half of them in\nNoord-Brabant province.\n\nQ fever was rarely known among humans in the Netherlands until 2007,\nwhen 168 cases were reported. In 2008, there were more than 1000\ninfections in the Netherlands.\n\nThe infection is spread by livestock, which shed the bacteria in\nurine, feces, birth products, and milk. The bacteria can reach humans\nafter feces and dirty straw are used as fertilizer and blown about,\nthe Volkskrant says. The disease, which leads to spontaneous abortion\nin sheep and goats, causes flu-like symptoms in humans but can lead\nto lung infections.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The pathogenic organism of Q fever, often acquired by close exposure\nto animals, is infectious with a very low inoculum and may be\naerosolized over a distance. It is not clear what contact the\ninfected people had with animals or how close they were to farms.\n\n_Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was discovered in 1937.\nThis organism is an agent that can be resistant to heat and\ndesiccation, and is highly infectious by the aerosol route. A single\ninhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human]\nprimates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was found to be\n1.7 organisms (1).\n\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals,\nincluding other species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C.\nburnetii_ does not usually cause clinical disease in these animals,\nalthough abortion in goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_\ninfection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of\ninfected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta.\nContact with contaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication along with the less resistant\nlarge cell form, metabolically dormant, and spore-like (3).\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. Other modes of transmission to humans, including tick\nbites and human-to-human transmission, are rare.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C: An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of 'Q fever.' Pub Hlth Rep 1941; 56: 1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D: Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12: 518-53\n[available at\n<http://cmr.asm.org/cgi/content/full/12/4/518>].\n3. Norlander L: Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes\nInfect 2000; 2: 417-24 [abstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10817644>.\n4. CDC online: Q fever; available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/qfever>.\n\nThe location of the southern province of Noord-Brabant (North\nBrabant) can be found on map at\n<http://www.amsterdam.co.kr/general/maps/nl_map_provinces.gif>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the Netherlands is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00bv>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 6 May 2009\n Infection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals,\nincluding other species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C.\nburnetii_ does not usually cause clinical disease in these animals,\nalthough abortion in goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_\ninfection. \n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. [History Q fever in animals, Netherlands]\n\n1. 2005: _Coxiella burnetii_ was 1st identified as the cause of\nabortion on 2 dairy-goat farms in the Netherlands.\n2. 2006: Q-fever outbreaks diagnosed on 6 dairy-goat farms and one\ndairy-sheep farm\n3. 2007: Q-fever outbreaks diagnosed on 7 dairy-goat farms\n4. 2008: Q-fever outbreaks diagnosed on 7 dairy-goat farms and one\ndairy-sheep farm.\n\nb. [History Q fever in humans, Netherlands]\n\n1. Period 1997-2006: N=93.\n2. Period 1 Jan 2007-4 Mar 2009\n2007: N=192; 2008: N=958, 2009: N=3\n\nExperts believe there is a connection between the outbreaks on goat\nand sheep dairy farms and the human outbreak, [since] large amounts\nof _Coxiella burnetii_ are spread by infected animals mainly via\nfeces and in case of abortions.\n\nc. Measures taken in 2008:\n\n1. Notification obligation for goat and sheep farms in case of high\nabortion rates:\n\n- For farms with less than 100 animals: 3 abortions within 30 days\n- For larger farms: greater than 5 percent abortion of pregnant\nanimals within 30 days\n\n2. Restrictions for infected farms:\n\n- No visitors allowed in the stable for 3 months\n- No manure may be removed from the stable for 3 months\n\nd. Vaccination of animals:\n\n1. 2008 - voluntary, applied vaccine 'Q-fever vaccine Coxevac,'\nProduced by CEVA (already in large scale use in France; not\nauthorized, but application has been submitted).\n2. Technical details: Inactivated, no adjuvants; 100 g/mL antigen.\n\ne. Measures that will be taken in 2009:\n\n1. Notification obligation for goat and sheep farms in case of high\nabortion rates (same as in 2008)\n2. Compulsory vaccination of 'high risk' goat and sheep farms of the\nNetherlands: Large dairy-goat and dairy-sheep farms (at least 50\nanimals), and Goat/sheep farms with a public function (e.g.\nchildren's petting farms)\n3. Voluntary vaccination in the rest of the Netherlands\n4. Hygiene protocol, which is in part mandatory\n5. Extra research\n\n[Byline: Christianne Bruschke, Dutch Ministry of Agriculture, Nature\nand Food Quality, 6 May 2009]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Netherlands has become Europe's heaviest Q-fever-infected country,\nwith significant public health concern. Consequent to the unusually\nextensive infection in humans, in 3 provinces, special preventive and\ncontrol measures in animals have been applied. Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (03): UPDATE, ANIMAL VACCINATION\n***********************************************\n Effect of\nvaccination with phase I and phase II Coxiella burnetii vaccines in\npregnant goats.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-05-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2009-05-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Presentations", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the \n Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "267526", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=267526", "date": "2009-08-14 03:00:07", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (06)\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 14 May 2009\nSource: Eurosurveillance 2009; 14(19): 1-3, 14 May [abridged, edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/images/dynamic/EE/V14N19/art19210.pdf>\n\n\n[The Q fever epidemic in South Netherlands has been continuing during 2009.\nEarlier 2009 postings addressed mainly public health aspects of the issue,\nprecise routes of human infection remaining, at least in several cases,\nrather ambiguous. The following Eurosurveillance Rapid Communication was\nwritten jointly by public and animal health experts, covering both aspects.\n- Mod.AS]\n\nSince 1978, when Q fever in humans became a notifiable disease in the\nNetherlands, until 2006, the number of notifications had ranged between one\nand 32 cases annually, with an average of 17 cases per year. However, in\n2007, Q fever emerged as an important human and veterinary public health\nchallenge, with large epidemics in the southern part of the Netherlands. In\n2007, 168 human cases were notified, and in 2008 exactly 1000 human cases\nwere registered. Notification criteria for acute Q fever are a clinical\npresentation with at least fever, or pneumonia, or hepatitis and\nconfirmation of the diagnosis in the laboratory. Currently, the laboratory\ncriteria are a 4-fold rise in IgG antibody titre against _C. burnetii_ in\npaired sera or the presence of IgM-antibodies against phase II antigen.\nIdentification of _C. burnetii_ in patient material with a PCR test will\nsoon be added to the notification criteria. Notification of probable cases,\ndefined as clinical signs with a single high antibody titre is voluntary.\n\nCurrent situation\n-----------------\nFrom April 2009, a sharp increase in Q fever was observed again, and a\ntotal of 345 cases (including 13 probable) were notified between 1 Jan and\n11 May 2009. For 11 cases, the date of illness onset was in 2008, and one\ncase fell ill in 2007, resulting in a total of 333 cases with confirmed or\npresumed illness onset in 2009. The overall male-to-female ratio for these\n333 cases was 1.7:1 with a median age of 49 years (IQR 38-61 years). The\nepidemic curve for 2009 shows an even steeper increase in case numbers in\nApril-May than in the previous 2 years, suggesting that an epidemic of at\nleast the same magnitude as the one in 2008 is imminent. While most cases\nreside in the same region in the province of Noord-Brabant as the cases\nreported in 2007 and 2008, the geographic area seems to be expanding [map\nfor 2007-2008 at\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/images/dynamic/EE/V13N31/Qfever_Netherlands_Figure3.jpg>;\nmap for 2009 (May) at\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/images/dynamic/EE/V14N19/Q_Fever_Fig2.jpg>.\n- Mod.AS].\n\nSeparate clusters with multiple sources\n---------------------------------------\nIt is becoming increasingly clear that the overall outbreak consists of at\nleast 10 separate clusters with multiple sources, mainly in the province of\nNoord Brabant. For some clusters, a clear epidemiological link could be\nestablished to small ruminant farms with clinical Q fever cases in animals\npresented as abortion waves. For other clusters, such a link was less\nobvious. An example of the latter is a medium sized city (87 000\ninhabitants) that experienced a 2nd Q fever outbreak in 2009 similar to the\none in 2008. In 2008, a dairy goat farm with abortions due to Q fever was\nsuspected as the source, but in 2009 there were no veterinary notifications\nfrom the area. The 73 notified human cases residing in the city were\nclustered in the same part of the city as the cases that were notified in\n2008. It remains unclear whether the same source is involved, whether the\nbacteria have persisted and survived in the local environment, whether the\nprimary source in 2008 has resulted in secondary sources in 2009, or\nwhether there is increased awareness among health professionals in this\npart of the city based on the 2008 experience.\n\nIn March 2009, the Animal Health Service reported a Q fever positive farm\nin the province of Limburg with more than 1000 goats. The place also serves\nas a care farm for young people with mental disabilities who work there as\npart-time farmhands. Prompted by this notification, the municipal health\nservice (MHS) South Limburg performed active laboratory screening by ELISA\nof the individuals affiliated to this goat farm. The screening, which\ninvolved a total of 96 people, has resulted in 28 notified symptomatic\ncases to date.\n\nVeterinary situation\n--------------------\nThe total number of registered small ruminant farms in the Netherlands is\n52 000, of which 350 are professional dairy goat farms with more than 200\nadult goats, and 40 are professional dairy sheep farms. In 2005, Q fever\nwas diagnosed for the 1st time as a cause of abortion at a dairy goat farm,\nusing immunohistochemistry on sections of placenta. A 2nd case was\ndiagnosed later in 2005. In 2006, 2007 and 2008, 6, 7 and 7 new cases at\ndairy goat farms were confirmed, respectively, mainly in the same area\nwhere human cases occurred. In the same period, 2 cases of abortion caused\nby _C. burnetii_ were confirmed at dairy sheep farms, one in the southern\nand one in the northern part of the country, but these 2 cases do not seem\nto be related to human cases. Analyses of abortion outbreaks showed that\nthe average number of goats per farm was 900, of which 20 percent aborted,\nranging from 10-60 per cent. The average number of sheep on both infected\nsheep farms was 400, and the abortion rate was 5 per cent.\n\nAbortion outbreaks before June 2008 were reported on a voluntary basis to\nthe Animal Health Service and also confirmed by immunohistochemistry. Since\nJune 2008, notification of Q fever in goats and sheep is mandatory in the\nNetherlands. There is a legal requirement for farmers and their private\nveterinary surgeons to notify the occurrence of abortion in small ruminants\nheld in deep litter houses. For large farms (greater than 100 animals), the\nnotification criterion is an abortion wave defined as an abortion\npercentage higher than 5 per cent among pregnant animals. For smaller\nholdings, a criterion of 3 or more abortions in a 30 day period is used.\nFrom January to April 2009, this new regulation has led to notification of\n3 dairy goat farms with clinical cases of Q fever. One farm is located in\nthe province of Overijssel (notified in February 2009), one in the south of\nthe province of Limburg (notified in March 2009), and one in the province\nof Noord-Brabant (notified in April 2009). This veterinary notification can\npotentially facilitate the detection of related human cases or clusters.\nVeterinarians, physicians and the public are informed through targeted\nmailings, publications and the media. The exact location of animal farms\nwith clinical Q fever is now reported to the municipal health service. In\nFebruary 2009, a nationwide stringent hygiene protocol became mandatory for\nall professional dairy goat and sheep farms, independent of Q fever status.\n\nVaccination campaigns\n---------------------\nIn the fall of 2008, a voluntary vaccination campaign was implemented in\nthe province of Noord Brabant. In total, about 36 000 small ruminants were\nvaccinated in an area with a radius of 45 km around Uden, a small town in\nthe centre of the high-risk area. Another mandatory vaccination campaign\nled by the Animal Health Service (GD) started on 21 Apr 2009. From April to\nOctober 2009, 200 000 small ruminants will be vaccinated in an area which\nincludes the province of Noord-Brabant and parts of the provinces of\nGelderland, Utrecht and Limburg.\n\nConclusion\n----------\nFor the 3rd consecutive year, the Netherlands is facing a large outbreak of\nQ fever. The new upsurge in Q fever cases in 2009 is alarming. The\nmandatory vaccination campaign among small ruminants that was started in\nApril 2009, if effective, is expected to reduce the occurrence of abortion\nwaves and excretion of _Coxiella_ in the lambing season of 2010. There is a\nlarge portfolio of ongoing multidisciplinary research, but it will take\nsome time before results become available that eventually will lead to the\nimplementation of extended and improved control measures.\n\n[byline: B Schimmer, F Dijkstra, P Vellema, P M Schneeberger, V Hackert, R\nter Schegget, C Wijkmans, Y van Duynhoven, W van der Hoek. For their\nrespective affiliations, refer to the original paper at the above URL]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nGut Laach\n52385 Nideggen\n<CVLonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[During July 2009, the Dutch ministry of agriculture issued several press\nreleases concerning Q fever. They addressed mainly the following two topics:\n\n1. Since animals should not be vaccinated during pregnancy and in view of\nthe need to increase the vaccination coverage, it was advised to delay the\nbreeding season of goats.\n2. Specific requirements pertaining to the treatment of manure on the sheep\nand goat farms were updated. Though such requirements address all farms,\nthey are different in infected and uninfected flocks.\n\nSubscribers are encouraged to read the full Eurosurveillance paper at the\nabove URL. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "While most cases\nreside in the same region in the province of Noord-Brabant as the cases\nreported in 2007 and 2008, the geographic area seems to be expanding [map\nfor 2007-2008 at\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/images/dynamic/EE/V13N31/Qfever_Netherlands_Figure3.jpg>;\nmap for 2009 (May) at\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/images/dynamic/EE/V14N19/Q_Fever_Fig2.jpg>. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 14 May 2009\n It remains unclear whether the same source is involved, whether the\nbacteria have persisted and survived in the local environment, whether the\nprimary source in 2008 has resulted in secondary sources in 2009, or\nwhether there is increased awareness among health professionals in this\npart of the city based on the 2008 experience. For their\nrespective affiliations, refer to the original paper at the above URL]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\n In the same period, 2 cases of abortion caused\nby _C. burnetii_ were confirmed at dairy sheep farms, one in the southern\nand one in the northern part of the country, but these 2 cases do not seem\nto be related to human cases. In\n2007, 168 human cases were notified, and in 2008 exactly 1000 human cases\nwere registered. The 73 notified human cases residing in the city were\nclustered in the same part of the city as the cases that were notified in\n2008. For some clusters, a clear epidemiological link could be\nestablished to small ruminant farms with clinical Q fever cases in animals\npresented as abortion waves. In 2008, a dairy goat farm with abortions due to Q fever was\nsuspected as the source, but in 2009 there were no veterinary notifications\nfrom the area. In\nFebruary 2009, a nationwide stringent hygiene protocol became mandatory for\nall professional dairy goat and sheep farms, independent of Q fever status. Earlier 2009 postings addressed mainly public health aspects of the issue,\nprecise routes of human infection remaining, at least in several cases,\nrather ambiguous. An example of the latter is a medium sized city (87 000\ninhabitants) that experienced a 2nd Q fever outbreak in 2009 similar to the\none in 2008. For large farms (greater than 100 animals), the\nnotification criterion is an abortion wave defined as an abortion\npercentage higher than 5 per cent among pregnant animals. In 2005, Q fever\nwas diagnosed for the 1st time as a cause of abortion at a dairy goat farm,\nusing immunohistochemistry on sections of placenta. Notification criteria for acute Q fever are a clinical\npresentation with at least fever, or pneumonia, or hepatitis and\nconfirmation of the diagnosis in the laboratory. Minister Gerda\nVerburg of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality (LNV) and Minister Ab\nKlink of Public Health, Welfare and Sport (VWS) will undertake the\ncosts of the vaccine as well as of its administration to the animals.\nHolders of dairy goats and sheep for whom the vaccination is not\nobligatory, will receive only the costs of the vaccine.\n\nMinister Verburg already published the vaccination area which\nincludes almost the entire south of the Netherlands (see map at\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/cdlpub/servlet/CDLServlet?p_file_jd=34143>). In\nthis area, holdings with more than 50 dairy goats or milking sheep\nmust vaccinate against Q fever. This applies also to children's and\nOccupational Therapy farms with smaller number of goats or sheep.\nFarms outside the prescribed vaccination area, which suffered\noutbreaks of Q fever since 2005, must also vaccinate. All the\nmentioned farms will get the vaccine and its administration free of\ncharge.\n\nAll others (holdings with fewer than 50 animals in the vaccination\narea or any holdings outside the vaccination area) may voluntarily\nvaccinate. They get the vaccine free, but must cover the costs of\nadministration by veterinarian.\n\nMinister Verburg has ordered 400 000 doses of the vaccine from a\npharmaceutical company by a pharmaceutical company. The 1st batch of\n50 000 doses will be supplied in mid-April 2009; the 2nd batch,\nincluding 300 000 doses will be supplied in mid June 2009. These 350\n000 doses are intended for the obligatory vaccinations. The remaining\n50 000 doses are expected in September 2009. The vaccination campaign\nis led by the Animal Health Service (GD) [GD is a Dutch\nmarket-oriented organisation primarily for the improvement of animal\nhealth and safety of animal products. Veterinary specialists provide\nfarmers and veterinary practitioners with assistance and advice not\nonly for the fight against infectious diseases but also regarding\naspects of animal husbandry and animal welfare. GD was founded in\n1919 by and for farmers, with the objective of preventing and\neradicating animal diseases. It was a foundation until 2000. In 2000\nGD was converted into a private company. - Mod.AS] Q fever\nvaccinations will be carried out by veterinarians chosen by the\nanimal owners.\n\nThe estimated cost of mandatory vaccination is nearly 2 million euro\n[USD 2 535 497]. On top of the vaccine and its administration, this\nbudget covers also the costs of the GD as well as monitoring and\nresearch.\n\nQ fever is a disease caused by the bacterium _Coxiella burnetii_which\ncan infect all domestic farm animals as well as pets, rodents and\nbirds. It is a zoonotic disease, which means possible spread from\nanimal to man.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The unique Q fever epidemic/epizootic which started in 2007 in 2\nDutch provinces, Noord Brabant and Gelderland, has become probably\nthe world's largest -- and an example of applied One Medicine\nconcept, since it led to the described effort by the 2 relevant\nministries, Public Health and Agriculture, to prevent human infection\nby large-scale mass animal vaccination. Vaccinations have been\nalready applied, though on a smaller scale, during the last semester\nof 2008.\n\nUntil 2007, the annual number of human Q fever cases in the\nNetherlands did not exceed 15; this has risen to more than 1000\npatients in 2008. Interestingly, the direct or indirect connection\nbetween animal and human has -- so far -- not been unequivocally\ndemonstrated in all cases. A considerable number of cases were urban;\nan official ban to spread manure from goat and sheep farms did not\nseem to achieve significant results. Other hygienic measures, and\nparticularly avoiding pregnant women from contact with small\nruminants, have been applied. Much still remains to be learnt and\nexplained. It is therefore fortunate that monitoring and research are\ncovered in the budget, mutually taken care for by the 2 ministries.\nHopefully, the contribution of the vaccination to improved public\nhealth will be convincingly demonstrated; results are anticipated\nwith great interest. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The unique Q fever epidemic/epizootic which started in 2007 in 2\nDutch provinces, Noord Brabant and Gelderland, has become probably\nthe world's largest -- and an example of applied One Medicine\nconcept, since it led to the described effort by the 2 relevant\nministries, Public Health and Agriculture, to prevent human infection\nby large-scale mass animal vaccination. Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/portal/page?_pageid=116,1640333&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_news_item_id=23704>\n\n\nMinister of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality (LNV), Verburg,\nannounced that [the animals] in the large sheep and goat dairy farms\nwill be vaccinated against Q-fever, starting Monday 20 Oct 2008.\nVaccine for other farms and holdings will become available on 3 Nov\n2008, but in view of the limited availability of the vaccine, it will\nalso be available only within 45 km (28 mi) around the outbreak in\nUden, where most human cases have occurred as well.\n\nThere are 80 000 doses of vaccine available. As each animal must be\nvaccinated twice, a total of 40 000 animals can be vaccinated.\n\nThe number of Q-fever cases detected in humans in Brabant during 2008\nexceeds any previously known figures. Most of these infections were\nsubclinical or expressed mild flu symptoms, but infections have also\nled to pneumonia, sometimes requiring hospitalization. The minister\nhas opted for a vaccination program [of animals] to prevent human Q\nfever infection. She does this in addition to the measures already\ntaken [regarding animals], namely mandatory disease reporting, manure\nhandling steps, and hygiene-related advice.\n\nDue to the limited availability of the vaccine and in order to obtain\na meaningful evaluation of the vaccination's effect, until 2 Nov 2008\nit will be limited to the 45 km radius area, within which it will be\napplied in commercial sheep and goat dairy farms with at least 50\nanimals, and children's farms.\n\nFrom 3 Nov 2008, other sheep and goat farms will be allowed\nvaccination in the vicinity of Uden. For this end, farmers are\nadvised to contact their veterinarians.\n\nThe vaccine is not yet officially registered, but the Bureau of\nAnimal Health Preparations has studied and approved all safety\naspects related to its field application. On this basis, the Ministry\nof Agriculture has granted an exemption for the use of this vaccine\nuntil 31 Dec 2008.\n\nThe vaccine is provided by the Ministry of Agriculture free of\ncharge. The costs of application of the vaccines by a veterinarian\nare to be borne by the animal owners. The general veterinary\nrequirements regarding registration, listing, and bookkeeping are\napplicable.\n\nThe vaccine is distributed, at the request of farmers, by the Food\nand Consumer Product Safety Authority (VWA).\n\n--\nCommunicated by\nM Wijdeveld, Baarn\nThe Netherlands\n<wijdeveld.baarn@wanadoo.nl>\n\n[According to OIE's WAHID [World Animal Health Information Database]\ninterface, the only member-country applying Q fever vaccination in\nsmall ruminants is Israel (26 957 vaccinations in 2007). The vaccine\nused in Israel is a commercial, inactivated, bivalent vaccine --\ncombined with chlamydia.\n\nAccording to OIE's terrestrial manual, an inactivated phase I vaccine\nis commercially available in Slovakia for vaccination of cattle. A\nreview of Q fever in Slovakia suggests that the decrease in the\noccurrence of human and animal Q fever could be the result of the\nlarge-scale vaccination of cattle that was carried out there during\n10 years, together with improved veterinary control of domestic\nanimal transport within the country (Serbezov VS et al (1999): Q\nfever in Bulgaria and Slovakia. Infected patients were followed\nfor symptoms and ultrasound was performed as indicated. A definitive\nsource of the infection could not yet be identified. Favourable\nclimatic conditions were suspected as the cause for the combination\nof widespread dissemination among goats and transmission to humans.\n----\nQ fever should be considered in patients in The Netherlands who\npresent with lower airway infection and, in rare cases, hepatitis.\nReporting atypical clusters of pneumonia to the Municipal Health\nService (GGD) is advisable. The GGD maintains close contact with\nAnimal Health Services, which is aware of current infectious animal\ndiseases. Targeted investigation can identify the source of infection\nand eliminate it. Q fever, an\ninfectious disease, which is transmitted to humans [usually] via\ncontact with sheep and goats, is caused by the _Coxiella burnetii_\nbacterium. It can cause fever and even pneumonia.\n\nUsually, only between 5 and 20 cases are reported a year, but in 2007\na major outbreak occurred in a village near the town of Oss, where\naround 170 fell ill.\n\nThis year [2008], the number has risen to 497 from all across the province.\n\nThe health authorities say they have no explanation for the sudden\nincrease in the number of infections, adding that they doubt whether\nthe outbreak has been brought under control.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 25 Jul 2008\nSource: Netherlands Info Services (NIS) News Bulletin [edited]\n<http://www.nisnews.nl/public/250708_2.htm>\n\n\nThe outbreak of Q fever in the Netherlands is unique in the world.\nThis is the conclusion of scientists following an international\nconference held by the National Institute for Healthcare ad the\nEnvironment (RIVM) in partnership with the Health Council.\n\n'Experts from Canada, France, Germany, Denmark, Sweden, and the\nNetherlands participated in the meeting. Via the exchange of\nexperiences it came to light that the situation in the Netherlands is\nunique in the world,' according to the RIVM. 'There have also been\noutbreaks of Q fever in other countries, but not in such an extended\nand densely populated area as at present in the province of\nNoord-Brabant.'\n\nQ fever occurred sporadically in the Netherlands before 2007. But in\n2007, the number of cases climbed to 497, of which 369 were in\nNoord-Brabant, many around the town of Oss.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail previously posted regarding the earlier part of this\noutbreak in 2007 (Q fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland)\n20070809.2592). As discussed below, the organism, often acquired by\nclose exposure to animals, is infectious with a very low inoculum and\nmay be aerosolized over a distance. It is not clear what contact the\ninfected people had with animals or how close they were to farms.\n\n_Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was discovered in 1937.\nThis organism is an agent that can be resistant to heat and\ndesiccation, and is highly infectious by the aerosol route. A single\ninhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human]\nprimates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was found to be\n1.7 organisms (1).\n\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals,\nincluding other species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C.\nburnetii_ does not usually cause clinical disease in these animals,\nalthough abortion in goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_\ninfection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of\ninfected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta.\nContact with contaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission\n(2).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication along with the less resistant\nlarge cell form, metabolically dormant, and spore-like (3).\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. Other modes of transmission to humans, including tick\nbites and human-to-human transmission, are rare.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C: An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of 'Q fever.' Pub Hlth Rep 1941; 56:\n1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D: Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12: 518-53.\n3. Norlander L: Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes\nInfect 2000; 2: 417-24.\n4. CDC online: Q fever\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/qfever>\n\nThe location of the southern province of Noord-Brabant (North\nBrabant) can be found on map at\n<http://www.amsterdam.co.kr/general/maps/nl_map_provinces.gif>.\nOss, in the northern part of the province, can be located on the map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image:LocatieOss.png>.\n\nGelderland, an adjacent province was also involved in the initial\n2007 outbreak - Mod.LL\n\nAn image of _C. burnetii_ bacteria is at:\n<http://www.ditrix.ru/images/pm/burnetii.jpg>\n- Mod.JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n Infection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals,\nincluding other species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C.\nburnetii_ does not usually cause clinical disease in these animals,\nalthough abortion in goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_\ninfection. \n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Q fever, an\ninfectious disease, which is transmitted to humans [usually] via\ncontact with sheep and goats, is caused by the _Coxiella burnetii_\nbacterium. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication along with the less resistant\nlarge cell form, metabolically dormant, and spore-like (3). There have also been\noutbreaks of Q fever in other countries, but not in such an extended\nand densely populated area as at present in the province of\nNoord-Brabant.' promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail previously posted regarding the earlier part of this\noutbreak in 2007 (Q fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland)\n20070809.2592). \n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. \n\nThe health authorities say they have no explanation for the sudden\nincrease in the number of infections, adding that they doubt whether\nthe outbreak has been brought under control. Usually, only between 5 and 20 cases are reported a year, but in 2007\na major outbreak occurred in a village near the town of Oss, where\naround 170 fell ill. LL\n\nAn image of _C. burnetii_ bacteria is at:\n<http://www.ditrix.ru/images/pm/burnetii.jpg>\n- Mod. Indeed, in [non-human]\nprimates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was found to be\n1.7 organisms (1). As discussed below, the organism, often acquired by\nclose exposure to animals, is infectious with a very low inoculum and\nmay be aerosolized over a distance. But in\n2007, the number of cases climbed to 497, of which 369 were in\nNoord-Brabant, many around the town of Oss. The location of the southern province of Noord-Brabant (North\nBrabant) can be found on map at\n<http://www.amsterdam.co.kr/general/maps/nl_map_provinces.gif>. This is the conclusion of scientists following an international\nconference held by the National Institute for Healthcare ad the\nEnvironment (RIVM) in partnership with the Health Council. Via the exchange of\nexperiences it came to light that the situation in the Netherlands is\nunique in the world,' according to the RIVM. ' Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nGelderland, an adjacent province was also involved in the initial\n2007 outbreak - Mod. The 25 Jul 2008 edition of de Volkskrant reports on an outbreak of Q\nfever in the southern province of North Brabant. \n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00", "1941-03-25 00:00:00", "1937-03-25 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "Denmark"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "99905", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands (03): (NBR, GEL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=99905", "date": "2008-08-02 17:00:28", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (03): (NOORD BRABANT, GELDERLAND)\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] Human, Eurosurveillance report\n[2] Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality Press Release\n[3] Animal Health Service\n\n*****\n[1] Human, Eurosurveillance report\nDate: Thu 31 Jul 2008\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=18939>\n\n\nQ fever is a worldwide zoonosis caused by the\nbacterium _Coxiella burnetii_ which is common in\na wide range of wild and domestic animals. Cattle\nand small ruminants, in particular sheep and\ngoats, have been associated with large human\noutbreaks. Humans become infected primarily by\ninhaling aerosols that are contaminated by _C.\nburnetii_. Most infections remain asymptomatic\nbut in about 40 percent lead to a febrile\ndisease, pneumonia and/or hepatitis. Chronic\ninfections, mainly endocarditis, are observed in\n3 to 5 percent of cases, with an increased risk\nfor pregnant women and persons with heart valve\ndisorders or impaired immunity. Q fever in\npregnancy, whether symptomatic or asymptomatic,\nmay also result in adverse pregnancy outcomes\n(1). Q fever in humans is a notifiable disease in\nThe Netherlands. The notification criteria for a\nconfirmed case is a positive serology defined by\nimmunofluoresence assay (IFA) test or a _C.\nburnetii_ complement fixation test (2). Also\nclinical patients diagnosed by PCR are considered\nas confirmed cases. Between 1997 and 2006, Q\nfever was notified rarely with an average of 11\n(range 5-16) cases annually [3). In 2007, we\nreported in this journal the 1st community\noutbreak of Q fever in the south of The\nNetherlands (4).\n\nCurrent situation\n-----------------\nWe report a 2nd large outbreak of Q fever that\nstarted in the 1st half of 2008. Since the spring\nof 2008, a marked increase in notified Q fever\ncases has been observed with a total of 677 cases\nnotified up to 24 Jul 2008 in OSIRIS, an\ninternet-based reporting system for notifiable\ninfectious diseases in The Netherlands. Of these\ncases, 17 had illness onset in 2007, 546 in 2008,\nwhile for the remaining 114 recently notified\ncases the date of illness onset is still unknown.\nThe majority of cases reported illness onset\nbetween week 18 and 24, similar to the outbreak\nin 2007 (Figure 1 [for figures see original URL -\nMod. LL]). The overall female to male ratio is\n1:1.7. The age distribution in 2008 ranges\nbetween 7 to 87 years (IQR 41-60 years, median 51\nyears) and is similar to the age distribution in\n2007 (Figure 2). The preliminary hospitalization\nrate of cases in 2008 was 22 percent compared\nto 43 percent during the same period (week 1-28)\nin 2007.\n\nOf the cases with illness onset in 2008 for whom\ninformation on symptoms was available (n=300), 94\npercent reported fever, followed by fatigue (89\npercent), night sweating (78 percent), headache\n(71 percent) and general malaise (63 percent). 65\npercent of the cases with known symptoms had\npneumonia. So far, no pregnancy has been reported\namong notified cases.\n\nAlthough the 2008 epidemic is located in the same\npart of the country as the outbreak in 2007, it\nis more widespread in the province of\nNoord-Brabant and expanded to the adjacent\nprovince of Gelderland (Figure 3). This area is\nknown for its large density of dairy goats. 75\npercent of the cases notified in 2008 reside in\none municipal health service region. Within this\nregion, several distinct clusters of Q fever have\nbeen observed in rural municipalities with\ncumulative incidences as high as 14 acute _C.\nburnetii_ infections per 1000 inhabitants (Figure\n3). The outbreak is ongoing but the numbers seem\nto decrease in the entire Q fever affected area.\n\nControl measures and new legislation\n------------------------------------\nSince 2007, Q fever has become an important\npublic health problem in The Netherlands,\nwarranting a continuous enhanced surveillance.\nEfficient data sharing between public health\ninstitutions and veterinary health partners on\nregional and national level is a prerequisite for\ntimely and thorough source tracing and\nidentification. Following the 2007 outbreak, an\ninformal agreement was made that the veterinary\nand the public health sectors would exchange\ninformation on farms with newly diagnosed animal\ncases of Q fever to allow for an adequate\nresponse and control. On 3 Jun 2008, an outbreak\nmanagement team was convened and recommended a\nmandatory notification of Q fever in ruminants.\nIn the same month this recommendation was\nimplemented by the Dutch Ministry of Agriculture\nand the Ministry of Health; farmers and\nveterinarians have to report symptoms compatible\nwith Q fever, usually abortion waves, in small\nruminants held in deep litter houses. In\naddition, a ban to spread manure during the 3\nmonths following the detection of Q fever at the\nfarm and a restriction for visitors at the and\nfarm were imposed (5,6).\n\nThe current situation has also led to public\nhealth questions about the need for screening of\npregnant women for Q fever and exclusion of blood\ndonations from individuals in affected regions.\nOn 22 Jul 2008, an international expert meeting\nwas organized by the National Institute for\nPublic Health and the Environment (RIVM) and the\nHealth Council of The Netherlands, with\nparticipation of the European Centre for Disease\nPrevention and Control (ECDC), to address these\nimportant issues. The outcome of this meeting\nwill be reported separately.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nThis is by far the largest community outbreak of\nQ fever ever reported in the literature. Other\nEuropean countries such as Denmark and Germany\nhave also reported a changing epidemiology of Q\nfever and an increase in cases in 2008 but not to\nthe same extent as in The Netherlands (7,8). The\nsharp increase in cases in the spring and the\nwidespread pattern of this community outbreak\nwith more than 600 cases reported in 2008 is\nalarming. This high number of notified cases is\npartly explained by an increased awareness of Q\nfever among general practitioners (GP),\nspecialists and medical microbiological\nlaboratories, especially in the region where the\n2007 outbreak occurred. We hypothesize that this\nhas also led to a different diagnostic approach\nand earlier diagnosis of suspected cases, leading\nto less hospital admissions in the notified\ncases. Signals from rural GP practices indicate,\nhowever, that there is an unprecedented marked\nand striking increase in pneumonia and signs and\nsymptoms associated with Q fever in their patient\npopulation [personal communication].\n\nTo date there has been no conclusive evidence as\nfor the source(s) of the epidemic. Although a\nsingle animal source can cause many human Q fever\ncases (9), the larger geographic area in which\ncases occur in 2008, compared to 2007, points at\nmultiple sources. Several studies to assess the\nrisk factors for Q fever in the general\npopulation, high-risk groups, and in ruminants\nare ongoing or starting in the near future\nincluding source investigations focusing mainly\nat small ruminant farms and pet farms.\n\nWe hope through this paper to raise awareness of\nthis problem and inspire colleagues from other\nEuropean countries to report whether they have\nobserved similar increase in Q fever case numbers\nand share their experience.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Carcopino X, Raoult D, Bretelle F, Boubli L,\nStein A: Managing Q fever during pregnancy: the\nbenefits of long-term cotrimoxazole therapy. Clin\nInfect Dis. 2007;45: 548-555.\n2. RIVM. Q fever. LL]\n\n*****\n[2] Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality Press Release\nDate: Wed 31 Jul 2008\nSource: Press release, Ministry of Agriculture,\nNature and Food quality [trans. from Dutch by\nMod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/portal/page?_pageid=116,1640333&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_news_item_id=23507>\n\n\nNew measures Q-fever outbreak Brabant\n-------------------------------------\nAn executive consultation on the Q-fever outbreak\nin Brabant has been held today [31 Jul 2008].\nRepresentatives of the ministries of Agriculture\nand Health, Animal Health Services (GD), National\nInstitute of Health and Environment (RIVM), the\nFood and Consumer Product Safety Authority (VWA)\nand administrators from the region discussed\nmeasures to be taken in order of controlling the\noutbreak.\n\nDuring today's [31 Jul 2008] administrative\nconsultations, the following 4 short-term\ndecisions were made:\n\n- Recently, the GD (Animal Health Services) have\nissued guidelines for goat farms about the\nprevention of Q-fever dissemination. The VWA will\ncarry out, during the coming 2 weeks, visits to\nall goat holdings in the affected areas in order\nto follow up the implementation of the said\nguidelines.\n\n- The Ministry of Agriculture will work with the\nVWA to ensure that hobby goat farmers are updated\nabout the hygienic requirements.\n\n- The Ministry of Agriculture will consult\nshortly manure-treatment experts about possible\nmeasures to limit the dissemination of the\nbacterium during the withdrawal process of the\nmanure from the animal dwellings [pen barns].\n\n- The Ministry of Agriculture will investigate,\nin a short term, whether the vaccination of goats\nagainst Q fever is useful and possible.\nSubsequently, the efficacy, safety and\navailability of vaccines will be addressed.\n\nFor the longer term, it was decided that RIVM\nwill make proposals for further studies into the\nroutes of transmission to man from the\nenvironment and from animals.\n\nAt present, the accumulated number of Q fever\ncases in humans is 686 [since Jan 2008]. The\ncases have been reported from the eastern half of\nNoord Brabant and from south Gelderland [Map at\n<http://www.map-of-netherlands.co.uk/images/netherlands-politcal-map.jpg>\n- Mod.AS].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Animal Health Service\nDate: Fri 1 Aug 2008\nSource: Agrarisch Dagblad [trans. and abridged from Dutch by Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.agd.nl/1057833/Nieuws/Artikel/Overal-antistoffen-Q-koorts.htm>\n\n\nAntibodies against the bacterium _Coxiella\nburnetii_, the causative agent of Q fever, are\nfound throughout the country in sheep and goats.\nThis is evident from the 1st results of an\ninvestigation of the Animal Health Service (GD).\nHowever, the percentage of animals with\nantibodies [outside the infected provinces, in\nthe South] has been low, as demonstrated by the\nresults of blood tests. 'These preliminary\nresults have been expected,' says veterinarian\nPiet Vellema of the GD. The final results are\nexpected early next year [2009].\n\nVellema calls it remarkable that only in the\nsouth of the country there are [heavily] infected\nfarms, and that human infections are limited to\nthat area. 'It is not clear how the\ncontamination on holdings took place. Possibly,\nan animal carrier had been present in the flock\nfor extended period before wider spread occurred'\n[This is indeed a possible mechanism of Q fever's\ndynamics, when wider infection follows a\nparturition or abortion of a single or few\ninfected silent carrier(s). - Mod.AS]\n\nThere are also holdings that have not suffered\nabortions in spite of the presence of animals\ninfected with _Coxiella burnetii_. 'The\npossibility exists that other species play a role\nin the dissemination of the bacterium, since it\nis not species-specific. But here we know too\nlittle.'\n\nThe knowledge about Q-fever deserves to be intensified, said Vellema.\n\n[Byline: Mariska Vermaas]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Additional background and data on the 2 major Q\nfever outbreaks in the Netherlands, in 2007 and\n2008, are available on-line at:\n\n1. Q fever outbreak in the Netherlands: a\npreliminary report. Eurosurveillance, Volume 12,\nIssue 32, 09 August 2007\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=3247#0>\n\n2. Large ongoing Q fever outbreak in the south\nof The Netherlands, 2008. Eurosurveillance,\nVolume 13, Issue 31, 31 July 2008 [1 above]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=18939>\n\nAccording to OIE's WAHID interface, Q fever in\nanimals became notifiable in the Netherlands\nsince 2006. Though such disease-status should\nenable quantitative information on the incidence\nof the disease, the Dutch report for 2006, while\nindicating that the disease was present, did not\nprovide figures. The interface does not include\nany information on Q fever in the Netherlands,\nsince Jan 2007.\n\nArticle 1.1.2.3. of OIE's Terrestrial Animal\nHealth Code says that a member country is obliged\nto notify, within 24 hours, any of the following\n(6) events:\n\n- the 1st occurrence of a listed disease listed\ndisease and/or infection in a country, a zone or\na compartment;\n\n- re-occurrence of a listed disease and/or\ninfection in a country, a zone or a compartment\nfollowing a report declared the outbreak ended;\n\n- the 1st occurrence of a new strain of a\npathogen of an OIE listed disease in a country, a\nzone or a compartment;\n\n- a sudden and unexpected increase in the\ndistribution, incidence, morbidity or mortality\nof a listed disease prevalent within a country, a\nzone or a compartment;\n\n- an emerging disease with significant morbidity\nor mortality, or zoonotic potential;\n\n- evidence of change in the epidemiology of a\nlisted disease (including host range,\npathogenicity, strain) in particular if there is\na zoonotic impact.\n\nNotifications, follow-up reports, and 6-monthly\nsummaries to the OIE are long due. -
