In a large retrospective\nstudy of patients seen between 1985 and 1998, 23 percent had chronic\nQ fever, and endocarditis was the predominant manifestation in 77\npercent of these patients.\nMost patients with Q fever endocarditis are men over the age of 40,\nbut women and children also develop this complication. An exposure\nfactor such as professional contact with cattle is frequently found,\nbut uncertainty about the incubation time and the usually long delay\nin diagnosis can mask important exposures.\nMost patients with Q fever endocarditis have preexisting valve\ndisease (93 percent in a series of 102 patients). The underlying\nheart disease may be congenital, rheumatic, degenerative, or\nsyphilitic. The aortic and mitral valves are often involved, but 55\npercent of patients in one report had prosthetic valve endocarditis.'\nIf further cases occur related to this cluster, it may be due to the\nrelative stability of the infectious form of _Coxiella burnetii_. The\norganisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA (SOUTH AUSTRALIA) (03): FATALITY\n***********************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-06-25 00:00:00"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "22090", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=22090", "date": "2007-08-09 16:00:13", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (NOORD-BRABANT, GELDERLAND)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 9 Aug 2007\nSource: Eurosurveillance weekly release 2007; 12(8) [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2007/070809.asp#2>\n\nOn 29 May 2007, a general practitioner (GP) from a rural village in the\nprovince of Noord-Brabant, in the south of the Netherlands, alerted the\nmunicipal health service about an unusual increase in pneumonia cases among\nadults in his practice. Cases presented with one or more of the following\nsymptoms: fever, night sweating, muscle pain, cough, and fatigue. A 2nd GP\nfrom a nearby village reported a similar alert soon thereafter and this led\nto a further investigation of the cases.\nEarlier in the month [May 2007], the same municipal health service received\nan alert by a regional medical microbiologist regarding an increase in\nsevere pneumonias that did not respond well to antibiotics. This 1st\ncluster of cases was initially attributed to _Mycoplasma pneumoniae_, but\nmore in-depth diagnostics revealed that the majority of these patients had\na positive serology for acute _Coxiella burnetii_ infection. Also, 6\nsporadic Q fever cases were reported from the same province through the\nmandatory notification system from January to April 2007. An investigation\nwas launched to describe the outbreak, find the source and route of\ntransmission, identify symptomatic and asymptomatic pregnant patients who\nare more likely to contract chronic Q fever (1) in the most affected area,\nand investigate possible links to animal reservoirs in the region in order\nto decide on appropriate control measures.\nAs Q fever is a rarely reported disease in the Netherlands, a broad case\ndefinition was used:\n- a confirmed case of Q fever was defined as any inhabitant of the\nNetherlands presenting to a GP with clinical symptoms consistent with Q\nfever since 1 Jan 2007 and who had laboratory confirmed positive serology\ndefined as a seroconversion or 4-fold increase of antibody titre using a\n_C. burnetii_ CFT (home-made complement fixation test using phase 1 and 2\nantigens) in samples taken at least 14 days apart, or showing positive for\nphase 2 IgM antibodies in the _C. burnetii_ IFA (Focus diagnostics) with a\n1:64 or greater dilution.\n- a probable case definition was also introduced only for an area in the\neast of the Noord Brabant region, where more cases were clustered, to\nbetter describe the outbreak there. Probable cases had clinical symptoms\nconsistent with Q fever and either a less than 4-fold increase in phase 2\nIgM within 14 days, or a single serum sample positive for phase 2 IgM\nantibodies in a dilution of 1:20 or greater.\n- in all cases, infection with _Legionella_ spp. was excluded.\nQ fever is caused by _Coxiella burnetii_, an intracellular bacterium. It is\nan almost worldwide appearing zoonosis whereby goats, sheep, and cattle\nhave been described as the most common animal reservoir for human\ninfections. Many Q fever outbreaks worldwide are temporally linked to the\nlambing season, as birth products from infected animals can be an important\nsource of environmental contamination and transmission to humans via the\naerosol route (2). At least 3 outbreaks of Q fever have been documented\nworldwide since January 2007: in the United Kingdom (3), Slovenia (4), and\nAustralia (5).\nIn the Netherlands, 5-20 cases of Q fever have been reported annually\nbetween 2000 and 2006 (6). From 1 Jan 2007 until 2 Aug 2007, 63 confirmed\nand probable cases with Q fever have been reported to the municipal health\nservices throughout the Netherlands; 59 of them were in the provinces of\nNoord Brabant and Gelderland, of which 36 were confirmed according to the\nused case definition. Among the 59 cases in these provinces, 27 were living\nin a well-defined area in the eastern part of Noord Brabant. It should be\nnoted that retrospective active case finding was initiated in the latter\narea for patients with a GP consultancy after 15 May 2007 to better\ndescribe the cluster of cases there. The overall male to female ratio is\n1.67 and the median age is 50 years. Date of symptoms onset is currently\navailable for 47 of all patients. The peak of case occurrence was in week\n21 [21-27 May] of 2007. According to the data available including week 30\n[23-29 Jul 2007], the last case had a symptoms onset in week 26 (figure,\nsee original URL. - Mod.LL)\nA trawling questionnaire was used to generate hypotheses about the possible\nsource of the outbreak in eastern Noord Brabant area. The municipal health\nservice undertook active case finding through the GP offices in this area,\nwhere about 11 500 inhabitants reside. The area is highly agricultural with\na large population of ruminants (cattle, sheep, and goats). The number of\ngoats has been reported to be increasing during the last decade in this\nregion, as has the degree of intensive goat farming (7); moreover, there\nhave been active reports of abortion waves due to _C. burnetii_ infection\namong the goat population in 2006 and 2007. Meteorological factors may also\nhave played a role in this outbreak setting, but this remains to be\ninvestigated. April [2007] was a very dry month; only 1.5 mm (0.06 in) of\nprecipitation fell in the nearby weather station of Eindhoven between 22\nMar 2007 and 6 May 2007, while the average precipitation value for April\nalone is 42 mm (1.7 in). Weather conditions, such as dry weather and wind,\nhave been documented to play an important role in other Q fever outbreaks\n(8,9).\nThis is the 1st documented outbreak of Q fever in the Netherlands, and it\nis currently under investigation. So far, only sporadic cases and family\nclusters related to direct animal contact had been observed here. It is\nalso an example of local GPs signalling an outbreak in the Netherlands,\nunderlining their role in early warning of outbreaks, before\nlaboratory-confirmed cases are reported to the health services. Further\nstudies are planned.\nReferences:\n1. Raoult D, Marrie TJ, Mege JL. Natural history and pathophysiology of Q\nfever. Lancet Infect Dis 2005; 5: 219-26.\n2. Cutler SJ, Bouzid M, Cutler RR. An investigation\nwas launched to describe the outbreak, find the source and route of\ntransmission, identify symptomatic and asymptomatic pregnant patients who\nare more likely to contract chronic Q fever (1) in the most affected area,\nand investigate possible links to animal reservoirs in the region in order\nto decide on appropriate control measures. Cases presented with one or more of the following\nsymptoms: fever, night sweating, muscle pain, cough, and fatigue.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["0180-07-25 00:00:00", "2007-01-01 00:00:00", "2007-05-06 00:00:00", "2007-05-25 00:00:00", "2007-08-02 00:00:00", "2007-01-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-04-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 01:20:00", "2007-08-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-05-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jena", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Slovenia", "country": "Slovenia"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Mycoplasma", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "98398", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands (02): (NBR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=98398", "date": "2008-07-28 20:00:28", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (02): (NBR) (02)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri 25 Jul 2008\nSource: Agrarisch Dagblad [trans. from Dutch by Mod.AS, edited].\n<http://www.agd.nl/1057422/Nieuws/Artikel/Forse-toename-meldingen-Q-koorts.htm?nb=agd&editie=28%20juli%202008&link=Forse%20toename%20meldingen%20Q-koorts&WT.mc_id=mail_agd_28%20juli%202008>\n\n\nA substantial increase in the number of reported Q-fever cases\n--------------------------------------------------------------\nThe number of reported cases of Q fever has risen sharply in recent\nweeks again [For the officially available data, indicating that the\n2008 epidemic seems to have peaked by now, see the commentary. - Mod.AS]\n\nThe Public Health Service for Brabant had, in their last census on 21\nJul 2008, 491 known cases. That means that 5000 Brabanders have been\nactually infected, says the Ministry of Health. The disease spread\nrapidly in Noord-Brabant and, to a lesser extent, in the Nijmegen\nregion. According to Roel Coutinho, head of the Centre for Infectious\nDisease Control, the actual number of victims is not 5-fold the\nnumber of reported cases but rather 10-fold.\n\nThe state branch of the Labour Party in Brabant has raised questions\nabout the matter to the Executive Council. According to council member\nNora Kasrioui, it is unclear what the directorate intends to do. 'The\ndisease is really a serious and growing problem for the population. We\nbelieve that the politics should go into action.' Kasrioui\nacknowledges that it is difficult to make policies aimed at Q fever\nbecause much remains unclear about the disease. 'Uncomfortable or\nnot, organizations can always use help, financial or otherwise.' [For\nthe official government policy and background, see item 2].\n\nAccording to Coutinho, the disease can never be fully eradicated.\nNormally it reappears during and following the lambing season. At\npresent, goats are seen as the main source of infection. The RIVM\n(National Institute of Health and Environment), along with veterinary\nexperts, is considering how the transfer from animal to man is\nestablished. Thereafter, a decision on further measures for disease\nprevention will be taken. Until last year [2007], Q fever was almost\nnon-existent in the Netherlands.\n\n[Byline: Jan Cees]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 10 Jun 2008\nSource: Dutch government official document No VD. 2008/1191,\n'Measures for Q fever' [Trans. from Dutch by Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/cdlpub/servlet/CDLServlet?p_file_id=28304>\n\n\nA letter from the Ministers of Agriculture and of Health to the Parliament\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nIntroduction\n------------\nDuring the recent weeks, a significant increase in the number of\nQ-fever infections in humans has been observed again in the\nnorth-eastern region of the province Noord (north) Brabant. This has\nled to unrest among local people. With this letter we will bring you\nup to date with additional precautionary measures that we will\nundertake to prevent the spread of Q-fever as much as possible.\n\nQ-fever\n-------\nQ fever is a disease caused by the bacterium _Coxiella burnetii_. It\nis a zoonotic disease, which means that spread from animals to humans\ncan take place. Q fever is traditionally present around the world and\nmay affect many species -- not only farm animals but also species\nsuch as birds, dogs, cats, rats and wild animals. Ticks can be a\nvector in the transmission of Q fever\nbetween animals.\n\nIn particular, small ruminants are regarded as a major source of\ninfection for humans. After excretion, the bacterium can survive a\nlong time in the air and sometimes spread over long distances. People\ncan be infected through various routes, including the inhalation of\ninfectious, airborne particles. Human infection is often manifested by\nmild symptoms but a more serious course may occur.\n\nThe main clinical sign of Q fever in ruminants is abortion in\npregnant animals, caused by the bacterium. During and after the\nabortion the animals excrete large quantities of the bacteria in\ntheir manure.\n\nSmall ruminants intended for milk production are held mainly in\nso-called pen barns. A pen barn is a shed where the manure is covered\non a regular basis with a new layer of straw. When the mixture of\nmanure and straw reaches a certain height, the shed is emptied.\nEspecially during the manure removal process, bacteria are shed into\nthe air with the consequent risk for both the public and animal\nhealth. Possibly, the spreading of manure on land is also a risk\nfactor, but this procedure seems to be of less significance than the\nremoval process of manure from the pen barns. This difference became\napparent since manure from Noord Brabant farms has been used as\nfertilizer in other provinces without harmful results in humans.\n\nInitiatives undertaken\n----------------------\nFollowing the 2007 Q-fever outbreak in Herpen, Noord-Brabant, some\nsteps were agreed between the Ministry of Health, Welfare and Sport\n(VWS) and the Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality (LNV)\nto obtain better insight regarding the Q-fever problem and to\nprevent, as far as possible, its spread to man. In this framework,\nadvisory information on the hygiene measures to be applied in\nsmall-ruminant farms has been prepared and published on the sites of\nthe Health, Welfare and Sports Ministry, the Agriculture Ministry,\nand the Animal Health Service (GD).\n\nResearch by the Health Services has been undertaken in both large and\nsmall ruminant sectors to obtain better understanding of the extent\nof the problem. This research is funded by both sectors and by the\ngovernment. There is also research under way into the risk factors for\nthe spread of Q-fever.\n\nThe relevant research institutes, namely the National Institute of\nHealth and Environment (RIVM), the Central Veterinary Research\nInstitute (CVI) and the Health Service (GD) are also in the process\nof development and validation of testing methods suitable for the\ndetection and identification of the bacterium.\n\nFinally, a research initiative is ongoing regarding intervention\nstrategies. Special attention is paid to a vaccine which is currently\nbeing tested in Denmark and France, considering its possible\nexperimental application in the Netherlands as well.\n\nDesignating Q fever as an infectious, reportable animal disease\n---------------------------------------------------------------\nIn order to be able to apply preventive and control measures on animal\nholdings, Q fever should be designated a reportable infectious animal\ndisease. Indeed, this has been carried out by the Minister of\nAgriculture, adding Q fever to the list of animal diseases (including\nzoonoses) for which compulsory prevention, control and monitoring are\nregulated. Holders of small ruminants kept in pen barns are required\nto report signs which may indicate Q fever. This requirement obliges\nthe veterinarians as well.\n\nMeasures regarding manure\n-------------------------\nExperts agree that manure probably plays an important role in the\ndissemination of the Q-fever agent in the province of Noord Brabant.\n\nAs a meaningful, provisional measure based on the precautionary\nprinciple, we plan to ban, for the duration of 3 months, the use of\nmanure from small ruminant holdings in pen barns where serious\ninfection has been established. A period of 3 months is regarded\nsufficient for a significant reduction of the infection load in the\nmanure. Since the removal of manure from the pen barns is unavoidable\nas soon as the installation runs full, a practical solution is to be\nsought and finalized soon.\n\nOther measures and consultations\n--------------------------------\nIn addition to the specific measures for the treatment of manure on\ninfected holdings, further sector-related advice will be given in\norder to prevent future spread of Q fever. One of the ideas is to\nprescribe an advanced timetable for an earlier-in-season spreading of\nmanure in the fields, preceding the lambing season. The aim is to\nprevent the utilization of the manure until at least 3 months after\nthe lambing season, allowing significant reduction of its infection load.\n\nHoldings with small ruminants are often frequented by recreation\nvisitors and others interested. Contacts of people with infected\npremises are also undesirable. Temporarily preventing visits to such\nholdings seems to us advisable.\n\nThere are also a certain number of sheep and goat farms which produce\ntheir own cheese. This is often made with raw milk. The consumption of\nraw products from infected farms is discouraged by the RIVM (National\nInstitute for Healthcare and the Environment). It seems therefore\nprimarily useful to prescribe pasteurization in certain cases. The\nMinister for Health, Welfare and Sport will take these measures in\nconsultation with RIVM.\n\nWith the above mentioned steps we try to limit, as far as possible,\nthe spread of Q fever. The measures are aimed at the earliest\npossible action to diminish the risk of further spread. The\ndevelopment of the policy is being continued.\n\n[Byline:\nG. Verburg, Minister of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, and\nDr. A. Klink, Minister of Health, Leisure and Sport]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above ministerial letter, addressed to the Dutch parliament,\nprovides interesting and useful information on the epidemiology of the\ndisease in the Netherlands and the preventive and control measures\nundertaken. It is also useful for those engaged in any handling of\nemergency situations related to zoonotic diseases. Hopefully, action\nplans and contemplated research will be accomplished according to plan.\n\nIn our previous posting (see ProMED archive below), data on the\ndisease incidence from different media sources were inconsistent; we\nare grateful to Naomi Bryant, National Travel Health Network and\nCentre (NaTHNaC), for drawing our attention to that. Official Q fever\ndata for the first 28 weeks of 2008 (1 Jan - 23 Jul 2008) are\navailable on the official website of the Public Health\nService for Brabant (GGD Hart voor Brabant). The total number of\nreported human cases during the said period was 538. The 1st cases\nappeared during week 3, remaining under 10/week until the 15th week,\nwhen it began to rise, peaking during week 22 (72 cases). She had underlying\nmedical conditions which resulted in a poor prognosis.\nI would also like to point out that I did not say that the risk of\nany further cases has passed. I said that it was unlikely but not\nimpossible that there would be more cases related to this outbreak,\nbecause the incubation period has passed and there have not been\nanimals at the abattoir since the middle of April [2007]. All 5 confirmed cases are residents of the\ntown of Cheltenham (Gloucestershire), population 109 800. There had\nbeen no cases reported in Gloucestershire since 2002. The cases\nreported in Cheltenham did not have any occupational risk factors.\nAlthough all 5 cases reported possible environmental risk factors, no\ncommon exposures have been identified so far.\nQ fever (caused by _Coxiella burnetti_) is thought to account for\napproximately one percent of community acquired pneumonia in the UK\neach year and can result in serious complications such as\nendocarditis. The main reservoir is sheep and other animals that can\nshed massive numbers in placental tissues. The main reservoirs are\nsheep, goats and cattle. Transmission of Q fever occurs primarily\nthrough inhalation of contaminated aerosols. The organism is robust\nand can survive in dust and animal litter for many weeks and in dried\nblood for at least 6 months at room temperature. The most infectious\nanimal materials are the fluids of birth and afterbirth, followed by\nblood, milk, urine and feces. Such infectious materials can be\nderived from livestock as above or from domestic animals,\nparticularly parturient cats.\nAlthough Q fever is rare in the UK, it is more common in the\nsouthwest of England and Northern Ireland, probably because of higher\nexposure to animal sources. The Health Protection Unit would be\ngrateful for information on any cases of Q fever who have visited\nGloucestershire during the incubation period (2 to 3 weeks, depending\non the infective dose). Please contact the Consultant Regional\nEpidemiologist, Isabel Oliver <Isabel.oliver@hpa.rg.uk>.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n[Cheltenham is in southern England in Gloucestershire and can be\nfound on a map at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheltenham>.\nCheltenham is well known for being the home of the flagship race of\nBritish steeplechase horseracing. More information is needed to\nassess how these individuals acquired this airborne infection, which\ncan spread over at least 1/2 mile. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nQ fever (caused by _Coxiella burnetti_) is thought to account for\napproximately one percent of community acquired pneumonia in the UK\neach year and can result in serious complications such as\nendocarditis. The\ngroup used Texas freedom-of-information requests to obtain documents\nabout the lab incidents.\nIn April 2007, the Sunshine Project reported that a Texas A&M\nresearcher had been infected with _Brucella_ after a February 2006\naerosol chamber mishap and that the school did not immediately notify\nthe CDC as required by federal law.\n[On 26 Jun 2007], the watchdog group reported that the exposure of 3\nother Texas A&M workers to _C. burnetii_, which causes Q fever, was\nconfirmed in April 2006 but also was not reported to the CDC.\nThe Sunshine Project said its investigation of Texas A&M came about\nthrough its review of select-agent labs that are vying to host the\nfederal government's planned new national biodefense facility,\naccording to a 27 Jun 2007 report in the Dallas Morning News.\nThe laboratory is affiliated with the Foreign Animal and Zoonotic\nDisease Defense Center, a US Department of Homeland Security (DHS)\ncenter of excellence that focuses on the study of foot-and-mouth\ndisease, avian influenza, and Rift Valley fever, according to the\ncenter's website. The center is funded by a USD 18 million DHS grant,\naccording to an Associated Press report.\nAccording to the Sunshine Project, Texas A&M notified the CDC about\nthe case of brucellosis in April 2007, a year after the worker's\nillness was confirmed. Shortly after Texas A&M report,\nrepresentatives from the CDC's Select Agents and Toxins Division\ninspected the laboratory and, in a 30 Jun 2007 memo, obtained and\nreleased by the Sunshine Project, ordered the lab to stop its work on\nall select agents and toxins until further notice.\nVon Roebuck, a CDC spokesman, told CIDRAP News that the agency has\nnever issued such a broad suspension order to a lab before. He said\nthe 30 Jun 2007 order applies to every agent the lab works with. The\nlist of affected agents is not public information because of security\nconcerns, Roebuck said. In the letter, the CDC outlined the concerns\nit has about the lab, which include the adequacy of biosafety plans,\nsecurity of the facility from unauthorized visitors, occupational\nsafety protocols, authorization from the CDC to work with certain\nagents, and compliance with federal select agent regulations.\nRoebuck said CDC officials would visit the Texas laboratory again in\nthe next few weeks to gather more information about its procedures\nand protocols. 'Then the agency will move forward with any\nrecommendations to get them under compliance,' he said.\nIn a statement sent to Texas A&M faculty and staff on Fri 29 Jun\n2007, the school's interim president, Eddie J. Davis, said the\nlaboratory incidents did not pose a threat to anyone on or off\ncampus, but conceded that the university should have reported the\nworker's brucellosis in a more timely manner. (The university\nprovided CIDRAP News with a copy of the statement.)\nDavis said none of the workers who were exposed to the Q fever agent\ngot sick and that Texas A&M was going beyond health monitoring\nstandards at other select-agent labs by monitoring workers' blood for\nthe organism. He said the University believed that the threshold for\nreporting worker exposure was a confirmed illness.\n'We are unequivocally committed to taking all appropriate steps to\nensure we are in full compliance with all CDC and any other relevant\npolicies and regulations,' he said.\n_Coxiella burnetii_ causes an influenza-like disease in humans that\nis rarely fatal, according to the CDC. However, it is highly\ninfectious when it becomes airborne and is inhaled by humans. The\nagent has previously been weaponized and is considered a potential\nterrorist threat.\nBrucellosis presents prolonged fever and a wide range of other\npossible manifestations, such as arthritis, hepatitis, and\nmeningitis. Symptoms can be prolonged, but the disease is rarely\nfatal. In livestock, brucellosis causes infertility and abortions. As\nbioterrorism agents, _Brucella_ strains are inexpensive to produce\nand disperse, according to an August 2005 article in the CDC journal\nEmerging Infectious Diseases (EID).\n[Byline: Lisa Schnirring]\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Texas A&M (Agriculture and Mining) University is located in College\nStation, TX, which can be found near the state capital of Austin on a\nmap of the state at\n<http://biochemistry.tamu.edu/images/tour/txmap.gif>\nPress releases from the Sunshine Project regarding these episodes can\nbe found at\n<http://www.sunshine-project.org/publications/pr/pr120407.html> and\n<http://www.sunshine-project.org/publications/pr/pr260607.html>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "[Texas A&M (Agriculture and Mining) University is located in College\nStation, TX, which can be found near the state capital of Austin on a\nmap of the state at\n<http://biochemistry.tamu.edu/images/tour/txmap.gif>\nPress releases from the Sunshine Project regarding these episodes can\nbe found at\n<http://www.sunshine-project.org/publications/pr/pr120407.html> and\n<http://www.sunshine-project.org/publications/pr/pr260607.html>. An outbreak of the disease has been linked to a Waikerie\ngoat abattoir. The Health Department says another person at Waikerie\nhas contracted the illness, taking to 5 the number of recent cases.\nQ fever is carried by animals and can cause flu-like symptoms in\npeople. The abattoir linked to the outbreak has suspended its operations.\nLoxton Waikerie Council says the abattoir is operating outside a 1997\ndevelopment application, which allows for the slaughter of emus and\nostriches. The Council had given the abattoir 21 days to stop\nprocessing goats, a deadline that expires next week [16-22 Jul 2007].\nThe abattoir's operator says the facility has been used to process\ngoat, sheep, and cattle for the past century.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Some forms of _Coxiella burnetii_ can be resistant to heat, drying,\nand many common disinfectants. These features enable the bacterium to\nsurvive for long periods in the environment and spread via aerosol\nfor some distance. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small-cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication (along with the less resistant\nlarge-cell form) and are metabolically dormant and spore-like (1). An\nearlier outbreak of infection in 51 persons in Scotland, UK, was tied\nto a meat processing plant and appeared to spread via aerosol for at\nleast 0.5 mile (0.8 km) (ProMED-mail 20060825.2394 Q fever, meat\nprocessing plant - UK (Scotland)(02)).\nThe Q fever organism is a Category B bioterrorism agent and, in fact,\nalthough not thought to be related to bioterrorism, was spread by\nmail in a post office in the UK in 1987 (2).\nOngoing drought in the area may produce more cases related to easier\naerosolization of the organism's infectious form.\nA map of the island country showing the location of South Australia\ncan be found at <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Australia>.\nReferences\n1. Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA (SOUTH AUSTRALIA) (02): ABATTOIR\n****************************************************\n These features enable the bacterium to\nsurvive for long periods in the environment and spread via aerosol\nfor some distance. Source: Australian Broadcasting Company [edited]\n<http://abc.net.au/news/stories/2007/07/13/1977731.htm>\n\nAnother case of Q fever has been confirmed in the South Australian\n The Council had given the abattoir 21 days to stop\nprocessing goats, a deadline that expires next week [16-22 Jul 2007].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00", "1987-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oxfordshire", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "18518", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever, veterinary students - Slovenia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=18518", "date": "2007-07-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER, VETERINARY STUDENTS - SLOVENIA\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 19 Jul 2007\nSource: Eurosurveillance weekly release, 2007 12(7) [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2007/070719.asp#1>\n\n[Reference:\nGrilc E, Socan M, Koren N, Ucakar V, Avsic T, Pogacnik M, Kraigher A:\nOutbreak of Q fever among a group of high school students in\nSlovenia, March-April 2007. Euro Surveill 2007; 12(7): E070719.1]\nA group of 33 veterinary students and 2 teachers contracted a\nlaboratory-confirmed Q fever infection during a training course on a\nsheep farm in Slovenia in March 2007. The disease is caused by\n_Coxiella burnetii_, an intracellular bacterium found worldwide in\nvarious species of farm and domestic animals.\nOutbreak investigation\n----------------------\nOn 17 Apr 2007, the Communicable Disease Centre at the National\nPublic Health Institute was informed about a case of Q fever in an\n18-year-old student of a veterinary high school. The patient had\ndeveloped high fever and a severe headache on 30 Mar 2007. Chest\nx-ray showed pneumonia. The student reported that her classmates in\nthe same school year had been complaining about similar symptoms.\nWe suspected that the patient and her schoolmates might have been\nexposed to a common source of Q fever when attending a training\ncourse on a sheep farm (Farm A) located in the southwestern part of\nSlovenia in March 2007 (1). An epidemiological investigation was\nlaunched involving all 3rd grade students of the veterinary high\nschool.\nEpidemiological and clinical data\n---------------------------------\nThe patient's high school year has 66 students. As part of their\ntraining, 45 of the students spent several hours between 5 and 23 Mar\n2007 on Farm A, together with 3 teachers. They were trimming sheep's\nfeet, disinfecting wounds, and applying intramuscular vitamins and\nanti-helminthic injections as a preventive measure to healthy animals\nin a stable with approximately 500 sheep. Parturition time of the\nsheep on Farm A was from end of January to beginning of March this\nyear [2007].\nWe interviewed all individuals who had been at Farm A, and tested\nthem for Q fever. In addition, 20 students who had not participated\nin the training course in March 2007 were included as a control\ngroup. One student from the control group had spent a short time on\nFarm A in autumn 2006. All interviewed individuals (68 altogether)\nhad been in contact with different domestic animals at home and\nduring school training courses at several locations.\nAmong 48 exposed individuals, there were 34 (71 percent) with fever\n(38 deg C (100.4 deg F) (or more) with or without a headache; 4\nindividuals (8 percent) had serious headaches only, but were not sure\nabout fever, and 3 individuals (6 percent) reported symptoms of a\ncommon cold; 7 individuals (15 percent) were asymptomatic. The 1st\nperson to develop symptoms of fever and headache started to feel ill\non 20 Mar 2007.\nAmong the 20 control subjects (including the student who had spent a\nshort time on the sheep farm in autumn 2006), 3 students reported\nhaving a prolonged cough, and one had symptoms of a common cold; 16\n(80 percent) students were completely asymptomatic.\nLaboratory investigation\n------------------------\nSerum samples were collected from 63 individuals (93 percent of the\n68 interviewees) and sent to the Institute of Microbiology and\nImmunology, Medical Faculty in Ljubljana. They were tested by\nindirect immunofluorescence (FOCUS diagnostics) for the presence of\nIgG and IgM antibodies to _C. burnetii_ phase I and II antigens. A\nlaboratory-confirmed case of acute Q fever was defined as an\nindividual with IgM titers higher than 1:16 and/or IgG titers higher\nthan 1:256.\nOverall, the results confirmed acute Q fever in 36 individuals (57\npercent of the 63 tested). Serum samples from 26 individuals (41\npercent) were negative and the test result of a single sample was\ninconclusive.\nOf a total of 48 individuals who were exposed on Farm A in March\n2007, 44 were tested and 35 of those (80 percent) were seropositive.\nThey are shown in the Figure by date of onset of symptoms. [To see\nthe figure, go to the original URL. - Mod.LL]\nOf 44 individuals tested, 8 exposed individuals (18 percent) were not\ninfected, and one had an inconclusive result. In the control group,\nnone was seropositive, except for the student who visited the sheep\nfarm in autumn 2006. The serology results of exposed versus\nnon-exposed individuals are summarised in the Table [refer to\noriginal URL. - Mod.LL]\nAmong the 36 laboratory-confirmed cases (35 exposed in March 2007 and\none exposed in autumn 2006), 4 were asymptomatic, while the other 32\n(89 percent) suffered from high fever, headache, chills, muscle\naches, sweating, and nausea; 25 patients (69 percent) consulted a\nphysician, and 3 (8 percent) developed radiologically confirmed\npneumonia. Although 13 cases (36 percent) were given antibiotic\ntreatment, only 6 (16 percent) received adequate antibiotic therapy\nwith doxycycline, a fluoroquinolone or a macrolide drug. At the time\nthe treatment was initiated, the laboratory results indicating Q\nfever infection were not known.\nConclusion\n----------\nThe data analysis showed a significant statistical correlation\nbetween a positive serological test for _C. burnetii_ and attendance\nat the training course on the sheep farm in March 2007 (p value less\nthan 0.001). There was no significant statistical correlation between\na positive test and attendance at school training courses in other\nplaces or contact with domestic animals at the students' homes. We\nconcluded that the sheep farm was the source of the Q fever outbreak.\nOutbreak control measures\n-------------------------\nThe 1st Q fever outbreak among humans in Slovenia was mentioned in\n1954. In 1985, 2 outbreaks were described. The source of one was\ncontact with a sheep herd; the other occurred among workers at a\ntannery, who were probably exposed through contact with sheep hides\n(2). Further outbreaks due to contact with infected sheep were\nreported in 1991 and 1992 (3,4). Between 1996 and 2005, between 0 and\n5 Q fever cases were notified [annually] in Slovenia (5).\nThe Communicable Disease Centre at the National Public Health\nInstitute was collaborating with regional epidemiologists from\nLjubljana and Koper, and with the veterinary high school and faculty\nof Ljubljana on the outbreak investigation. Further collaboration\nwith the Department for Infectious Diseases and the Health\nInspectorate at the Ministry of Health, and the Veterinary Office at\nthe Ministry of Agriculture resulted in a cascade of public health\nand veterinary measures.\nPublic health measures:\n-suspension of all student training courses and visits to the sheep farm;\n-ban on selling dairy products from the sheep farm;\n-improvement of sanitary conditions on the sheep farm;\n-serological testing of farm employees;\n-workplace risk reassessment (farm employees, forestry workers in the\nvicinity), in process;\n-serological testing of students who had been trained on the sheep\nfarm in 2007, final results expected;\n-clinical and serological follow up of seropositive human cases, in process.\nVeterinary measures (6):\n-serological testing of animals at the sheep farm (to date 60 percent\nseropositive animals);\n-re-introduction of Q fever monitoring in small and large ruminants\nproposed by the Veterinary Chamber;\n-vaccination of animals considered, vaccine procurement in process.\nThe regions endemic for Q fever have never been determined in\nSlovenia. A joint research project is planned by public health and\nveterinary scientists to investigate the burden of disease in animals\nand humans, to determine endemic areas of Q fever in order to develop\na sufficient basis for workplace risk assessments, and to determine\nthe risk for the general population.\nReferences\n----------\n1. CNB novice, monthly CNB report, CDC, NIPH Slovenia\n<http://www.ivz.si/javne_datoteke/datoteke/1311-CNB_maj.pdf>\n2. Epidemiolosko spremljanje nalezljivih bolezni v Sloveniji, Oddelek\nza epidemiologijo za leto 1985, CDC report, NIPH, Slovenia\n3. Epidemiolosko spremljanje nalezljivih bolezni v Sloveniji, Oddelek\nza epidemiologijo za leto 1991, CDC report, NIPH, Slovenia\n4. This organism\nis an agent that can be resistant to heat and desiccation and highly\ninfectious by the aerosol route. A single inhaled organism may produce\nclinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human] primates, the dose to kill\n50 percent of the primates was found to be 1.7 organisms(1).\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals,\nincluding other species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C.\nburnetii_ does not usually cause clinical disease in these animals,\nalthough abortion in goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_\ninfection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of\ninfected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta.\nContact with contaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission\n(2).\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication along with the less resistant\nlarge cell form, metabolically dormant, and spore-like (3).\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. Other modes of transmission to humans, including tick\nbites and human-to-human transmission, are rare.\nAlthough not available in many parts of the world, a Q fever vaccine\nis often used in high-risk populations such as livestock handlers,\nabattoir workers, veterinarians, and laboratory workers working with\nanimals infected with _C. burnetii_, particularly sheep. The vaccine\n(Q-Vax) contains formalin-inactivated phase I organisms and has been\nshown to be very effective in preventing Q fever in high-risk\nindividuals (4, 5). _C. burnetii_ has 2 distinct antigenic phases.\nPhase I is pathogenic and is found in infected animals or in nature;\nphase II is less pathogenic and is recovered after bacteria are\npassaged repeatedly in cell cultures or eggs.\nReferences:\n1. The state health department\nreports another 11 cases in 2006 alone (19 total). Given a total of 4\ncases in the previous 3 years, this activity represents a significant\nincrease in incidence and/or reporting. Is anyone else seeing similar\nnumbers (or increases in numbers) of cases of Q fever?\nThe 8 patients live in southeast Iowa or northwest Illinois within an\narea approximately 100 miles in diameter. Only 2 of the cases had an\napparent direct epidemiological link to one another. The cohort had\nan age range of 41-71 yrs. Clinical presentations were prolonged\nfever (>4-6 weeks) with mildly elevated transaminases in 7 cases; one\nof these cases had significant cough early in the course of illness,\nthough he had no infiltrates on chest x-ray. The 8th patient\npresented with acute hepatitis with very high transaminases and\nfever, which resolved spontaneously. No patient had a history of\ncardiac valvular disease, evidence for it on exam, or sonographic\nevidence of endocarditis.\nSeven patients had either detectable IgM and/or IgG to phase II\nantigens or high overall (IgG+ IgM) titers to phase II antigens. The\nother patient had a single IgG titer to phase II antigen of 1:256. 3\nof the cases have had markedly elevated IgG titers to phase I antigen\n(greater or equal to 1:1024). Two patients had liver biopsies; one\nshowed the classic donut granuloma. The other biopsy showed fatty\ninfiltration with an epithelioid granuloma and a lipogranuloma.\nTwo of the 8 had clear exposure histories to domesticated cattle,\ngoats, or horses. Four patients had more tenuous histories of animal\nexposure. Another patient's illness closely followed his return from\na military tour in Afghanistan. Finally, 2 patients were coworkers\nwho had recently cleaned out some heavy equipment stored in a shed at\ntheir workplace. No patients are known to have consumed unpasteurized\ndairy products.\nAll but one of the 8 patients is currently on antimicrobial therapy.\nA response to therapy (usually a combination of doxycycline and\neither a quinolone or hydroxychloroquine) has taken a few weeks. One\npatient presented after approximately 1 month of therapy with [for?]\nerythema nodosum.\nThe cases show that the exposure to animals can seem trivial on\ninitial questioning, which may reflect the highly infectious nature\nof the organism and its ready dissemination via aerosols. One notable\nfeature of the illnesses of many of these patients is the prolonged\nfever and malaise in the setting of very high titers to phase I\nantigens, as if the patients were/are in the process of converting to\nchronic Q fever.\nWe are curious whether readers of the listserv have experience with\ncases characterized by such high IgG titers to phase I antigen\nrelatively early in the disease (that is, less than 6 months\nfollowing onset and thus not fitting the arbitrary definition of\nchronic disease).\n--\nJason H. Infection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals,\nincluding other species of livestock and domesticated pets. _C.\nburnetii_ does not usually cause clinical disease in these animals,\nalthough abortion in goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_\ninfection. This very stable form of _C.\nburnetii_ is associated with compact small-cell variants of the\norganism that are produced during standard replication (along with\nthe less resistant large-cell form) and are metabolically dormant and\nspore-like (3). Clinical presentations were prolonged\nfever (>4-6 weeks) with mildly elevated transaminases in 7 cases; one\nof these cases had significant cough early in the course of illness,\nthough he had no infiltrates on chest x-ray. The Q fever organism is a Category B bioterrorism\nagent and, in fact, although not thought to be related to\nbioterrorism, was spread by mail in a post office in the UK in 1987\n(4). Infection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. No patient had a history of\ncardiac valvular disease, evidence for it on exam, or sonographic\nevidence of endocarditis.\n The cases show that the exposure to animals can seem trivial on\ninitial questioning, which may reflect the highly infectious nature\nof the organism and its ready dissemination via aerosols. 3\nof the cases have had markedly elevated IgG titers to phase I antigen\n(greater or equal to 1:1024). Ingestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. One\npatient presented after approximately 1 month of therapy with [for?]\nerythema nodosum. We are still waiting for the\nresults of blood tests on the remainder of the staff. However, we are\nseeing a steady decline in the number of absences through illness.'\nScotbeef, he said, has begun plans to redesign the layout of the lamb\nlayerage area. But it only takes a simple blood test to\ndetect the fever. Infection with greater\nnumbers of organisms will result in shorter incubation periods. Most\npatients become ill within 2-3 weeks after exposure. Those who\nrecover fully from infection may possess lifelong immunity against\nre-infection.\nIn the USA, Q fever outbreaks have resulted mainly from occupational\nexposure involving veterinarians, meat processing plant workers,\nsheep and dairy workers, livestock farmers, and researchers at\nfacilities housing sheep. Q FEVER, MEAT PROCESSING PLANT - UK (SCOTLAND)\n***************************************\n Some 25 workers have been\ntaken ill at the Scotbeef factory in Bridge of Allan, 11 of whom have\nbeen diagnosed with the disease.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Stirling", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aberdeen", "country": "United Kingdom"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2460", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland)(02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2460", "date": "2006-08-25 00:00:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER, MEAT PROCESSING PLANT - UK (SCOTLAND)(02)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 24 Aug 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2006/060824.asp#2>\n\nOn 9 Jul 2006, local public health authorities became aware of an increase\n[in the incidence of] influenza-like illness in people who worked at a meat\nprocessing plant where cattle and sheep were slaughtered and meat packaged,\nin the town of Bridge of Allan in central Scotland (1).\nAn investigation was initiated and, by 14 Jul 2006, 49 members of the\nstaff, out of a workforce of 228, had been identified as having fallen ill\npredominantly with 2 or more of the following symptoms: fever, headache,\nmyalgia, dry cough and joint pain. All those with symptoms were screened\nfor a range of pathogens and results from blood samples tested at the West\nof Scotland Specialist Virology Centre confirmed the illness as Q fever.\nSince then an epidemiological investigation has been undertaken including\nscreening of all staff working at the plant. 9 patients had been admitted\nto hospital by 18 Jul 2006. By 4 Aug 2006, 51 cases for which the initial\nIgM result was greater or equal to 256 had been identified. The\ninvestigation continues.\nThere is a risk of contracting Q fever by airborne spread especially within\na half-mile radius of a source. The plant is not situated near to\nresidential buildings, but is close to a road with much vehicular traffic.\nEnhanced surveillance was begun to identify cases in the surrounding\ncommunities. All public health authorities in the country were alerted. So\nfar no cases have been identified in individuals who do not work at the\nplant. Control measures including shutting down of the putative source and\ncleaning and disinfection have been put in place.\nQ fever is an uncommon zoonotic infection caused by an organism called\n_Coxiella burnetii_. In the United Kingdom (UK), the organism is most\ncommonly found in infected farm animals, especially sheep, cattle and\ngoats, it may also be found in cats and wild animal species such as birds,\nrodents or bats; in some countries it is also carried by ticks.\nTransmission of _C. burnetii_ to humans occurs primarily through inhalation\nof aerosols or dust contaminated with feces or urine, or from direct\ncontact with infected animals or their products of conception, or at\nslaughter. It may also be acquired from drinking unpasteurized milk. It is\nextremely rare for the infection to be passed from person to person. The\ninfective dose can be as low as 1 organism, and so large outbreaks can be\ncaused by a small source. _C. burnetii_ can survive for many years as a\nspore-like form before being inhaled and causing infection.\nHuman infection is divided into acute and chronic Q fever, although several\ndistinct syndromes have been described. Usually symptoms occur 2 or 3 weeks\nafter exposure (range 9-40 days) and illness is typically self-limiting and\ninfluenza-like. Symptoms include fever, headache, muscle pains, fatigue,\ndry cough and pneumonia. Q fever is diagnosed by a blood test but a\npositive result is obtained [not until] 2 to 4 weeks after onset of the\nillness.\nFull recovery usually occurs, even without treatment, but in some cases\nsymptoms can be serious or prolonged, especially with pneumonia or\npre-existing valvular disease, and may require hospital admission. Acute Q\nfever is treatable with antibiotics. The chronic Q fever form, particularly\nendocarditis, is a more serious complication and occurs in about 10 percent\nof cases. It may not appear until several years after the primary episode.\nIn the UK, most Q fever cases are sporadic or associated with exposure to\nfarm animals or occur in areas (such as slaughterhouses) where animals are\nhandled. Retrospective serological studies have shown evidence of extensive\ninfection in high-risk populations, which suggests that many cases are\noften not identified at the time of illness (2). Q fever is not uncommon\nand seroprevalence studies indicate that approximately 27 percent of\nfarmers and 10 percent of the general population in the UK have been\nexposed to _C. burnetii_ at some time. Being present at calving and\nhandling cattle products of parturition may pose significant risks, as high\nconcentrations of the organism are found in the placenta and birth fluids.\nAnimal infection is most commonly reported in ruminants and studies in\nEngland and Wales have suggested that infection [rates] may be as high as\n20 percent (3). Although heavy infections in sheep have also been\nassociated with abortions, it is not generally considered to be pathogenic\nin animals. Q fever is not uncommon\nand seroprevalence studies indicate that approximately 27 percent of\nfarmers and 10 percent of the general population in the UK have been\nexposed to _C. burnetii_ at some time. In the United Kingdom (UK), the organism is most\ncommonly found in infected farm animals, especially sheep, cattle and\ngoats, it may also be found in cats and wild animal species such as birds,\nrodents or bats; in some countries it is also carried by ticks. Transmission of _C. burnetii_ to humans occurs primarily through inhalation\nof aerosols or dust contaminated with feces or urine, or from direct\ncontact with infected animals or their products of conception, or at\nslaughter. Retrospective serological studies have shown evidence of extensive\ninfection in high-risk populations, which suggests that many cases are\noften not identified at the time of illness (2). Q fever is rarely recorded as a cause of bovine abortion and\ndisease although 1.6-6.3 percent of ewes in England are seropositive, with\nover 30 percent of ewes positive in some flocks (4). In the UK, most Q fever cases are sporadic or associated with exposure to\nfarm animals or occur in areas (such as slaughterhouses) where animals are\nhandled. [in the incidence of] influenza-like illness in people who worked at a meat\nprocessing plant where cattle and sheep were slaughtered and meat packaged,\nin the town of Bridge of Allan in central Scotland (1). The chronic Q fever form, particularly\nendocarditis, is a more serious complication and occurs in about 10 percent\nof cases. Q fever is diagnosed by a blood test but a\npositive result is obtained [not until] 2 to 4 weeks after onset of the\nillness. Usually symptoms occur 2 or 3 weeks\nafter exposure (range 9-40 days) and illness is typically self-limiting and\ninfluenza-like. Animal infection is most commonly reported in ruminants and studies in\nEngland and Wales have suggested that infection [rates] may be as high as\n20 percent (3). All those with symptoms were screened\nfor a range of pathogens and results from blood samples tested at the West\nof Scotland Specialist Virology Centre confirmed the illness as Q fever. Full recovery usually occurs, even without treatment, but in some cases\nsymptoms can be serious or prolonged, especially with pneumonia or\npre-existing valvular disease, and may require hospital admission. Being present at calving and\nhandling cattle products of parturition may pose significant risks, as high\nconcentrations of the organism are found in the placenta and birth fluids. In 2005, Q fever has already been\ndiagnosed in 5 persons. All of them worked in the Peter Alekseev weaving mill.\nThe 1st person fell ill in the spring of 2005, the 2nd person in the\nsummer, and now 3 more persons with similar symptoms, high fever and a\nheadache -- have been hospitalized in the autumn of 2005. The reason for\nthe human infection is thought to be contaminated sheep's wool. Both\ncarders and spinners worked with the wool.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The method of diagnosis of Q fever here is not stated.\nCarding wool can be done by hand or machine. Either way the 'cards'\ncontain small metallic 'needles' that by being pulled over the wool will\nhelp separate wool fibers. The fibers are then rolled into a slender tube\ncalled a rolag and from there the material can be spun into wool for knitting.\nQ fever was first described in Australia: it was called 'Query fever'\nbecause the causative agent was initially unknown. _Coxiella burnetii_, the\ncausative agent, was discovered in 1937. This organism is an agent that can\nbe resistant to heat and desiccation and highly infectious by the aerosol\nroute. A single inhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in\nprimates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was found to be 1.7\norganisms(1).\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including\nother species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C.burnetii_ does not\nusually cause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats\nand sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection. Organisms are\nexcreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals. Most importantly,\nduring birthing the organisms are shed in high numbers within the amniotic\nfluids and the placenta. Contact with contaminated wool is known to be a\nmode of transmission (2).\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication along with the less resistant large\ncell form and metabolically dormant and spore-like (3). The Q fever\norganism is a Category B bioterrorism agent and, in fact, although not\nthought to be bioterrorism related, was spread by mail in a post office in\nthe UK in 1987 (4).\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from\nair that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental\nmaterial, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are\noften very susceptible to the disease, and very few organisms may be\nrequired to cause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration\nof the contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other\nmodes of transmission to humans, including tick bites and human to human\ntransmission, are rare.\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C: An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of 'Q fever.' Pub Hlth Rep 1041; 56:1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D: Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12:518-53.\n3. The diagnosis was confirmed serologically in 11 other\nstudents that were tested.\nAn epidemiological investigation was conducted to disclose the source of\nthe infection. It revealed that all the patients had either eaten in or\npassed through the dining room of the school before the outbreak started. A\npossible source of the infection might have been a parturient cat in the\narea of the dining room and possible spread of contaminated aerosol by the\nair conditioning system. Unfortunately, we were unable to prove this\nassumption.\n--\nDr. Ziva Amitai\nDeputy Tel-Aviv District Health Officer\nMinistry of Health, Israel\n<ziva.amitai@telaviv.health.gov.il>\n[Q fever is a worldwide zoonosis caused by _Coxiella burnetii_, a strictly\nintracellular bacterium that is a potential bioweapon. In Israel, the\ndisease was 1st described during the 4th decade of the previous century and\nhas been notifiable in humans and animals for more than 50 years. Cases in\nhumans and in farm animals (cattle, sheep and goats) are recorded every\nyear; in the latter, the infection is manifested by abortions, causing\nconsiderable economic losses.\nThough the world literature incriminates mainly farm animals as the source\nof human infection, this is not always supported by evidence in Israel;\nwhile in some human cases a link to farm animals or their fomites/products\ncould be demonstrated, in the majority of cases, no such association is\napparent. Other sources/animals should be considered as well. The current\nobservation may indicate the need for more attention to the potential role\nof pets, particularly cats; the stray cat population in Israel is estimated\nto exceed 6-figure numbers, with high densities observed in urban areas.\nEpidemiological investigation regarding their infection rate with _Coxiella\nburnetii_ might be justifiable.\nFurther reading:\n1. The Moore County\nman does not work around livestock or in a laboratory or\nslaughterhouse and is not a veterinarian, circumstances normally\nassociated with getting Q fever, said Dr. James Alexander, a vet with\nthe Department of State Health Services in Canyon. It's possible the\nman might have caught the disease, which can spread from animals to\nhumans, from contaminated soil, Alexander said.\n\nThe patient told officials he has a friend with livestock but that he\nhad no contact with the animals, Alexander said.\n\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary carriers of the bacteria\n[that cause Q fever], known as _Coxiella burnetii_, according to the\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention website. It's extremely\nrare for the disease to spread from human to human, said Dr. Steven\nBerk, regional dean for Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center\nSchool of Medicine and an expert on infectious diseases. Common\nsymptoms resemble a serious case of the flu. A high fever comes on\nsuddenly, and those who get infected experience chills and sweating,\na general feeling of sickness and loss of appetite. Blood tests are\nused to test for Q fever, and it responds to antibiotics. It has been confirmed that 9 farmers in the state's\nmid-north have the disease, and there are another 6 suspected cases.\nDr. Jack Shephard, from Jamestown, says anyone who comes into contact with\nsheep, cattle, goats, or kangaroos could contract the disease. The source is probably\ndiseased livestock such as sheep or goats, health officials said.\nThe state health department has confirmed 13 human cases in the state in 2005,\nincluding 6 in Weld County. In 2004, there were 3 confirmed cases throughout\nColorado, said John Pape, a state health department epidemiologist.\nQ fever, or 'query' fever, is caused by a bacterium called _Coxiella\nburnetii_. It builds up in [livestock] placental tissues, putting\nveterinarians and farmers at high risk, though it is treatable with\nantibiotics and is rarely fatal. Symptoms include a high fever and headache,\nand may include profuse sweating and hallucinations.\n'Most people, even untreated, get better in 2 to 3 weeks,' said Dr. Daniel\nMogyoros, an infectious disease specialist with Kaiser Permanente. 'Most\ndoctors go through their training and most of their career without ever seeing\nthis disease.'\nWeld County health officials have investigated 6 more possible cases but have\nnot yet confirmed them, said Jill Burch, a county public health nurse.\n--\nGeorge A. Robertson, PhD\nDOR Biopharma\nMiami, FL\ufffd\n<grobertson@dorbiopharma.com>\n[The following is adapted from the CDC site on Q fever (a Category B\nbioterrorism disease)\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/qfever/index.htm#Significance%20for%\n20Bioterrorism>.\nQ fever is a zoonotic disease caused by _Coxiella burnetii_, a species of\nbacterium that is distributed globally. In 1999, Q fever became a notifiable\ndisease in the USA, but reporting is not required in many other countries.\nBecause the disease is underreported, scientists cannot reliably assess how\nmany cases of Q fever have actually occurred worldwide. Many human infections\nare inapparent.\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including other\nspecies of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does not usually\ncause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats and sheep\nhas been linked to infection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and\nfeces of infected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers in the amniotic fluids and the placenta. The organisms\nare resistant to heat, drying, and many common disinfectants. These features\nenable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. Infection\nof humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from air that\ncontains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental material,\nbirth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are often very\nsusceptible to the disease, and only very few organisms may be required to\ncause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration of\nthe contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other modes of\ntransmission to humans, including tick bites and human-to-human transmission,\nare rare.\nOnly about one-half of all people infected with _C. burnetii_ show signs of\nclinical illness. Most acute cases of Q fever begin with sudden onset of one\nor more of the following: high fevers (up to 104-105 degrees F), severe\nheadache, general malaise, myalgia, confusion, sore throat, chills, sweats,\nnon-productive cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and chest\npain. Fever usually lasts for 1 to 2 weeks. Weight loss can occur and persist\nfor some time. 30 to 50 percent of patients with a symptomatic infection will\ndevelop pneumonia. Additionally, a majority of patients have abnormal results\non liver function tests and some will develop hepatitis. In general, most\npatients will recover to good health within several months without any\ntreatment. Only 1-2 percent of people with acute Q fever die of the disease.\nChronic Q fever, characterized by infection that persists for more than 6\nmonths, is uncommon but is a much more serious disease. Patients who have had\nacute Q fever may develop the chronic form as soon as 1 year or as long as 20\nyears after initial infection. A serious complication of chronic Q fever is\nendocarditis, generally involving the aortic heart valves, less commonly the\nmitral valve. Most patients who develop chronic Q fever have pre-existing\nvalvular heart disease or have a history of vascular graft. Transplant\nrecipients, patients with cancer, and those with chronic kidney disease are\nalso at risk of developing chronic Q fever. As many as 65 percent of persons\nwith chronic Q fever may die of the disease.\ufffd\nDoxycycline is the treatment of choice for acute Q fever. Antibiotic treatment\nis most effective when initiated within the first 3 days of illness. A dose of\n100 mg of doxycycline taken orally twice daily for 15-21 days is a frequently\nprescribed therapy. Quinolone antibiotics have demonstrated good in vitro\nactivity against _C. burnetii_ and may be considered by the physician. Therapy\nshould be started again if the disease relapses. Chronic Q fever endocarditis\nis much more difficult to treat effectively and often requires the use of\nmultiple drugs.\nSince _Coxiella burnetii_ is a highly infectious agent that is rather\nresistant to heat and drying, it is considered relevant in bioterrorism. It\ncan become airborne and inhaled by humans. A single _C. burnetii_ organism may\ncause disease in a susceptible person. This agent could be developed for use\nin biological warfare and is considered a potential terrorist threat. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nGeorge A. Berger's remarks on the increase in Q fever cases in the\nSauerland region since 1990 [see end].\nWe have observed cases of Q fever in the Hochsauerland for more than 3\ndecades. This region is not only known for sheep raising but also for\ntourism. It is to be supposed that many cases of Q fever in tourists\nreturning from their holidays, and in the local population, remain\nundetected, when an etiologic diagnosis is neglected in cases of\ninfluenza-like respiratory disease.\nThe increase in number of Q fever cases, which was observed during the last\ndecade, seems to be linked to a significant increase in the number of sheep\nbeing kept. An increase in demand for sheep and lambs has apparently\noccurred during the nineties. It may be the result of an increase in the\nTurkish population [mutton eaters] but may be due even more to abstinence\nfrom beef due to the BSE crisis. Sheep raisers have brought in sheep from\nother regions, probably without previous contact with _Coxiella burnetii_.\nSeveral proposals were made to prevent human exposure to Coxiella infection.\nVaccination of sheep may be useful, but an approved vaccine is not available\nin Germany. Antibiotic treatment of sheep is probably not feasible for many\nreasons. But an improvement in the hygiene of animal husbandry would most\nprobably prevent transmission to humans in many cases. If the sheep were to\nbe kept in closed stables during lambing and the placentas burnt or treated\nwith disinfectants, instead of leaving them to birds, dogs and foxes, this\nwould most probably help a good deal against the spread of Coxiella\ninfections. The hygiene of sheep raising should be controlled very strictly.\nPersons who neglect the principles of prevention should be summoned or\nshould be forbidden to raise sheep.\nAnother problem is that cases of Q fever go undiagnosed or are diagnosed too\nlate, e.g. in the case of pregnant women. Therefore practitioners must be\nadvised to send specimens for the diagnosis of Q fever to the lab in all\ncases in which this diagnosis is suspected for clinical or epidemiological\nreasons. Young [medical] colleagues starting work in that region should have\nknowledge about this special risk.\n--\nDr. med. Werner Slenczka\nInst. of Virology\nRobert Koch-Str. 17\n35037 Marburg\n<slenczka@mailer.uni-marburg.de>\n[We are very grateful to Prof Slenczka for these first-hand, authoritative\ncomments and reminder, and his response to our RFI. Indeed, elementary\nhygiene measures, responsible animal husbandry methods and alertness of the\nattending veterinarians and physicians are vital on the front line of\nzoonosis prevention and control. - Mod. [By 30 Aug 2002],\nthere were 79 [clinical] cases of Q fever in residents of or visitors to\nthe Chamonix Valley. 22 cases have been confirmed, most of whom live in the\nvillage of Chamonix.\nQ fever is an infectious disease caused by _Coxiella burnetii_; a bacterium\nthat generally infects ruminants (cattle, sheep, and goats). Humans are\nusually infected via inhalation of dust or aerosols containing the\nresponsible organism. The investigations conducted by sanitary authorities\nin collaboration with health professionals of the Valley [Chamonix]\ncoordinating with the agricultural services have not identified the source\nof this epidemic as yet. Q fever is not transmitted from person to person.\nIn the majority of cases, the infection is sub-clinical. When illness\npresents it is after an incubation period of an average of 2 weeks, and\npresents as a flu-like syndrome associated with a high fever, chills,\nheadaches, nausea, and aches. The illness usually resolves after 7 to 10\ndays, often without specific treatment.\nIn people with valvular heart disease or other serious disease associated\nwith impaired immunity Q fever can evolve into a chronic disorder. Such\npeople, when infected, require medical follow-up and prolonged antibiotic\ntreatment. Infection can lead to spontaneous abortion in pwomen in the\nearly months of pregnancy.\nPeople who live in or have visited the Chamonix Valley since June 2002 may\nhave been exposed to the risk of infection. People who belong to identified\nrisk groups (valvular heart disease, immunocompromise, pregnant) are\nrecommended to consult their physicians for testing to identify if\nantibiotic therapy is indicated.\nAdditional information can be found on the following websites (in French):\nMinist\u00e8re de la Sant\u00e9 ( www.sante.gouv.fr ), l'Institut de Veille Sanitaire\n( www.invs.sante.fr ), and the Centre National de R\u00e9f\u00e9rence (\nhttp://ifr48.free.fr ).\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon, 02 Sep 2002 15:26:18 -0400\nFrom: 'Patricia Doyle, PhD' <dr_p_doyle@hotmail.com>\nSource: Yahoo News Fri 30 Aug 2002 9:45 AM ET\n<http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&u=/ap/20020830/ap_wo_en_po/france_fever_outbreak_1>\n\nQ fever, human - France\n-----------------------\nPARIS: At least 22 people in the French Alps have been infected by Q fever,\na flu-like illness that usually affects livestock, French health officials\nsaid on Friday. Nearly 80 cases were suspected.\nThe outbreak was detected in the Chamonix valley, a popular ski area, the\nHealth Ministry said. Most of the confirmed cases are residents of the town\nof Chamonix.\nQ fever, which causes aches, nausea, and fever, can be treated and cured\nwith antibiotics. It primarily infects cattle, sheep, and goats. Humans\ncontract it by breathing in contaminated dust or eating contaminated animal\nproducts. It does not spread from person to person.\nThe Foreign Ministry has asked the region's pregnant women, people with\nheart valve problems, and those with weakened immune systems to consult\ntheir doctors for a blood test. Those vulnerable may become chronic cases,\nand pregnant women may risk losing their babies.\n--\nPatricia Doyle, PhD\n<dr_p_doyle@hotmail.com>\n[Q fever is caused by the bacterium _Coxiella burnetii_. Cattle, sheep,\nand goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_. Infection has been\nnoted in a wide variety of other animals, including other breeds of\nlivestock and domesticated pets. _Coxiella burnetii_ does not usually\ncause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats and\nsheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection. Organisms are excreted\nin milk, urine, and feces of infected animals. Most importantly, during\nbirthing the organisms are shed in large numbers within the amniotic fluid\nand the placenta. The organisms are resistant to heat, drying, and many\ncommon disinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for\nlong periods in the environment. Infection of humans usually occurs by\ninhalation of these organisms from air that contains airborne barnyard dust\ncontaminated by dried placental material, birth fluids, and excreta of\ninfected herd animals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease,\nand very few organisms may be required to cause infection\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/qfever/index.htm>.\nGIDEON (<http://www.cyinfo.com/> offers the following background on the\nepidemiology of Q fever in France:\nMost cases occur in the south. Sixty-two per cent of cases present as\nhepatitis. Five to 8 per cent of endocarditis in this region are due to Q\nfever and 0.57 per cent of the population were seropositive in 1985. Among\npregnant women in southern France 0.15 per cent were seropositive in 1996.\n289 cases were confirmed in the Bouches-du-Rhone district (southern France)\nduring 1990 to 1995 (regional rate 35.4/100 000). An outbreak of 29 cases\nreported in Briancon (French Alps region) in 1996 was ascribed to ingestion\nof raw meat.\nOutbreaks of Q fever in France have also been associated with bird\ndroppings (1), sheep and wind (2), and ingestion of raw goat milk products (3).\nThe source of the current outbreak is unknown at present. It is interesting\nthat an outbreak in the French Alps in 1996 was related to ingestion of raw\nmeat. More information on this outbreak when available would be appreciated.\n1. Stein A, Raoult D. Pigeon pneumonia in Provence: a bird-borne Q fever\noutbreak. Clin Infect Dis 1999; 29(3): 617-20.\n2. Tissot-Dupont H, Torres S, Nezri M, Raoult D. Hyperendemic focus of Q\nfever related to sheep and wind. Am J Epidemiol 1999; 150(1): 67-74.\n3. Fishbein DB, Raoult D. A cluster of Coxiella burnetii infections\nassociated with exposure to vaccinated goats and their unpasteurized dairy\nproducts.
