Most importantly, during\nbirthing the organisms are shed in large numbers within the amniotic fluid\nand the placenta.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1996-03-25 00:00:00", "1992-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "1985-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-08-30 00:00:00", "2002-09-02 00:00:00", "2002-06-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Provence", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Briancon", "country": "France"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202513", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - France (Chamonix) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202513", "date": "2002-09-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER - FRANCE (CHAMONIX) (02)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 11 Sep 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance Weekly - Issue 37 11 Sep 2002\nhttp://www.eurosurv.org/update/\n\nQ fever outbreak in the Chamonix Valley, France, summer 2002\n-----------------------------------\nAt the end of July 2002, the Direction Departementale des Affaires\nSanitaires et Sociales (DDASS) was informed of several dozen patients who\nhad consulted their general practitioners (GPs) in Chamonix with fever,\nmyalgia, and severe headaches. Most of the patients had serum transaminases\n2-3 times above normal level. Most patients recovered spontaneously after\n5-10 days. Several patients were hospitalised.\nIn mid-August 2002 the diagnosis of Q fever was confirmed for 10 patients\nby the presence of Q fever phase II IgM antibodies >25 in serum.\nAn epidemiological investigation was carried out by the Cellule\nInterregionale d'Epidemiologie de Lyon (CIRE), the Centre National de\nReference des Rickettsies (CNR), the Institut de Veille Sanitaire (InVS),\nand the DDASS, to identify the mode of transmission and the source of the\noutbreak, and to implement appropriate control measures.\nCases were identified through the GPs of the Chamonix valley, the local\nhospital, the medical laboratory in the valley and the CNR.\nCase definitions used in the investigation:\nPossible Q fever: individual residing in, or visiting Chamonix valley since\nJune 2002 and having presented after 20 Jun 2002 with fever >39 degrees C,\naccompanied by at least 2 of the following symptoms: myalgia, nausea, chills.\nProbable Q fever: a possible case with an increase of transaminases AST and\nALT, above normal.\nConfirmed Q fever: a possible or probable case with positive serology for Q\nfever (phase II IgG >/= 100 and phase II IgM at >/=25).\nUp to 30 Aug 2002, 79 cases were identified: 25 possible, 32 probable and\n22 confirmed cases. All were adults between 17 and 92 years of age. The M:F\nratio was 1.8:1. Eleven individuals required hospital treatment.\nPlace of residence was known for 71 cases; 57 (80 percent) live in the\ncommune of Chamonix, 11 (15 percent) live in another town in the valley, or\nclose to the valley, and 3 are French tourists.\nAn exploratory study carried out on 19 confirmed cases suggested airborne\ncontamination from one or several excretory herds (sheep, goats, or\ncattle), possibly moving to summer pastures, or from manure-spreading\nareas. None of the cases has a high-risk profession for Q fever infection\n(for example, stock breeder, abattoir technician, etc.). During the\nexposure period, 4 individuals had close contact with ruminants, 4 had\neaten cheese made from unpasteurised milk, of which one only had eaten\nlocally produced cheese. None had drunk unpasteurised milk and 7 had\ndomestic animals. The cases questioned did not attend an event involving\nanimals. Neither is there an abattoir or knacker's yard [a knacker buys\nworn-out domestic animals or their carcasses, usually for animal feed or\nfertilizer] in the valley.\nThe epidemic curve, which is not complete for week 33 and after, due to the\ndelay in getting the onset dates, suggests a persistent source of\ncontamination. [see webpage at above URL for Figure: Cases (possible,\nprobable and confirmed) of Q fever by week of onset of symptoms, Q fever\noutbreak, Chamonix Valley, 2002.]\nA case control study is in progress to determine risk factors and\ntransmission methods (movement, consumption of unpasteurised milk, direct\nor indirect contact with manure or animal herds, participation in an event\ninvolving indirect or direct contact with animals, etc.). In parallel,\ninformation is being gathered on the animal herds present in the valley\nsince June 2002. These enquiries should further clarify the hypothesis on\nthe source of contamination and allow us to put control measures in place.\nRecommendations to the public\nSince June 2002, residents and visitors of the Chamonix valley may have\nbeen exposed to _Coxiella burnetii_, the agent causing Q fever.\nConsequently, the Ministry of Health recommends that persons belonging to\nhigh-risk groups (pregnant women, persons with valvular cardiac disease, or\nimmunosuppressed persons) who were resident or who stayed in the Chamonix\nvalley between June and the present time consult a doctor to get a\ndiagnostic test, and, if necessary, suitable medical treatment.\nAn alert was sent to the European national health authorities via the\nEuropean surveillance network for alert action on 27 Aug 2002.\nReported by Anne-Claire de Benoist (<adebenoist@phls.org.uk>), fellow of\nthe European Programme for Intervention Epidemiology Training (EPIET),\nPublic Health Laboratory Service Communicable Disease Surveillance Centre,\nLondon, England; Alexandra Mailles, Institut de Veille Sanitaire, Paris;\nSylvie Rey (<cirei.lyon@wanadoo.fr>), CIREI Rhone-Alpes, Lyon; and\nGenevieve Dennetiere, DDASS Haute-Savoie, Annecy, France.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is a nice summary of the investigation to date. In the absence of\nidentification of the source of the outbreak (airborne, ingestion of\ncontaminated unpasteurized milk or milk products) implementation of control\nmeasures is difficult (an understatement). We look forward to additional\ninformation as it becomes available. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 11 Sep 2002\n Reported by Anne-Claire de Benoist (<adebenoist@phls.org.uk>), fellow of\nthe European Programme for Intervention Epidemiology Training (EPIET),\nPublic Health Laboratory Service Communicable Disease Surveillance Centre,\nLondon, England; Alexandra Mailles, Institut de Veille Sanitaire, Paris;\nSylvie Rey (<cirei.lyon@wanadoo.fr>), CIREI Rhone-Alpes, Lyon; and\nGenevieve Dennetiere, DDASS Haute-Savoie, Annecy, France. \nA case control study is in progress to determine risk factors and\ntransmission methods (movement, consumption of unpasteurised milk, direct\nor indirect contact with manure or animal herds, participation in an event\ninvolving indirect or direct contact with animals, etc.). Consequently, the Ministry of Health recommends that persons belonging to\nhigh-risk groups (pregnant women, persons with valvular cardiac disease, or\nimmunosuppressed persons) who were resident or who stayed in the Chamonix\nvalley between June and the present time consult a doctor to get a\ndiagnostic test, and, if necessary, suitable medical treatment. Around 100 people have been symptomatically infected\nin every outbreak during recent years. In the outbreak that is still\nongoing, a 35-year-old has died, one person now has a chronic infection, and\nabout 40 people have been hospitalised with pneumonia, hepatitis, or\nendocarditis. As of today, a total of 72 cases have been registered.\nI am in urgent need of information about vaccination programmes for sheep,\nto reduce the risk of Q fever infection for humans in this endemic region.\nIn this region there is a large sheep population of about 50 000. All the\noutbreaks could be linked to infected sheep. There is a high percentage of\nsheep that have tested serologically positive (about 30 percent).\nThe normal measures alone [seem not to have reduced] the risk (we have\nordered in-house lambings, adequate disposal of the placenta and of other\ncontaminated materials, and controlled movement of sheep). We have an\nongoing study about ticks; it appears that in that region _Dermacentor\nmarginalis_ is not present.\nWe are currently considering the possibility of vaccinating the sheep. Hence\nmy question:\nDoes anybody have experience with the vaccine (there is one in France) and\nvaccination of sheep, and does anybody know whether vaccination of sheep\nthat have tested serologically positive is a problem?\n--\nAngela Wirtz, M.D.\nSection Head, Public Health\nHesse Department of Social Welfare\nGermany\n<a.wirtz@hsm.hessen.de>\n[Inactivated vaccines against Q fever have been used to vaccinate sheep,\ngoats, & cattle in several countries. The sheep vaccine may be combined with\nother antigens, particularly with chlamydial antigen, to provide a\npolyvalent vaccine, since the aetiological agent, _Coxiella burnetii_, is\nknown to induce abortions. Details on the vaccine, its manufacture,\ntesting, and use may be found in OIE's Manual of standards Diagnostic Tests\nand Vaccines 2000, Chapter X.3:\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/normes/mmanual/A_00113.htm>\nThe vaccination protocol usually consists of one subcutaneous injection in a\nnon-pregnant animal, preferably 15 days before insemination or mating. In a\nheavily infected environment, a second inoculation may be given a month\nlater. In general, the clinical efficacy of vaccination has been recognised,\nbut it is less effective in preventing excretion of the organism in milk\n(Durand J.L.,1993. La fievre Q. Epidemiologie et prophylaxie humaine et\nanimale. Bull. Soc. Vet. Prat. de France, 77, 269-297). Vaccination failure\nhas been observed among sheep and goats. In an infected environment, annual\nrevaccination is recommended.\nThe correlation between positive serology in sheep and clinical cases in\nhumans is not always an indication of an aetiological connection. Milk-borne\ninfection is also a factor to be considered.\nReaders with recent experience on the issue, especially regarding\ncommercially available vaccines, are welcome to send their comments. -\nMod.AS]", "summary": "--\nAngela Wirtz, M.D.\nSection Head, Public Health\nHesse Department of Social Welfare\nGermany\n<a.wirtz@hsm.hessen.de>\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Details on the vaccine, its manufacture,\ntesting, and use may be found in OIE's Manual of standards Diagnostic Tests\nand Vaccines 2000, Chapter X.3:\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/normes/mmanual/A_00113.htm>\n Does anybody have experience with the vaccine (there is one in France) and\nvaccination of sheep, and does anybody know whether vaccination of sheep\nthat have tested serologically positive is a problem?\n The sheep vaccine may be combined with\nother antigens, particularly with chlamydial antigen, to provide a\npolyvalent vaccine, since the aetiological agent, _Coxiella burnetii_, is\nknown to induce abortions. Berger, M.D. <mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\nSource: GIDEON <http://www.GideonOnline.com>\n\nThe following background data on Q-fever in Germany and details of\nthe human vaccine [an additional option in high-risk situations] are\nextracted from GIDEON.\nQ-fever was first recognized in Germany in 1947. Reporting was\ninstituted in West Germany in 1962, and in East Germany in 1979. The\n2 systems were combined in 1991. Most cases are reported in Bavaria,\nBaden-Wurttemberg, Rhineland-Palatinate, Hesse, Northrhine-\nWestphalia, and Thuringia. Hesse has experienced the greatest increase\nin incidence since 1990.\nYear/Cases/Rate per 100 000\n1964 /437\n1965 /28/0.05\n1970 /29\n1975/54\n1976/27\n1977/69\n1978/100\n1979/39\n1980/41/0.1\n1983/181\n1984/54\n1985/62\n1986/23\n1987/23\n1988/40\n1989/56\n1990/71/0.1\n1998/150/0.183\n1999/276/0.336\n2000/206/0.251\n2001/294\n22 percent of blood donors (nationwide, 1983 to 1986) and 22 percent\nof military personnel (1985 to 1987) are seropositive.\n12 percent of cattle in the southern Bavarian foothills are seropositive.\nThe average number of reported herds infected with Q fever was 71\nper year during 1971 to 1979; 328 during 1980 to 1989; 303 during 1990\nto 1998.\nOutbreaks currently peak during spring to summer, and may be related\nto urbanization.\n40 outbreaks were reported during 1947 to 1999. Sheep were\nimplicated in 24 of the outbreaks, and cattle in 6.\n2 laboratory outbreaks (in 1947 and 1948) were reported during 1947 to\n1999.\nAn epidemic occurred in Berlin during 1992, involving 80 cases,\nmostly staff from a veterinary institute. An outbreak in Hessen during\n1993 involved 121 cases.\nIn 1996, 60 cases were confirmed in the Rollshausen area (Lohra,\nHessen) during an outbreak associated with infected sheep.\nA University outbreak in May 1997 (105 confirmed cases) was\nassociated with proximity to sheep.\nAn outbreak in Dortmund during 1999 (81 cases) was associated with\nproximity to sheep.\nAn outbreak (68 clinical cases) was reported during December 2000 to\nJune 2001 in Hochsauerland and Nordhessen.\nRegarding the [human] vaccine: Q-fever vaccine is produced from\ninactivated phase I whole _Coxiella burnetii_ under the proprietary\nname Q-vax. The typical adult dosage consists of 0.5 ml s.c. (deltoid\nregion) for high-risk populations (e.g., occupational exposure).\nCurrently use is limited to Australia, notably among abattoir workers.\nProtection persists for at least 5 years, and there are no clear guidelines\nconcerning boosters. Potential side effects include fever and headache;\nthe only contraindication is known allergy to the vaccine itself.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[We are very grateful to Dr Berger for the epidemiological data. Some\nof the statements -- e.g. the alleged linkage between urbanization and\nthe observed Q fever peaks during spring to summer -- might need\nclarification (rural vacations of city dwellers?). I think we're all in agreement here, and I'm\nsorry if my original comments were carelessly written and open to\nmisinterpretation. I intended only to inform ProMED readers where Q Fever\nvaccine could be obtained in the US and to share my own (frustrating)\nexperience .\nI know that new drugs must be rigorously tested and I am aware of the\nreasons for each of the 'hoops' through which study participants jump (e.g.,\npregnancy tests, HIV tests, screening); I also hope this vaccine will 'pass\nmuster' and be more readily accessible when the clinical trial is concluded\nin 1998. Now, over\na year later, they (or their higher-ups) still have not decided whether to\nproceed. I think this is unfortunate; whether the delay has to do with the\n'hoops' necessitated by the experimental protocol or internal bureaucratic\n'hoops' I don't know.\nI would be happy to receive _constructive_ comments/suggestions sent to my\ndirect address.\nKaren Cowgill, RN, MPH\nDistrict Seven Health Department\nIdaho Falls, ID\ncowg100w@wonder.em.cdc.gov\n(although I have a WONDER account, I am only a\nlowly local health dept. employee -- not affiliated w/CDC)\n...............................................mhj\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. [see\nQ fever vaccine, availability 970218180712\n Q FEVER VACCINE, AVAILABILITY (05)\n==================================\n From: cowg100w@WONDER.EM.CDC.GOV\nSubject: Q Fever Vaccine Availability\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2190433", "headline": "PRO/AH> Q fever vaccine, availability (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2190433", "date": "1997-03-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER VACCINE AVAILABLITY (04)\n================================\n[see\nQ fever vaccine, availability 970218180712\nQ fever vaccine, availability (02) 970228172147\nQ fever vaccine, availability (03) 970322161006]\nFrom: 'Donoghue, Ann' <donogha@HESKA.com>\nSubject: FW: PRO/AH> Q fever vaccine, availability\nDate: Wed, 26 Mar 1997 16:32:00 -0700\nIt's important to remember that this vaccine is still under 'investigation',\nmeaning it is not an approved product, and therefore is not considered to be\nsafe and efficacious for widespread use.\nThe IND (Investigational New Drug) process allows the manufacturer to\ncomplete the required clinical efficacy and safety studies in order to\nachieve registration of the product. Therefore, the product must be\nadministered under the direction of the study director, following an agreed\nupon (by the FDA) protocol.\nThe people receiving the vaccine are volunteers and must be made aware if\nit's experimental nature before agreeing to be vaccinated. The paperwork,\nprotocol and oversight of the study director are to ensure the safety of the\ntest subjects (people!) during the experimental use of an unlicensed product\nand that they gave an informed consent to be a volunteer.\nIf an unapproved product were to be used widely, and some people became ill\n(or died!), all you-know-what would break loose! Instead we have people\ncomplaining about having to jump through hoops because they just can't go to\nthe local physician and receive a shot! Can't have it both ways!!\n---\nAnn Donoghue\nAnn R. MHJ]\nFrom: Ross Tancred <rosst@meat.aust.com>\nSubject: Q fever vaccine\nDate: Tue, 25 Mar 1997 10:23:47 +1000\nWe operate a number of beef processing plants in Queensland, Australia, and\nrecently have had pressure put on us by the state Government Workplace\nHealth and Safety Authority to perform manditory tests and subsequent\nvaccinations on all employees prior to commencment of work.\nThe current demand means visitors and new employees will be required to wear\nrespirators. This will really help us instill a view of how safe our meat\nis to overseas visitors (after anthrax and salmonella this is wonderful) and\nbe realy practical for people working hard in a very manual industry. We are\nof course challenging this 'interesting' plan.\nI thought this information may be usefull to some readers and I am\ninterested in hearing what other States and Countries require or what other\ncompanies do in relation to this issue.\n---\nRoss Tancred\nGeneral Manager\nConsolidated Meat Group\nrosst@meat.aust.com\nPh. 61 79 305860\nFax 61 79 305869\n[Having myself worked as a Meat Inspector in Calgary in the early '60s and\nthus with first hand knowledge of how dangerous this work can be, even with\nunobstructed vision, I referred Ross's statement to Bill Geering, Oz Deputy\nCVO, and Mike Poidinger, University of Queensland, for comment. MHJ]\nFrom: 'Geering, Bill' <WAG@mailpc.brs.gov.au>\nTo: Martin Hugh-Jones <mehj2020@vt8200.vetmed.lsu.edu>\nSubject: Ross Tancred and Q fever\nDate: Thu, 27 Mar 97 13:38:00 PST\nQ fever (Coxiella burnetii) is endemic in Australia, with the highest\nprevalence probably being in the State of Queensland. Various hygiene\nprocedures are required to be carried out in abattoirs to reduce the level\nof contamination, including restricting the opening of gravid uteri to\nspecial rooms. Nevertheless, abattoir workers are at high occupational risk\nof contracting _C. burnetii infection_. The Queensland Workplace Health and\nSafety authorities have therefore established a policy which requires skin\ntesting and subsequent vaccination (where necessary) of new abattoir\nemployees; with a requirement that effective respirators (an approved face\nmask) be worn by such employees in risk areas until two weeks after they\nhave been vaccinated, or testing has shown vaccination to be unnecessary.\nVisitors are also required to wear respirators if going into risk areas of\nabattoirs.\n---\nBill Geering\nCanberra\n[and]\nDate: Thu, 27 Mar 1997 10:47:43 -0500\nFrom: Mike Poidinger <mikep@biosci.uq.edu.au>\nSubject: Re: New Queensland regulations\nThe following is lifted wholesale from\nhttp://hna.ffh.vic.gov.au/comm_dis/cdu/qfever.html\nI am currently trying to contact the responsible persons in both Queensland\nand Victoria for more uptodate information. ps I dont mind being quoted,\nand since this is an excerpt from a public Web page (date unknown), I am\nsure quoting it is OK as well.\nMore to follow as I can get it (given the 4-5 day Easter break upon us).\n---\nMike Poidinger\n--------------------------------\nQ fever - Update\nSheila Beaton\nQ Fever is an acute illness with fever, chills and muscle pains and\noccasional long term complications. The micro-organism responsible,\n_Coxiella burnetii_, is carried by cattle, sheep and goats and is\ntransmitted by contact with animal faeces, urine, etc or by inhaling dust\nfrom infected premises. It is and occupational hazard paticularly for\nabattoir workers and meat inspectors, but also for shearers, wool sorters and\nveterinarians. There is no endemic reservoir in Victoria, but the organism\nis commonly introduced in stock from interstate.\nFollowing a notification of illness in a female abattoir worker, the\nInfectious Diseases Unit investigated an outbreak of Q fever at an abattoir\nin northern Victoria. The abatoir has been operating for approximately two\nyears and a large number of staff are new to the industry. Prevaccination\nscreening showed approximately 80% of workers were non-immune to Q fever. At\nthe time of the outbreak, the abattoir was involved in an immunisation\nprogram for the workers, however, some were already incubating the disease\nat the time.\nTo date, there are 26 confirmed cases of Q Fever with a further 3 yet to be\nconfirmed from a workforce of approximately 100.\nThe Commonwealth Serum Laboratories have prepared a vaccine, Q-Vax, which\ngives a very high level of protection, except if given after a person has\nalready been infected. Q-Vax is different from other vaccines in that the\nrecipient must first be tested for immunity, since those persons already\nimmune may have severe reactions with the vaccine.\nThe details of the immunisation program are as follows:\nTwo visits to the workplace are required, one week apart. At the first visit\nall employees who consent to be involved are given a skin test for Q Fever\nby injecting a small dose of diluted vaccine into the skin. At the same time\n5-10 mls of blood are taken and tested for Q Fever antibodies. Each employee\nis given a short questionaire enquiring about their duration of employment,\npast history of Q Fever, allergies, etc. A previous history of infection\nwith Q Fever vaccine is a contraindication to vaccination.\nThe skin test is read 7 days later. Training is required in both the\nperformance and reading / interpretation of the skin test. If both skin test\nand blood test are negative and the person is not allergic to eggs, he/she\nis offered the vaccine which is given by injection under the skin.\nThe object of the immunisation campaign is to avoid the possibility of a\nmajor outbreak of Q Fever at any particular workplace. Preventing Q Fever\ncan lead to significant savings to the employer in avoiding Workcover costs.\n---\nDr Mike Poidinger\nMicrobiology, UQ\nAustralia\nmikep@biosci.uq.oz.au\n[and]\nDate: Thu, 27 Mar 1997 16:37:57 -0500\nFrom: Mike Poidinger <mikep@biosci.uq.edu.au>\nSubject: Re: New Queensland regulations-more info\nI just talked to Dr David Smith, the Principal Medical Officer for the\nQueensland government division of Workplace Health and Safety. He gave me\nthe following that you can quote:\nA 1994 study showed the following Q fever refferrals in Queensland:\n1990 235\n1991 358\n1992 301\n1993 429\n1994 286\nThe last death due to Q fever in Qld was 2 years ago.\nAbout 50% of these were in meat workers, mostly abbatoir workers. The recent\npolicy decision sent to you regarding respirators and vaccination is a\nresult of these ongoing figures, and not a response to a specific outbreak\nin Qld or indeed any other part of Australia.\nAs far as Dr Smith is aware, no other state has any similar regulations.\nThe vaccine costs $65/ampule, and given the tests required prior to\nvaccination, can cost $120-$150/person.\nQ fever currently costs the Qld meat industry about 1 million dollars/year\nin terms of man hours lost.\n---\nDr Mike Poidinger\nMicrobiology, UQ\nAustralia\nmikep@biosci.uq.oz.au\n\n[Although most cases of Q fever infection are mild, it can on occasion be\nnasty, even lethal. While their preventive measures are possibly draconian,\nthe Health & Safety authorities are faced with a high attack rate in\nslaughter house workers and the duty to take all possible preventive\nmeasures; plus, workers compensation claims can be very high. But I would\nstill be frightened to work on the killing floor wearing a respirator.\nOur thanks to all concerned - Ross, Bill, Mike, and David Smith.\nMartin Hugh-Jones, ProMED Moderator (of the day).]\n..................................................mhj\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. There are a number of other\nfacilities in this country and Canada at which this vaccine is utilized, in\naccordance with an investigational protocol.\nBecause this vaccine has, in the past, caused severe local reactions in\nindividuals already immune to _Coxiella burnetii_, a screening intradermal\nskin test with Q fever antigen is required prior to vaccination. The purpose\nof the skin test is to identify those individuals at risk of developing\nsevere local reactions to the vaccine, and individuals with a positive skin\ntest should not be vaccinated. A similar problem exists with the Australian\nvaccine, and a screening skin test is also required prior to use of that\nproduct. In addition, it should be noted that individuals with positive skin\ntest reactions to this Q fever antigen do not need vaccination, because the\npositive skin test reflects pre-existing protective immunity to Q fever.\nAs an investigational product, IND 610 is subject to applicable FDA\nregulations and policies. It can be administered only according to an\napproved investigational protocol under the supervision of the principal or\nan associate investigator, but it is not being 'held in reserve'. Inquiries\nregarding the availability and use of this Q fever vaccine should be directed\nto the Commander/Director, USAMMDA, Fort Detrick, Frederick, MD 21702, Ph.\n301/619-7643.\n---\nCOL W. Russell Byrne\nBacteriology Division\nUSAMRIID/Fort Detrick\nFrederick, MD\ne-mail: <W._Russell_Byrne_at_USAMRIID4__FTDETRCK@ftdetrck-ccmail.army.mil>\n[Thanks to Colonel Byrne for clarifying the situation. -- Mod CHC]\n............................................................................\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
